Quick, quick, quick!  Seated quickly, coffee served quickly, ordered quickly!  All that and service with a smile!  

For an airport restaurant -- the food was decent, and very well-priced and large portioned!  

Service waned a bit when I finished a plate or bowl, there it sat on my table for approx 15 mins before anyone came to check on me and/or pick it up.  Pet peave of mine -- I like dirty plates taken 'quick', too!

All in all, it exceeded my expectations, and I would eat here again.

Very chill, with great wines and brews, absolutely delicious flat bread pizza!  Entree prices seem very low for this really nicely designed place (which I am sure, tons of $'s spent).  Most items on the menu were below $13.  

I sat at the bar with my best bud, and we had 2 ultra-cool bartenders helping us out.

This is a great place for a lower-priced date that you won't have to break your piggy bank for, a small group get-together, or just a nice hang with your bud...like ME!

There's isn't much in the way of Chinese or Japanese cuisine in a 15 mile radius, just a few choices.  There is a menu of the usual suspects, but also offered is a dinner buffet and mongolian BBQ for $16.99.  Priced too high?  I think so, but I went "all in" anyway.

Mongolian BBQ -- A fairly wide assortment of meats (incl shrimp, scallops, and imitation crab), and the usual veggies but Boy Choy is added (love).  Cooked up well, the chicken and beef were beyond awful and terrible texture.  I scooted it aside, and the rest was fresh and edible.

Chinese Buffet -- A small amount of choices (12-15), but not top quality (by a long shot).  Edible, but doesn't get rotated enough to get a positive nod.

Bar Area -- it has a better than average bar.  Not happening, but it's nice.

A little 80's, but clean.  Bottom-line, if this is your only option, this will get your fix...but it has issues.

Hold your horses guys and dolls -- there's 2 menus!  I settled quickly on Sushi - a Tempura Shrimp Roll ($7.50) which was good, but my buddy got the crab rangoon roll ($8.95), which was amazing and in an even more amazing sauce.  Little did I know there is a whole second menu with everything from burgers, salads, tacos, and fish & chips!

I enjoyed this fun and energetic environment!  There are 2 rooms, and both are centered around a bar ("Matilda...get the tequila!  It's a party!").  The front room is better for watching games and hanging out as it has TONS of TV's, and the back room (larger) might be better for groups or conversations.

The server for my first time: Mary.  She was sweet!

Went for a big TNF game.  Trouble with the satellite feed caused my buddy and I to focus on other things.  The obvious two (no, not that!): basketball and college football.  But let's get this out of the way, the girls are outrageous and gorgeous.  Natalie, probably the least buxom of the bunch, made up for it with a personality to the max.  Kudos.

Our order (and a couple of beers, of course):
==================================
1.  Jack Daniel's honey shot ($2.99 each, a special had them 2 for 1) -- sign is up for four!  (5.0 stars)

2.  Peaks Sampler ($12.25) - a bunch of fried crap: fried pickles, buffalo chicken tenders, and mozzarella bites.  Overall, not worthy.  (3.0 stars)

3.  Chicken Fried Chicken ($13.45) -- We each got it, and it was gooood!  (4.5 stars)

Overall:
======
It's a fun place to hang and watch a game.  How does it compare to Hooters or Tilted Kilt?  It doesn't stand out, but it's right in there somewhere.

Huge inventory of 4x4 stuff; clear product descriptions; easy to do business; good prices; reasonable shipping costs; responsive phone service.  Winning!

If that's not enough, I've needed help or guidance from both service and sales, and they've been quick to answer and resolve my every question, no matter how dumb I sound.  Excuse me, how "novice" I sound.  Very friendly people, and very helpful.

Recommend using them online, but they also have a nice printed catalog they'll mail to you...which is easier to drool on when looking at all the nice products!

One of the noisiest, busiest, yet -- most fun and interesting Starbucks EVER created.  It's a biggie, too.

It's quite large inside, large outside with seating, and a large behind-the-counter area for the staff.  The Barista and staff have to yell orders and jokes back and forth to the cashiers (and it's constant!).  The busier it is, the louder it gets.  All of it adds to the noise-level, and it significantly increases in volume.  The savior to all of this?  The service is outstanding!

As a customer, all of the above is a two-edged sword: making it fun but a little difficult to concentrate.  On the other hand, if you like distractions...it's a good choice: student body left, and student body right.  UCSB is close-by.

My one beef?  The floor is huge, and it has some seating but could have more.

I stayed at this hotel this week, and it was a wow.  Yes, it's a Hilton and larger than it sounds, but it has a rich, boutiquey feel.  It's both classic, and modern.  The location is right next to Penn on the side of the Annenberg Center for Performing Arts.  Well, it was $379/night.  Ouch.

The room was luxurious, well-furnished, thoughtful.  I don't think they are all like this, but great to know it's available, my room was HEPA filtered...and I slept like a baby in the cushy bed with pillows.

The breakfast is a standout, and rivaled some of the finest hotels I've ever been to (Four Seasons-like).  The cold and hot buffets had many many unique items with tons of choices.  I could've gone crazy if I allowed more time and didn't have a late dinner.  It was totally delicious.

#WonderfulHiltonHotel

Tremendous experience.  Awesome food, great service, I'd almost give it a 5.0 star - but at lunch, it had no vibe.  Mark my word, I'm coming back for dinner sometime soon.

With a great draft beer selection, a full apps, salads, sandwiches, and burgers - it had the makings for something special.

1.  Beer ($3 at lunch with a meal, normally $5) -- a given. I got one of the home brews, Orange Wheat Blossom.

2.  Fried Pickles  ($6.50, 5.0 stars) -- to die for.  I've had them from the east, to the west, to the south, and the north...and these are the best I've ever had.  Big dill pickle chunks with a thick beer-batter crust.  Amazing.

3.  Chili Cheese Fries ($9.50, 4.0 stars) -- really good, a little too pricey for the item.

4.  Chile Verde Burrito ($11.50, 4.5 stars) - near perfection. Huge and delish at a great value price.

The service by Jennifer H was wonderful.  I can't wait to go back.

Next up: Burger & Duck Fat Fries

I came here last time I was in SB to try tandem biking for the first time, and it was fun!

It was really easy to rent the bikes, and the staff was friendly. No fuss - you sign some papers, take the bike out, and pay for it when you return.

My friend and I opted for an hour and we rode around the beach. They have some paths for you to follow, and an hour was good for us. We couldn't go that far, but we still got to bike around for a while. 

Besides bikes, they offer other options like surreys, choppers, scoot coups, so you can take your pick! :)

I came here with my friends after dinner, and we got a table and some drinks. The place was super colorful and brightly lit, and most of it was part of the outside patio. It was still pretty cozy though!

Our server was nice, but she disappeared for a while and we had to look for someone else when we wanted to order more. But other than that, the service was okay.

The one thing that I didn't like as much was that there were a handful of bachelorette parties going on. There was clashing music, girls hitting on random strangers, and etc. I mean it wasn't such a big deal that it bothered me much, but it was just a little odd. And if I were having a bachelorette party, I don't think I'd want to look over at the next table and see another bride-to-be with pretty much the same thing going on there.

"Blenders in the Grass" makes me think of lawnmowers or something of the sort, but having been there, I now think of delicious smoothies! 

I had the mocha blend, which was made with non-fat milk, coffee, chocolate, ice milk, and banana! Yummie! It was so smooth and creamy without being overwhelmingly thick or sweet! The banana added a nice touch too. I also tried some of the Red Banana, which was really tasty too. No need to even compare it to Jamba or other places because this is on another level! You can also add supplements to your drink, and they have a wide selection to choose from. Each drink runs about $5, but they're huge! More than enough to split with a friend. :)

You're hungover. Turkey leftovers are tired. Gyros sound like more the ticket! But mom can't find out you're skipping the remains of her laborious turkey dinner.

Okay by now, it's clear I'm talking about my cousin... definitely not me!

But I digress. A couple clicks on my Yelp app yielded what would turn out to be a deliciously messy, completely necessary experience with an overstuffed gyro. Sure, Soco Gyros & Deli doesn't look like much on the outside... but tell that to your mouth after putting away one of these stacked sandwiches!

Meat: Most excellent! Tzatziki: Luscious. Pita: Very good. Hot sauce (don't judge): Terrific. Presentation: Perfectly swaddled like a newborn baby (read: ain't no meat falling out of this pita!). Only menu item I can live without is our shared appetizer, the hummus, as it lacked that homemade taste and super creamy texture I love.

Just a little over $20 for a solid lunch of two gyros, two soft drinks and that ho-hum hummus. And mission accomplished: I got back to my cousin's couch and promptly fell asleep for three hours! That's one hell of a gyro-induced coma doing its job and erasing hangovers all over the StL.

I wanted to love it, I really did. But Berix fell a little flat for me in a few key areas.

My mom, brother and I came here for lunch with pita and cevapi specifically on the brain. You order at the counter and then take a table. The restaurant itself is really clean, spacious and has sort of a cozy ski-lodge feel. 

My mom placed an order for our cevapi, a cheese pita and also two pitas to take home. However, when the order came up all the pita was on the tray instead of being packaged to-go as she had asked. Not a biggie, but they also gave her spinach pita instead of cheese for some of the order. No language barrier, just unmindful customer service.

My cevapi themselves were really good, but there's more to cevapi then just the meat. The bread and kajmak also contribute to the total awesomeness. While the bread was perfect (and I mean perfect!), the cevapi were served with ajvar. I asked for some kajmak but received... sour cream! Lack of the ideal (and authentic) cevapi condiment? Somewhat of a letdown. 

The pita was so good my mom served it at Thanksgiving dinner instead of making her own. So we'll definitely be back for that. Berix also makes burek, sarma, gulas, raznici, kebabs and pljeskavica in addition to more Americanized sandwiches.

Trivia: wondering about the name origin? No, it's not Bosnian. It must be derived from the name of the intersection-- Reavis Barracks (Berix) and Lemay Ferry.

Legitimately a bonafide, can't-miss St. Louis institution.

Best known for their shakes and malts, you'd be silly to make a trip out here and not get cozy with one of their fine ice cream items. My choice? The marshmallow shake, extra thick. You can request the density of your shake altered by paying a $.50 upgrade for 'thick' or $.75 for 'extra thick'. Aaah, this is how it's done my friend.

Almost a centenarian now and old-fashioned gal Crown Candy has hardly changed. Save for the neighborhood, it's a bit rough. Come. Order a BLT and a big shake and leave 5 pounds happier.

I'm loving Northwest Coffee even more now since they started serving eggs several days ago.

Plain eggs, eggs with cheese, eggs in a tortilla, eggs on a bagel, eggs on an English muffin... you get the picture.

They actually steam their eggs under one of their espresso machines! So, they come out extra light and fluffy, and the water expands them nicely. No butter or oils necessary! 

And, their eggs are locally-sourced from the River Hills Poultry Alliance. They're 'happy eggs', as they come from free-range chickens that are free of antibiotics and humanely raised. And yes, you CAN taste the difference.

They still make the meanest latte ever here, too! Try 'em.

Modesto is my hands-down favorite restaurant in St. Louis. It's a warmly hip, high-spirited eatery that is a far cry from the typical Italian sleepers that have long defined "The Hill".  It's somewhere you can go for a big girls night or conversely, come for a catch-up dinner with friends you haven't seen in years. Every year since they opened in 2001, I meet my high-school best friend and her husband as they visit from Boston over the holidays. One year I made the mistake of 'changing it up' by selecting a Pan-Asian restaurant and I deservedly heard about my error until the next year. Never again.

I live for tapas and sangria, so it's no surprise that I try the most highly-recommended Spanish restaurant in any city I visit or have lived in. From NYC to DC, to Miami to L.A., to Boston to Chicago, I have not tried a better sangria than Modesto's. It's authentically-crafted with Brandy and simmered with sugar before cooling. It's pricey at $24/pitcher, but worth the praise you'll receive for suggesting it as well as the laughs that will soon ensue.

You really can't go wrong with the food. While the paellas are fantastic, the small plates are just more fun. The smoked trout with Serrano bacon and lemon is delicious, and the grilled baby octopus with fried potatoes and the sherry vinaigrette is stellar. The grilled lamb skewers are to-die-for and the Serrano ham cups with avocado, goat cheese and basil with a beet vinaigrette is another can't-miss.

Don't take my word for it, you better show up before I drink them dry of that sangria.

Awhile back, I purchased a Sony mirrorless camera and slowly stopped using my Nikon DSLR. Though I actually prefer my Nikon, I found it and all its gear just too bulky when traveling. And I really only use my mirrorless and DSLR cameras when traveling, so the compact Sony camera won.

A few months later, I found out that Schiller's buys used camera equipment in good condition. As I had no real emotional attachment to my Nikon, I decided to visit Schiller's to see what I could get for it. Lo and behold, I was offered $430 for my gently-used camera, 3 lens, and a speedlight flash which I thought was more than fair. 10 minutes later, they cut me a check and I was on my way. 

If you're coming here to peruse camera gear, their selection is second to none! New, used, vintage SLR, DSLR, mirrorless, you name it. Their service is very comprehensive so the only negative may be that you may end up waiting awhile... and there's no clear queuing system. Otherwise, Schiller's is tops within their niche!

New Day Gluten Free is a true sanctuary for those of us who can't process wheat like the rest of you lucky folks. There's even a sign on the door stating no outside food can be brought in, to ensure the environment isn't contaminated!

Indeed, New Day is 100% wheat-free. Visiting their new location had topped my bucket list for the last couple of months, as they were moving their previous shop to a shiny, larger location in Clayton. And what a gorgeous space it is! Just going on 3 weeks new, we snatched the last open table on a busy Saturday.

Nothing can prepare you for the beauty that lies in the glass-encased baked good display case. Generously frosted cupcakes, gooey butter cookies, lemon bars, the cutest cakes and much more! I ordered a carrot cupcake and lemon bar to-go for my mom and me, and for lunch we opted for a turkey club and a California melt.

While both sandwiches were outstanding, I think my mom was a bit envious of the warm bun that hugged the overflowing toppings of my sandwich. Fresh turkey, provolone cheese, a liberal spread of guacamole, onions, lettuce and some mayo. But THAT BREAD! Wow. Just as good as bread made with conventional flour. This was my favorite type of sandwich in my gluten-eating days, so it was a dream to take in. 

After suppressing the temptation for a solid 8 hours, I finally gave in to the decadent carrot cupcake that had been staring me down all day. Holy cream cheese frosting! That was definitely the highlight for me and then some, as the cake portion was slightly dry. Still, it was one of the better gluten-free desserts I've had. Next time, I'll be trying the vanilla cupcake as that's my usual go-to treat.

Thanks for filling in a much-needed void in St. Louis, New Day! You've earned some new lifetime fans.

Love coffee mixed with a heaping side of socializing? Then Northwest Coffee Roasting Company is your spot, yo.

But first let's cover the important stuff-- the beans! I chose a Mocha nonfat latte as my inaugural drink at NCRC. No bitterness, just a smooth, rich caffeination ride. Mocha-choca-latte-ya-ya!

Grab a seat at one of the tables or at my pick, the coffee bar. The super friendly staff is fun to chat up... Emily the barista sensation is a sweetheart! Really, this coffeehouse is more Cheers than coffee depot. After today, I bet they even remember my unusual name. 

Free wi-fi should you feel like being productive.

Gosh, with a name like 'Double D Lounge', I wasn't sure whether to expect an extension of Hooter's or a seedy cocktail lounge with a selectively-functioning marquee. Nope, neither-- Double D actually sits squarely between dive and corner bar. Karaoke was not on the menu the night we were here, but still, plenty a patron was singing along to jukebox tunes. Ah, karaoke 'light'. 

About five beers on tap-- Blue Moon is as fancy as it gets. Tables abound and secondhand smoke is also plentiful, but that's life sans ban. More challenging is not having a good time here. From neighborhood button-downs to post-collegiate coed sports teams, you'll find 'em all here. 

A parking lot exists, just be careful as it sits at the bottom of a steep hill. Not a walk for the well-heeled... wear your sneaks!

When the 'lover of sweets' file cabinet is opened, I'm not in there. In fact, when I feel a craving coming on for something outside the realm of savory, I'll turn to Yelp's unofficial guru of all things sweet, Johnny T. A recent conversation with a very indifferent me went something like this:

Me: I think I want something sweet, but I never know what to get. What do you usually go for when craving sweets? 

JT: Ice cream. Chocolate. Cupcakes. Cookies. Pancakes.

Me: Nah... keep going.

JT: Macaroons. Fruity drinks. Pralines.

Ding, ding, ding - PRALINES, people! I'll go on record to say that pralines are the most satisfying form of sugar I've ever put in my mouth, especially if they're from Southern Candymakers. You know you're in for an inimitable treat when you're greeted with that smell - a heady mix of childhood nostalgia that for me, was reminiscent of waffle cones being made at Six Flags (only exponentially better). A candy crafter was busy at work hand-scooping creamy dollops of praline onto a marble slab and cheerfully asked if I'd like a sample, even though I had already acknowledged I was purchasing a few. Oh good gracious, southern hospitality... teach the rest of us, please?

I walked out, practically skipping on a clear, sunny New Orleans day with my decadent collaborations of fresh cream, butter, sugar, and Louisiana pecans swinging in my right hand. The world and my heart stopped for a moment while I took that first bite and contemplated saving the other two pralines for later... but I couldn't. A handmade praline is a gift, and you shouldn't deny yourself the unequivocal, wholly-sating sugar high only a perfect praline can bring on.

It should be noted for tourists that Southern Candymakers' pralines are wrapped very simply (for those considering bringing them back as gifts)... think of the wrapping as expensive lingerie. Is it really necessary when you're about to be passionately consumed with what lies underneath the package? Exactly. Take it from a new-to-the-club praline junkie - these exquisite treasures simply should not be missed!

Modesto just keeps moving, tweaking and re-inventing. Just because you've got a good thing going, you can't rest on your laurels. And these restaurateurs get it-- from menu redesigns to new tapas, evolution is the word @ 5257 Shaw Ave.

I met up with my longtime bestie from Buenos Aires for a night of girl talk, sangria and our favorite small plates. The restaurant was full and we didn't have reservations, but you can reserve a table in the bar area... 10-minute wait, score!

Can't-miss:
Mussels steamed in hard cider with chorizo and peppers
Lamb skewers with yogurt and herb salsa
Baked goat cheese in spicy tomato sauce
Hangar steak with port reduction
Bacon-wrapped dates stuffed with Cabrales cheese

Pass: Flatbread with caramelized onions, olives, garlic and Manchego cheese. Just a bit too sweet.

Service is always courteous and professional, and the sangria... oh the sangria! If you haven't tried sangria made the authentic way with brandy, well then just you wait. It's the champagne of buzzes... exquisite!

The bottom line first: it doesn't matter how good your cevapi are, Bosna Gold, if I'm too thirsty to enjoy 'em. Seriously... waiting for ice cubes to melt so you can suck down an inkling of hydration is not cool.

Argh.

Such is the problem with many European restaurants. You want authentic Bosnian fare? You got it. However, that also comes with a heaping side of blatant disregard for good service. If I may make a suggestion, order a soft drink or Fructal juice in addition to a glass of water (the food is salty and you'll be dying mid-meal if you're depending on a refill). You're welcome!

But I digress. The food is solid-- I tried the salad with feta (no lettuce, just cucumbers, green peppers, tomatoes and feta) as well as the cevapi. The meat is excellent, and the homemade lepinja bread is more buttery than most I've tried... delicious! I did miss the kajmak though... what's up with all the Bosnian restaurants in St. Louis serving sour cream instead? It's just not the same! Sigh... I feel cheated.

Oh, and my take on the restaurant? Jimmy Buffet meets Vermont ski lodge. Quaint, cozy yet hokey. Niiiiice.

This hot brunch spot may be called Half & Half, but it's wholly delicious.

First, the important stuff - this girl's gotta have her caffeine! I didn't see it on the menu, but just because Aimee K wrote about it, I ordered a half coffee/half hot chocolate. Oh.My.Awesomeness!

For my meal, I ordered the cornbread and chorizo dish. Easily the frontrunner on their menu, my plate was perfectly portioned with the headlining ingredients plus two sunny side-up eggs, cilantro and red onion. Spot-on sensational.

My cousin had the fried egg sandwich, which is usually what I would order if it's available. The rest of the menu boasts fairly inventive selections - think Clara cakes (pancakes with raspberry, mascarpone and granola), a Brussel sprout and cheddar omelet (WHAT?!), salmon hash and housemade donuts. All good in this 'hood!

Can't wait to return to eat my way through the rest of the menu. Well done, good folks!

Aunt Gertrude and four of her friends show up hungry, unannounced? What's a gracious hostess to do? You get in your car and drive to P'sghetti's. You can order spaghetti by the GALLON here. So naturally the pre-measured portion sizes, along with its strip-mall location with free parking, make it tres popular among the soccer mom set.

But P'sghetti's is good, I swear. The pastas are okay, but you have to try a sandwich on their freshly baked Hawaiian-style bread... you know the bread, slightly sweet and more yellow than white? 

Cheap, fast and tasty. Oh, and don't leave without a loaf of the cinnamon bread.

Sorry guys, but I really can't get on board with your sushi. Next time, I'll try one of those burgers you keep braggin' on.

But, big props for featuring a $6 cocktail every day! My poison pick? Allow me to recommend Pearl Caramel vodka with soda. Did you know caramel mixed with soda = a dreamy cream soda?

Bell Biv DeVoe... now you know (I've always wanted to drop that).

Yes, it's true: the space is very, very pretty.

However, good looks alone shouldn't warrant a restaurant resting on its laurels. Maybe it was just an 'off' night, but my cousin, brother and I certainly weren't overly impressed.

We sat down and were quickly greeted by our server with a smile and an introduction. Nice! She asked us what we wanted to drink, but being that Copia is a wine bar, kind of difficult to do that without a wine and/or drink list in front of us. We also asked for a beer list (which they don't have), but our server was happy to consult her own personal list and recite the anemic selection for us. I know you specialize in wine, but craft beer and good wine go hand in hand!

We ordered the calamari appetizer to start. Though it came out super fast, it was over-breaded, over-cooked and under-seasoned. I tend to love most calamari whether it's fried, sauteed or grilled, but this was an underachieving dish. I should have gone with my gut instinct and ordered the baked brie! At this point, we finished our drinks and decided against ordering more food.

I'll have to return to try additional dishes, but this particular evening proved 'a-okay' at Copia. Though I do love the concept of selling bottles of wine at retail price plus an $8 corkage fee to keep it legit!

Though I'm neither vegan or vegetarian, I really enjoy eating as healthy as I can... most of the time, anyway!

It makes me so happy to see spots like this in my hometown, beautiful eateries celebrating mindful eating with clean ingredients. So often restaurants in this vertical are more casual, which I certainly enjoy, but it's really nice to have a more elegant option as well. And Frida's certainly looks the part! Though you won't feel out of place if you are dressed down.

On a recent weekday afternoon, I met a gal pal for lunch at Frida's. We both ordered the same salad as she highly recommended it: the taco salad with the addition of sunflower taco meat and gluten-free chips for an additional $2.75. Crunchy romaine, cheddar jack, black beans, black olives, tomatoes, red pepper, scallions, avocado, and house-made chipotle ranch made for such a healthy yet unbelievably tasty meal. Coming in at $14.25 for the souped-up large, it's a touch spendy but well worth it! The salad is truly a generous portion, which translated into a very light dinner that evening. 

Can't wait to eat my way through the entire menu, there's truly something for every palate and dietary restriction at Frida's!

Now THIS is what a luxury hotel should strive to be like.

As others point out, the amenities are plentiful and they just make good sense. For example - offering free wi-fi not just in the lobby but in every guest room. I can't tell you how often I pay an arm and a leg on wi-fi services that feel like AOL dial-up, circa 1996!

Also, the complimentary courtesy car (available for trips within a 3-mile radius) is such a swell add-on. I used this service at least three times!

But best of all, is the wine hour enjoyed in the lobby every day from 5-6pm. This is something I did not miss! The wine is actually really good and runs like water (free + plentiful) much to our group's delight.

Of course, the hotel is beautiful from trim to fixtures to the stately but small, elegant rooms. Service is wonderfully southern, and the hotel's conscientious environmental efforts are commendable.

Would I come back? In a Nashville heartbeat.

What a gem. Not a hidden gem, but a pretty, polished gem... this sleek, warm brownstone is gorgeous inside and out!

On to the important stuff - the beer. Or is it the food? Well, you won't be forced to split your loyalties at Square One as both are very, very good. Cousin and I tried the charcuterie plate and ate our way through the pub pretzels (that jalapeno cheese sauce is a dipping darling) and would have ordered more if it wasn't for a heavy lunch earlier that day.

I had a difficult time zeroing in on just one beer so I naturally sprang for the beer flight once I discovered it's an option - especially as the individual flight pours are robust at five ounces each. Essentially, you get a pint+ for the same cost as a regular pint! I chose the Maple Stout (my favorite!), Spiced Pumpkin Ale (solid), Spicy Blonde (loved the ginger notes) and the Bavarian Weizen (classic banana + cloves; nice and easy). 

Much joy was had and I look forwarding to visiting again when in my hometown.

I can't dance worth a crap, but get a sangria in my hand and I'll salsa you senseless. Speaking of the sangria, it's definitely not good, but the free salsa lessons on Thurs. and Sat. evenings along with a mostly international crowd make Viva a refreshing change of pace on a hot St. Louis night.

Live blues, 365 nights a year 'til 3am. Now that's what I'm talking about!

No, they don't serve food. But you can get that across the street at the Broadway Oyster Bar (fantastic music acts over there as well). But after I've spent a few hours at the Oyster Bar, my friends and I like to change up the scene by heading to Beale. It's a bit darker, a little grimier, and more intimate. The performers on this stage are top-notch, occupational musicians... if you're looking for 'real' blues in St. Louis, you've come to the right venue.

There's always a cover (maybe $5-7) but you're supporting St. Louis' vibrant local music scene... here's to keeping it alive! The bartenders are no-nonsense pros - drinks are strong and the beers are cold. And if you get the chance, visit during the warmer months so you can soak up the sparkle of the Beale on the patio. Cheers!

Vodkaaaa. It's the only spirit that I drink! And with nearly 260 brands at this bar, you're sure to find 'the one'.

Sub Zero has done a fine job of profiling an extensive list of drinks, including a specialty champagne cocktail roster. My favorite? The Bling Bling, comprised of Grey Goose, raspberry puree and simple syrup then topped with champagne. Hello, sweetness!

Sub Zero's the perfect spot for people watching, catching up, meeting up, and just plain loungin'. Also, I haven't yet tried their sushi or burgers but my discerning friends who frequent Sub Zero regularly give the fare a thumbs up. 

But I'll be back here for vodka topped with bubbles... a vodka parfait, mmm!

Marinka is the perfect blend of savvy realtor, outstanding marketer, and wonderful human. She recently sold my childhood home after only being on the market for 3 days. She also went out of her way to help my Croatian-born parents with filling out paperwork, which is obviously beyond her scope of duty but yet she happily offered. When my father fell ill which landed him in the hospital, Marinka worked with us to make sure all the papers could be signed in his hospital room on closing day. It was truly a flawless and stress-free transaction in every way. If you're looking for an empathetic realtor who's at the top of her game, Marinka is your woman. I can't imagine working with anyone else and I'd recommend her to anyone. As we say in Croatian: svaka čast, Marinka! Bravo on a job well-done.

More than two and a half years later, I'm STILL jonesin' for the Creperie every time I'm in St. Louis! What's even funnier - I'm still ordering the same crepe: banana, brown sugar and sour cream. I'm so predictable!

The Creperie is very kid-friendly so go in expecting it to be somewhat of a zoo. However, they've added some tables outside if you'd prefer to read your newspaper with a side of peace and quiet.

The coffee here is still my favorite - really rich yet very smooth! I can't say enough good things about this special spot... so go experience it for yourself!

It's always a treat to see a thriving new restaurant in my hometown... especially one with a creative hand, constantly keeping things fresh with a seasonal menu.

My sister and I took the rare opportunity to have a girls' lunch while her hubby stayed home and the kiddies napped. She recommended we check out Nosh, and after checking out the Yelp reviews and the online menu, I had to agree. 

Not a dealbreaker, but the first thing I noticed is that it's a little cold inside. No biggie - we took a table furthest from the door and I made sure to order a piping hot cup of the French onion soup. Fastest way to a sure warm-up! Quite delicious, too.

For the main act, I ordered the Fried Egg BSRP: Two organic free range eggs cooked medium with bacon, spinach, roasted red peppers, smoked gouda and dijon red pepper aioli served on a butter croissant. Verdict? Even better than it sounds. I could barely finish as it's a sandwich made for a hearty appetite... but it was so good, I couldn't tear myself away. My sis really enjoyed her ham and brie sandwich, though she commented it could have used a touch more brie. So, we like our cheese! But still, spectacular sandwiches indeed. And next time, I'll be sure to try the chicken gouda sandwich or the steak and gorgonzola flatbread. Trust me, I was plenty enticed by a few of the offerings.

Service was attentive without being intrusive. Keep on keeping, Nosh! I'll be seeing you again soon.

Good thing my sister loves this darling cafe as much as I do, because Sunday morning breakfast here is de rigueur EVERY time I'm back in St. Louis.

Besides, it's fun pretending that you're French. Crepes, sidewalk seating, gratuitous people-watching, the boutique-laden streets of Clayton, and coffee served in oversized white mugs.

Oh, and did I mention the coffee is INSANELY good? Because it truly is.

Okay, back to feigning the francais.  7 years of French classes have left me with only a gaping void.  Apparently, no one in the Midwest speaks French.  Not that I really can anymore, either.  But to snag a table at City Coffee House & Creperie, with my reporter's notebook in hand, feels... well, French.  Or at least channels a throwback to the "Sex and the City" episodes in which Carrie briefly lived in Paris.

If you want to sit outside, get here early (read: before 9:30 am).  My sister and I easily accomplish this as her 17-month-old daughter wakes up at the crack of dawn on the weekends, er, 7 am.  If you don't have one of those, be sure to set your alarm because the Creperie draws a crowd.

And don't get discouraged by the line at the counter-- this moves very quickly.  Crepes are thin, so they cook fast.  Use this time wisely to study the elaborate menu, which is scrawled out on a chalkboard!  Tres francais! Though they also serve sandwiches and pastries, order a crepe and some coffee.  Do as the name suggests and you won't be disappointed!

The crepes run the gamut from savory to sweet.  My personal favorites are the Clayton Club, the Banana with brown sugar and sour cream, and the classic Nutella. The Lemon Curd is also fantastic, but for some reason, they skimp on the decadently rich yet tart filling. A perfect portion if you're not ravenous, though.

If you're hard-pressed to make a decision, I'd recommend the Banana with brown sugar and sour cream crepe. Actually, I order this one time and time again :)

Parking is easy as meters abound on Brentwood and there is also a metered parking lot adjacent to the Creperie.

Bon Appetit!

You stop looking at me like that. I know, I know - Penn Station is a chain and eating at chains while traveling is practically a cardinal sin. But, I had only a few minutes to spare... and my choices including walking a few blocks further or grabbing a Penn Station sub next to my hotel (which would ultimately free 15 extra minutes to take a quick soak in the luxurious tub). What would you do? Uh huh. Priorities!

Anyway, the staff was nice enough though one staffer was barking at another woman for ringing people up separately though they were in the same group (awkward!). After ordering my sub, I was told it would be 7-8 minutes. 

I brought the club sandwich back to my room and ate it (okay, devoured it... I did just drive 3+ hours) while I ran my bath. It was a bit more compact than I anticipated but was loaded with bacon. Dare I say, almost too much bacon! It kind of overshadowed the taste of the other ingredients. But, it did hit the spot. Would I eat at Penn Station again? Probably not with all of the fantastic artisan sandwich crafters out there.

But... it was all about the tub in my bathroom at the Conrad.

I'm a huge fan of the one-stop wine, beer, cheese and more (delicious hummus!) shops. See, I think I could survive on only wine, beer, cheese, hummus, crackers and olives. What?

So yes, I could live in Starrs, though I'd probably get in the way of their perpetually hustling bustling store. Most patrons come for their fantastic wine selection-- I found a really, really great Tempranillo for about $12 today. And they stock all of my favorite beer plus some obscure picks too. 

Sometimes service can be a bit slow but it's always very intimate and personal. They know my cousin by name and can pronounce it properly, which, being a Croatian name starting with a y-sounding 'J' is no easy feat. 

Love to love ya, Starrs.

Coming to the Scholarly Tap Room is always a special treat for me. Even while living in St. Louis, it was always a treat. I can't think of a better spot for delicious local brews, live music and a feel-good casual atmosphere. 

Food: You must try the Warmed German Camembert Cheese Plate. For real. The menu description reads 'glazed with brown sugar and walnuts and served with caramelized pears, dates, roasted garlic and John Dough bread'. As in WARM Camembert cheese doused with all of that aforementioned good stuff. Yep, I'll keep going. Next stop: the Fish & Fries. As others have mentioned, the Tap Room produces some of the best fish and chips I've ever had. I wasn't even able to find a better version in Southie, Boston. Again, I'm not messing around. Dessert-- believe the hype, the Sticky Toffee Pudding and the Bread Pudding are legitimate forces of awesomeness. Save some room, or at least sit long enough with your beer until you can stomach some pudding.

And for the piece de resistance, the beer! Wow. So the Hefeweizen and the Pale Ale are great staples. Seasonally-speaking, summer's my fave because Schlafly then brews their Weissbier and Witbier. The Weissbier is brewed in the classic Bavarian-style, unfiltered with hints of banana and cloves. The Witbier also tastes all-summer, containing subtle notes of orange peel and coriander. I had a pint of each this past weekend and am still replaying their goodness. You can also purchase their beer in kegs or growlers to bring back a bit of beer bliss to your own home.

Minus one star for the sometimes gruff service. If the service was consistently better, the Schlafly Tap Room would be a surefire five-star establishment in my book.

If this gives you any idea of how efficient the good people of Nashville International Airport are, here goes:

We left our hotel at 7:50am (approx. 8 miles from the airport).
We checked our bags at counter, went through security and were sitting at the gate by 8:25am!

Whew. That's impressive!

Restrooms are clean, baggage comes up fast, there's a Starbuck's and a 20-minute manicure spot, and best of all... it should be relatively easy to wrangle a ride as it's not a zoo in front. It may not be the prettiest airport, but it's certainly the closest I've come to travel nirvana.

This tiny little place... it really did make my heart sing.

A small bit of history: In River Phoenix' last fully-realized screen performance - The Thing Called Love - we get a glimpse of songwriters auditioning to play at The Bluebird Cafe. Samantha Mathis stars in the flick too (who I fell in love with watching Pump Up the Volume) and though the movie isn't the best, the little cafe stayed with me. 

Fast forward to last night, when a dear friend suggested we hit up The Bluebird Cafe to catch Nashville's finest songwriters singing the hits they never recorded but painstakingly birthed. After waiting in line for about twenty minutes, they started letting us into the intimate venue. Now some may say this is a fantastic date spot, but really it'll only play that part if you're with someone you already know well as conversation is discouraged. The hushed demeanor definitely reminded me of Chicago's famed Green Mill!

But that's where the parallels stop. Where Green Mill is dark, The Bluebird is sweet. While Green Mill's musicians boast with their big sound, the modest artists of The Bluebird make you wonder, 'what if?'

I bet they too wonder, 'what if'.

Take Gary Burr (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Burr), who wowed us with just a taste of his collection of hits, performed by greats such as Kenny Rogers, Lynyrd Skynyrd, Faith Hill and even Ricky Martin and Christina Aguilera. Gary was as accessible as an artist can get, regaling us with his stories and forcing us to re-think music as we already knew it... a musical coup of déjà vu!

Thinking about what could have been usually proves to be a bittersweet road and Gary's performance was no different. Cheers to The Bluebird for introducing audiences to the real legends behind the music and also, for reuniting songwriters with their babies. 

About as special as it gets.

One large group + light but insistent rain + an overly-crowded Whiskey Kitchen = After-dinner drinks conundrum.
 
Ack.

We were ready to give up and head back to the Hutton for drinks in the lobby bar, when our lovely local tour guide nudged us next door to Virago. And I'm glad she did for otherwise we would've missed a real Nashville hot spot!

So baby, it's a scene all right - it's dark and slick and sophisticated, but still tinged with that unmistakable Southern hospitality. Seriously, are all Nashvillians born with honey in their voice? Right off the bat, our sweet server offered to take separate checks for our group of 10 or so. Thanks, but luckily we've got some manners, too! 

I ordered a drink with strawberry puree, St. Germain and cava... easy does it! I believe it was called a Strawberry Sparkle. Or maybe it was Strawberry Smash. In any case, it's delicious alliteration. If I ever get asked 'if you were a drink, which one would you be?' in an icebreaker game again, I now know the answer! 

So they do sushi, too. Go see. Be seen. Check the scene. Sex and the city? Oh yes.

I've been going to Kaya's for a decade now. Yes it's in a strip mall, but once inside, you'll find a collection of wine and spirits that will make you forget you're in South County. Personally, I frequent Kaya's for the extensive selection of Croatian wine, beer and liquor, but they do a swell job of stocking other worldly spirits.

Every Friday from 5-8pm, Kaya hosts a wine tasting and also serves complimentary cheese, sausage and crackers. Check it out! You're also welcome to purchase a bottle onsite and enjoy it without being charged a corkage fee. 

Don't be surprised if you find yourself walking out with gifts for every family member... Kaya's has something for the imbiber in everyone!

Sugga, sugga!

Just because I ended my meal with a dessert (an oversized slightly gooey sugar cookie) doesn't mean I can't start my review with an homage to the sweet. Well done, Fido!

So Fido is this totally cute, totally happenin', totally cool coffehouse/eatery. There's tons of space so you can grab your co-workers for a group meal or to sprawl and sneak in a working lunch. Or, you can do like us and accomplish both!

They serve breakfast all day (huge plus for me, as sometimes I like to have pancakes for dinner), as well as a strong collection of specialty coffee drinks, artisan sandwiches, salads and larger plates. I tried the flank steak sandwich with swiss, roasted onions, garlic mayo, lettuce (hold the tomatoes) on herbed focaccia. GONE in 10 minutes flat... take that Nic Cage!

Yet another reason to frequent Fido? Their mission to find homes for displaced dogs. A feel-good operation right here in Nashville, indeed!

There's a time and a place for a large local supermarket like Schnuck's and a time and a place for Starrs.

Starrs time:
- You'd like some personalized advise on selecting wine or craft beer.
- You're searching for a hard-to-source wine or beer.
- You'd like to take your time to shop sans crowded aisles and grocery cart bumps.
- You enjoy supporting small local businesses.
- You want to impress your boss/potential girlfriend/family with a unique buy.
- You're an oenophile or craft beer connoisseur.

Schnuck's time:
- You're nowhere near Starrs.

Why why why why why? Why do I continue to eat here?

It's a love/hate relationship.

Rationale: they've got a 24/7 drive-thru (I've never seen them close) that happens to be around the corner from my brother's abode. Convenience is the name of this late-night game... oh Del Taco, you're my faux Mexican booty call!

True story: I found my little dream home driving to Del Taco hungover one morning in a quest for a breakfast burrito. Saw an open house sign, wandered in, fell in love, called my parents and the rest is history! I lived in this cute little house for 4 years before moving, and now it's my brother's nest. Thanks Del Taco!

I was bamboozled.

Well, not really as I walked out of Saks with an *enhanced* appearance (courtesy of loads of Chanel make-up), but all that prettification sure did cost a pretty penny.

Because I put together a half-assed halfway to Mardi Gras costume consisting of only a long, light purple wig, I needed a dramatic face that could pull its weight. One with super long, fluttery eyelashes (read: faux) and smoldering eyes. I, unfortunately, am not competent when it comes to fake lash application nor at creating the smoky look... sigh.

I first stopped by the MAC counter, knowing full well that they make the best fake lashes and are awesome at creating a theatrical look (also - they're relatively inexpensive among department store cosmetics brands). But alas, they were booked solid and a sales associate at Chanel coaxed me to her chair. After asking what the minimum spend would be to get my make-up done (3 products or $75), I restrained my inner thriftonista, remembering I was also on a strict time budget. Proceed, lady in black!

And so she did. 45 minutes later, I was transformed into a va-va-voomin' vixen with a sexy, smoky eye, mile-long eyelashes (purchased from MAC), what appeared to be cheekbones (oh, hello!) and a demure, rosy lip to balance the strong eye look. Now, for my (not really necessary) product picks: blush, liquid eyeliner and a Glossimer lip gloss. Total cost? $112. Gulp.

But my make-up endured the test of 12 hours out and my new Chanel products will last much longer. When shopping at pricey department stores like Saks, it's best to go in knowing exactly what you need as saying 'yes, I'll take that!' just one too many times can easily result in a 4-digit spend. While the sales associates warm up as you spend some time with them, I did find their reception initially chilly... and a bit too 'sales-y' for my taste. Guess I'll always be a Nordstrom kind of gal - all the brands I want without the pressure or pretense!

I'm almost reticent to ask, but does a better beer garden than McGurk's even exist? Anywhere?

Whether I'm craving a liquid lunch or a low-key evening out, McGurk's is my go-to pub in St. Louis. They do reubens and fish and chips well, hell, even the most discriminating Irish lad would be proud. And the live music-- the bands actually hail from Ireland and if you stick around late enough, you may find yourself in a battle of shots type o'war. Proceed with caution ;)

The service can be spotty... I lounged in the beer garden this past Friday afternoon and the late lunch rush left us waiting... and waiting... but 9/10 times, I'm a happy, full and sometimes tipsy girl.

Lots of good beer on draught. And did I mention the beautifully landscaped beer garden? Come, sit and tip back a perfect pour of Guinness with me... on that note, I may be heading there right now!

I stayed here in August or September 2007 when I had to go to Tampa for some training.  

Due to the proximity of this hotel to the Nielsen Company location on Brooker Creek, this place should just rename itself "The Nielsen Dorm Facilities."

A jewel in Ybor City, La Creperia Cafe's specialty are crepes... both sweet and savory.  But if you don't like crepes, they have an extensive menu that includes panini, pastas, salad, wraps, and a myriad of beverages.  

The crepes are large and made fresh to order in the window at the front of the store.  I had the Turkey a la Brie, packed with roasted turkey, creamy Brie and tomatoes with a small side of lettuce, tomatoes and cucumber.  It was sooo yummy, but I couldn't finish it because it was so large!

I was tempted to order the "Latin Lovers," a sweet crepe with Nutella and bananas, but I figured I should have something more substantial than dessert for dinner.

No Yelp Elite member reviews yet? Hmm, okay, let me take a stab at it. 

I had bought a Groupon for Dawna Ara and it was soon to expire. So I tried calling but I didn't get a response. In the voicemail, she prompted to book via the website. You check the website and the only date that was available was the day after the Groupon's expiration date.

Hmm...Plan B.

Decides to email her directly and email Groupon just in case I can't use it. Groupon responsed and said they would give me credit in Groupon money if I never used the deal. Dawna also responded and after exchanging a few emails, we had settled on a date.  So if you have problem getting through her, I would say email is the way to go.

The date arrived and finding this place wasn't too difficult via GPS. However, it's a residential building and does not have any company name posted. Look for the house with the little white fence.  I walked in and just saw candles lit and chairs with literature on the table. I also saw an Iphone but I figured that was hers. I was finally greeted by Dawna after what looks like the owner of the building came in and shut the door. 

Dawna does everything herself. So there's a bit of a wait before, during, and after the session. This was my first time at acupuncture and I actually did feel something working immediately after I finished the treatment. I came in for multiple ailments but she concentrated on the main aspect of my problem. BTW, the treatment was relaxing since I was lying down for 30 minutes but the actual treatment was a little bit shorter than I expected compare to the other reviewers. Also the massage was a bit shorter than I expected. Nevertheless, this place should be tranquil enough after she updates it with some furnishings since it is really bare at the moment. Thus, not bad for the Groupon rate. Note to add, if you ever check out the bathroom, it feels a bit slanted.

I've been having a hard time finding a good brunch spot, until I found Jones.  Unfortunately for me, Jones is a 3 hour drive.   So I will not be frequenting it - but one can dream.

We sat upstairs, which I recommend - a little quieter & you can watch everyone below you.  We were there around 11:30 on a rainy Saturday, and were sat immediately.  Service was fine, and fast.  Decor is super cute.

I had the French toast with tater tots.  Tater tots, you ask?  Yes, because where I'm from, they are not quite ubiquitous.  My Philly friend (aka tour guide) also had the French toast, and my husband had the avocado sandwich with fries.   The French toast was thick and tasty, and probably the biggest piece of French toast I've ever seen.   I enjoyed the tater tots.  My husband liked his sandwich and fries, but the fries went cold fast.  

Perhaps a second location in DC or Boston is needed?

I don't always get drunk and go to clubs, but when I do, I like to make sure I'm on vacation in a different city and pay a cover.

I remember mostly EDM with some hip-hop, a lot of dancing, and it being super crowded. Floor was sticky. Definitely a dressier crowd. I don't miss my club days.

I had fun, but keep in mind, I was feeling the effects of alcohol. I'd probably not choose to go here sober, however, I didn't see many other dancing options in the immediate vicinity.

My iced almond milk caramel latte was fine, as was my friend's cortado and bagel. Four stars for the overall atmosphere, decor, and service, but three for the coffee. I've had better, and I've had worse. I prefer a strong coffee/espresso flavor, and my latte was missing that. It was more milky than anything, so the overall balance was off. Pastries (not bagels) looked tasty, and if I did happen to stop in again, I'd grab one.

Muriel's is a fine dining gem. I had been wanting to visit and finally, on my last night in New Orleans, I did. I enjoyed the fantastic service and delicious food.

I hadn't yet had a Hurricane and figured this would be the perfect place to get one. I definitely enjoyed it. The bread is addictively good and I couldn't stop eating it. I ordered my new standard--greens and redfish courtbouillon. I love redfish. Both the items were great. I loved the greens and the popcorn rice paired well with the redfish and sauce. I was too full for dessert, but I definitely want to return and will definitely be ordering dessert.

If you are looking for fine dining and excellent NOLA cuisine in the French Quarter, Muriel's is your spot.

This shop is fantastic. It's very welcoming and not gimmicky. I felt like the staff was really knowledgeable and helpful. You could tell they love talking about and teach about voodoo. My interaction was great--I told the super nice gentleman what I was going through and he recommended the perfect item. My Oya doll and I haven't been separated since. I really appreciate that he took the time to explain her protections and offer other suggestions as well. I'm looking forward to returning here on my next visit.

We all really enjoyed Pho Street. We didn't plan our visit, but were happy to have happened about this place. It's casual with plenty of seating and you can order at a kiosk, which is much appreciated.

I did a quick scan of the reviews to know not to order the pho. I ordered the grilled pork vermicelli bowl (bun thit nuong with cha gio), my sister had the Vietnamese hoagie (banh mi thit nuong), and my brother-in-law ordered the broken rice (com tam) with a cha gio side. Everything was excellent. The pork was super flavorful and there were tons of fresh vegetables and herbs in my bun. My sister said the bread on her banh mi was great. And my BIL loved his perfectly cooked and delicious com tam. We all appreciated the crispness of the cha gio. Even my baby niece enjoyed the vegetables we gave her. I love that they have a house-made fish sauce, which add depth to everything.

I'd stop here again if craving Vietnamese in Center City.

Our iced caramel soy lattes were OK. Something was missing--perhaps a stronger coffee flavor? Their hot lattes may be better, as some places are better at hot lattes than cold ones.

However, I did love the fun, eclectic vibe, and the food we saw looked delicious. I'd come back to try some noshes, keeping in mind that the line gets long and parking will take a few circles around the block.

This bustling station is beautiful. It probably works well if you know your way around, but as a visitor, it's frustrating, due to lack of available information. Directional signs are not clear. The website is basic, at best (given that it is run by Amtrak, that is no surprise), so finding information prior to visiting is a chore. A quick peruse of the food court options also proved to be basic and most close early. No place to grab a great coffee in the morning. Bathrooms are fine and at least there's an ATM and a convenience store, but this place could be better.

I could've skipped this and would've been OK in life. Anyone who tells you need to do a cemetery tour in New Orleans is lying, unless they are are really boring or really into history. The tour was good, but I was bored. You can walk around a free cemetery and see some graves--no need to pay. You can see a bit of this particular cemetery from outside the walls (this one you have to pay for and can only get in with an official tour) and that's all you really need in life. Save your money and your time for the important things, like drinking.

Hipster heaven, but my barista was surprisingly friendly.  Very good lattes, though I definitely needed sugar for mine.  Cool atmosphere, and the pastries looked amazing.   Definitely better than going to a Starbucks.

I was struggling with what was going to be review #1500. Would I go try a new place? Would I seek out something unique and fun to celebrate? I contemplated it. But I decided I'd rather review Wat Mongkolratanaram, a Buddhist temple in Tampa that offers a lovely Thai market on Sunday mornings. It's not something you come across too often.

I had been looking for cool things to do in Tampa, which are hard to come by, as I left the city somewhat indifferent about it. Luckily, before I left, I had found out about this place on the Tampa talk threads. From what I can tell, you need a car to get here.

I agree with much of what has been said: come here early (parking is rough and food runs out), bring plenty of cash, and plan to grab some small items to eat while you stand in line for the noodle soup. I missed out on the noodle soup because of poor planning. Do not let this happen to you. Also, come with people that like to eat and understand waiting in line for food.

Food wise, we tried various spring rolls and dumplings, beef satay, pumpkin curry, and chicken basil. Everything was great, and I'm fairly obsessed with the spring rolls. I also tried the papaya salad, and that was the only thing I did not really care for, and normally, I love it.

The grounds are idyllic, and the temple is gorgeous. There's really no other way to describe it. Ideally, when I return, I'll return alone, and be able to stay for services, which all are welcome to join. 

As a visitor to the area, I definitely recommend finding a way to get here. It was a highlight of my trip.

Not sure what else I can add, except the gelato is delicious.  A little pricey, but they let you try as many flavors as you like.  After trying a few, I had the bacio (dark chocolate & hazelnut) and cashew.  So amazing.  I also had a cappucino, which was good as well.

This Hyatt Place is fine. It's clean and comfortable, but not at the height of luxury or at all trendy. Beds are comfortable. Wifi was good. I was on a low floor, so it was a bit loud. Elevators are slow and constantly busy. Staff was super friendly and helpful.

The location is only good if you are going to a convention. It's not far from some good restaurants, but you can find hotels that are much closer to the fun. 

I'd not stay here again, but if you end up here (remember, for a convention only), it should be fine.

This was my worst JetBlue experience, and I normally love JetBlue. Curbside check-in is appreciated, though the staff does not speak well and was extremely rude. Gate staff was also impolite, while the flight crew were unprepared and kept barking orders at everyone. The on-time departure was nice, but I'd appreciate a calm, prepared, friendly crew in the future. I hope my future flights will be with a different Tampa-based crew.

Saint Lawrence is cute with a friendly staff but I was underwhelmed with the food. We ended up here due to location and the fact that it was open a bit later than other places. The food is fine, but there are better options. I didn't love my drink--it was a little sour. My red beans and rice, collards, fried chicken, and cornbread were OK, but a bit lacking in flavor. I needed hot sauce on everything. I'd go somewhere else before returning here.

Herbsaint is the first restaurant I visited in New Orleans and my first true experience with Cajun/Creole cuisine. It was an amazing introduction to the cuisine of the region. My only goal for my day was to eat amazing food (I left D.C. at 6 a.m. and was at Herbsaint by 11:30 or so--I literally flew to New Orleans, dropped my belongings in my room, changed, and headed here) and that is what happened.

This restaurant is exactly what I imagined a restaurant in New Orleans to be. It's hard to explain, but the decor and ambiance, along with the patrons (mainly a business crowd during lunch), created a charming, relaxed atmosphere. And the hospitality and service was amazing. From the lovely hostess to the skilled servers, everything was exceptional. 

I couldn't drink, which is too bad. I would have liked to try their cocktails, but will save that for next time. I ordered the gumbo, gnocchi, and fried apple pie. There was also bread and an amuse bouche. The bread was delectable. The amuse bouche, a marinated clam on a cracker, was the perfect morsel of deliciousness. And their gumbo remains in my dreams. It was so flavorful and so hearty and is definitely my favorite version of this dish. The gnocchi was light and tender and I appreciate the cloud of Parmesan. I couldn't finish it as I knew I wanted dessert, which I also couldn't finish. I had no idea what fried apple pie was, but it's basically an apple empanada, and since I love carbs that have been stuffed, rolled, and fried, this was a great dessert for me. It was definitely rich and I recommend splitting it with someone (though I mostly dine alone so that doesn't work for me). 

Herbsaint is fantastic and I highly recommend everyone experience it while in New Orleans.

Great museum for the little ones! We had so much fun here. My friend who lives in Philadelphia has two young children and has a membership, and I can see why. I feel like if you live close by and have children, it's definitely worth it. The kids love this place. And it works for a range of ages, from my then 8-month old niece to my friend's early school-age children, everyone had a good time. I think we spent ~2.5-3 hours there, and I was ready to leave (and drink) at that point, so it's a good amount of time. 

The exhibits are interesting and interactive. It really is a "please touch" place (I brought hand sanitizer and hand sanitizer wipes). It's also really pretty and well-laid out. A few spaces may be a bit cramped, but overall, it worked. You can park on the street if you don't want to pay for parking, which is great. 

I'd love to return to see the new exhibits and see the children in my life really enjoy themselves and run around and just be children.

I did not want to go to the Country Music Hall of Fame.  Truth be told, I didn't really even want to be in Nashville.  I mean, I'm a city-loving R&B girl, and had no idea why I'd want to learn about white people singing songs I can't relate to.  Watching trains go by in the middle of the night and drinking muscadine wine isn't even something I'm remotely interested in and I don't know all the words to every Tanya Tucker song (but, you can often find me drinking from a red Solo cup).

However, country music is part of the fabric of American life, and I loved the Country Music Hall of Fame.  You'd be remiss if you spend time in Nashville without visiting.  It's chock full of history and interesting facts, and it's great to see how and where country music started from, and where it is today.  The exhibits were very nicely done, with my favorite being the Crystal Gayle one (I will always want her hair).  They have a few of Elvis' cars, which are super cool and very detailed.  It takes a good 2--3 hours to get through everything, so don't go hungry (like we did).      

And while I didn't leave a lipstick tube on the bathroom floor, I was a bit sad to leave this place.  You definitely realize the significance part this musical genre plays in other types of music, and in American history.

The food and service at Melograno were great.  They open at 5:30 on Saturdays, and at 5:25, there were already people inside! Because we were early, they seated us with one person missing, but I hear that is not the norm.  It definitely filled up quickly.

Our server was friendly and good, though there were minor mistakes - automatically pouring the wine (not everyone was drinking), credit card slips in wrong jacket.  The decor is really pretty - we were seated right by the big chandelier.  

Food was great - my husband & I were still talking about it the next day.  Between four of us, two had the wild boar bolgnese, one had the mushroom app with the ravioli entree, and I had the ravioli special: cocoa ravioli filled with rabbit and topped with the brown butter sauce.  It was delicious.  Bread was also good, and you can't beat BYO.  I absolutely love the idea of BYO - it was the first restaurant I've been to that does that.

Why not 5 stars?  The foyer needs to be cleaned - I noticed spiderwebs (with spiders) in the corners.  My wine glass was dirty.  And one hostess was rude (though the first one was nice).

This was the closest Cuban restaurant to my dad's place, so we decided to check it out. It's definitely popular and does a good take-out business. We sat at the small bar, and became quickly disappointed to find they do not have liquor (only beer and wine). It took a while for someone to take our orders, but staff is friendly.

I ordered a chicken empanada and lechon asado with rice and beans and tostones. I was hoping for Cuban bread, and it actually comes on the platter, not before the meal, so don't get disappointed. The empanada was tasty and crispy. I was underwhelmed with my platter. The bread was good and so were the tostones. But the rice and beans and lechon were not super flavorful and sort of dry. I asked for a side of mojo, which made it better. I was also unimpressed with my friend's ropa vieja.

I might try a sandwich from here, as the bread was really good, and I noticed many take-out sandwich orders. But I wouldn't get a full entree here again.

I will visit Longwood Gardens anytime - it is absolutely beautiful. I was here in early November, on a rather rainy day, unfortunately. I had been wanting to visit, especially due to the perfume exhibit, and luckily, Ariela M. had the same day off as I did, so a quick trip to Philly & Longwood Gardens was in store for me. 

The outside grounds are gorgeous, even without flowers and waterfalls in November. The inside gardens were just as amazing. My favorite was the orchids, of course! 

I had been wanting to see the perfume exhibit, as I am obsessed with perfumes. It was small, but with nice information on scents and perfumeries, as well as a beautiful perfume bottle display of some of the most popular perfumes and prettiest perfume bottles. Though I had been to a perfume bottle museum before, I never tire of seeing the bottles and thinking about new fragrances. 

The cafe was nice and the meals looked tempting, though we only split a slice of pecan pie. The Pierre du Pont house was also nice to walk through, especially as we needed to get out of the cold. A really cute cat lives there! The shop had some really pretty home decor, if you are into flowers. I must get back in the summertime!

I really enjoyed Dook's Place. To clarify, since I couldn't find a website for them, the MSY website sucks, and Yelpers, per usual, are confused: this is NOT Dooky Chase's airport location, which is close to Concourse C. This is an offshoot from his grandson, and is before security in Concourse B, the Southwest terminal. It looks like the only good place to eat, aside from its more famous namesake.

Dook's Place is nice. It's well-lit with a nice bar and colorful artwork. The R&B was bumping and service was good. They kindly made the modifications to my chicken sandwich with no problem. I didn't get to try a drink, but from what I saw, they looked good. I loved my fried chicken sandwich and fries. That sandwich was on point--the chicken was hot, crispy, and flavorful. Fries were great. I'd be happy to return and try more on the menu.

MSY lacks in many areas, most notably dining. If you are going to be hungry before or after your flight, come early/stay late to eat here. The food and ambiance are great and it's also one of the only good options.

I've been to my share of convention centers and this is one of the worst. Yes, it's one of the biggest, but who cares? I never attend a convention here. The design, both interior and exterior, is extremely dated. The food court offerings are awful. In a city known for it's food, at least you could offer excellent food, but not here. And there isn't even any good food right outside, so if you are at the center, you can't leave to grab something good (unless you have plenty of time and can hit up Cochon). It's not in an awful location, but you do have to walk at least a few blocks to find some good food. 

A convention center, much like an airport, can really represent a city, and this one (also much like the New Orleans airport), does not. At least it's named for Morial (the first African-American mayor of New Orleans) and you can hire a jazz band. That's all I got.

I was super hungry and Royal House had no wait, so I stopped in. I was excited to try the shrimp Creole, as it was near the end of my trip, and this was one dish I still had yet to try. I thought it was was just OK. The shrimp were not the big, beautiful Gulf shrimp I was expecting and the sauce had little flavor. It also took a really long time to prepare, given that the restaurant was not that full. Those around me mostly ordered sandwiches, and I wish I had gone that route. Service was really good, though. There are better restaurants in the Quarter.

Visiting Tampa for the second time, our colleagues here decided to take us out to Boizao.  I've never been to one of these Brazilian Steakhouses, but have heard a lot about them.  I knew that I was in for a lot of food.

Food - The amount of meat that you eat here is ridiculous.  14 different types of meat is offered to you throughout the evening.  There is a cardboard circle in front of your seat that is red on one side and green on the other.  If you place the green side up, they will offer you a piece of meat....if you have the red side up, they will pass your table.  I had the green side up most of the evening. I think I sampled everything except one or two types of meat.  Here's what I tasted:

Filet Mignon
Filet Wrapped in Bacon
Lamb Chops
Leg of Lamb
Pork Tenderloin
Ribs
Prime Rib
Picanha
Picanha com alho (with Garlic)
Top Sirloin
Bottom Sirloin
Brazilian Pork Sausages
Chicken Legs marinated with beer

Yep....I pig'd out!  I passed on the salad bar though....as I knew I would have to save room in my stomach for all of this food.  I even had a little room for a Tiramisu for dessert.

Service - I thought the service was excellent.  There were 7 of us and we never had an empty glass of wine, water, or food.  The servers were very attentive and cordial.

Atmosphere - The dining room is large and dark.  Nice setting for a dinner.  The tables are spaced appropriately....what I mean is that they aren't too close together.

Parking - There is valet parking that's available.

Special Offers - I hear that kids under 7 eat FREE.  That's what my colleague who lives in Tampa tells me.  He says they come here once a month with his 5 kids.  That's a great deal.

Will I return?  Only when I'm in the mood for massive amounts of meat....which is not too often.  That's not because I don't like the restaurant, it's because I don't eat meat that much.

This place is a dump.  It's basically a gutted warehouse that looks like it was built in the 1960's and hasn't been updated since.  We came here for a gun show, which had very few vendors.  The parking is small and the entry to the expo center is weird....it's on the right side near the back of the building.

If I was a meeting planner, I wouldn't hold any meetings here unless it was for a swapmeet.

Return Factor - 1%

Ok, so I found this place using Yelp.  I was in town on business and my hotel was only a couple of miles away.  After reading the excellent reviews, I decided to give it a try by myself.  Here are my thoughts.....

Service - Everyone was friendly and knowledgeable.  I was greeted by the host and seated immediately.  My waitress was on top of things and the food came out on time an fresh.

Food - I had the Tomato & Feta Bruschetta w/Baked Tortilla for an appetizer....it was awesome!  I highly recommend it.  The bread was fresh and delicious.  For an entree, I had the cheeseburger....I would have tried something else, but I really wanted to try the bruschetta appetizer and I didn't think I could eat that and an entree by myself.  The burger was excellent....just the right size, not too large and not too small.  The fries were steak-cut fries and cooked perfectly....not too hard/soft.

Atmosphere - I was here in the Spring time and the weather was awesome....so I ate outside on the patio.  I'm glad I did....it was very relaxing.

Wine - The wine selection was decent....not great, but decent.  I had a glass of the Malbec....don't remember what the vineyard was though.

While I was dining....there were no more than 5 tables occupied in the joint.  I heard that lunch and brunch are much busier.  So, I guess if you want to enjoy the place and have a nice, relaxing time.....go at dinner.

Will I return?  If I'm in the area.....For Sure!

Stayed two nights here.  Rooms are very nice, but the bathroom is a little small.  They're modern and clean, which is very important to me.

They have a very good selection of restaurants.  We dined at the Buffet, Steakhouse & Mexican joint during our stay.  Reviews on those are here:

PY Steakhouse
http://www.yelp.com/biz/py-steakhouse-tucson#hrid:8KJbPpTCgqNlNOgIBiLAWw

Tequila Factory
http://www.yelp.com/biz/tequila-factory-tucson#hrid:32_J-W-4rNrDap9JNFCmog

Festa Buffet
http://www.yelp.com/biz/festa-buffet-tucson#hrid:bGixUWahY--pO_K9AC42-w

The staff is very friendly.  They greeted you at every guest touchpoint and asked if you needed assistance.

Overall, this was a very cool place for a short weekend getaway.

TIP - Be careful of the speed traps on the road to/from this place.  There are photo/radar speed traps that will nail you if you are not careful.  Signs warning you about it are small and difficult to read...easy to overlook.  A friend got a ticket during our trip

Return Factor - 88%

This bar was located in the lobby of the hotel I was staying at.  The place is decorated with sports memorabilia and the banners of the local teams. 

Food - The food here is ok.  I tried the Angus Sliders, which were good and the nachos, which were bleh.  The menu is an extensive bar menu with all of the typical bar menu items.

Drinks - It is a full bar, so they can make all types of drinks.  The one thing that surprised me was that they didn't have Shock Top....which is a wheat beer.  You can find Shock Top all over Tampa, but not here for some reason.  Instead, they have Blue Moon....which is very good, but I enjoy Shock Top when I'm in Tampa.

Service - The waitresses and bartenders here are very friendly.  However, at times they can forget about you and leave you with an empty glass for a while.  One good thing is that there are tons of TVs in the bar, so if there is a game you want to watch that's not on one of the TVs, they will put it on one for you.

Will I return?  If I'm staying in the area.....yes.

Amazing find on Yelp....my business partner and I were in Tampa for a business meeting and decided to get some Italian Food....found The Laughing Cat and were glad we decided to take the trip to Ybor City.

Food - I had a Caprese Salad for an appetizer while my friend had the Mussels with Marinara sauce.  The portions were huge.  

For entrees, I had the Lasagna while he had the Veal Parmigiana....again, both huge portions.  The Veal was really big....there was no way we were going to finish.

The food was excellent.  The only thing that I would have liked done differently is that I like my pasta al dente.  The Lasagna was a little overcooked in my opinion.....great flavor though.

Service - The service was awesome.....can't complain.

Atmosphere - The place is a hole in the wall.....not upscale by any means, but the food is worth it.

Will I return?  If I'm back in the area....you bet!

On the way back to Phoenix, I searched the Yelp app for a Sandwich joint nearby to grab some lunch before the trip.  This place had 4 & 5 Star reviews, so I thought I found a winner.  I ordered:

8" Deluxe Grinder, $4.89
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eegees-tucson-4?select=5GUDytvicuMtazmAP7_uhg#5GUDytvicuMtazmAP7_uhg

French Fries, $2.29
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eegees-tucson-4?select=hUcEgMIuvWuP_URura7TAw#hUcEgMIuvWuP_URura7TAw

The Grinder was just ok at best.  I thought the Bread was too soft and sweet for my tastes....almost like Wonder Bread, but shaped like a Hoagie.

The Fries were nothing to brag about either.

Overall, it's a 3 Star joint for me....would have given 2.5 Stars if Yelp had 1/2 Stars available.

Return Factor - 10%

On the second night of our trip, we decided to give this joint a try.  The standard complimentary Chips & Salsa are served when you sit down.  We asked the waiter for extra spicy Salsa and he gladly obliged with a Habanero Salsa that kicks your heiney....yum!

After browsing the menu, we decided to order:

Cheese Crisp, $3

2 Crispy Tacos & 1 Bean tostada, $12
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=pCI5eN2ZiGzVnJl7ppauDg#pCI5eN2ZiGzVnJl7ppauDg
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=pufGHErnon1I3FlCCnL8Eg#pufGHErnon1I3FlCCnL8Eg

Chicken Arizona (Chicken Breast, Avocados, Tomatoes, Green Chile, Pepper Jack Cheese, Veggies, Spanish Rice), $10
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=mTrEqN0RXH7ONKqdI2B6Yw#mTrEqN0RXH7ONKqdI2B6Yw
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=OIhripvCwd2wcqxbnsUTtQ#OIhripvCwd2wcqxbnsUTtQ

Number 6 - 3 Soft Tacos (Carne de Cabeza, Trepas de Leche, Chicharron), $12
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=WozpsO6J77Zhvwx6PblT8Q#WozpsO6J77Zhvwx6PblT8Q
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=hcM2oHdeErA9yjzcjf2vIw#hcM2oHdeErA9yjzcjf2vIw

The Cheese Crisp was ok.  So was my Tacos & Tostada.  I wasn't overly blown away with it.

The Better Half had the Number 6 combo and it was a little to exotic for her.  She didn't realize that she was ordering Cow Brains, Cow Stomach, and Pork Skins....LOL  

Kiddo had the Chicken Arizona and he was very pleased with it.

Overall, it's an OK dining experience.  

Return Factor - 60%

Located near the Tucson airport, this casino is nice, but very small.  Self parking is kind of far from the entrance.  We walked from the hotel to the casino and it was a bit of a walk....not sure why they didn't make it closer.

The machines were so/so...it's all luck anyway, but the selection of machines were quite limited.

Return Factor - 50%

I am visiting Tampa for a week on a business trip and asked the front desk clerk at the hotel where I'm staying where I should go for dinner.  She referred me to The Green Iguana, which is located near the Football and Baseball Stadiums.  I decided to go check this place out.

Food - I asked the bartender what their most requested dish was....she said the "Cheesiest Cheeseburger"....so, I decided to give it a shot.  Here's what the menu says about it:

"CHEESIEST CHEESE BURGER - $7.49
