Ordering is an art form. Seriously. Before I became a semi-adventurous eater, I was attracted to any dish that involved chicken or beef. Lame, right? Anyhow, last night at Chifa, my friends and I gorged on some crazy awesome dishes, and I proudly ate outside of my comfort zone. We sat in the back room where I felt like an extra on the set of Eyes Wide Shut...you know, in the scene with all the naked women and creepy monk-men with masks? Chifa totally has that vibe. The booth was cozy and I got to lounge on the pillow that cushioned my lower back. Nice touch.

The food: Everything was brought out in smallish bowls, but there was so much food, we were totally pleased with the portions. We had the lomo (beef and veggies), caldo (seafood bisque type soup), bbq ribs (there were no bones!) and chicken wings (no bones either!). There wasn't an unsatisfactory thing about our dishes. You'll also have to ask for more bread. It's unreal.

As for the cocktail, I got the Black Tea Sidecar. I'm a big fan of Courvoisier cognac (random, I know), but trust me, you can drink a gallon and you won't have a hangover in the morning. Promise. Anyway, I had to ask for an extra bit of simple syrup because the cocktail felt a little lacking in the sweet dept. I also think it could have used more lemon...I'm not sure if lemon was used at all.

Overall, outstanding time and great food.

Agent is, hands down, the best clothing store on South Street. Every time I walk in there, I peruse the fine selection of men's shirts. While they offer stuff for the ladies too, the store is heavily bro-geared. It makes me wish I were a guy. OBEY shirts, awesome local prints promoting the Illadelph, a vast array of Nixon watches, cheap, trendy shades, wooly winter hats, this store could outfit the coolest of cool.

And it's all fairly inexpensive. If you ask me, Agent is all about keeping it real and keeping it local. I mean, their store tees read, "I Copped This Jawn At Agent." How much more Philly can you get?

Any visit to Rami's is sure to be a great experience. Rami, himself, is nothing short of a delight. Always courteous and thankful for your business. If you're female, he'll probably greet you with, "hello beautiful lady." And you'll smile because he's just so cute, with his accent and all.

Moist isn't typically a desirable descriptive, it actually evokes gross-worthy thoughts, BUT when it comes to Rami's falafels, I wouldn't have them any other way. Where other falafel spots dry their chickpeas to the heavens, Rami's is right on. 

The falafels are the truck's claim to fame, but it's not what I go for. I prefer the chicken sandwich with hummus, feta, tabouli and hot sauce. It's not on the menu, but it's the way to go. Before you choose Greek Lady, give Rami's a try.

Without wanting to drive well out of the city, Sammy's proved to be the nearby Chinatown option to cure our afternoon Korean craving. 

We were one of very few occupied tables, but that didn't bother us -- the ambiance however was lacking (but no surprise there). 

We started with the complimentary banchan and I found the kimchi fresh and fermented, just the way I like it :) The pot of barley tea warmed us up on the cold and rainy afternoon, but it didn't help that heating/insulation seemed to be non-existent. 

The food is what really impressed though, my dish in particular. I'm a fan of dolost bibimbap and galbi, but I'm always torn on what to order. Here, there was no need to choose; my galbi came served atop my piping hot bowl of bibimbap! It was magnificent. Similarly, my date's bean paste soup was a winner. 

Come for the galbi bibimbap!

Big fan of my neighborhood coffee shop. Aside from the make-yourself-at-home ambiance, CH's coffee is bar none. 

There are 2 drinks I regularly get - the Black and Tan (chocolate & peanut butter mixed into coffee) and the Summer Soda (club soda mixed with raspberry and I think blackberry flavors...sooo refreshing).

They always welcome my dog and the music's great. There's just a lot of good energy in here, people.

After trying just about every vet there is in the city, I've -finally- found the one. Tucked away in the heart of South Philly is a state-of-the-art, environmentally conscious vet hospital. 

I called this morning looking for a quick appointment and to my surprise, they were able to see me just an hour later at 10am. The facilities are really impressive. The room was spotless and felt less like a sterile vet's office and more like a cozy little holding pad. 

Dr. Majeska saw Giles (my pup) within 15 minutes of us getting there and get this, she sat on the floor with him. She gave him a very complete exam and talked me through every step of the way. There was never a feeling of being rushed out so she could get to another patient and her placid, conversational demeanor instantly put us at ease. 

Just as much as Dr. Majeska cares for pets, she's clearly got a thing for the environment. This brand new facility boasts a green roof, environmentally sound architecture, reused plastic bags, and paperless billing, to name a few features. 

After diagnosing the pup and suggesting a system of attack (he's got a growth on his paw and his ears are chronically itchy), we proceeded on to the medication I should start giving him. I agreed with all her suggestions, which sounded totally logical, and upon paying for all the antibiotics, pills, ear cleaner, ear medicine, and doctor's exam, the total came out to $150. Seriously, that's nothing compared to what I had calculated in my head. 

The staff was beyond cordial and Giles and I couldn't have been more happy. So I think: amazing service, amazing facilities, thorough exam, AND affordability - I wish she could be my doctor.

Brauhaus. What happened? I came here with a friend last night and we were both incredibly disappointed. In looking for a middle-of-the-road option (nothing dressy or too expensive, but something nicer than say a hot wings corner bar), I suggested we head to this spot.

We each got a 1 liter beer, an entree, and potato pancakes to share. 

The beer: My friend and I wanted to drink out of a boot, one of those glass 1-2 liter boots we'd seen others enjoy. After selecting the Ayinger Oktoberfest brew and my friend getting the Hausbrau liter, the waitress informed us that his pick didn't come in a 1 liter serving (because the manager doesn't like to offer that beer by the liter). Without really explaining why, she walks away, but only to come back with both of our selections in a boot! Super! Except that my beer was warm...and later cost me $19.50!!!!! She explained that they didn't have a way to charge me for the boot (um, hello, why do you even have them then?) so she just charged me for 3 beers. Based on a general rule of thumb, whenever there are, let's say, 3 different sizes of things, each one costs more, yes, BUT you've got to save a little for going with the larger size. Think of it as if you were ordering a large drink over a medium one at a movie theater ("for only a quarter more..."). My friend's beer, $11...exactly what that boot should cost.

Food: My friend ordered the Wurst plate ($16) and I went with the Rouladen ($20). The wurst came out cold. Cold! As for the Rouladen, I should've ordered the Wiener Schnitzel.

The most redeeming part of last night's dinner were the potato pancakes ($6)...not because they were amazing (they're just potato pancakes), but because they were still warm when they hit our table. 

Our grand total came to $78.49. I would ordinarily have no problem paying that much for excellent food and service, but here, I felt swindled. 

Final thoughts: completely overpriced for food and beer that's half-assed.

I ordered the steamed chicken with mixed vegetables and while I didn't like it, my dog sure did. The chicken looked like something you would've dissected in high school biology class. 

One extra star though because they delivered in the middle of this blizzard.

While most other steakhouses offer stuffy vibes with expensive cognacs in visible, showcasey vaults and wine racks reaching the heavens, Butcher and Singer has its ambiance nailed. This Old Hollywoodesque interior is refined without being uppity, it's classy without being unboring. 

There's no cocktail menu and your server/bartender will most likely steer you in the direction of a classic libation (think: Manhattan, Old Fashioned, Sazarac, Tom Collins, Gin Martini). I gave the bartender a knowing look when he mentioned there was no menu...I rested my hand on the bar and said, "I'll take a screwdriver." He gave me a puzzled, unimpressed glance and when I realized I'd just asked for a orange juice and vodka cocktail, I quickly retracted my request and said, "bartender, what a clumsy mistake I have made. I will take a Sidecar, not a screwdriver." He released a subtle sigh of relief and assured me I'd "come to the right place." 

And so I had. My mom and I split the Porterhouse "for two." This 28-day aged cut had me pulling a Meg Ryan all throughout dinner. People stared, I didn't care. If you want the best steak of your life, this is it. At least it's the best steak I've ever eaten...and I've eaten lots and lots of steaks. The hash brown side was phenomenal and came out looking like a crispy potato pie. Golden on the outside with tiny potatoes on the inside. The green beans were also fantastic. 

We kept our order simple, but simple is right when the steak is this dang good. We finished off with a Baked Alaska for dessert. Christ in a handbasket. This was amazing and even if every bite was a painful addition of bloat to our bellies, each spoonful was well worth it. If you like bananas or meringue, order this yesterday. 

Here's the foolproof way to go:
Sidecars
Porterhouse for two
Stuffed Hash Browns
Green Beans Amandine 
Baked Alaska

I'll be thinking about this meal for a long time.

Affordable fancy cocktails, gooey homemade bacon mac n cheese, and retro go-go dancers shimmying in their fishnets atop glowing boxes. Yes, The Trestle Inn is in a league of its own. 

Just over a year ago, I'd heard sordid stories of the elicit acts performed in the once bar that'd turn strip club. It was a roughneck sorta place that only my most adventurous friends would frequent, but today, the scene couldn't be more opposite. The once seedy rathskeller is now a sleek red-light speakeasy minus the sex for pay.

The only downside is the bathroom situation. Later in the night after the crowd's had a few, the line will likely build up in the middle of the room. Great spot after a show at Union Transfer or if you're on a bike bar crawl.

I checked this place out over the weekend, and I'm surprised the reviews are so unfavorable. My friend and I were seated immediately (right by the window, in fact) and our waitress came over with menus and suggestions in no time. The beer arrived within 10 minutes of sitting down and the food followed up shortly there after. 

My friend and I shared the Gulaschsuppe (beef stew) and the Bratwurst. Both were pretty decent, but since feeding me is like feeding an army, I had to order the obligatory second lunch. I opted for the Wiener Schnitzel (lightly breaded and fried pork cutlet served with slices of lemon and parsley). That was definitely my favorite.

I'm not a huge fan of German cuisine, but I do really love the beers. I can sense spontaneous cravings for weiner schnitzel in my future, so I'll most likely make this place my one trick pony.

I used to think that if a bar offered the citywide special, then they were, by default, a dive. And so, I came here expecting another ramshackle beer hole.  A dive where the carpeted floor looked like a stampede of cowboys had vandalized the place with their heels and spurs and then spewed all over it upon exit. Floors that acted as a cigarette cemetery. But that's not Fiume. 

It may be cramped and the people may smell, but their birch wood flooring tells a different story. Fiume is all about order and cleanliness, a fact made clear from their shiny birch to their vast assortment of microbrews to their militant bouncer who smiles at her friends but scowls at the newbies. They even have a fully legit top shelf bar with organic and esoteric spirits. 

The Thursday Bluegrass band (aptly titled "City Wide Specials") is all class, all honky-tonk, and not to be missed...but then again, prepare to suck in and stand, you'll be elbowing people with every move you make; it's -that- cramped. While I've never checked it out on an off night, I can imagine this place being a pretty decent hang-out.

It's 2am, the bar has closed, and it's a choose your own adventure situation. You can either:

1) Watch amateur strippers @ The Republican. Note: the girls are gross and it's very smokey.

2) Eat a western omelet at Midtown Diner.

3) Join the sausage party at Ruba Hall. Note: the old man owner gets really grumpy at 330.

4) Join the shirtless gay men at Vouyer for a continued dance party.

My selection varies depending on the night, but this past Friday when I checked out the Making Time party at Vouyer, I was met with a floor full of people just as enthusiastic as I was when the DJ transitioned from MGMT's "Kids" to The Waitresses' "Christmas Wrapping." 

Imagine my excitement when I got to publicly cut a rug to music that's typically reserved for weekday nights spent practicing dance moves to a disengaged mirror.

The next time I think it'll be fun to watch a scary movie, I'll think back to last night when I stayed awake until 5am, anxiously waiting to either be dragged out of my bed by evil paranormal forces, or fall into a possessed state and kill my dog, my neighbors, and ultimately myself. Finally, when fatigue overwhelmed fear, I slept, but woke up only an hour later to the sound of my dog's muffled dream-barks. 

Thankfully, I knew holy humans with warm, reviving beverages were a mere 2 blocks away. I ventured out into the crisp morning air and despite the darkness at dawn, I thought it better to be mugged than remain captive to my racing imagination. 

One cup of coffee later, I returned to my doomsday domicile, curled up on the couch and thumbed through my roommate's coffee table literature: a photography book aptly titled, "Women Before 10am." Better dreams next time. Avoid "Paranormal Activity;" it will haunt you!

This place just keeps getting better. At first, I thought it was all about the cocktails and now I've come to find out they give other brunch spots in town a run for their money. 

1pm on a Sunday and Southwark had no wait and a private outdoor courtyard for my friend and I to sit and eat and gossip. Considering we were the only outdoor diners, our guilty confessions of nights past went unnoticed. 

The eggs benedict was absolutely perfect and my friend's chipped beef was creamy, eggy, and awesome. We also shared the shrimp ceviche special (soooo good). The food was fantastic, the service excellent, and the outdoor setting on a sunshiny day is a real plus. 

I have to find out what coffee they use, it was some of the best I've had...and the sugar cubes gave it the finishing touches. This is my new foolproof brunch go to.

What's my favorite indoor/outdoor Sunday brunch Tampa retreat? Clearly, this place. I hung out around the Seminole Heights hood to find a smattering of spots that were obviously established to attract people like myself. Among them, Ella's. With its wonderfully stocked bar, live jazz, hand muddled caipirinhas (although you won't find them on the cocktail menu), sprawling tree laden deck space and comfort food options, I was instantly blissful.

We bellied up to the stools surrounding the massive tree and sucked down a handful of muddled beverages. First mojitos and then caipirinhas. Nearby, I couldn't help but be completely awe-struck by the Bloody Marys. Where a celery stalk should be, is that a pork rib? Yes, that's a rib in your Bloody Mary. 

Despite not liking Bloody Marys, I can't turn down ribs and so our half-buzzed group occupied a booth space. Everything was awesome and Ella's is definitely going to happen again.

All I wanted was 7 margaritas last night, but after a number of "closed" signs reared their ugly heads, my friends and I settled on Moriarty's. We all walked in grumbling a little under our breath (this isn't even CLOSE to being Mexican!) but my former roommate/friend (who's ever so hard to please) got excited about being able to watch the Phillies. So we stayed.

Lindsay (friend) waited and waited for the bartender to change channels so she could enjoy the game...but it wasn't until the 3rd inning that she switched it on. Lindsay got dangerously close to smashing pints, Mutton Chop ordered far too many genetically enhanced chicken wings, and I didn't really enjoy the cheese fries.  

As far as Irish bars are concerned, Moriarty's gets 2nd place in Center City (McGillin's gets 1st). But then again, I typically avoid places like this. And no, not the best wings. Hooters still takes the cake in that department :)

Like a poor orphan I entered Soy Café with a mere 8 dollars to my name. I examined the menu and carefully selected what I thought was my best option for a lunch meal. 

The Funky Monkey called my name. Bananas, peanut butter, oatmeal, soy milk, and honey blended in smoothie form? Yes. I might say it's been the best $3.75 I ever spent...and now my new favorite smoothie in all the Philadelphia land. At 5:55pm though, I'm hungry. A blended beverage is no meal replacement unless there's whiskey involved.

With all the traveling I've done and all the food I've enjoyed, I always miss Cantina. Nothing quite beats the mista salad paired with platanos machos, a platter of nachos with shredded chicken and a blood orange margarita. This remains my eternal order and, with a bullet, Cantina takes a spot in my top 5 favorite restaurants you wish were always near. 

Since I no longer live in Philly, opening up my own little version of their successful recipe might be the closest thing to comfort.

Ok, I'm not about to take credit for this, but a number of months ago, I suggested (in a review) that DJ Deejay retire Michael, Madonna, Prince and adopt himself some new divas. Last night at Sister's, he did just that.

It went a little something like this:

Clock strikes upon the hour and the sun begins to fade. Still enough time to figure out how to chase my blues away. I saw the sign and it opened up my eyes, so here I go, here I go, here I go again, girls what's my weakness? Black, white, Puerto Rican, Chinese boys.

Straight up now tell me whether we could have a bad romance. Steal the night, kill the lights, feel it under your skin. Time is right, keep it tight, cause it's pulling you in. Wrap it up, can't stop cause it feels like a overdose. Evacuate the dancefloor. I'm a slave for you, cause you're hot then you're cold, you're a cold-hearted snake. 

Whitney Houston, Paula Abdul, Ace of Base, Katy Perry, and more? DJ Deejay is just what Sister's needs and vis versa. Well done, chap!
This coffee tastes like campside marshmallows in the Redwood Forest. I love it.

If any bar takes its name literally, it's this one. Immediately upon entering, you're greeted with a wall of smoke so thick that you feel like you're visiting your great aunt's house in coal country. The bathroom smells like Philadelphia's biggest landfill. No really, there's a serious disregard for the courtesy flush rule...every time I go in there, I'm met with someone's last meal.

I want to like it, because I know you all do, but I. just. can't.

I am not the kind of girl who goes to Parc. It's just not me. I'm not bougie, and I'm not even fond of Rittenhouse food and bar culture. BUT, I must say, having brunch at Parc yesterday couldn't have been more magical. 

The ambiance was exactly what I wanted: bustling open-air interior, cougars running rampant, ladies with their miniature dogs, bottles of sparkling water over your standard tap, brunch cocktails (yes, please). Even though Parc isn't exactly my bag, eating my steak and eggs by the window, overlooking Rittenhouse Park, made me realize how much I love Philly.

The food was great, too. My steak was perfectly cooked and the eggs came served over a saucy baguette. I, of course, made sure to employ the "perfect bite" philosophy. My brunch buddy ordered the country chicken club. It came with the perfect balance and selection of toppings: avocado, BACON, tomato and chicken married with a special sauce. 

So, okay Steven Starr, I'll give you this one. Thanks for bringing Paris to Philly.

I've walked past Paul a few times, and while I've been intrigued, I've never been certain of what they had to offer. Then of course, I consulted Yelp and low and behold, Paul had a mere 2 reviews. So I decided I wanted to blaze a new trail (i.e. try spot that doesn't host 50+ reviews); they only recently opened after all. When the gays decided it was high time for a classy, self-affirming team dinner, I quickly offered up Paul. They were understandably confused since they thought I was bringing new bait (named Paul) to dinner...

The interior is bright, airy, and *gasp* not cramped (as many BYOs are known to be). Sure, it's small, but they're not forcing communal dining to accommodate more guests. The menu is inventive but accessible; I'm used to going to fancy restaurants where I'm asking the server for a translation- this isn't the case here. Halibut, chicken breast, scallops, oysters, duck...they make it sound much better, but they cover the basics and offer something for any omnivore. 

I had the pancetta wrapped halibut. I recently started eating fish, so my palate is still in development, but this dish left me considering dropping red meat altogether. Perfectly flavored and generously portioned! I was expecting a thin filet, but what arrived was at least 10oz! I highly recommend ordering it, or at least convincing someone at your table to order it so you can steal a bite.

After your meal, you'll want to open another bottle, chat up Effie and your server, and close the place down. You'll instantly feel at home. As for the name, the BYOB is named after Effie's late father, Paul. It goes without saying, but he'd be pretty proud.

This review has been a long time coming and while you won't find me with many bones to pick, I've got it out for the PLCB. I could dive into the many many shortcomings of this state-run system of ours, but alas, I keep this on the local level. 

When you walk into this South Street store, you're met with unhelpful, disgruntled employees. They have little, if any, input on the liquor selection offered and you're more likely to walk away with a bottle based on the label art than the actual contents inside. Why not train your staff on the difference between a Merlot and Pinot Noir? Or Bourbon and Scotch?

Let's look at beer. If you walk into The Foodery or any other specialty beer store, you'll find a staff willing and eager to give you their picks. Given they've got the time, any beer store employee knows something about the product they're selling. Not the case with wine and spirits. 

So, allow me to offer some advice:

1) Hire staff that cares about their job. Pretty basic, but clearly overlooked.
2) Offer a more interesting, esoteric selection. I know there's more to Australian Shiraz than Yellow Tail.
3) Jack Daniels is not bourbon, please don't try to convince me otherwise.
4) Arm your staff with product knowledge! Do they not have a voice? Do they not bleed?
5) Have them smile and say "hello."

Seriously PA. Get it together.

You can walk into this frozen yogurt shop, grab a cup, and self-serve away. It's easy to load up on tons of flavors (tart yogurt, mango, green tea) and have your toppings (fresh strawberries, captain crunch, kiwi) follow suit. But don't be greedy, you'll pay for your glorious yogurt mountain when the cashier weighs your cup. I'm waiting for them to add mochi to their arsenal of toppings...do they still not have it?

Went to an industry cocktail party at Positano with my friends...I'll lay out the scene. 

My friends: casually dressed in jeans, sneakers and hoodies 
vs
Other guests: cocktail dresses, stilettos, fine Italian men's suits

As you could imagine, my friends wanted to run for the hills, BUT I assured them the cocktails would make up for the awkward company we found ourselves mingling with. Then again, I thought, they are normal. We are outcasts.

What did we learn? There's nothing a drink can't fix. I'm now a fan of Positano's cocktails. They feature a fully organic cocktail menu and by next week, they'll have a completely new list in place. The bartenders here spend a ton of prep time getting all the fresh ingredients ready. One of my favorites is the tobacco-infused cachaca (Bazillian rum) cocktail. It's amazing and I don't even smoke anymore.

Drinks here are well-balanced and sometimes they even feel like they're good for you.

When my dinner date-friend exclaimed, "take me to pleasuretown...and make it Mexican," I knew just where to go. I grabbed a bottle of tequila and down the street we hopped. 

I half-expected it to be crowded, thanks to the night's lovely weather, but thankfully there were tables abound! We were seated outside and within minutes, we placed our drink and appetizer order: Blood Orange Margarita, traditional guacamole, pork carnitas. With speed, the items dropped like kisses on my forehead. Except they dropped on the table, not on my face, and they were delicious. The guac maintained the perfect salt balance; the carnitas were served in a lovable DIY sloppy fashion; and the pitcher of blood orange margaritas took us to where we needed to go.

We split the short rib entree and found ourselves scarfing down every last bite...but it was just enough to leave us feeling full and bloated, but not the uncomfortable variety of bloated. 

Um, what else. Oh yeah, we got dessert. This was sadly very disappointing. The Tres Leches came out very stale and hard to gently scoop into the spoon and then chewing took a bit of effort too. 

Nevertheless, Lolita scored...and then I did too. 






j/k

This place almost got me to cave in to buying a fanny pack. In fact, their fanny packs are so cool, I desperately tried to think of another use for it. That was a senseless pursuit, fanny packs are meant to be worn waist-side. I even came up with a new name for it: the extra hip pocket-pack. I thought it akin to being a superhero. Either way, there was no caving and the fanny wasn't getting any love from my hips. 

Instead, I gushed over a polka-dotted Reload bag. I pretty much settled on buying it and even promised the owner I'd come back for it. "Well you know what? I'm a liar" (from a Violent Femmes song). I never came back for it and the past few days have been spent with copious ass kicking of my own ass. The lesson learned here is: buy the shit when you want the shit. Other than that, this is a great store with some very sexy, fine handmade products; even if most of those products are fanny packs and you happen to disagree with the recycled fad (as I do).

Even if this were the most amazing breakfast sandwich, I could never give it above 2 stars. Why? For the egg white portion of my sandwich, dude pulled a solid, white pancake-like object from behind the counter (that was the egg white) and cut it into quarters. 

Then he nuked it in the bizarro half microwave-half monster. When it was all said and done, he forgot to add the Black Forest Ham to my sandwich. The only thing that was probably made out of anything real was the bread. I'll probably get these every morning though.

Ever since I was young, my mother's been yelling at me for inhaling my food. You'd think I grew up in a competitive eating house with a team of rugby players where it's every (wo)man for him/herself. I eat FAST. Which leads me to my next point. I had dinner at Chew Man Chu last night where the food's so good, I needed to heed the restaurant's reminder to, well, chew man chu.

Please prepare yourself for the overwhelming array of dishes I'm about to lay on you.

Our table started with the oxtail dumplings, pork and shrimp pot stickers, and the scallion roti. While I've never been a real fan of oxtail, I found myself devouring one and then fighting my tablemate for hers. Ultimately, I thought of my mom, and then I resisted. Same goes for the pork and shrimp pot stickers. I shared those as well. I'm a huge fan of roti though and I was able to slyly hide this dish from my fellow eaters. One asked, "what's that on your lap?" "Oh nothing," I replied. (It was the scallion roti).

The Crispy Chinese Salad came next and that I was willing to share. It's salad. I'm willing to sacrifice. Nevertheless, it was a great salad. 

Next up: Pad See Ew (my favorite hangover food), Angry Lobster, and Black Pepper Sirloin Steak. The PSE was definitely on the spicy side, so if you're not a fan of spice, you should probably mention that to your server before ordering it. I can definitely understand why the lobster was angry. Chef Tyson chopped it up into pieces. I'd be angry too. It was fantastic though and covered with scallions, garlic, ginger, and oyster sauce. Finally, the Black Pepper Sirloin was a perfect balance of pepper and chives. I feared it might come encrusted in pepper (ick), but it wasn't, it came encrusted in awesome.

I'm not done yet. Sorry.

The Wok Fried Rice with Tofu came next and by that point I was tenderly petting my food baby. Satisfied I was. Still, I had to taste it. Really, I did it for you, dear reader. I can assure you, my taste was a good one and even better when I added soy sauce. 

Fiiiiinally, our wonderful (wanna eat him with a little spoon) server brought over Chef Tyson's famous homemade donuts. What a lovely touch. Tyson was so impressed with our eating enthusiasm that he finally came over to our table and invited me out for a game of racquetball, ping pong, or golf. I think he's worried I'll get fat. Ok, I'm done now. Thank you for reading.

DiBruno's is a must stop shop for anyone with culinary leanings. Want to host a small dinner party? DiBruno will hook you up from hors d'Oeuvres to dessert.  All this selection making you woozy? Stop by their coffee bar for an Illy espresso. Need a nibble on the fly? Sample from their generous array of freebies. Hankering for potato salad? Check out their cold to-go dishes. Navigating the city in search of Orangina? It's there. For the business lunch crowd, head upstairs for a café experience, you order, they prepare. 

If you, like me, are always hungry, DiBruno's is a serious place to stimulate your olfactory. Their stuff isn't cheap though. I came in last night for a bottle of olive oil and $14.99 was the least expensive thing they had. Imported ish comes at a price, y'all.

I love the art house cinema vibe: the selection of imported chocolate at concessions, the hot chocolate + tea beverage options, the film bill for current and upcoming features, and the carefully curated films. It's here where I've seen some of my favorites. 

The only thing missing is a liquor license, oversized leather chairs with movable arm rests, and eardrum blasting surround sound - then I'd really be able to get comfortable. 

This is a great place to go on a date by yourself.

I'm realizing that all my reviews focus on the drinks...so, I'll start by talking about the sliders I ate last week for lunch. Yes, yes, yes, they were great and if you get the chance, get themmmm.

So this place has amazing infusions; Bacon vodka, jalepeno tequila, apple and spice whiskey. Did I lose you at bacon vodka? I'm a huge fan of the whiskey and I typically pair it with a Kenzinger...or whatever other beer I happen to be in the mood for. Don't shoot it though, sip it slowly like the sophisticate you are.

I like to go there on off-nights because I think the Rittenhouse crowd has started to flock here on weekends. Don't get me wrong, I love the Rittenhouse crowd...errr..

They have great Quizzo and feature a weekly line-up of other talent (The Olde City Sideshow for eg.). Oh and for brunch, you can make your own bloody mary. They give you a list of ingredients and you basically take your pick. Don't ask me though, I'm not a big fan of the stuff.

National is an oasis in a land of Old City cheese.

If you're the kind of person who enjoys hooking up in bathrooms, Triumph is your place. They're almost like mini-rooms with ample space for movement; stalls be gone! 

Aside from that, it's a hit or miss crowd. On busy, South-Jersey-invades-Old-City-nights, Triumph might be the last place I'd go, but it beats the other area sleaze asylums. 

The space is very accommodating for groups and the beer selection is great. I'll take their home brews over Philly Brewing Co.'s any day. Personal fav is the Irish Red. The food also scores, try the Cuban sandwich.

If South Street is a sea of philistines, Hoof + Fin is the lucky piece of driftwood washed up on shore. Tucked away from the madness, H+F sits on 3rd between South and Bainbridge. A spot like this would seem better suited for Rittenhouse, but maybe that's why I liked it so much. It's something awesome in the least likely of areas. 

Surf and turf menu with simple but inspired dishes. Spotless aesthetic:  vintage prints of animals in gold frames of all different sizes, hung on a large wall to create a giant collage of cute. I was originally drawn to this place weeks ago when I admired their sign: a wooden slab and the haphazardly carved, "Hoof + Fin."

Armed with lots of cheap wine and a bunch of gays, dinner at H+F was already off to the right start. To begin, someone ordered the calamari. Each ring was lightly fried and glazed with a sweet and tangy orange sauce. Delicious and we fought until the very last one was had.

I went with the whole fish special - a perfectly prepared mild, white Mediterranean pesce. This being the first whole fish I've ever ordered at a restaurant, one of the servers was kind enough to debone it for me. My friend's skate wing was awesome, she mentioned never having had this kind of "bird" before. Oy. All the gays on a diet ordered the mahi mahi - really awesome - and my final friend went with the short rib pappardelle - my favorite pasta dish. Sadly, we didn't have room for any of the homemade dessert. 

The best part? Towards the end of dinner, a man and his guitar hopped on a stool and started serenading guests with lovely little flurries of background music. 

What a hidden gem you are, Hoof + Fin.

Last night was frigid and the streets were abandoned. It seemed everyone was wrapped in their snuggies at the precise moment when I was wandering the streets, looking for a warm bar to enjoy a neat bourbon. 

When my mate suggested Misconduct, I gave him a double-take. You mean the bar I've never really thought about patronizing? Since he's a man of fantastic taste, I obliged his suggestion and on we trudged. 

I ordered my Maker's, he went with Knob and after the kind bartender informed us of half price burgers, we got one of those too. I'm a total snob when it comes to burgers (there's a bun to meat ratio that needs to be adhered to) and theirs was fantastic. So good that I'd say it's one of the top 5 simple sandwiches I've had in the city. 

Next time I'm hanging out with a bar snob of a friend, I'll suggest this place, it's unexpectedly awesome.

I have a dog and he has style, so, we sometimes go to doggie style. But it's only for the bare necessities. Miracle spray, gourmet dog food, a hoodie for the cold days. Their stuff is pricey, so I avoid it whenever possible. 

The other day, however, everything changed. 

Remember that sinking feeling you'd get after your mom would drop you off at school and as you're trying to inconspicuously sneak away, she yells from across the parking lot, holding your brown lunch bag out the passenger-side window? That's the same feeling I got when she pointed to the sign from across the street and hollered, "WHAT'S DOGGIE STYLE?" 

A big part of me is glad she doesn't know.

Oh IKEA, up until a few days ago, you had never failed me. I wish I could compare you to something (or a summer's day), but you were like nothing else: attractive and cheap.

For those of you who don't know, I'm in the process of moving and as you can imagine, it's an experience that really opens your eyes to every worthless purchase you've ever made. Before you know it, you're throwing away shoes, shirts, tennis racquets, dressers, box springs...sigh. Things you once spent a LOT of money on! Anywho, I decided to stop wasting and start making. Making money, that is.

I posted an ad on Craigslist to sell the IKEA desk I purchased from the previous tenant. I sold it in 2 days! The buyer and her husband showed up at my house a few nights later to pick it up.

Do you want to know what happened to the desk, IKEA? Do you want to know? It fell apart. The desk fell apart just as the husband and I lifted it from it's place. I can't begin to tell you how quickly and awkwardly they fled from my house. 

Despite the embarrassment you've caused me, I'm willing to forgive you. I think Beyonce says it best, you're "irreplaceable."

Years after being a regular at Zahav and then moving away, I came back to Philly to find this sacred Old City food temple to be just as fantastic as I remember it. Worried I'd be the victim to high expectations unmet, I cozied up to the bar and found the cocktails are just as amazing as I remember them, the hummus and laffa is the best my life has ever had and the service is similarly as pleasant and smart. 

I pretty much managed to sum up my experience in the first paragraph, but in case you're wondering what my favorites might have been, I started by ordering the restaurant's darling cocktail, the Lemonnana and followed that up with one (and then another) Desert Rose (gin, hibiscus, grapefruit, cucumber). Both cocktails are fantastic, but the second one really satisfied the well-balanced, fruit cocktail lover in me. 

As for the food, we didn't eat much, but the Hummus-masbacha (hummus with warm chickpeas) is a game changer. You'll compare every inferior hummus you've ever had with their superb rendition. Then there's the laffa that served alongside. This on its own crushes any bread that ever did happen. After Zahav laffa... well, there is no after. Whether it's to snag a seat at the small bar or go all out for dinner, and regardless of whether you're a vegan or carnivore, Zahav does certainly satisfy.

As I gingerly cut through my helping of not 2, but 4 balls, I thought, what better way to enjoy these little chicks than by spreading them on pita, smearing hummus all over them and tenderly biting inch by inch. I caught a little hummus drip on my lip, but waste it I couldn't - so creamy and delicious it was! The right balance and salty and spunky! 

Too soon?

Ok, seriously, the falafels came served over a base of hummus with drizzled tahini. I've been forever fond of Maoz falafels, but these puppies make the aforementioned look like the McDonald's of the Middle East.  What I hoped would be an entree felt more like an appetizer though. They forgot to bring me the promised pita bread with grilled vegetables and rice. Bastards. I'll just have to dine in next time with a hidden machete. You know.

Through the doors of El Rey and you're suddenly transported to LA or the desert. Starr really sets the mood here and you feel like you're stumbling into a roadside diner somewhere near the border of Mexico. 

Mexican prison artwork hangs on the wall across from the bar and the small, yet careful selection of tequilas (and only tequila) does the authenticity of a Mexican diner experience justice. 

My dinner date and I tried to sample as much as we could from the menu. The short rib enchiladas were good, but the gorditas stole the show. Make sure you don't miss out on these. The shrimp and whitefish ceviche was not good though. It came tossed in Mexican ketchup...ketchup with ceviche? No no no. The empanadas were a bit too salty and greasy, but I really enjoyed the fresh guac - delicious chunks of avocado assured the freshness here.

The food was good, the tamarind margaritas were great (a better bet over the traditional ones), and the ambiance was A+. The only thing amiss were the guys in suits seated in the back who looked like they were checking the books and going through the numbers. After watching them grill the servers, I'm guessing they were Starr's business partners? Isn't there an office for this kind of thing? Anyway, I wish they hadn't ruined the mirage of cool this place exudes. 

I'd definitely come back for more of those tamarind margs and the gorditas.

Summer is here (not technically) and I'm really trying to watch my figure. Thanks to The Cheesecase Factory, there are meals like the Weight Management Asian Chicken Salad (which I ordered). Thanks to food that tastes like nothing, I was still hungry after the fact.

Note to self and others, weight management is for suckers.

Ok, here goes. My favorite cheesesteak in Philly? Yeah. Sonny's.

Contrary to popular (tourist) belief, a typical Philadelphian's breakfast, lunch, and dinner is -not- comprised of a cheesesteak. If it were, however, I suppose Sonny's is where I'd go. Not Pat's, not Geno's, not Jim's, but Sonny's. 

While the aformentioned hot spots cater to visitors, Sonny's feels a bit more local and genuine. There's no colloquially forced ordering procedure ("wit," "witout," "whiz" - I'm pretty sure Pat's/Geno's/Jim's does that to suggest local flavor) and they offer more sophisticated toppings. After all, a cheesesteak is just like any other sandwich, one that's not limited to just onions and cheese. 

So if you're in the neighborhood, hopping off your Olde City carriage ride or walking out of the Constitution Center, Sonny's is a sure bet. You won't find a line trailing around the corner and you won't find a bunch of tourists reciting the proper way to order their cheesesteak in line. No pretension, no bull, just good meat and cheese sandwiches. 

Holla.

Great spot for lunch. $6 beef and veggie burgers, Anchor Steam on draft, and the veggie burgers are actually homemade and slapped together using actual vegetables. It almost looks like shoestring veggies pressed together into a patty. Top that off with cheese and it's awesome. 

Their house infused liquors are killer as well.

Coolest bar in Old City if you ask me.

Hotel Provincial was a wonderful addition to our vacation in New Orleans! The front desk was very accommodating. We weren't supposed to check in until 3, and we arrived a few hours early. We were only expecting to check in our bags and return later on, but the desk found us an open room and let us check in early! Very nice!!! 

I love old, historic hotels. The architecture was awesome. We actually stayed in the 500 building, which used to be a confederate hospital. It's said to be haunted, but we did not spot any spirits during our stay. There is a nice courtyard with a fountain for outdoor seating (even though it was too cold and rainy for us to enjoy during our stay). 

They served a continental breakfast every morning, and provided tea and hot coffee 24 hours a day. Very good coffee (Community Coffee) I might add. 

If you are mainly going to NOLA to stay in the FQ, this is the perfect location. A couple of blocks from touristy Bourbon St., a couple of blocks from Frenchman St., and a block over from the French Market. The atmosphere and decor of the hotel kind of takes you back in time. It was very relaxing and accommodating. I would definitely stay here again when I come back!

Greatness! 

This was the best meal that I devoured during my NOLA visit! 

We came across this place totally by accident. It was a rainy Sunday, and we were taking a walk down Frenchmen Street. It was lunch time, we were hungry, and The Praline Connection happened to be right in front of us! We hadn't heard of it before, but we took a chance and entered. Not only did it turn out to be a shelter from the rain, but a haven for gorging and overeating. 

The wait staff was excellent, very helpful and friendly. The establishment is separated into two parts, the candy store where they sell pralines, and the restaurant. The walls were decorated with antiques and paintings, it had a good vibe. There weren't too many people inside at the time, so I was kind of wary...but that all changed once the food came out. 

I had the seafood platter...shrimp (great), oysters (great), catfish (great), deviled crab (great), half of my friends bread pudding (OMG sooooo awesome!). The seafood was seasoned perfectly and the bread pudding had a praline sauce on it that consisted of pralines and bourbon I think. She had The Taste of Soul platter that consisted of ribs, chicken, catfish, etc... When I think of the amount of food that we both ate that day, I almost get sick. The words gluttony and greed come to mind. So, my lesson for you, the reader, in this review, is please try to not overeat during your visit here. It not hard to do!

I want to start this off by saying that I only came here to eat, I didn't listen to the live music...so if you are coming for the music, you may have an altogether different experience than I had.

On that note...we came to Snug Harbor on Monday night (1/10/11) to get a quick bite before going to listen to music along Frenchmen St. The show at Snug Harbor had a cover of $15, and there is so much awesome, free jazz along that street, we chose not to partake.

We entered, and the person who was supposed to greet us, didn't. I wandered inside and asked the guy at the bar if we could eat, he told us to ask the dude up front with the hat on, he told us that he would seat us. We went back up front. I had to ask him if he could seat us. He took us in the dining area. There was a large party and another couple near the cold window in the front of the dining area, the other half of the room was empty. Naturally he squeezed us in between both parties where we were literally rubbed by people getting up from their table. Eventually the big party left along with the other couple. That's when everyone else was seated on the opposite side of the room, away from the cold window, except us. I asked the waitress about the seating priorities, and she mumbled something and laughed incoherently. When we were done, I had to turn around to search for the waitress. A group of them were sitting in the back of the dining area at a table (the warm part of the room), and I had to wait patiently for her to notice me staring. She then got up and got my tab, not even asking if I wanted another beer or anything.

I know that I'm bitching, I don't like people that bitch and moan all of the time either, but shit...I was on vacay, and I wanted to have a nice night out. The wait staff obviously didn't want to be there.

I ordered the shrimp sandwich with a baked potato. It was decent. Not bad, but not worth the frustrating staff. This is based only on my personal experience on 1/10/11 at around 9:30pm at the small table by the window next to the pole. Too much good food (Prailine Connection) and too much good music (Spotted Cat and La Maison) nearby to have to go through that shit.

After a night on Frenchmen St., hanging out at the Spotted Cat, we decided to call it a night and head back to the hotel. As we ventured out onto the street, we heard music. Granted, on Frenchmen St. at that time of night, it's not abnormal to hear the sound of jazz music coming from every direction...but this was different. As we approached Maison, the sounds of The Jackson 5 poured out of trombones and saxophones, and onto the busy street. The open doors and people dancing inside the large windows beckoned us to enter. When we went inside, we had one of the best experiences during our trip to NOLA. 

That night happened to be a "open mic" night. A night where locals brought their own instruments, jumped up on the stage, and joined the group, ad libbing and free styling r&b, jazz, and any other genre that was requested. You could tell that these were regulars, some of the musicians on stage would call others in the crowd, asking "Where's your trombone?", and telling people that they need to "Hurry up and get up on the stage!" The jam session quickly turned into a trombone vs. trumpet battle. Both sides taking turns trying to top each other....blaring notes, clapping hands, and shouting filled my eardrums as the audience watched. 

This is a part of NOLA that I always heard about, and was so happy that I got to see. I heard that the food was good as well. I didn't try it, but next time I definitely will. Great spot!

When the boyfriend told me that we'd be making the trip to Philadelphia this winter, I just knew I needed to fulfill my girlish dream of seeing the first Anthropologie store. I had seen photos of the building online before and was curious to see this fancy shop's flagship location. Located in an old granite mansion in Rittenhouse Square, this location is seemingly large but seemed to have less than the locations I have visited in California. However, 4 floors of adorable (and expensive) clothes, books, and sundries is fun to wander around in and the architecture alone was worth the visit. There was a beautiful stained glass dome ceiling inside (see my photo) and the sale section located on the basement level featured everything under the sun. I grabbed a couple things (at 75% off!) then bid adieu to possibly the only girlie store I really love.

Holy Macakarel! John Yi's Fish Market  is my favorite fish monger in all of Reading Terminal Market. Great prices on incredibly fresh seafood and a selection that makes me weep-- and I live in California! The close proximity to places like Maine and Maryland mean crab cakes and other such eastern delicacies are at the ready for prices we can only dream about on the West Coast. On my last particular visit, their 11.99/lb. baccala was on my mind. A staple in many European countries, and something that is just so luxurious and easy to work with-- dry salted cod sounds simple, but is both easy to mess up (in terms of quality) and difficult to find. Two generous slabs ran just above a pound and travels well. A must-try for seafood lovers.

Specializing in craft beer and wine, this place is one of the better bottle shops I have seen on this side of the country. While the wine selections aren't much, it's their incredibly well-stocked beer fridge that is the star. They had an incredible amount of international selections- better than most larger stores with ties to major distributors. I came home with a few prized bottles including 3 Belgian gems including a beautiful farmhouse Saison from Fantome. Prices were reasonable and there is also a tasting area for those who want to open up their bottles or try any of their wine and cheese pairings.

Ok, I'm in St. Louis on a business trip, what to do for dinner? Hooters?  Nah, not really interested in wings and orange short-shorts.  How about some ribs?  I stumbled on Masterpiece and got pulled in by the smells, who can resist ribs?  Order at the counter and grab a table, within 10 minutes I'm greeted with a large slab of ribs over white bread along with a side of cheese bread and baked beans.  

Overall Masterpiece made some good ribs but not great.  A bit drier than I expected, I'm guessing they were sitting outside for a while.  Sides were ok but nothing to write home about, nothing particularly fresh.  I do enjoy my KC Masterpiece BBQ sauce at home but can't really say that you've got to try the place when visiting St. Louis.  There are probably better and more authentic rib joints in the city.  But I have to admit, the Gateway Arch on the walk back to the hotel was VERY cool....

While drive from NYC to NC, I planned on dropping in for my first real Philly cheesesteak and picked John's given its reputation and location off of I-95. This little foodie mecca had about a 25 minute wait at 2pm but wait I did. 

While the lines can get long, they have an efficient operation here. If you wanted anything but a cheesesteak (roast pork, meatball, etc) you were fast-tracked up front. But I grabbed a fresh cheesesteak and roast pork sandwich for my ride back home. And wow, so good! Lovely sesame seeded roll, about 11" long, stuffed with flavorful steak, provolone and onions. Loved the sliced roast pork that's simmered in a wine broth and spiked with sharp provolone. You can get it with spinach (not broccoli di rabe) at John's. 

I devoured half of my two sandwiches (they are big) on my 8 hour ride and then finished them off for lunch the next day. So simple but so good! Hope to get back up here, some day...

Gosh, there was a time when I loved Chili's chicken crispers but it's been years.  A group from work stopped in at this Chili's for a quick dinner and let's just say it was a reminder of why I haven't been to one in ages.  The appetizers were ok but nothing interesting, ribs were lacking meat and the margarita was a bit weak. Add in a less than clean interior, average service and I'm not sure why people eat at chain restaurants like Chili's.  

There are so many better places and ways to spend your money even if the commercials may be catchy.  I'm guessing I won't be baby-back, baby-back in a Chili's again for at least another couple of years.  Underwhelming food and dining experience, end of story...

We have gone on several Carnival cruises from the port here. We always had a good a time and met nice folks. The food is decent, not great. The entertainment is good. The rooms are small, but you do not spend much time in the room. The cabin staff was great, as was all the service.The opportunities for fun are totally unlimited in port or on the ship. We have now tried some other lines and some of them have nicer amenities, but we had a lot of fun on Carnival.

Kelley's is a good solid place to eat. The breakfast/brunch menu is outstanding. I like the dinner menu as well. I also like coming to the bar in the evenings. They have a great location and have been doing a great job for many years.
The place to go to get a great deal on a custom built aluminum trailer. They built 3 or 4 for me over the years. All functioned perfectly and they will maintain it for you also.

THE  place to stay to get a balcony overlooking bourbon street and party all the time. It's all happening below you and right outside your door. If you like to get some sleep, better go somewhere else, it is non stop on bourbon street every weekend.

I love Trader Joes. It is my favorite grocery store ever. They manage to combine great quality, service and selection with low prices. Some of my favorites here are the coffee, wines, and snacks. They have some of the best trail mixes you will find anywhere.

This is the coolest book store I have ever experienced. It is not the most upscale, but it is big, full of all kinds of books on every topic you can think of. You can literally spend an afternoon browsing around inside, I have on several occasions.. They sell new and used books. This store is locally owned and operated, and has been here for many years. A friend turned me on to it about 20 years ago, and I have been a fan since then.

A really good restaurant at the tourist district. They have all the traditional Greek foods, all very well done. They have been here for many years and know what they are doing. The pastries are some of the best in town.

A nice locals place in IRB for seafood. I have been coming here for years. Nothing has changed much. They continue to do a pretty good job on simply prepared seafood. We usually have a good time here and leave satisfied.

This is quite a nice place to hang out. I like the bar up front and the patio in the back. The mixed drinks are very good. My only gripe is it gets so loud on the back patio that it is hard to hear people talk.

I think this was one of the first Japanese retaurants in Pinellas county. It used to be THE place to go back in the day. They always serve consistently good, if not great food. It is always a fun place to go. The 3 sided sushi bar lets you strike up conversations with other diners easily. The staff are awesome, especially the sushi chefs.

A cool place with history, character and personality. They have been here a long time, but nothing has changed much. Get some fish spread and some smoked fish. They know what they are doing with these items. Sit on the picnic tables and wash it down with a cold drink, as people have been doing here for 50 years.
The roast pork was excellent, the baked chicken was a little lacking in flavor. The portions are huge and the folks that serve you are very nice.
I have had some memorable meals here and would go back in a heartbeat. The service has been very good, the wines excellent. Food is made with fresh top quality ingredients and has always amazed me.

This is a pretty nice club, and one of the very few places you can go around here at night. You can dance and have a good time. The crowd is really young and can be quite rowdy, so be prepared for that.

The Tiki bar is the place to see and be seen at Clearwater beach on Sundays. It has been wlidly popular for many years. People come by car and boat to be here. It is a young crowd of hard partiers, so be prepared. The restaurant inside is just so so in my opinions. The nightclub can be fun, but my favorite part is the outside by the beach when the bands are playing.

We think Muriel's is absolutely fabulous. From the moment we were greeted everything was flawless. We loved the appointments in the dining room. The seafood gumbo was delicious. I had the stuffed mirliton. Now the mirliton does not have a bold flavor on it's own, but when filled with a seafood stuffing, and served over a creole roasted tomato sauce, it was a flavor bomb. Our service was impeccable, and the lunch menu price made it an outstanding value.
Skyline is a unique twist on chili, and I enjoy it. My favorite is the 4 way. The Burritos look interesting also. I think this is a big improvement on the normal fast food fare available nearby.

The park is nice and very well maintained. They have a nice dog play area, and an onsite restaurant and event center. The location is convenient to town and to Lazy Days, if you are having any work done. There is a Camping World store nearby as well. The part of town it is in is not the best, but we always felt completely safe here.

This is a nice Home Depot. I really like how they layout their stores in the same way, so you can find things easily in any store you go to. I needed a specialized plumbing part on my recent trip. When I arrived in the plumbing department, an associate quickly showed me just what I needed. I picked up the other things I was looking for, and was on my way in a few minutes time. Great customer service.
They make some nice burgers here and I do enjoy them. The massive size and the bottomless fries can cause you to overeat and leave feeling stuffed. I would only dine here infrequently.
They saw our kitty and took good care of him. We have been using them for boarding, but this was our first visit to a vet. We were happy with our visit here.
These guys are simply great. My bike rides so much nicer now that they tuned it up. They adjusted the fit on my wife's bike. Prices on gear are very good here as well. Check this place out.

Nice hangout at John's Pass village. They have good food and do a booming bar business. You can come by land or sea, they have a dock and dock master to moor boats. The place picks up at night, this is a very popular night spot. It has a great view of the waterway, and there is usually a breeze to cool you off.

Very cool small park in the CBD. It is a great venue for events. The big trees make this place very relaxing and the shade cools things off when it is hot outside. A good place to sit and eat or just relax.

We stopped here after the Bucs game for a bite before heading home. I hadn't eaten at a Moe's in quite some time, maybe 5 years. I think it has gotten better. I had the chicken rice bowl and it was quite good. The chicken had been freshly grilled and the rice was very tasty. They top it with your choice of ingredients. The highlight was the salsa bar, which had about 6 different choices. I tried several and they added some major flavor to my meal.

In addition to the great bar and service, the food is awesome here. I had a roast beef sandwich which was flat out delicious. My partner had a BLT and loved it. We came here because they serve food late, but come in anytime for a great sandwich.

This is a very nice pool bar and restaurant at IRB. the food was way better than expected, and its a great place to watch the boats cruising down the waterway. The pool is nice and crowded every weekend. You can come by car or boat.
I like this Home Depot. It was my go to store when I lived in town. It is in a very convenient location of Clearwater. The customer service has always been very good here.

The desert is quite beautiful here I the Tucson area. You have to careful where you step to avoid having an encounter with a cactus. You really want to look but not touch anything here. We did not see much wildlife, but walking among the desert plant life is quite an experience.

Absolutely fabulous place for hiking. A real memorable experience hiking in the Bear Canyon. There are trails for all level hikers in this National Forest area. This place is popular, the lot fills up quickly. If you arrive mid morning, you will probably have to wait for someone to leave to get a spot.

Great place for bluegrass and hillbilly music. The bands we saw were very talented. The servers are friendly and accommodating here. The crowd is a bit more laid back than some of the rowdier places in town.

After having been here a number of times and frequenting the casino, bars, restaurants and the club, i rate this place as a 2 star, bush league place. The staff can be extremely unfriendly at times for no apparent good reason. It does not live up to what you expect from a Hard Rock establishment.

I will rate the surrounding areas a 5. This is some of the best of the best of the desert. The city itself is a 2. The place has so much potential, and you can find small gem areas in town, but for the most part, it is a let down. We were here for a few weeks and tried hard to find things we liked. We found some, but actually found may more things we didn't like here.

I love the trail. You can trek just about all of Pinellas county here. It is more congested going through Clearwater, and more open north and south. There are plenty of places to pull over and get food and drinks along the way. I have had fun riding my bike and roller blading here..

This place was so great. We arrived early and got seated with no wait. Drinks were served quickly, and our service was wonderful throughout. Every small dish we tried was a taste sensation, bruschetta first. It had a unique twist on this classic Italian dish. Next up was the Tempura shrimp, barely battered and sauced with some Japanese mayo and Asian mustard, so delicious I do not have words for it. Fish tacos, small and delightful flavor. Last up, the lamb sliders, so good. One of the best burger type items I have tasted.

Winghouse is always a fun stop. I have been frequenting this location for many years and it has been consistently good. I like the extra crispy naked wings best and they are quite good here. Service is always good and the crowd is usually lively. They have done really well and have many locations now so the concept must work well.

Ybor City is a small gem of the Tampa area. Developed by immigrants many years ago 7th Avenue has a cool vibe, that is a bit reminiscent of New Orleans. Most of the things of interest are clustered on or around 7th Avenue. This used to be the world's center for Cigar rolling for many years, and the large factories are sprinkled around. Lots of restaurants, shops and bars line the streets, great place to visit.

We had a very nice stay here. Sites are unusual for an RV park. Ours had a large space, much bigger than you would expect. Ours had a nice yard in front and was shaded by large Oak trees. Everything worked well at the site. Wi Fi worked but was a bit intermittent. The whole place was very well maintained. The location was convenient to everything in the area.

We enjoyed their salads and Pizza here very much. A salad and Pizza is plenty for 2 people so the pricing is great. The Pizzas are freshly cooked in the brick oven, and very tasty. The butter pecan salad is excellent.
This is a very nice Winn Dixie store. It is large and well stocked. Very neat and clean inside. The employees are very pleasant also. This store is much nicer than the ones near my home in Orlando.
I haven't been here in a few years. In that time this place has gotten even better. One of the best in the area with no doubt. Food is superb, as is the service. You can't go wrong here.

After walking by this cute place a few times, I finally had a chance to stop in. The space is inviting, and usually pretty busy. They made me a very nice latte, and the menu of drinks looks very good. This place is open late, which is a plus.
We stopped in here recently to get subs. The service was lightning fast as usual and we were very happy with the sandwiches. It is easy to stop in here on the way to the beach.

All of Tucson is a gem show at the beginning of February. It is quite a site. You can get some good deals here as well. Some shows are wholesale only, this one was open to the public. Well worth checking out.

Sandwiches are good, and it always amazing to see how fast they serve you. This store gets very busy at lunch time, with lots of deliveries. The staff really hustles to make sure everyone gets good service. That was impressive.

This a fun place to hangout, day or night. It is especially nice on a nice beach day. You can have a drink and you are at the beautiful white sands of St. Pete beach. You can play some beach volleyball or just lounge around.
We love it here. Every time I pass through it makes me want to move here. Love the architecture and the plethora of things to do in this neighborhood.

This place is quite touristy, but the food was good, and reasonably priced. They have lots of game and wild animals on the menu, but I stayed somewhat conservative and got the barbeque ribs with a loaded baked potato. The meal was very good, the ribs were super tasty and fell right off the bone. Service was wonderful.

This place has been the go to Pizza place at Clearwater beach for decades. They don't make the best Pizza in my opinion, but they are always consistent and many people seem to love it. This is more Greek style Pizza, and I prefer a thinner crust.
A nice Super Target. It is impossible to come in here and not find things you want. Target carries some nice items for around the house, which is what we are usually after here.
This place is awesome. I have enjoyed dining here since my first visit many years ago. I have never had anything but excellent food and service at this establishment.

My dogs love it here at the small dog park. They allocated plenty of space for the little guys. We played with the frisbee and had plenty of room to run. Met some nice other small dogs to play with. It was great fun.
Love their pizza's and atmosphere. as do many others cause it is usually crowded.  A little oasis of real food in an area where it is hard to find.
3 stars because this is the original and it is an OK place to stop for a beer. The food is pretty mediocre in my opinion. I just never liked anything on the menu.
They have some great bands playing here. The place is nothing special, but the music acts are. This is a fun place on Bourbon street, and one we will return to.

This is a good place to see a show. The sound is usually very good here, as they do not have as many reflections as in an indoor venue. You have a good hike from the parking lot to get in, that is a small minus. Plenty of food and drink vendors once you get inside. I always look forward to shows here.
Very nice high end Scandinavian furniture. I have always liked this style and enjoyed shopping here.

Came here a few times lately and was happy with the coffee and breakfast sandwiches. I thought they operate like any typical Dunkin store. Then I saw all the super bad reviews here. I did not have any issues.

This is a decent place to watch a band. You can see and hear them quite well from the sidewalk so you can decide if you want to go in or not. There is no cover, but you have to buy a drink once you go in.

We are enjoying our first year as season ticket holders. Last years home game blackouts pushed me over the edge, I was dying to see more Bucs football. We are enjoying the stadium and look forward to a great season.

It is well worth seeking out this out of the way place, tucked in the back of a bar. The sandwiches are very good. They make some killer Po Boys that deviate a bit from the standard presentations, while remaining quite yummy.

This is a cool older building on Printers Alley. The exposed stone and wood inside gives it a nice vibe. We stopped in because we heard the food was good here. After perusing the lunch menu, we did not find anything we liked, so we just had a drink and left. They have burlesque shows at night here.

I have always enjoyed the Dunedin Brewery. They have a nice laid back crowd of regulars that create a sense of community. The beer selection is great, and it is very pleasant to spend some time here at any time of day. I used to stop in all the time when I lived in the area, and still drop by when I am back visiting.
I don't really care for Sonny's BBQ. The meats usually are dry and bland.

A nice local place to hang out, drink and eat. It is convenient to stop in when on the Pinellas trail, and they are dog friendly. The crowd is usually a mix of ages. You can watch or play games while here. I have always had a good time when visiting.
Great place to buy cigars and accessories. They also have a very nice lounge to relax and smoke a cigar inn. This store is worth a visit if you are in the area.

I have been here many times and always enjoyed. It is a place where locals hang out. I see many folks I know from Clearwater hanging out here. It is hard not to like a place like this. It is directly on Clearwater beach, with outstanding views. Parking is very convenient in the adjacent lot, as long as it is not filled to capacity. They are always open all day and night and usually have live music.
This a great place for fresh seafood and great water views. You can get things to go or eat in. All the food is fresh and tasty. The views of the marina are very nice and relaxing.

We really enjoy this place. They have a very nice attractive facility here. The venue is well laid out and nicely appointed. The sound system is good and they book some good bands. Drink prices are reasonable. They have a small menu of food available as well.

We had a nice time here. There are multiple levels and multiple themes. There was a band downstairs and DJ's up above. Lots of folks having a good time.They serve food here as well, sort of covers all bases, We liked it.

Great buffet of southern food. The fried chicken was excellent, as were the fresh vegtables and desserts. The price was very reasonable and the service was great as well. Adjacent to the Plant City farmers market.

A very nice music club. They usually charge a small cover and seem to have top bands here. The service is very good at the bars. The place is a bit larger than most in the area, and feels spacious inside. Thee walls are dark wood and have an interesting texture to them, maybe they improve the sound. We enjoyed it here.

A pretty cool neighborhood dive bar. This place has been around a long time. I first stopped in in the 80's. The atmosphere is very laid back.  It is a good place to hang out and enjoy a drink or two.

This is great place to stay if you want to spend a night or two checking out the club scene in Ybor City. You can walk to everything easily and the hotel is very nice. You are actually staying closer to everything than if you drive up and park your car in one of the public parking lots.

The Salt Rock Tavern has such a nice layout. I loved the decor and the TV's at the tables. The selection of beers and wines was extensive. We were here for a Sunday Brunch, and were truly impressed. The service was excellent, although we generally served ourselves from the ample varieties of food. They had anything you could want, omelettes, breads and cheeses, cooked foods, a raw seafood bar, it went on and on. Everything we tried was quite good. We really enjoyed the brunch here.

I really like Jackson's, more for the experience of it than the food. The place is great, it packs a huge crowd, and the food is OK. You can spend a good bit of time here working your way through the indoor and outdoor spaces.

The burgers and fries are absolutely great here. Service was awesome. The singer was too loud for the place and a bit annoying for trying to enjoy a meal. We wished we had a volume dial to turn him down a notch.

Shells is always a good choice for seafood. They have everything on the menu and are well known for their pasta dishes. The pricing is really reasonable compared to just about every one else. Survive is fast and efficient. They have been around the Tampa bay area for a long time and  really know what they are doing and do a great job at it.

We like this place very much and try to make it a point to stop here whenever we can. The food is consistently excellent and a great value for the price,. The selections change from trip to trip. We recently had some pot roast here that was out of this world, along with delicious mashed potatoes.
Nice locally owned tackle store. They have been around a long time and know the local fishing scene. If you need some gear they will hook you up. The have a great selection of custom rods here.

I give it 3 stars. It is hard to park here. It gets over crowded, and they could do most things better. The saving grace is the location, right on the beautiful beach serving food and alcohol. So that redeems the place. I have stopped here many times and will continue to come back.

They sell some  high quality seating here. The company specializes in seating and they are really skilled at producing great products. The prices are higher than some other places, but the products are of higher quality.

Fort De Soto Park is 1136 acres of awesomeness on 5 little islands. There are tons of outdoor activities to do here. You can camp at the beautiful campground. There are more than 200 sites, many of them with beautiful waterfront views. There are multiple beaches here, one for dogs to enjoy. It is also a nice place to ride a bike or hike. There is a huge boat ramp here for boaters, and plenty of spots to fish from bridges, piers and the shore. You can also rent canoes or kayaks and follow a marked course. There are plenty of facilities and snack bars spread throughout the park.

They have many activities here at the fairgrounds. The parking is ample and access is fairly easy. There is plenty of space here for indoor and outdoor events. I have been to home shows, RV shows and a few other events here. They are always fun.

I agree with the other reviews. Like others I have eaten here over many years. It has always seemed that they are just going through the motions, never trying to excel. The food service and ambiance is always average to mediocre. It could be done much better.

I have stayed here quite a few times over the years. it has a convenient location, but  the rooms can be small, and you do get quite a bit of noise from the riverboats. I still like it, the courtyard is charming and the staff are helpful. You can often find great online discount prices for rooms here.

Love the Cajun music here. The bar itself is like many on Bourbon Street, but the music sets it apart. They do try to be unique with the drinks, Shark Attack, Horny Gator, Hand grenade, etc. We had fun here.

Honky Tonkin on 3 levels. You can go up or down until you find some band you like. The place gets packed just about any night of the week. You will see some awesome musicians in here, the local bar bands in Nashville are the most talented I have ever seen.
I like it on the off hours the best. When the crowds are smaller, this place is more enjoyable. When they get busy it is pretty much wall to wall college kids. That can be fun also, but not my scene.
This is a top notch place. We like to stop here when passing by for a delicious ice cream concoction. In fact, it is hard to drive by without stopping.

This cafe has really good food, We tried 3 of the rice bowls and loved them all. The bar features a big selection of high end whiskey. At night they become a club with a DJ and dance music. The sidewalk tables are a great place to hang out.
Great place for Pizza and beer. The Capogna family are the best. A Clearwater landmark. The place has been here forever and it is still a great place to go for a casual dinner.
This is not a great theater. The screens are not very large, the sound is marginal, and the seating is poorly laid out. We came here for the convenience of it, but can't give it a very high rating.
I bought a watch here. The price was great, as was the service I received from the staff. They have been in business here for many years.

I thought this was an OK museum. I know virtually nothing about country music so it was educational to me. The history is all pretty recent, but it is well represented here. The facility was very impressive. The bang for the 25 buck admission a little less so.

I like going here, mostly for the location. It is a nice old converted house, and the outside patio is a great spot to have a bite to eat and watch every thing going on outside. The food can be a bit hit or miss, but is usually decent. If I was rating on food alone I would say 2 stars, but the overall experience is 3 stars.

This is a super place to do business with. I had a small exhaust leak on one of my cars. It only required tightening a few bolts. They performed the service and would not accept any money. They are my go to place for exhaust work in the area.

I have always enjoyed this place. Nothing is out of this world, but it is mostly consistently pretty good. Some of my menu favorites are the chili releno, Chicken burrito and the carnitas. Service is usually fast and friendly. The prices are very reasonable.

We love the Capital Grille. I am glad it is a chain, I feel very comfortable eating at one when I am travelling, knowing I will be in for a night of outstanding food and service. We have eaten at this location more than any other. It is hard to not rate this place 5 stars, everything is done just about perfectly. I usually always get steak here, and it never disappoints. The wine selection is excellent, the atmosphere is outstanding, and the service is professional and unobtrusive.
A dive bar with an interesting drink menu. service can be slow and apathetic, but other than that I like it.

A very cool place for Christmas items. They have much more selection than you usually will see. Want to do your lights and ornaments all in one color? They have you covered. I like to stop in once a year.
The pulled pork was just OK, not special. The sides were very nice. I would say it rates 3 stars at most.
