We were somewhat disappointed with our meal here. Have they lost their way recently? The Gumbo of all things was bland, and lacking in the amount of seafood being in it. The shrimp creole was  just not good at all. The rest of the meal was fine, but overall this place was a let down.
The Long Center is a beautiful Rec center. The aquatics area is especially impressive. Adults and children can participate in all sorts of sports activities here.

Love Trader Joe's, hate the parking situation. They need a bigger lot, plain and simple. The problem is, there is no room to expand it. So this store will apparently have a permanent parking problem which makes it a bit of a nightmare to shop here. Much as I like the brand, I don't like coming to this store.
This place is kind of a dump. It is a nice place to stop and have a drink or two outside. I was not comfortable ordering any food here. It certainly does attract a diverse and interesting crowd.

They serve pretty decent southern Italian food here. I like the family style concept quite a bit. In addition it is lively and festive here. I have always had pasta as an entrée, and I always enjoy it.

I love the decor in Cheddars, It creates a welcoming ambiance when you dine here. The food is quite good also. I had the Key West Chicken and shrimp and enjoyed it quite a bit. The prices are very reasonable and our service was excellent.

Nice friendly dog loving folks at this pet salon. We feel really comfortable with them taking care of our pets. The salon has all kinds of great stuff inside. We had to buy the ultra cool harnesses they sell that glow in the dark, just couldn't resist them.

This is my favorite area flea market. It is very large, and you can easily spend a few hours here. There are vendors selling just about everything, food, plants, merchandise, sports equipment,  hot tubs, you name it.

Great store with great prices. They have an incredible selection of products. My downfall is when I go in here I tend to over shop and buy a bunch of stuff I don't need. But is hard to resist doing that when you are getting such good deals.
I ate here and thought is was OK. You can do much better than OK here in NOLA, so I would not be in a hurry to return.

The Croissants and pastries here are very good. You can dine in and get coffee or pick up the items to go, as we did. Lots of locals eat here and recommend it. They also have great assortment of cookies, tarts, cakes and other desert items, along with preparing crepes.

A very nice place to stay and visit New Orleans. You are in walking distance to the French Quarter. It seems to be a safe walk, you go right by the Police station on the way. We walked to the Quarter and back every day with no issues. The park is well set up and the sites are level, and paved. The facilities are nice here. They even have very good free coffee in the office, a big plus.

Oldsmar has dedicated lots of space to parks and they have some great ones. This place is just filled with recreational options. You can access the waterway here, play with your dogs and play all sorts of sports. We loved it here.

5 stars and just about perfect. We loved everything about this place, especially how steeped in tradition it is, while remaining quite dazzling on all levels. Service is impeccable and the food is outstanding. The current chef is doing an amazing job.  It is a bit hard to get reservations here as it is so popular, so book yours in advance.

This is a nice place to go for a Southern breakfast. We enjoyed it very much. We waited about 15 minutes to get a table on a Sunday morning. The coffee was very good and served right away, starting things off right. I had an omelet that was quite nice, and the biscuits and gravy, which I did not try looked very good as well. This place is very popular and crowded on weekends.

I love Trader Joe's. They have really good wine besides the 2 dollar bottles. They also stock a pretty good assortment of organics and gluten free items, all at great prices. I am happy that there is finally one in Florida that is in my occasional stomping grounds. I can't wait until we have one in my town of Orlando.

This is a rip off tourist trap. They charge about double the going rate for drinks. The place is filthy. My wife couldn't even use the bathroom here it was so nasty. The band was OK, too bad they have to work here. Don't waste your money here. One of the worst places on Bourbon Street.

They did a great job for me selling some furniture. They sent someone out to look at it, suggested some pricing that was agreeable, and took the furniture away. Within about 8 weeks, they had sold it all and sent me a check. I was very pleased with the transaction.
This is a greek pizza restaurant. i think they do the Greek food better than Italian, but not as good as Tarpon Springs restaurants.

Does Angry Chair have the most comfortable tap room in town where you want to sit for hours sampling the entire tap list? Nope. Are you guaranteed to find a wide variety of styles that will satisfy everyone in your party? Nope. Is parking plentiful and easy? Nope. Can you growler the more coveted varietals? Usually not.

So in spite of all this, what is the appeal? Simply put Angry Chair makes some of the best beers in the country. Whether you're looking for a mouth puckering sour or a dense pastry stout, Angry Chair can and does knock it out of the park. Producing some of the most flavorful and unique barrel-aged beers I've ever tried, Angry Chair sets the beer game bar high. Burkitshi, an Imperial Sweet stout with cacao, toasted coconut, and Japanese sea salt remains one of my penultimate favorites, rich and laden with flavor it reminds me of an Almond Joy. Another winner, Barrel Aged Popinski with Peanut Butter & Marshmallow tastes like a fluffernutter. A bottle we got lucky enough to enough to happen upon by pure happenstance, Bourbon Barrel Dave's Barleywine, had an excellent malt backbone and tasted like toffee.

The taproom itself is trendy and industrial, with cool metal bone seats that are more decorative than comfortable. Funky art scattered about, and of course the many references to "angry" chairs make for a laid back atmosphere. While by no means a spots bar, they do have a couple of televisions as well should you want to watch the game with a cold brew. Be warned though, the space itself isn't particularly large, so it may not be the best spot for a big group (although occasionally you can snag one of the coveted few more sizable tables).

While unfortunately I don't live close enough to synchronize my visits for every release, Angry Chair is my "must do" brewery every time I'm in Tampa, just in the hopes that I will strike the jackpot and pop in when they've just released something sinfully delicious. If it isn't already on your brewery bucket list make sure to put it near the top, Angry Chair produces the kind of stuff that both well seasoned beer geeks and novice drinkers will dream about.

A girl walks into a bar right as a band prepares to play, and goes to take a look at the drink menu. Vintage and seasonal cocktail options? Check. Interesting ingredients (like eucalyptus or Thai spice bitters)? Check. Then the music starts, upbeat and jazzy, and it feels fitting for the French Quarter. So she decides she should order a drink...

Quite some time later and I must admit, I was sold on 21st Amendment at La Louisiane. The drinks are solid, the atmosphere is lively without being raucous, and the music is exquisite. While it is a more intimate venue, seating routinely becomes available as the crowd ebbs and flows, making it a comfortable spot to hang out for a spell. 

Come with friends, come for a date, or come alone just to hang out at the bar, indulge in a cocktail, and enjoy the performance. 21st Amendment at La Louisiane offers a seductive scene with the winning ingredients to make a delightful night out in The Big Easy.

A small city unto itself, Gaylord Opryland is a sight to behold on par with some of the larger resorts in Las Vegas. A conference center and hotel, Gaylord Opryland offers ample walking paths, multiple restaurants, a river boat ride, a salon and spa, and now a water park as well. It is quite the labyrinth and is easy to get lost despite the signposts peppered throughout, although this often makes for the best exploration. While the hotel isn't located in the heart of downtown Nashville, it isn't a terribly far drive either.

Taking a stroll through the atriums is like being in a tropical oasis. There are multiple waterfalls, streams, and lush foliage. While I have no idea what any of it has to do with Nashville itself or its history, it is quite lovely. The strategically placed oversized guitars feel a bit out of place, and yet seem more authentic to the local flavor. Compared to Gaylord Palms in Orlando which actually has decor centered around Florida (Evergaldes, Key West, and Saint Augustine), I felt less of the connection to the city here. However, I can't deny that the hotel is still quite picturesque. Visit around Christmas, and the entire hotel is bedecked in holly and strings of twinkling lights as well.

Like any major hotel, Gaylord Opryland  comes with its pros and cons. The parking is high on my annoyance list, because although it is ample, it is pretty steep extra on top of the cost of your actual room. Whether you are a short term visitor, or a hotel guest, expect to pay around $32 a day. Also the restaurants are plentiful (think Italian, Mexican, sushi, and a grill), but none are particularly great. They do have Starbucks on premises if you are short on time, but walk or drive across the street to Nashville Coffees for a better selection and more interesting options.

If you are staying on business or at the hotel for a conference, the conference center is massive and quite convenient. There is more than enough space for an exhibition hall and smaller rooms for more intimate talks. WiFi is available throughout the area if you need to sneak away to get work done on your laptop. Speaking of the WiFi, you can also connect throughout the grounds or in the hotel rooms, and they have a direct wired connection if you need something faster, which makes a better choice if you need to connect to a VPN or are on a call.

The rooms themselves are comfortable, although certainly some sections are better than others. For example, a room in Magnolia may have you in a fairly basic look (your standard outdated hotel) and a view of a courtyard/pool, whereas in Delta the rooms seem to be a bit more modern, and if you're lucky you can get a view of one of the domed areas, which makes for great people watching.

Worth visiting at least once, even if you aren't a hotel guest! At the very least make a stunning venue to get some steps in...

Honey + water + yeast= mead

What seems simple enough, a historic combination standing the test of the centuries is still a popular beverage in modern times. However, Garagiste is not your average mazer, and the meads they produce are anything but ordinary. Well balanced Reboog Vitis is an elegant take on a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Other varietals include adjuncts ranging from vanilla beans to maple syrup to raspberries. If that weren't enough to entice, then they add barrel aged versions that add additional complexity from Madeira to Cognac.

Many of the meads take on almost a wine like quality, balancing honey laced sweetness with a biting acidity. For those unfamiliar with meads, or those just wanting to try more of their masterful libations, I highly suggest grabbing a flight. The menu is ever changing, and often includes limited offerings that may not be available otherwise. Each mead is quite distinctive and may range from fairly dry to on par with a Sauternes. They do offer some snacks as well, which can provide balance to an otherwise saccharine tasting.

Truly one of the best meaderies to be found, Garagiste is undoubtedly worth a visit when in Tampa. Even those that think they may not enjoy sweeter drinks may find themselves a convert.

Okay, I'll admit it. I may enjoy an art project here or there but I have zero woodworking (or power tool) experience. Zero. Zilch. Nonexistent. I am also pretty klutzy in general, so the idea of making anything using sharp objects vaguely terrifies me. That being said, the Florida School of Woodwork in Tampa is outstanding. A valuable resource for fledgling newbies (like myself) and for those who are more advanced.

I signed up for the cutting board course with my mother. Apart from both leaving with all our fingers and toes present and accounted for, we learned a lot and had fun too. Our instructor walked us through the entire process, and allowed us to flex our creative muscles (within the scope of the intended project). We glued, sanded, cut, and other far more technical terms I cannot pretend to recall. Even better, we left with two beautiful and functional cutting boards (complete with my own pyrography pen design) and a lot of great memories.

Book in advance for an afternoon, or even a weekend workshop, their classes are outstanding. Very well organized, and safe too. It is also a delight to work alongside instructors who are not only knowledgeable but truly passionate about their craft.

As St. Pete continues to develop and thrive, it is really nice to see the influx of some great bars and restaurants.  The Mill is one of my brunch go to places when in the area, offering some of the more innovative items I've encountered. 

First, you should know that they do not take reservations, so if you would like a table, I'd highly recommend arriving early.  The only tiny niggle in an otherwise perfect plan, is that you cannot order a cocktail in the city before a certain time, so although you may be guaranteed a seat, their delightful libations may be out of your reach.  I actually first tried some from this restaurant at a cocktail competition in Miami, and they definitely know their stuff. So for the drinks at least, you may want to make a return visit. 

As for the food, I typically struggle with what to order as the changing menu is filled with tantalizing dishes. Typically I end up sharing with the table so as to increase the number of options I can sample.  If they have it let me just say that the Vegetarian Crack cakes are sure to hook you whether or not you actually are a vegetarian.  A combination of zucchini and squash pancakes, topped with preserved lemon crema, guava onion butter and a sweet pea salad, they make me believe that I could give up meat and still be blissfully unaware of what I'm missing. Thankfully this item seems to be a menu constant.  Although the sweet options change too often to recommend a particular choice, I'd like to note that options like the banana bread french toast with rum raisin compote and coconut dulce are worth ruining your diet for. Although not every selection is total nirvana, you're more likely to find hits than misses, so be sure to give them additional chances if your first experience seems to be a bit lackluster.

Whether you are a local seeking for your regular breakfast place, or a visitor looking for a high caliber new choice, The Mill is undoubtedly the restaurant you want.

Wine bar meets restaurant, it sounds like a perfect match.  

After doing some research, I discovered that this is a Illinois based chain, where they produce their own wines, and then serve them in the restaurant as well.  If you want a table, I would recommend making reservations in advance, or just resigning to sitting at the bar.

 The wine tasting room is right at the entrance, and is definitely a lovely piece of tasting room eye candy. Style-wise it competes with any number of higher-end wineries.  Wine tastings are fairly inexpensive, and ranges from $7-$12.  They do seem to offer quite a broad range of wines, with an especially large number of sweet wines.  Personally, I decided to spring for the "Lux" flight and found almost none of them to my liking, but everyone has different preferences.  I don't think there is anything wrong with cheaper wine, and in fact, I believe there are many great wines that are relatively inexpensive.  That being said, there just wasn't much complexity, and there seemed to be unpleasant lingering aftertastes with many that I tried.  I also didn't appreciate that my entire tasting was a sales pitch for my server, during which time I was forced to endure endless droning about the perks. 

When I finally got around to dining, the menu seemed on par with your average chain.  They have a variety of options, and large portions.   The food is quite competent, and will definitely satisfy hunger.  Cooper's Hawk isn't organic, gastronomic, or tapas-style, so don't expect it to be.  Also, yes, they only serve their own wines, but this makes sense to me considering that is the whole point of the venture.  Additionally there are some cocktails if you really are not feeling wine.    

The pretzel bread that is served before the meal is a bit more interesting than the standard crusty Italian bread loaf.  It is a large soft, pillowy bun of pretzel dough, which can then be slathered with the slightly sweet butter.  Also, I did receive excellent service throughout my meal. 

Cooper's Hawk is not the place to come for wine experts, nor for a truly gourmet dining experience.  That being said, it is a fun girls night, or a unique venue to go with friends or on a date.

Commander's Palace is one of those spots so often raved about I felt I simply couldn't miss dinner here for an authentic and tasty New Orleans meal.  It's a nice excuse to get dressed up, and as they will remind you when you make a reservation, jackets are required for men.  The decor was charming and beautiful (although the many stuffed birds were a bit strange), and the service was without a doubt, completely stellar!  Our waiter was friendly, full of suggestions and quick without being overbearing.
       Despite the great company, staff and ambiance though, I have to admit that by the end of the meal I left a bit disappointed.  I know it's an institution and everyone loves it.  The food wasn't bad by any means, but over the multiple courses I just found myself leaving feeling like it was nothing special.
      The gumbo was warm and hearty, but I had better elsewhere while in New Orleans.  I had never tried turtle soup before, but I figured if I was going to this would be the place.  Maybe it was my lack of knowledge, but it seemed a bit bland, the sherry too overpowering, and it lacked much actual turtle.  The entrees were completely forgettable.  The best part of the meal (apart from the really great service) was the dessert.  The bananas foster wasn't the most amazing I could ever imagine, but it was a really fun tableside presentation and a nice palate-cleaning finish to the meal.  The bread pudding souffle was decent but again, nothing so epic I'd have to rush back.
         Perhaps my expectations were too high, but I really did have much better meals elsewhere while in New Orleans.  It wasn't a price thing, and I did have a good experience with everything but the actual cuisine.  I wanted to leave in a food-coma induced euphoria with lasting memories of a magic meal that opened me up to all that the city had to offer.  This is a great way to get to try lots of traditional dishes, but don't expect to necessarily be blown away with incredible execution or taste.

Oh Cigar City. You lured me in with your beers and special releases at Hunahpu Day, tempted me with rotating taps in your cider and meadery, and now, a brewpub? You're on fire.

Reservations can be made online, although there is seating at the bar if you can snag a spot as well. While the brewpub does offer some of Cigar City's brewery beers, they also have a selection of their own unique beers as well. Not only can you drink a cold brew there, but you can also fill a growler to take home later. In addition to the standard Cigar City fan memorabilia, you may also be able to snag a bottle of something special (read "rare") from the fridge on your way out.

Not really in the mood for beer? No problem, they have wine and cocktails as well. You can even combine the two with their beer cocktails. 

Feeling hungry? The food menu is quite varied, with some Latin-flair and plantains thrown in for good measure. Burgers are offered a couple of ways, or you can chart your own destiny and choose the toppings. The Cuban (Ham, mojo pork, Fiorucci salami, Swiss, mustard) is a great version of the classic sandwich, and the upgrade to yucca fries with aioli is well worth it. The Chicken Saltimbocca delivers grilled chicken breast wrapped in prosciutto, fresh sage and smoked gouda, served over a wild mushroom risotto with a choice of vegetable. I thoroughly appreciated the addition of the sage, and the creaminess of the risotto. They also made a very tender Ropa Vieja (a slow stewed flank steak with peppers, onions, and tomatoes served over black beans and rice, with sweet plantains). For dessert, Hunahpu's Imperial Flourless Chocolate Cake is quite dense, but the acidity of the berries cuts through some of the richness nicely. I wouldn't say all the dishes are the best I've ever had, but they are solidly enjoyable and better than your typically bar fare.

The venue is very laid back, with a cool use of Cigar City beer cans and barrels turned into lighting fixtures. Definitely a cool place to grab a bite with friends while watching a game, and I'm sure we will be back to see what other bottles they've got stashed in that fridge for sale.

I couldn't have been more excited to stumble upon this darling wonderland on our humid explorative trek around Nashville.

I felt like we were experiencing a sliver of San Francisco at Kellie's healthy delectable oasis. I especially appreciated all of the gluten free options on her menu. I don't have a gluten allergy, but i always find myself having an easier time digesting things, when things happen to be gluten free.

Our first meal here we had the  Mediterranean Vegetarian Sandwich (sans feta cheese) on fresh Gluten free bread - consisting of eggplant, roasted red pepper, sun dried tomato, and freshly made pesto, and the Spinach Salad (sans feta cheese) consisting of spinach, dried cranberries, sliced almonds & balsamic vinaigrette. Kellie even went out of her way to replace the feta cheese with some additional vegetables like tomatoes and cucumbers. Both were excellent, reasonably priced at $6.00-$7.00 and you could taste the love embedded in each. We washed down both with A Matter of Taste's cold refreshing fruit tea.

We were so impressed with our experience at A Matter of Taste that we decided to venture out here again the following day. We decided to try their regularly rotating lunch specials. We went with the Pumpkin Brittle and Watermelon adorned salad, as well as their Fish Tacos. The salad was outstanding. A Matter of Taste makes their own salad dressing and you could tell. The fish tacos were also very flavorful. 

A Matter of Taste's eating area is intimate, but if you take a look in the back you can see their sprawling immaculate kitchen where all of the magic happens.

If you're looking for quality and healthy food for reasonable prices - A Matter of Taste is outstanding. I recommend them wholeheartedly. My only regret is not sampling one of their gluten free desserts - ranging from moist looking cupcakes to large rockin' cookies.

Trust.

Bliss.

Absolute bliss.

Thanks to Katie B's gushing recommendation - we joined her, Farrah A, and Tomas R at Bacchanal for the most delightful afternoon - full of chilled rosé, stunning cheese plates, and beautiful music. 

Sitting in the comforts of the shade beneath elegant overhanging trees - while beaming faces - enjoyed the enclosed oasis of fantastic wine and wonderful company - I felt abundantly thankful.

Bacchanal is worth the Uber ride. It's non-pretentious, full of great vibes, and it's always graced by lulling live music.

I recommend coming on the earlier side- since I've heard it does get busier later on in the early evening. But definitely don't sleep on this New Orleans gem. You could easily spend all day here.

Trust.

It was late. We were headed back to our hotel, when my husband spied some people devouring pizza slices. Our hotel plans were momentarily dashed - as we embarked on a new mission to hunt down after-hours pizza. We chased down some at Outlaw Pizza. We showed up just in time to buy their last slice.

My husband said the pizza was solid - in between taking big bites of his pepperoni slice, as we headed back to the hotel. Just then -we heard someone running up behind us. It was the gentleman from Outlaw Pizza who had sold us his last slice. He had run all the way from Outlaw Pizza to give my husband back his forgotten credit card.

Thank you Outlaw Pizza for saving the night - when it came to greasy evening sustenance and for allowing us to make future late night purchases for the rest of our stay in New Orleans.

Trust.

We'd heard from a number of in-the-know locals that The Bluebird was a sure thing for an intimate encounter with great musicians. 

On one of our last nights in the city we took a pricey cab out here for their open mic night. 

We were advised on the phone to arrive early, due to the intimate size of The Bluebird. Walking in around 6pm - we grabbed a table, just as two guitarists finished their set.

The whole place was full, so we were lucky to snag some seating. A waitress quickly came by to take our order. We ordered some sweet potato fries, the blackened sandwich and the chicken sandwich. The catfish sandwich was great. Spicy and bursting with taste.

The Bluebird Cafe is a big deal in Nashville. If you have the opportunity to play here - you savor it. All of the performers were so genuinely honored to be playing at such a love filled spot, in which people give their full attention to those playing. Everyone around the room appreciated the talent that glided around the room in smooth chords and octaves. 

While we had a great time here, I wasn't always fond of some of the more new-country ballads that were performed during the night, and preferred more of the closing soulful country stuff. I would definitely love to come here again, but would maybe try to go on a different night other than the open mic. A good time, but sometimes it's nice to know what kind of music to expect when you make a night of it.

Trust.

Desperate to bounce out of Bonabooooooo on our epic Tennessee adventure we scanned Yelp fervently on my dying Iphone for a hotel room.

With no battery and only seconds to spare - Club Hotel Inn came up on my phone screen and I just dialed. Their room rates were reasonable considering the busy week that we were inquiring about (CMA awards, Fanfare, as well as Bonnaroo all happening around the same time) and they had a room available that night.

We booked it. And then my phone died.

With no expectations -  we rolled up to Club Hotel in a dusty cab. Despite sporting unwashed clothes and hair, the staff were exceptionally friendly. We were led to spacious room with a comfortable bed, comfortable couch, big screen TV, a mini fridge, a microwave, and some standard toiletries. 

The first thing we did was shower. After washing off all of the Bonnaroo yuck - we began to explore the place. Club Hotel Inn not only has a convenient work-out area, but it also has a great outdoor pool area. Our second night there - we asked for a room with a balcony and were able to perch ourselves on it, read, and overlook the pool. So relaxing and such an exhilarating feeling after grueling Bonnaroo. 

Some of the exciting perks about Club-Hotel were their mini fridge and microwave, which allowed us grab some groceries and make some make-shift lunches for ourselves, their on-site laundry facilities - which allowed us to bring back clean smelling clothes for our journey home, the complimentary shuttle which took us back to the airport, and their complimentary wowing breakfast spread.

Each morning we would tiredly drag ourselves downstairs to indulge in a breakfast display that made our hearts beam. With a waffle maker on hand, hot eggs, sausages, homefries, cereal, muffins, bagels, fruit and more - we would go to town every morning - fueling ourselves up for mid-day pool lounging. Definitely key for those on a tight budget.

The only drawback for this place was the location. It's convenient if you want a spot near the airport - but if you want to go downtown - expect to pay about 25 dollars for a cab ride over there. Other than that - it was perfect for our needs and a much needed break before we headed back to SF.

Trust.

I felt so fancy in my silk dress and perched upon Virago's bar stool. 

Virago's interior design is jaw-droppingly sexy. From smooth-soft-to-the- touch wood accents. Sleek bamboo tables, low lounge-y booths, to come hither lighting. Their newly added bar rooftop - is just as stunning as the evening Nashville view from it. 

It was our first night of vacation, and we were with folks who knew Virago's menu well - and so we went big.

We ordered:

1.) PISTACHIO HAMACHI 
crushed pistachio, maldon sea salt, serrano, yuzu, unfiltered olive oil

2. V2 EDAMAME 
wok-charred, togarashi, sweet soy

3.) CRAB AND SHRIMP DUMPLINGS 
carrot-ginger sauce

4.) BLACKENED AHI 
sushi-grade tuna, mango vinaigrette

5.) BIG ISLAND HEARTS OF PALM 
spiced Marcona almonds, strawberry papaya, mojito vinaigrette

6.) RISING SUN 
crab, salmon, shrimp, tempura crunch and spicy mayo rolled without rice, tempura-battered and fried, topped with pepper tobiko and honey fire sauce

7.) EQUADOR 
tuna, hamachi, cilantro, cucumber, avocado, chives, jalapeño, masago, tempura crumbs, wasabi mayo, sesame seeds and sriracha

The Blackened Ahi, the Rising Sun, and the Crab and Shrimp Dumplings were the standouts for us. Each melted in our mouth with pronounced flavor. The Edamame was also excellent - spicy and sweet and the perfect way to start our dramatic feast of quality sushi.

Our meal at Virago was a tremendous was to start our blossoming Nashville adventure. If you're in the area and looking for a swank spot for the night - be sure to make reservations at Virago. 

My only advice is to ask the server for recommendations  - since some of our ordering items, though tasty, didn't wow us - as much as others. I would also recommend trying to check out Virago during the weekdays, since like all hot-spots - the weekends are the busiest. Also, while it's often suggested to sit at the bar at sushi spots, I would suggest holding out for a table. Our server - was traditionally a bartender at the space, and though he was friendly enough, he didn't seem as well versed in the menu as he could have been.

Trust.

The impressive array of diverse flat-breads, convenient outdoor seating, and massive interior here - should be enough reason to check out Urban Flats Flatbread.

Urban Flats carries everything from spicy Thai flat-bread to lobster mac and cheese and a wealth of other colorful dishes as well. 

If you have a big group - Urban Flats is ideal. They have a wealth of big tables and their menu is big enough to accommodate all particular food fancies.

I just wish that I'd stuck with the straightforward sure thing items such as hummus and the veggie flat-breads, instead of feeling adventurous and ordering the salmon. My bf looked at me hard and even politely challenged my order. 

"Are you sure you want to order fish? Ya do know that Tennessee is land-locked."

But I was not to be swayed.

He was  - of course-  right. My salmon was dry, lacked pronounced flavor and was dwarfed by a strong tasting mustard sauce. Fail. That being said  - his Spicy Thai Flat-bread was quite good, and the chocolate lava cake we had to finish our meal - was decent.

Sitting outside on our last evening in the city - we wished we'd been more adventurous with our final Nashville meal, but the warm friendly service and the easy walk to busy-tourist-filled Broadway for some live music was worth it.

Trust.

My husband lived off of the frozen Irish Coffees here - during our New Orleans stay. While I didn't partake myself -  I always enjoyed the walking adventure of getting to this quaint bar.

Molly's At the Market is perfect for reviving the tired, hot and thirsty on a busy New Orleans day. The staff are always quick and welcoming, their customers are always laid back, their bathrooms are clean, and their frozen Irish Coffees are beyond dreamy.

Like others have recommended - if you stop in here - for a frozen Irish Coffee - get the large. Just do it. Everybody that we took here during our stay - was so thankful for their caffeinated treat - and it proved to be a perfect sustenance pick-me-up for strolling through the humid New Orleans streets.

Trust.

My small circle of good friends venture onwards to our second New Jersey vineyard tour at Hopewell Valley Vineyards, which surely brings life from "From Crisis to Triumph" Exodus (13:17-14:31). 

There are ample outdoor seating with shades under large umbrellas where my small party of four enjoyed our meal with Brie cheese and other munchies. With excellent company in the presence of good friends we had the pleasure of Hopewell's wine barrel tour which is included in the $6.00 tasting. This same $6.00 tasting enables wine connoisseurs to go further with their dollar especially in today's ailing economy of "permanent decline" noted by Huffington Post to keep their tasting glasses. Staff fully exercise their wine knowledge and visibly hone their interpersonal skills to demonstrate quality customer service. 

Personally, I enjoyed the Sangiovese 2008 for it harness a nice fruity and light acidic flair without overpowering too citrus. The Vidal Blanc was very enjoyable to be sweet for the light and very airy crisp. My favorite was the Spuma Rossa Red Sparkling Wine which makes a delightfully seductive sweet dessert for two of a happy ending to close the night. The tasting menu is fully detailed with notes, wine names with corresponding year thus there are no secrets as Hopewell is very upfront and direct. 

Hopewell Valley Vineyards ensures the world there is HOPE!

This review is based entirely on the toll free customer service.  After waiting an eternal ten minutes of being on hold to be finally connected in speaking to a human being, the representative repeated to same questions three times. All I wanted was to be demoved from their mailing list of endless catalogs in the mail. Is it so difficult to be removed against my will?

Beautiful park in South Philadelphia known to South Philadelphians as "The Lakes" (originally named League Island Park and now locally known as the "Lakes"). 

The park's gazebo, lagoon, and creek are an oasis built by Olmsted Brothers, the firm of Frederick Law Olmsted and John Charles Olmsted in the early 1900s (same park designers as the renowned New York's Central Park). Franklin Delano Roosevelt Park was reclaimed mostly from marshlands.  My closest and sincere friends came to Philly in persuit of a day retreat away to celebrate my birthday differently outside the active yet abrasive hustle and bustle of New York City.  Franklin Delano Roosevelt Park replinish my sweetness lost enable me to retreat calmingly to renew my spirit.

Nearby located under Interstate 95 is FDR Skatepark which once played host to the Gravity Games 2005.  An excellant skate park with many ramp, vert ramp and wall of concrete known as a challenge for skaters, roller bladders of all levels from beginners to advanced to professional.  FDR Skatepark sits directly under Interstate 95 overpass thus protected from rain and snow in the winter months.  While I'm not the outdoors type of gal, my two close friends walked by as observers which I noted all athletics are not wearing any helmets or head gear.  In New York State skaters, roller bladders, et al are required by law to wear helmets sadly today's volatility world can damage goods.  Wishful thinking... why are there no protective gear for the heart in preventing it to be broken to become one man's vile trash and damage goods?!?

Warning:  Public restrooms are nastily vile as there are no locks on the stall's doors and no hooks to hold personal belongings.  There is no tiolet tissue holder attached to the wall either.

http://www.fairmountpark.org/fdrpark.asp

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franklin_Delano_Roosevelt_Park

In my past life of adult times I bought a "First Christmas Together" Christmas ornament in honor of a special year.  

Lenox is traditional yet classic home decor and housewares.  I rate Lenox Corporation four stars due to lack of designs for "First Christmas Together" ornaments.
Seriously. The. *** BEST *** flavors, service, ambiance, & curb appeal!! Best, best, best!!! Such a favorite!!!!

Sucks. Sucks. Sucks. 

SMALL. SMOKEY. DIRTY. SCUM BAG. GROSS. 

After visiting Vegas, Mohegan Sun, Pechanga, & other International casino's, this pathetic Tampa location should have it's tail between it's legs. 

It's filthy. Literally dust and grime wherever you sit or stand....Dirty carpets...FILTHY bathrooms...ALL bathrooms...FILTHY...

No COMPS...No free cocktails as you play, no complementary players club buffet or discounted rooms compared to the other casinos. 

Not to mention the huge ATM & Valet fees. 

YUCK! Wish there was a negative star scale! 

Get your act together Seminole!
Great Hotel, best in Nashville hands down considering options. Not a 5 Star, but nice. Boutique hotel, on point concierge, 1.5 miles from downtown.

Great Amphitheatre. Very organized parking & exit for large event. 

There really doesn't seem to be a bad seat in the house. 

Great acoustics. 

Perfect location right next to Interstate. 

(but....stupid new name! "1-800-Ask-Gary" c'mon! We see him enough on the commercials!)

A perfect location, ambiance, comfort, welcoming & charm! 

Kimpton never disappoints! 

(Dog friendly too!)

5 star view. Exceptional service. 

But the food? Eh, I'm begging to think yelp has 4 stars based on a popularity vote. The flavors & quality were just ok. Nothing to write home about.

SO GREAT! 

Love the river view, fantastic lobby, comfortable & large rooms, fantastic service, exceptional restaurants, great location! 

(Only downer, $14.95 a day for WIFI)

I wasn't feeling well... and if I had my choice it would have been a matzo ball soup type of night. Or I may have just skipped dinner and gone straight to bed, but felt like I needed to eat something while pregnant. 

My colleague and I opted for dinner at Wildflower Grill, conveniently located within the Matrix Hotel we were staying at. We made our way downstairs and were seated immediately (no reservations necessary on a Tues night).  

By no fault of Wildflower Grill, but thanks to my stuffed up nose, there wasn't much on the menu that sounded appealing, but I finally settled on a caesar salad. And of course I couldn't pass up on ordering the bread appetizer that so many yelpers raved about.  Both hit the spot, especially the very warm bread that practically melted in my mouth.

I'm sure there's even better food on the menu that my bread and salad, but I"ll have to wait until my next trip to Edmonton when hopefully I'm feeling 100%.

Thank you Comcast Wall for keeping us entertained for 3 hrs while working the check-in table at the fabulous Yelp Spring Feastival. Fortunately, the Philadelphia yelpers are one cool bunch so getting bored wasn't a problem, but when have to sit at a table for 3 hrs staring at a wall of a building it's pretty awesome if there's a show occurring right on that wall.

This is one cool wall! You'd think I'd be sick of watching it after 3 hrs, but not so much the case (maybe just a bit dizzy).  I do still question the tourists I watched stare at the wall for several hrs at a time. Yes, it was a rainy day in Philly, but surely there's cooler stuff to do than spend a day staring at a wall even as awesome as this one.

Traveling with a bad cold is not fun...I was totally that person full of germs that I typically avoid on planes. Fortunately once I arrived in Edmonton (after passing my germs to everyone on the plane) the Matrix Hotel provided me with a clean spacious room and a comfortable bed so I could get a little bit of rest during my short trip.

Overall, I liked this hotel and wouldn't definitely stay here again. My colleague and I were in town to do interviews and they have a nice lounge upstairs that was the perfect spot for them (and it helped that it was empty too). 

It's also centrally located near lots of restaurants, shops and more...so there's no need to rent a car in what I believe is typically a driving city.

The restaurant downstairs was also solid if you happen to visit during one of Edmonton's infamous cold winters.

It's your typical country bar, but considering I never go to country bars in Chicago I thought it was great! My friend had her rehearsal dinner here and it was a blast. A low key atmosphere, BBQ food that didn't do much for me (but my fiance and others seemed happy), and most importantly fabulous service (I had a drink in my hand at all times).

So apparently I visited Posh on the wrong day because there were not $9 suede boots like the ones Caitlin D snagged...lucky gal.  I didn't happen to snag any shoes, but that's  probably because I didn't save any room in my suitcase for yet another pair of shoes...even shoes as cool and funky as the ones at Posh.  If I ever do make it back to Nashville I'll be sure to save some room in the suitcase for a stop at Posh!

I was about to give up on Tampa after a few visits to Ybor City. No offense to the locals, but that street is Austin's Sixth Street Gone Wrong.  Then I discovered the lovely Harbour Island area and realized that I just haven't experienced the good parts of Tampa. Phew!

We found ourselves at Jackons's for dinner in Harbour Island, which was conveniently located behind The Westin my in-laws were staying at.  There's a little something for everyone on this menu: burgers, salads, and even sushi for raw fish addicts like myself.  I'm usually a bit suspicious of sushi from nontraditional sushi restaurants, but the yelpers raved about it so figured I couldn't go wrong.  And the yelpers were right (as usual)!  I truly enjoyed all of the fresh sashimi and crab roll that came with the Jackson Sushi Dinner.  Everything else seemed to be a hit at our table as well!

I hear this place also turns into a club late night. Clubbing isn't quite my thing these days, but I'd definitely come back for more sushi and other good eats.

I'm not typically a fan of Marriott Courtyards, but when I needed a hotel at the last minute due to attending a funeral anything would do. I noticed this Courtyard happened to be attached to the country club where they were holding a celebration of life following mass...and so I booked it! $200/night seemed a bit expensive for a Courtyard in the Philly burbs, but you can't put a price on convenience.

Overall, the hotel was fine. The staff was friendly enough, the room was comfortable enough and even spacious enough for 2 since my colleague and I opted to share a room. We weren't in the hotel very long, but got a bit of sleep, a quck workout in the adequate hotel gym and a coffee downstairs. There's a restaurant attached to the hotel as well, but we weren't there long enough for a meal.

If visiting Philly for fun I"d opt to stay downtown. If I had to be in the Springfield area again I probalby would look for other options, but this was A-Ok for what I needed.

My day trip to Nashville meant I didn't have to spend too much time away from the fam (yay), but it also meant I didn't get to explore much of Nashville (boo). I spent the entire day in the lovely Hutton Hotel and visited this onsite restaurant not once, but twice.  Yep, that's twice..once for lunch and once for dinner.  

I'm typically wary of hotel restaurants, but have to admit this one was pretty good. During a working lunch our party of 10 enjoyed their private room, which even had a TV that we were able to use for a presentation.  I started my meal with the corn gazpacho (eh) and then followed it up with the flat bread (yum). And my colleague was sweet enough to share her fries that came with my burger.

When I stopped back in later that night for dinner I decided to get my own fries and burger. I'm usually not a burger type of girl, but this one was so good!

The lunch service was a little on the slow side, but they were on their game during dinnertime, which allowed me plenty of time to get to the airport and head back to the fam.

I first dined here 15 years and it was easily the most delish meal of my lifetime. Then again, my standards weren't quite as high when I was 22, but it was tasty. Really tasty.

When I arrived back in NOLA 5 years later I planned on having a few less hurricanes, but did plan on going back to Emeril's.  Not sure if the quality had gone down or my standards had gone up, but it was just A-OK. 

And I went back again this past weekend after 10 years this time with 20+ friends in tow to celebrate a friend's 40th bday. I was hopeful it would live up to the initial 2002 hype, but the overall experience was more A-OK 2007.

I was starving so ate every last bite of food, but was almost annoyed to be wasting calories on mediocre food (besides the 6 pieces of delicious bread that I couldn't help but devour after a long travel day). As for the rest of the meal:
Crab cake: 3 stars
Mushroom pasta: 1 star 
Salad: 2 stars
Salmon: 3 stars
peanut butter pie: 4 stars (next time i'll be ordering JUST wine and peanut butter pie)

While serving a group of 20+ women who have had too much wine is no picnic, it was painfully slow...and we were receiving our yummy peanut butter pie when my friends at the table next to me where just getting their entrees.  Thank goodness I had good wine & even better company so it was still a memorable evening.

Not quite a country music fan (although I should be after 3 days in Nashville!), but have to say I enjoyed myself at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum.

Warning- they charge $20 to get in (slightly less for students and triple A members), which I thought was quite expensive, but I guess Nashville has to make their $$$ somehow!  

Many of the exhibits were pretty cool, but I didn't look at anything in too much detail because I was busy chatting away with my 2 friends and was having trouble multi tasking. 

And I probably should be embarrassed to admit that we spent more time in the gift shop of the Museum than looking at the exhibits....but if you're looking for a cowboy hat or anything else country related this is the place to get it!

Stayed here, as well as attended a friend's wedding, here this weekend. The wedding rate was $149/night and for that this is a 4 star hotel, but the usual rate is over $250 so in that case it's probably more like a 3 star hotel.

The good:
- Nice sized rooms with a separate living room area
- Comfortable beds
- A huge bathroom to primp myself for the wedding
- Right in the middle of downtown Nashville, as well as across from the country music museum
- Plenty of cabs always available even though Nashville isn't actually a cab friendly city
- elevators that move at lightning speed
- $13 breakfast buffet that I didn't try myself, but my fiance has mentioned what a great deal it was at least 10 times (it's the little things in life that excite him)

The bad
- unimpressive workout room
- pretty gross indoor pool that you couldn't pay me to step foot in
- they need to learn how to make a latte...I could hardly drink the one they made for me downstairs

For those of you looking to plan a special event in Nashville I"d also recommend the grand ballroom- my friend had a beautiful wedding here last night! It's a simple, yet elegant ballroom...the type where any decorations will work.  

Would I return to the Hilton during my next trip to Nashville (if there ever is another trip to Nashville)? Yes, probably...but it would depend on the price. I would be happy staying here for under $200, but over that I'd seek shelter elsewhere.

After waiting FOREVER for my iced latte I was expecting the best beverage ever, but it turned out to taste quite disgusting and I opted not to waste my one caffeinated drink of the day on such a drink.  Even Starbucks can do way better than this! I would have been happier at a SB, but my colleague and I had booked a few meetings at Transcend Coffee and were camped out for a few hours. 

I found myself waiting in another long line there just hours later when I got hungry, but wasn't impressed with any of their food options. I chose a muffin, ate a few bites and decided to hold out for lunch at MRKT.

I had already eaten an early dinner, but when colleagues suggested late night sushi I wasn't going to pass up raw fish. I have to admit I was skeptical of finding really good sushi in Nashville, but I was proved wrong. 

We called while on the way and were told there was a 15 min wait on a Thursday evening at 9pm. But then when we arrived literally 2 min later we spotted at least 10 open tables and were seated immediately. Perhaps pretending to have a wait makes them seem more popular? 

Sam, our fab waiter, helped us make the perfect choices for the 2 of us (myself included) who eat anything related to sushi and our other 2 colleagues who are vegan. 

We started with the crispy rice app, which I can't ever pass up when I see it on a menu. So good. And from there ordered 2 rolls. Both were fantastic. I'm blanking on one of the names, but would never forget the tasty kuro scallop roll.  And we could get enough of the crispy Brussels sprouts. I may even be able to get my "I don't touch vegetables" 3 yr old to eat these. 

I left so full (2 dinners will do that to you) and so impressed with Nashville's sushi scene.

3.50 stars.  

Gabby's wasn't open.  I knew that.  Neither was Rotier's.  But my handy Yelp app had assured me that Fido's was open.  Imagine the disappointment when I realized there was a very real possibility that no burgers would happen on this trip down to the Deep South.  Would I really have to wait two more weeks when I would find solace in East Texas?   

"We can try Burger up," I mentioned.  

"Why don't you just call them?" hissed the appropriately nicknamed Viper.  

True.  We didn't have to keep driving around aimlessly.  So I call Burger Up, and a very pleasant, sweet voice assures me they are indeed open.  

Viper: "What was her name?  She sounded hot."
  
Me: "Paige."

Viper: "Yeah, she's definitely hot.  Have you ever met an unattractive Paige?"

Me: "Good point.  At least we have that going for us."

Paige was indeed attractive, but this review isn't about a photogenic individual who happens to work at Burger Up.  It's about what ended up being a visit to our fourth choice for burgers in Nashville.  

Burger Up follows a national trend towards upscale burgers.  My particular order consisted of a medium rare patty served with aged cheddar, Benton's bacon (very good), and ketchup served on an artisan bun.  Basically, it was a gussied up bacon cheeseburger, but it was a rather tasty one.  My major complaint is that I wish the actual meat itself exhibited more flavor.  Having said that, the burger was cooked properly and the flavors worked well together.  I ordered some wilted spinach on the side (mediocre) and truffle fries.  Let's talk about those truffle fries for a bit.  I know more people are apparently into the sweet potato fries here, but I think they are missing the boat.  Burger Up's truffle tries have pleasant aroma, taste great, and are the perfect texture for soaking up oil.  If you are on a diet, it is true you should skip these delightful fries.  But if that were the case, why are you at a burger joint in the first place?  Seriously, if you get nothing else out of my review, please do yourself a favor and order the truffle fries.  

Burger Up also boast an interesting beer menu with semi-obscure breweries from the Deep South included in the list.  I tried a pecan-infused amber from Mississippi - not bad.  I could imagine Burger Up could be a decent place to drink for a bit after eating.  

If I attended Vanderbilt, I would probably go here on a moderately frequent basis.  If you want a change from the dive bar hamburger, Burger Up is a decent change of pace.

3.50 stars.  I was told to go here for the shrimp and grillades (grits) and fried chicken, but I ended up loving the gumbo more than anything.  Located in Mid-City, Li'l Dizzy's is a cozy diner serving up an all you can eat breakfast/lunch consisting of fried chicken, trout, shrimp creole, rice & beans, grits, gumbo, omelettes made to order, fruit, and maybe a few other items as well.  It was all pretty standard until I reached the gumbo.  

Li'l Dizzy's gumbo is heavenly.  They don't hold back on either the sausage or the seafood as you have generous cuts of andouille sausage and crab legs in the wonderfully thick dark brown soup.  They got the flavor so perfect I felt no need to add any tabasco to my order.  I'd definitely come back here for the gumbo.  

Overall, you have plenty of options for breakfast/lunch in this city, and Li'l Dizzy's is a good one if you are in Mid-City.  It's a great option if you just want a cup of gumbo.

THIS PLACE IS AMAZING!!!!!   I grew up two hours from this place, and it was my favorite restaurant within reasonable driving distance of my house.  If I was limited to giving five "five star" ratings for restaurants nationally, Jacques-Imo's Cafe would certainly be in the discussion.  Simply one of the best places in the entire country to eat Cajun Food (like every other poster on here, I'm going to tell you to try the shrimp and alligator cheesecake).  If you can pick only one place to eat in New Orleans, this should be it (Arnaud's and K-Paul's are also great selections for the uninitiated).

I'm in love with the "hot chicken" concept, and I hope it goes national.  Nashville's unique contribution to Southern cooking entails the preparation of fried chicken basted in a fiery combination of peppers and spices that absolutely will send you running to the closest fire hydrant to squelch the burning sensation where your lips and tongue once resided.  Mr. Bolton will make you hot chicken from almost any part of the bird, and he will even do it with chicken tenders should you choose (which comes with the welcome addition of ranch sauce to alleviate some of the heat).  I opted for wings and a call to the fire department.  

Aside from the heat, it should be mentioned that Bolton's approach favors flavor.  The wings themselves were fried perfectly and reminded me why I frequently hold my head in only mildly feigned agony when eating "Southern food" in places like my current hometown of Washington DC.  The green beans at Bolton's, flavored liberally with bacon, were so impressive that I ended up ordering green beans at nearly every single restaurant and dive that I visited in Nashville.  I assumed it was a Nashville thing; I was wrong -- it is a Bolton's thing.  Maybe some pseudo-celebrity chef should visit Bolton's and say it was the best thing (s)he ever had; it certainly was the case for me when it comes to green beans.  The mac-n-cheese is also very nice with heavy use of white cheddar and liberal amounts of black pepper.  If you like a "bready" mac-n-cheese, this is probably not your style.  I thought it was delicious.  

Mr. Bolton himself was an appreciate and friendly man who probably should have been annoyed that two rather inebriated individuals were awkwardly ordering (ex. me: what's the one that is hot chicken?  Bolton: i can make any of them hot chicken?  me: ok, i'm confused now) but he helped us out anyhow.  I know Nashville loves this business, but if I ever find out how to teleport people, Mr. Bolton is coming to Washington DC.  But at least you got my lack of an advanced degree in any engineering on your side.  Outside of a moment of idiot savant-like genius on my part, you are probably safe.  

Finally, although it rarely happens, there are a few somewhat misguided reviews that lament that the chicken wasn't spicy enough when they ordered MILD or make similarly obvious patently illogical complaints.  There is a saying that the inability to appreciate the Mona Lisa speaks more about the criticizers than the actual work.  I feel the same way about the plebeian fools that dare to defile a culinary gift from the Gods (or, in this case, a gift from the able hands of Mr. Bolton and his staff).  Bolton's is divine and is a foodie must for anyone visiting Nashville.  Unless you are vegetarian or hate chicken, to visit Nashville and not try hot chicken from Bolton's is about as despicable as going to Vanderbilt and cheering for the University of Tennessee.  It simply should not happen under any circumstances.  As for locals, if you haven't been here, then I would highly recommend that you support this culinary gem of a local business.

While I will readily admit that gelato isn't exactly my first love, I can still appreciate the obvious work that goes into the preparation of the creations at Capogiro.  First and foremost, like Jeff W. and Michelle P. point out in their respective reviews, the actual substance is unparalleled within the frozen dairy industry (even surpassing the treats at DC's beloved Dairy Godmother) and the consistency in unmatched as well.  Second, the breadth of flavors is impressive.  While I was enjoying a more traditional Bacio, some of my dining companions were getting gelato spiked with all sorts of Thai spices and exotic fruits.  I commend Capogiro for providing both options.  Third, the price point is correct.  While spending $4-7 certainly may seem expensive for gelato, the generosity of the serving size is beyond reasonable debate.   Finally, I thought the individuals working the counter were quite patient with our group (which consisted of both grizzled Capogiro veterans and first time visitors).  The bottom line is that gelato is rarely a destination point; this is one of those rare spots that bends all your existing paradigms and rewrites them in an entirely positive fashion.  If you are in Philadelphia, it's worth a visit.

3.25 stars.  I always think of those old Road Runner/Wiley Coyote when I see the word "ACME" so I was rather hesitant based on simple nomenclature when we happened upon this branch of the famous New Orleans eatery.  In fairness, I eschewed the local specialty (the charbroiled oysters) in favor of fried oysters and seafood gumbo.  The fried oysters were quite good; the light, flavorful, and slightly spicy coating taking precious little flavor away from each underlying oyster.  The seafood gumbo was likewise a solid offering combining generous portions of backfin crab meat and shrimp with a satisfying roux.  I would have loved jumbo crab meat or plump shrimp especially at this price point, but the food was undeniably tasty.  Overall, I wouldn't call this destination cuisine, but then again, I haven't tried the charbroiled oysters.

4.25 stars.  Yes, it's absolutely touristy.  Yes, the trashy shitshow that is Bourbon Street spills off of the street and directly into this venue on a regular basis.  But if there is a better karaoke experience than Cat's Meow anywhere in the country, I've yet to see it.   

Now I've seen some people complain about the drinks here but Cat's Meow knows its audience.  Namely, the idea of serving drinks in glass is simply a terrible idea when you have patrons so obviously beyond their usual limits.  To wit, by the time we reached the second floor to take a Roman Colosseum view of the events below, two girls from a bachelorette party - one the bride and another an aging bleached blonde with a silicone chest - were fighting for crowd attention and eventually each other (silicone kicked the bride on the karaoke floor!).  No one wants glass in a venue like that.  

By the way, if you don't particularly care to karaoke or dance, may I strongly suggest this second floor?  From our original vantage point, you get a bird's eye view of all the lunacy.  For example, we watched a horrific breakup (the girl grabbed another man's you know what right in front of her man), people falling on stage, the best drunk dancing ever, and the obligatory drunk people coupling from the balcony.   

The range of songs offered by Cat's Meow is quite good.  But what really makes the event are the MC's who bring the party back every single time after a bad song.  These dudes can sing, dance and are pretty much a bachelorette's dream as they are pretty sculpted too.  Their ability to bring energy back into a place is borderline magical.  

It was my friend's b-day, and I was proud that she left the second floor and was having fun dirty dancing with the MC's.  Eventually, all of us participated in either dancing or singing, and just had a great overall time.  

If you're looking for a place where you're encouraged to leave your inhibitions behind in a positive manner, Cat's Meow is the appropriate tonic.

3.75 stars.  Conjure up images of New Orleans and at some point you are going to think of the humble "poor boy" sandwich (po' boy) consisting of a soft French style baguette, lettuce and onions, and a fried seafood interior.  At Domilise, you can get a number of these sandwiches (including the popular roast beef with debris gravy), but I went ahead and stuck with the seafood versions (if you order the half and half, you get a shrimp po' boy and an oyster one as well).  

Everyone has their favorite po' boys (mine happens to be at Darrell's in Lake Charles, LA), and I'll say Domilise is solid.  Both the shrimp and the oyster are satisfying, and you can get them dressed to your liking.  For essentially 12 dollars, you are served a rather generous sandwich.  This little shop is rightfully famous, but I'm still saying the best ones I've ever had are outside New Orleans.  

Still, that isn't to say you shouldn't come here (or Killer Po Boys or Guy's up the street or Parkway or really any other awesome po' boy in the city).  You will receive an extremely satisfying sandwich here and you'll even get some friendly service and LSU love from the people who operate it.   It's worth a visit if you are in New Orleans.

The Casino
Man... This casino hotel has redefined the word:  OVERKILL!!!
Overkill on glass and neon lights freakin everywhere!!!   So much it gave me a headache walking through the entire place!    Somebody please fire the interior decorator!  ARGH!   It's annoying enough that it makes everyone's teeth light blue!  Seriously!   I notice a lot of penny slot machines and not a vast selection of card games.    As for the hospitality, they loss points for the rude bell staff - they did not offer to help with our luggage and failed to open the doors as we tried to open the doors ourselves with luggage and snowboards in hand.    I really felt like telling those guys off... but nevermind.   So not worth the trouble.

The Hotel Room
Something kinda freaky about tall mirrors as bed head boards especially when they reach all the way up the ceiling.    "chicka chicka bow wow"

The Ski Package
So this where we set up shop for Omar's Bachelor Party.  Here's the details:
-Hotel room for two nights (Friday, 02/01 and Saturday, 02/02)
-Five dollar food coupon for any Peppermill restaurant (we used ours at Island Buffet)
-Shuttle from Peppermill hotel to Northstar Tahoe
-Northstar Ski Lift Ticket
-Shuttle from Northstar Tahoe to Peppermill Hotel

Total Cost for Eight People:  $1095.00 (that's $137.00-$147.00 per person)

I purchased this ski package because I wanted everyone to enjoy the rewards of not-driving to Northstar.   The bus shuttle was packed and took about an hour to the ski resort and hour and half back because of the storm.    There are bus transfers in between, but it didn't bother me as much.    One star missing because the driving didn't blast the heater.  It was freakin' cold on the bus.     But one star back because it had movies.  On this trip:  Miracle http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0349825/

Once we arrived back to the hotel, we got ready and hit the town.   Thank God we took our naps on the bus ride back.

Thank you to the hot brunette waitress, Jessica, for the Silk Panties!

Silk Panties is a drink!  HA!   Get your mind out of the gutter!   This lounge is really tucked away inside the Peppermill hotel!   It took some time to find so here's a clue when venturing around Peppermill - it's located right next to the Coffee Shop.    I must have gotten lost from about 15 minutes searching for this lounge.   Thanks Eric for remembering - You were the only sober one in the group!

Silk Panties Drink
1/2 oz vodka
1/2 oz peach schnapps
1/4 oz Chambord raspberry liqueur

Pour ingredients into a stainless steel shaker over ice. Shake until ice cold. Pour into a large shot glass, and serve.

Great for conversation:   Yes.  Bring your hot date here!
Secluded Private Lounge: Yes!  Red couches turn me on!
Romantic:   Gotta put it to the test someday.  The fire in the water display calls for intimacy!
Serves food:  Not sure...We came for drinks. 
Cover charge:  No.   
Dress code:   If you wanna get some tonight, dress appropriately.
Music:   80's videos.  No DJ.   This is more of a "kick back" lounge.
Drinks:   $8-$12.    Silk Panties:  $8.00 each

No Snake Bites!   The bartender made a poor attempt to make a Snake Bite and failed.   So here's link to help them out:   http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snakebite_(beer_cocktail)
They have their own version of Guinness but it didn't match up.    There version maybe a local favorite, but unfortunately not mine.    It didn't have that certain kick and pleasing after taste.   It was dry and lacked that coarse bitter taste. 

Three stars for the live performance from the Brew Brothers Band!    Rockin' out to a live band playing music from the 70's, 80's, 90's and today's music is awesome!    FYI - They only perform on Friday and Saturday nights starting at 10:30PM til 1:00AM. 


Perfect for Girls Night Out:  Yes!  Especially if it's a bachelorette party!  The place had several parties for the ladies.    My buddies Noah and Jay did pretty good partying with the local ladies!    HUSH!   No details!

Mixed Crowd:  Yes.  The way I like it although the place will get too crowded.

Recommended for visitors:   Yes!   I'd skip the clubs because it's casual dress here, $5.00 admission after 10:00PM (get there early to have dinner), and it's indoors inside the El Dorado area.     There are a lot of threads about "Any Clubs in Reno?"    So this is my big recommend to check it out. 

Serves Dinner:  Yes.   We came here for the drinks and entertainment, so I can't Yelp about the menu.    Will I go back and try the menu?  Maybe.

This is truly UNDER THE SEA!!!   See attached pictures!   Two stars for the decor and theme of this enchanting seafood restaurant.

Here's our power lunch on our first day in Reno:

Raw Oysters on Platter (this wasn't like Ranch 99 oysters.  The small portions enough for appetizers).
Two Draft Blue Moons
Two Fat Tires
Two Cabo Oyster Shots
Three Thai Oyster Shots
One Shooter Sampler
Unagi-Fresh Water Eel
Long Yoshi Sushi
Pan Roasted Scallops
Bowl of New England Clam Chowder
Seafood Fettuccini 
Two coffees

What's the damage:  $150.00 for three Yelpers (Ed H., RJR, and Walter P).   Eat well especially if you're having seafood.     If this sounds too expensive for you, then go down to the coffee shop.    

Attention to Detail:  Even the silverware had waves and complimented the environment.    

I'm going back to try:  San Francisco Cioppino 
(Crab, Scallops, Mussels, Clams, Shrimp and Fresh Fish in a Spicy Italian Tomato Stew).

One thing missing from this venue:  Mermaids.

Driven by sex consumed by fear
Let the dollars hit the floor

(original lyrics:  Drowning Pool - Let the Bodies Hit the Floor... this was CJ's entrance song).

This night belonged to CJ of Hustler!  Thanks Jeremy for hooking it up!     YOU ROCK CJ!    It was so worth the blue balls the next morning.

Here's what the other Yelpers should have mentioned:
$20.00 at the door... regardless if the Reno tourist magazines say FREE.   Its still $20.00 at the door!
$20.00-$40.00 for a lap dance (depending on their mood)
$60.00 for private couch (so not worth it..... songs average about 1:40 to 2:30 minutes).   Yes, I know my "timed" music and edited versions.

Expensive:   Hell Yeah!   
Topless Only:  Yes.
Clean seating & Lounge Space:  Yes, although you'll be open pray to the hungry kittens!
Best seat in the house:   Center Stage seating.   You'll discover that your dollars will last longer just by sitting there.    
Smoke Indoors:   COUGH.. yes... COUGH.   Your clothes and lungs are getting it. 
Would I Go Back:   Only if I was on the FREE guest list.
Drinks:  Serves alcohol (Thank you Nevada for easing the pain of losing my money to your skilled artists).

Here's another reason to cope with hunger:  Nevada buffet places!    Not so healthy, but enough to pick and choose your calorie intake for dinner.     An average of two plates and you can send yourself into food coma and feeling guilty in the morning just by looking at the mirror.    What the hell did I eat last night?!

The only highlights:
Prime Rib (get the medium rare portions).  Don't settle for the dry portions.   
Build your taco or nachos.
Steamed shrimp & crab legs
Desserts (take the fresh baked cookies and get a scoop of vanilla ice cream - make an It's It out of it!).
Skip everything else!    You'll know what I mean even before making your selection.   

Venue:  Remind me of an oversized Rainforest Caf.     Don't worry...you're not hallucinating!   If you had a lot to drink ( or your medication kicking in )   Yes..the trees do move.  


Price:  $26.99 per person on Saturday and Sundays.   If you're staying at the Peppermill, you can use the $5.00 off coupon.

Great for large groups:  Yes.  Large dining area for family and friends.    Keep in mind that this place gets busy for dinner so reservations are recommended in advance. 

One extra service for our friendly and attentive waitress:   Even though you're serving yourself at the buffet, the wait staff works their butts off to remove your used dishes and refill on drinks.    Please tip generously.   One this night, we dropped $25.00 for our waitress.   Thank you!

Once upon a time in a land far away, I was a little wild. I know, hard to imagine, yet true. This review centers on one of those times.

My friend lives in the neighborhood, so I've been here more times than I can count. Another friend called it "The Sipowitz Bar" and I'm still not sure why. The food is solid and the drinks are strong and reasonably priced. The last time I was here a severely drunk guy with his relatively normal friends at the table behind us. On the way out, drunk guy walked up and said "If I weren't so drunk, I'd ask you out." And I said "If you weren't so drunk we might take you seriously".

Ok, but here's the real story. When I was living on the east coast (and wild), one of my friends lived in SF and the rest of us would celebrate her birthday without her. One year her birthday coincided with a friend's husband's birthday, for which she had rented out the upstairs room of the London. Since it was such a fancy occasion, we made a 15 inch cutout of our friend in SF (we'll call her Cutout J) and took her out for the night.  Cutout J was a huge hit as she posed for pictures down other people's pants and shirts, pictures of people licking her, pictures of her hanging out with the monkeys painted on the wall of the upstairs bathrooms (I have the photos, I know I wasn't imagining them). The waiters working the party were in love with Cutout J and asked to keep her. I said sure, as long as they didn't throw her away. Her parents went into the bar a couple of months later and noticed a 15 inch cutout of their daughter hanging out with the bottles behind the bar. That, my friends, was a high point in my career of fucking with my friends. Well, that and the time that Cutout J's parents threw a party at the London and I convinced Cutout J that another friend of ours had just gotten engaged at the Hard Rock Cafe in Philly after her boyfriend hired a mime to mime out "will you marry me?" Yes, I'm going to hell.

I used to come here quite often for champagne-o-ramas, which are glasses of champagne in orange sugar rimmed flutes. YUM! Gets a little crowded at night with a bit of the yuppie set, but fun nonetheless.

I came for lunch the other day. Miso soup was good, but I wish there was a smaller sized option available because it's just too much to eat unless you're getting it as your entire meal. But I wasn't. Know why? Cheesesteak eggrolls - fucking delicious! Insanely delicious! Deep fried cheesesteak... how can you go wrong? They bump this three star place up to four stars. 

Our waitress seemed like she needed a bit of coffee. Maybe it was her first day? She introduced herself and then she was so out of it that when she walked away, my friend said "Ok, XXXXX (no need to embarrass her publicly), wake up, it's 1 pm and it's January 2nd". Then she dropped a glass, poor thing. Or maybe it's because the Continental seems to hire people for their looks. Everyone in there IS nice to look at.... and people that pretty must be stupid. Or mean. Or just bad waitresses. Or none of the above.

My first time having an Acai Bowl!!! And ever since then...I've been craving it!!!

What a great way to start your morning with a fresh bowl of Mother Nature's goodness. Us ladies were actually on our way to a hefty southern breakfast over at Cajun Kitchen but wanted to "pre-game" and have ourselves a healthy appetizer. 

I ordered the Berry Bowl (kids size) which comes with blended: acaí, banana, strawberries, & apple juice and toppings: banana, fresh berries, goji berries, granola & honey. BOMB dot diggity com!

Everything tasted fresh! Love that we can take bowls to-go. And also love their seating area inside this location.

I also noticed little kiddos enjoying some pretty massive bowls. Wowza.

You can see some live food porn of my bowl in my YouTube vlog here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z7Lz6k-tXhI&list=UU5YaBtOxOYqeFEEQ_aW6JiA

Did I walk into a day-time underground Rock N Roll night club transformed into a wine tasting room in a city I've never even heard of? Why yes, yes I did!

Our fabulous foodie friend and road trip organizer, Lorrie M. took us to this awesome winery to meet the owner and taste his awesome wine selection.

The tasting fee was very reasonable and we got to a taste a few others that were "off menu". I love when wineries share more than what's standard. :)

The owner here is quite eclectic, chillax and looks like an all-around bad ass to be honest. He has good rock music blasting throughout the place and it seems like they possibly even have bands playing here since there was a killer stage inside. 

My favorite wine we tasted was called Autumn which was a 2012 Cabernet Franc AND the name of his first daughter he and his wife are about to have. Amazing!!

I definitely recommend my wine-o friends to swing by this winery if you ever end up in Solvang, CA and you're wanting to step out-of-the-norm when it comes to wine tasting.

If you hate American coffee (especially Starbucks) but shy away from gut-scortching Italian espresso, this place is for you.  If I lived in Philly, this place alone would convert me back to being a coffee drinker.

it's kind of like getting hooked on Motrin 800's...  
giving them up because you just we're "feeling it" any more...
and then having someone walk in and hand you a Percocet 10/350.

(I hurt myself a lot.  that was the best analogy I could come up with)

Jersey Shore meets Reno. 

Surprisingly fun and great dancing (the band was going off, great dancing, strong drinks).

Some interesting people watching too.

As for the food, skip it. tried a few apps friends ordered and no one was enjoying them (they actually screwed up fried calamari)

Just calling it what it is, Tonic is like fishing a koi pond with a shrimping net. If you don't catch something, your net must have some serious holes in it. 

Great music. Lots of people. Lots of space outside (Perhaps a little cramped at times on the dance floor, but nothing to complain about at all) 

The service is quick (it helps to bring people who work next door and at surrounding bars and restaurants) and you won't go home disappointed.

Not to be missed.

Definitely get there early for batting practice, and for those Tony Luke cheese steaks (the line behind us hit over 60 people, and it was still 90 minutes til the Nat'l Anthem).  Mine is Whiz, Wit and a side of the Broccoli Rabe.

The Schmidter is disgustingly good (just don't ask what's actually IN this sandwich) and they have Blue Moon over there and a short line.

Definitely worth the money for the Diamond Club.  behind the plate, comfortable seats, great (and relatively cheep) bar inside, great food, and access to all the fun stuff like the Hall of Fame on the 2nd level.

if you're a baseball fan, or like history, definitely check it out (they have an original 1889 scorecard).
always a stop on my Reno pub and bar crawl.  always.

Started at the bar while they set up the table at the restaurant. 

Sure, we could have waited around, but we would have missed out on the live country music, dancing, stiff drinks and the smell of amazing homemade chili (behind the bar). 

I ordered the baby-back ribs per the recommendation of the waiter and I was very impressed. Also had a bit of the duck which was equally good. 

Great service and great appetizers (got the platter/sampler). Definitely bring your appetite though. they don't skimp on the portions. 

Looking forward to coming back soon.

No question this place has some incredible rolls and sashimi.  Definitely the place you go for the creative and unorthodox (not for the same-old-same-old sushi).  

there are 200 items on the menu and I've only had the pleasure of 10 of them.  but as I return, I will expand this review (for now, anything with habanero sauce is to die for and the baked green lip mussels are killer...but be careful, they come in groups  of five so I hope you know how to share "awesomeness").

god bless my girlfriend for introducing me to this place.  can't wait to go back for the oysters (which, fyi, can run out if you get there too late!)

I've apparently been missing out on an entire dimension of what it means to be an American.

"Thank you" to the 100th Anniversary of the Indy 500 for getting me up to speed (at around 230 mph).

Not only is this a blast to go to the night before (the Speedway gas station and liquor store across the street are by far the biggest party i could ever imagine at a gas station) but the event itself is ridiculous, regardless of where you sit.

Courtesy of some amazing friends, we watched 50 laps from the first row facing the pits (bag or Church's Chicken in one hand, Jeremiah Weed cans in the other), the last 30 from the first row the press box, Box 8, and got a first class tour of the infield (ps: the snake pit in turn 3 is unfortunately no longer what it once was) in between.

never have a seen such debauchery and fun WITHOUT people causing a problem. heck, even with ridiculous traffic, i never heard a car horn outside. Yeah, the Midwest is in a class all it's own.

as for getting there, DO NOT take the interstate. find a local who knows the back roads and you will get there in minutes as opposed to hours.
