Kinda ridic, but hey, people love them their infant-sized burritos. Or so they think. Do yourself a favor. Your eyes really are bigger than your stomach. Know your limits.

I had every intention of ordering a burrito after getting a glimpse of all the fresh ingredients, but then was plagued by thoughts of days of yore... When scarfing down a burrito for brunch meant not needing to eat for the rest of the day. I didn't want that going on with a scant few hours of being awake ahead of me, so I passed and had some of their better-than-decent guacamole instead. If you get it as a side order, it comes in a largish bowl (of course it's large, what isn't there?). Overall, I was very impressed with the burrito assembly line going on here. You really can get whatever you want in there. You can even get a BOWL if you, uh, don't wanna ROLL YOUR OWN. Muahahhahahaha

Come to think of it, I actually can't recall the last time I had a burrito... Possibly a sad affair from a local joint about a year and a half ago. No matter how good it smells/tastes, it just never seems worth the belly bomb.

Maybe some day. I'd do worse than return here!

I can't leave this review at 4 stars. Nope, Mint is a straight-up five.

Five for the lychee mojito. Five for the creative cocktail menu featuring an array of tropical Thai flavors!

Five for the friendly, attentive servers.

Five for those divine avocado rolls, bursting with fragrant herbs, chewy vermicelli noodles and silken avocado (dipped into peanut sauce reminiscent of manna from heaven).

Five for the lemongrass tofu. This is the best I've ever had! It's crunchy/sweet/slightly spicy and the tofu texture is chewy rather than spongy. It is featured in the soups, rice/noodle bowls and banh mí.

Five for the enormous bowls, bursting with the aforementioned incredible lemongrass tofu (so many places skimp on this!), vermicelli noodles, crunchy fresh veggies & herbs. If you're vegetarian, they'll substitute peanut sauce for the fish sauce that normally comes with.

Pro tip: arrive hungry or take home the rest of your dinner so that you can have a delicious lunch tomorrow! Confession: I ate every single bit of my food (spring rolls and noodle bowl) and this made me want to go home and relax rather than get started on my night out on the town. And you know what? It was worth it.

I love this place and I need to come here more often. That's a promise, Mint!

Add me to the scores of believers... I mean fans. I live close to Creole Creamery and yet I only recently tried it. Probably for that very reason. I don't think I'll be the same again after this. Luckily I exhibit a fair degree of self control. The cruelest irony that ice cream season coincides with swimsuit season. WHATEV, right?

So, this is the best ice cream I have ever had. Want some cockamamie never-hear-of-before flavors (Green Fairy, anyone?) They've got that here. Die hard traditionalist? They've got you covered (anything from vanilla to butter pecan). Diabetic? There's both an ice cream and a special sundae for you. Can't have dairy? While I didn't see any soy or nut ice creams, they do have sorbet. On a diet? Well, then, I'm afraid you're SOL. There's a kiddie cup, but it's for the kids only. Their small cup *probably* won't kill you too much, though.

First visit had me sampling my friend's choice: red velvet cake. While not a fan of red velvet cake, I can't deny this ice cream brings it to a whole new level. Instead of being merely red velvet flavored ice cream, it's got bits of red velvet cake throughout. Scream-worthy, right?

Second visit, I came with a mission: to try four flavors via the 4 scoop sample (you get 4 small scoops for $4. A bargain, no?) My choices: sweet corn with raspberry and black peppercorn, Green Fairy, butterscotch butter pecan, and blueberry pie, my favorites being the latter two, however I wouldn't throw the other two out of bed... I mean the bowl. Green Fairy wins the creative award because I'd never think to have absinthe-flavored ice cream! It also has bittersweet chocolate and orange peels, which make for a really tasty, unique concoction. My only issue is that I'm not a fan of chocolate bits in ice cream, otherwise, I'd be all over this. Butterscotch butter pecan brings a bit of a more intense, grown up twist to an old timey classic (I had to wonder if there's booze in it). Blueberry pie... sigh. Just perfect. I need a moment alone with it. Perhaps even a year. The sweet corn is a bit too overpowered by the peppercorns and could stand to have more raspberry, in my opinion. That's the *only* criticism I'd have. With all those flavor choices, who cares? Oh and feel free to sample if you're on the fence (but obey the sign: don't be a sample hog).

The best thing about this ice cream is that it's not crazy sweet. I realize that sounds ridiculous, but it's true. Take the salted caramel, for example (I know you will). I tried my friend's and was quite taken with it. I love the idea of salted caramel but I've had that flavor before at other places and found it sickeningly sweet- not at all salty. Creole Creamery has somehow managed to achieve just the right balance of flavor.

And so, I bid Creole Creamery farewell... meaning in this review. Already planning what flavors I'm going to try next visit. Hey, it's ice cream season, don't you know?

My new favorite hotel in New Orleans. I'm an Omni loyalty guest at the highest level, yet I'll never again stay at one of the three Omnis in town (even with the promise of upgrades) because now that I've stayed at the Ace, I am ruined. Ruined, I tell you.

A stuffy corporate cookie cutter room just isn't going to ever cut it again when the promise of dark walls, vintage fridges and turntables with charmingly worn records are waiting for me! I believe the room I stayed in was a medium size (ie, not the smallest, not the biggest, not a suite). I absolutely adored it and wished I was staying longer than merely one night. Comfy bed, delicious bath products, space for dancing... What a unique space! I didn't indulge, but appreciated the variety at the mini bar (nice prices too. What?!) December weekday rates are so so incredibly fair, I don't see how anyone could opt to AirBnB it. Naturally when it's high season, rates will comparable with other hotels, however their group rates always seem the fairest in town and I book groups on the regular.

There's a dark and slightly mysterious theme going on throughout the hotel. Rather than old timey Southern style, which is kind of the NOLA hotel thing traditionally, the Ace is designed in the style of a wealthy artist, movie mogul or musician's mansion in the late 1930s... perhaps in Manhattan or Havana. I know, I know. I may not be making sense. I wasn't around in the 1930s (but I kind of wish I was). It's a little too much verging on, but not quite, Mid Century, and definitely post Art Deco (just not TOO post...) I suck at describing the things I love.
 
The bar area... I just never ever want to leave it! Between some of the best bartenders in town (not to mention super friendly, no matter how packed it is), the comfortable sofas, and lighting so perfect, you feel like a movie star... oh and the cocktails don't hurt either. I stuck to bubbly but tasted some of the other concoctions and was truly impressed. Then there's the sitting area just beyond Stumptown Coffee. They recently redecorated it and it's one of most hauntingly beautiful spots in town. Go see for yourself.

Do I need to touch upon the rooftop pool area? It's a popular spot in town. I've spent many an early evening here sipping on frozen goodness in the summer. Now I hear it's heated in the winter, but I foolishly didn't check it out.

The Ace Hotel is my favorite in town, whether I'm staying here or just popping by to visit. I declare a deep, deep love for the brand.

Three Muses = trifecta of booze, music and food. Add me to your long list of fans, Three Muses! 

When you think about it, they could probably get away with serving less than fantastic food. Many venues do! Three Muses puts as much attention and love into their food and drink as they do their bookings and this is how they are in a league of their own. Each time I've been here, I've been pretty blown away by what I've ordered (last night's tofu bulgogi being the best of the best!) Don't be deceived by a modest-sounding menu. The plates are small, but contain mucho deliciousness. You know what they say about too much of a good thing, right? That said, this is the kind of place you don't come starving after not eating all day (like last night). Besides the flavorful and light bulgogi, I also dig the edamame which comes in sesame oil. Falafel balls are amongst the best I've had, however I think they could use a lot more tahini (unless it was left off by accident. I couldn't taste any).

Cocktails. Last night's drinks were both a hit and a miss for me. The absinthe drink is described beautifully on the menu but the flavors described just did not come through. It really just tasted like absinthe. The lavender lace, OTOH, I could have drank all night. Champagne plus lavender? Oh hells yeah.

Music. What can I say? They book great stuff here. Each time I've been, I enjoyed the acts immensely. You'll get the quintessential jazz club experience. 

Service is friendly and if the bartender is able, will keep coming back to check on your table if you need drinks. A personal preference would be to have full table service, as I don't like ordering at the bar. Since they don't do separate checks, this requires one person from your party to go up and give in your entire order. It's just awkward if you're with more than one other person. That's about the only thing that makes this four instead of five stars for me. 

Bonus points, however, for that awesome blonde gal working the door and seating your party!

Tiki Tolteca has changed so much since my last review (being that I was FTR AHEM)! Although Beachbum Barry's is my ride or die, Tiki Tolteca has good vibes and good times in droves and although my guy had to be dragged here by friends the other night (he's been anti Tiki Tolteca since we were turned away around three times when they were seemingly having more private parties than nights open. But that was years ago), we all had a round + a pretty awesome time.

It's a Polynesian tropical paradise up in here! Get yo'selves upstairs above Felipe's and feel like you've stumbled into a perfectly preserved Mid Century Tiki Time Warp. From the ubiquitous giant glass orbs dropped from the ceiling encased in fish nets to the bamboo thatched walls to the Tiki totems and rattan furniture (couches, booths and high boys). It's pretty dang perfect. Even if the drinks sucked, I'd be happy here because this is so my jam.

What else has changed since the early days of five years ago? That menu sure has expanded. Tiki drinks galore! I had a Pain Killer and believe me, I wasn't feeling any after that one (understatement of the year). 

One thing I'm going to admit may be a draw for some people, but not so much for me is the giant TV playing sports. It clashes with the vibe big time, but hey, it's football season and that's definitely going to be a draw for most people.

Also that 11pm close time is a bit of a drag. On the bright side it's open 'til 2am on weekends.

One of the cool things about Suis Generis is that because the menu changes on the regular, I get to update my reviews on the regular!

I had dinner here on Friday night and there were two vegetarian options: a house-made gorgonzola ricotta baked pumpkin seed ravioli with asiago-parmesean cream sauce & asparagus AND a Burmese noodle bowl with organic baby bok choi, bamboo shoots & miso-ginger broth. I went for the latter because although the former piqued my interest (and my love for all things pumpkin seed), I figured it would be overkill with the "Fabulous Mezze Plate" (doesn't that sound like something I'd write on my own? But it's their words, not mine) that I also ordered. So much cheese, y'know? While one might think you can't have too much of a good thing, well that one wouldn't be me because you sure as hell can have too much of a good thing when it comes to foods that are rich and decadent.

A note on the mezze plate: It is, indeed, fabulous. It, too, changes so while I can go on about how that double-aged Beemster X-O North Holland Gouda got my taste buds in the throes of passion, you may not get that on your Fabulous Mezze Plate next week. You can trust the fine folks at Suis Generis to pick out other excellent cheeses, however. I'm sure of it.

A note on the Burmese Noodle Bowl: It's damn delicious. So, if they have noodle bowls on future menus, go for it. There was a ton of ginger in there. Seriously, at least a 3 inch fat root chopped up. I ate it all. I love ginger.

A note on Suis Generis' plates and glasses: they make me feel like I'm at a party happening in the late 60s or early 70s. I expect fondue to be served at any minute. 

I love Suis Generis for the food, but I also just love the atmosphere. I love how at night they dim the lights and throw on the fake fire places and disco balls so that you feel like you're in the super cool rec room of some hip teenager circa 1970. It's intimate enough to be perfect for a date and friendly enough so that you can easily come in and eat alone. 5 stars! And read my earlier review about their Bellinis...

It's been almost 8 years since I last visited and reviewed Muriel's.

I think I've resigned myself to the fact that this is just going to be one of those places that I visit for atmosphere and history, rather than for a phenomenal food. They just don't really seem to be inspired to do anything approaching creative nor outstanding for their vegan and vegetarian customers. It's a traditional kind of place and that is agreeable to a lot of people.

The restaurant really is lovely and the service is also excellent. Dare I say I just need more these days? I'd expect something a bit more interesting after 8 years.

So. You'll get a salad with the whatever-makes-it-more-than-just lettuce left off. You'll get a tasty, if unexciting, pasta with vegetable entree. I don't believe there were any dessert options.

I'll be back for wine at the bar and to soak in the beautiful surroundings

Birthday dinner at Muriel's? Yes, please!

It's so hard to settle on just one place for your big night, so my guy made the decision for me. That's nice for a change as you can imagine I'm always being asked to make the choices by friends and family.

My experience was again good, but not 5-star excellent, given the caliber of the restaurant. It was a Saturday night and the restaurant was reasonably filled, as it was Carnival season and getting close to the big day. My issue was with the lighting. I'm of the mind that at nighttime, unless you're at a diner or fast food joint (and that would be *never* for me), lights should be dimmed and the candles brought out. Not so at Muriel's. Some people hate dimly lit restaurants, so have at it if this is you! 

Another thing, and this is more of a criticism of my fellow Americans than anything: Muriel's doesn't have dress requirements like some of our fancier joints in town, but really, when you go out to a *nice* restaurants with table cloths and a typical bill for 2 is over $100 can you please make an effort?! Or how's this, please don't wear shorts and T-shirts. Or worn out jeans. At least the hostess made the guy take off his baseball cap. On that note, this "no hats" rule seems at odds with the fact that they let the table of 4 slobs in anyway. A brightly lit restaurant filled with tables of bachelorette parties (I saw no less than 4 tables of ladies on the prowl) wearing silly wigs and hats do not for a romantic dinner out make. If they are going to ask that gentlemen remove hats (and I get that, even if the hat is a really nice one), it seems they should stay consistent with a more refined vibe. No?

Now that *that* is out of the way...

I started with the wood-grilled Eggplant Reloude. *Incroyable!!!!! So good that I needed to exclaim in French. The eggplant is perfectly grilled and is sweet/smoky with delicioso (see? I did it again) ricotta/marscapone inside and topped with a bit of tomato sauce. Perfetto. (stop, Joi, just stop).

As I mentioned in my previous review, Muriel's main nod to vegetarians is with a seasonal "Vegetarian Soiree" entree. I appreciate the seasonality but last year's vegetable plate was much much better than this year's - I visited during the same season, winter. This time there was a so-so mushroom crepe rather than polenta. There was no kale. There was inedible eggplant that was tough/bitter/chewy. Pickled cucumbers. Pedestrian spaghetti squash. In fact, it was altogether unmemorable to the point that I had to just look at the menu to remember what was on it so I could write this review. Not bad, just nowhere nearly as impressive as last year. Give us vegetarians at least one other exciting option, perhaps? A vegetarian tasting menu? Dare to dream...

On the other hand, that butterscotch pudding dessert was birthday bliss-worthy.

So, there you have it. Five star lunch combined with a 2.5 star dinner (five star service and decor) means just hanging in there at 4 stars. I'm still a fan of this legendary and beautiful French Quarter restaurant. I think, however, I'll stick to having extravagant lunches here rather than dinner.

Where do I start? Angie and her crew are legit lifesavers. I use them 1-2X per week for a short term rental. But let me first tell you how my relationship with them began.

Three years ago, my regular cleaners told me that they could no longer work with me (moving out of town). I interviewed a few companies, but Angie really impressed me because I could tell she was organized and committed to providing a top notch service. At the same time, however, I had a friend who cleaned homes and was in need of a job, so I alternated between her and Angie's crew. Angie always could help me out in a pinch and her cleaners are super fast but very thorough (the benefit of having a team of cleaners rather than one person of course). I used her services sporadically throughout the past three years and she always came through for me, even tried her best when she was completely booked. This is crucial when you are relying on income from a STR and need last minute reservations when they come through.

When my friend gave her notice this past spring, I actually felt like it was going to be ok, because I had a company that had proven themselves to be dependable and loyal to their customers. Angie and her crew have been my regular cleaners ever since and will be henceforth! The best!

Lots of pluses for Pals! I could go on about the drinks (seasonal cocktail menu in a diveish bar that you need to be ringed into? Yes, Please!) and the fact that there's just something so cool about ordering champagne in this kind of setting. But let's get down to the nitty gritty.

+That men's room. Oh you better believe I pranced myself right on in to see the nude chick hall o'fame. Seems like Pal's has a thing for well-endowed girls of the 60s and 70s judging by what's up there.
-and who do the ladies get? Burt Reynolds?! I think it's a Playgirl shot. Whatever it is, it's just unappealing. Again with the 70s. Or maybe that's the 80s. Either way, I must be the wrong demographic b/c I definitely have no interest in seeing Burt Reyond's wang. Come to think of it, I may be blocking it out, but his wang might not even be visible. That thick carpet of chest hair, OTOH... Mondo trauma. 
+I love the curved staircase leading up to the ladies. I just don't like who's waiting for m in there. 
+bar snacks. Pretzels and champagne? Helllls yeah. Dinner of champions.

Truth: I love Vietnamese food so much, I could eat it daily. I'm a regular at Lilly's Cafe in the LGD because they have such an incredible variety of vegan dishes and it's insanely cheap. That said, the ambiance lends itself better to lunch (not to mention they close at 9pm and sometimes that's dinner time for me). To add to that, they don't have a bar. This year for my birthday dinner, I wanted Vietnamese food and I wanted a cocktail or two... enter Mint.

First of all there's the name conjuring up both minty goodness served alongside a giant bowl of bun or pho and the impression that this place is *mint*. I've wanted to try it since it opened last year, although it's on the other side of town from where I live and I know it gets really packed on weekends.

Ambiance: more spiffy, more... mint than Lilly's, with their mirrors, modern furniture and chandeliers, not to mention a large bar. I'm not too crazy about how bright it is in there and definitely not a fan of the huge TVs, but that didn't detract from all the other greatness going on... like the food and the cocktail I soon had in my hands (I can ignore TVs, but it's funny how the child next to me was transfixed on the Simpsons as soon as he sat down. We need less TVs in restaurants, world!). 

Getting back to the cocktail: Mint Iced Tea. GET. IT. On this warm Sunday in February (75 degrees in the evening!), I couldn't resist a taste of summer and even though I typically detest sweetened tea, this drink is on point! I can easily see myself throwing back three of these on a porch somewhere. It goes just as well with the avocado spring rolls I ordered, however. These spring rolls are now my favorite in town, because they are just bursting with fresh ingredients, like mint, avo, carrots, sprouts and vermicelli. Dip these babies into that perfect peanut sauce that comes with. So so so good! 

Veg heads get happy for there are options a-plenty. I can't refuse a bowl of bun, and there is a lemongrass tofu option that is brimming over with tofu and vermicelli noodles. Lilly's has an option to add veggies to that, so next time I'll ask if that's possible here because it could only make this better! The lemongrass tofu is spectacularly tasty, with a texture that is crunchy on the outside and slightly firm on the in. Herbs and hot sauce only serve to heighten the fresh flavor that's going on up in here! (side note: please keep those Sri Racha bottles clean... the nozzle had that unsightly crust going on that makes me kind of ill to consider).

Dessert? Not for me, as I was far too full. I couldn't even manage a second cocktail (my typical dessert, truth be told). Portions are enormous, but the food quality and freshness do not suffer. I'm adding Mint to my regular rotation, especially when in Uptown and needing a restaurant that's both affordable and on the nice, not-too-fancy side.

"Why can't oral surgeons adorn their space so it resembles that of your favorite day spa? Wouldn't that be cool?" I mused as everything slowly faded to black. But first I laughed because of course this is what I'm thinking as I'm going under. Aesthetics. They are uber important!

I was referred to Dr. Loyola by my regular dentist at Mid-City Smiles. I'll be honest and say I had misgivings when I walked into what could only be called a dreary waiting room (it's tiny, without windows). I was called into yet another dark, slightly sinister room (I was scared like a baby and I have a terrific imagination. C'mon, laugh with me here) and then realized it had to be this way because, X-rays. But come on, at least make the waiting room inviting?

OK, so I realize how ridiculous this all sounds. The *good* news? Getting my tooth pulled here was 10X more seamless than it was when I got my last one pulled elsewhere three years ago (I'll spare you the horror story). Dr. Loyola had me in and out in about 30 minutes. Can you believe that? I was terrified about going under with anesthesia as last time, I just received novocaine. And that, was horrible, so it didn't take much convincing. My last dentist couldn't get my bottom tooth out (after 20 minutes of yanking. I guess I can't totally spare you from that horror story), and so recommended that I go to a surgeon. Dr. Loyola told me that it's pretty common for the bottom teeth to be more difficult. He was also honest and said that I should just spare myself enduring the procedure while conscious. 

One other thing: he was also honest that the source of my pain could be due to something else (namely, clenching and grinding my teeth) and said that I didn't necessarily have to get the tooth out. I appreciate being conservative rather than "just get it yanked, you don't need it" philosophy that's all the rage these days, but I knew it had to go and I was right. 

Getting put under was not quite fun (I have these veins that are difficult to tap into) but what I did like was that it was almost twilight-y (not of the glitter and teenaged vampire variety) and I wasn't entirely unconscious. I didn't feel any pain, though I guess I was moving a lot b/c I recall being reprimanded a bit by the doctor. He's more stern than jokey, but whatever. The tooth. Is. Gone.

The reason for three stars? Their billing policy is utterly absurd and unheard of (to me, at least). Get this: even though my insurance covers anesthesia, I had to lay out the 300+ dollars *just in case they didn't.* What kind of BS is that? Oh and the clincher? The ridiculous % surcharge for using your CC. Because surely it makes sense to carry almost 400 dollars in cash around with you for dental services. It's unacceptable and I won't return here for that reason alone (it cost me well over 30 dollars for the "convenience"). I realize you've been burned by patients before but that doesn't exactly instill confidence in your professionalism. I've been to two other dentists in NOLA and they always bill you later if your insurance doesn't cover a procedure.

So, that's that. I'd give only two stars for the ridiculous payment policy but I was rather impressed by my practically pain and discomfort-free extraction (and that's probably what you really need to care about). Plus the ladies who assist and work the reception are really nice. And yes, I did receive a check from them right away after they were paid by my insurance. This was a month after the procedure was done and I can survive without that 350 dollars in my account but not everyone is that lucky. 

Oh and another positive note: the room where you get your surgery done is practically cheery, with big windows!

First to review this store that I haven't been able to forget since I last visited four long years ago? OH YES!!

I used to be a regular patron of Mystic Curio, which was located a few stores down from Erzulies on Royal. RIP Mystic Curio! Four years ago, Erzulies had the last precious stock of oils from Mystic Curio, which I believe closed right around the time of Katrina (I understand the owner is happily retired in Florida).

Sadly, the oils no longer exist, and Mystic Curio's owner remains a cherished memory (he'd pull out an oil to recommend to you after talking to you for just a few minutes...my favorites were Musk Royale, Voodoo Nights, Black Rose and Cleopatra). But  Erzulies' oils deliver! 

There is a fabulous woman (maybe the owner) who greets you as soon as you pass the threshold. She is there to answer any questions you may have and suggest various fragrances. I think she has a sixth sense and can tell what scent will work for you not unlike the owner of Mystic Curio. There's a fair amount of variety to choose from, but I zeroed in on my favorite, which I had run out of, as well as a newer oil that she showed me.

You can also get readings here as well as various other esoteric needs fulfilled. It need be reiterated that the owner is so friendly and approachable that you feel you can ask any question, no matter how clueless you are. I think it's important for one to feel comfortable with the occult (rather than frightened, that is). Nothing intimidating here! Pure white magic in the best sense of the word. 

I have no doubt you will walk out of here just as satisfied as I have been on my past two visits.

Review by a coffee fiend...

True, when one is fiending, you might think any ol' bean extraction would suffice, but I'm no coffee whore. I'd gladly suffer the headache rather than swallow down some weak swill.

Envie's got the goods. The espresso drinks are buzz-worthy here (don't ask me about their drip. Don't ever ask me about drip). What's more, you can add booze to 'em! Do it! I have... one fierce hurricane afternoon. The occasion called for it. It was during Hurricane Isaac (this was about the only good coffeehouse open in the area). No one had power in their house for days. Most people were skipping work. And most people seemed to be at Envie. They kindly set up power strips and extension cords and it was like a Social Media Palooza going on in there. Because of course Facebook and Twitter is vital at a time like this. As is a giant, sweet, cold boozy coffee drink.

I've met the banh mí that I want to marry and live happily ever after with!

I shamefully admit that for a while now, I've been kinda meh about banh mí in general. I'd listen to people go on and on about them and was skeptical. I've found that in my experience, there's too much bread and flavorless filler stuff and not enough "meat" (OK, tofu). But now that I've met Lilly's, I've seen the light... These are some serious sandwiches! They aren't shy with the protein and what makes this sandwich more flavorful is that they slice the tofu up really thin before marinating and frying up in what I believe is lemongrass and various spices. Add on some soy sauce and super-tangy but flavorful slaw and you've got the best damn banh mí this vegetarian has ever had. It's also large (think: 6" po boy) and at a very fair price. 

Need something a little heartier and/or hotter? Veg heads take note: there are loads of vegan options (including pho). Fantastic spring rolls that have both tofu *and* avocado. Bun. They love us, they really love us!

My days of bemoaning the fact that I can't fulfill a cheap Chinese craving here in NOLA are over. I really do not care AT ALL when there's far healthier and more delicious Vietnamese to be had.

Let's say you're looking for a creepy Victorian-era baby portrait in an oval frame with curved glass...

Hey, don't judge. One of these can really add freaky flair to a wall.

Magazine Antique mall has the best collection of creepy Victorian portraits I've ever seen and I've been to many an antique mall. There's one of a lady that is positively bone-chilling (and I don't mean one of those silly fake hologram deals where the 'normal' portrait turns into a grinning wraith). 

This is also a place where you can find a decent amount of vintage Mardi Gras throws (Czech glass beads) and other memorabilia (like a framed poster from 1986... which is *not* an antique, OK? Just sayin'). 

I like this place and if I ever had an extra 125.00, I'd buy one of those aforementioned portraits. Thing is, the prices here are fairly higher than I am used to spending. Y'know I'll say it time and time again, I blame shows like American Pickers for ruining it for the rest of us. That said, my boyfriend picked up a stellar piece of religious folk art, also in an oval frame with curved glass that was marked half off for some bizarre reason. I hope it's not haunted. No, seriously. There are such things- haunted paintings. Google it. And if you wish to be able to sleep tonight, do NOT Google haunted Victorian dolls. There's a seller on Ebay who is truly disturbed, as she fabricates an entire fucked-up story about the dead child who is haunting the dolls. Not for the faint-hearted.

Haven't I made your day now?

The bubble tea gods have smiled upon us here in New Orleans! 

Although I know you can get bubble tea at various Vietnamese restaurants in the city, sometimes you just want a quick grab & go plastic cup of blended frozen deliciousness STAT. If I worked in the area, I'd definitely stop into Honeydeux on the regular, especially during those times when I'm on a coffee hiatus (rare, but it happens).

Their menu features a decent variety of flavors from fruity to tea-based and if you're allergic to super sugary concoctions like I am, you can get them to adjust that, as well. I went for a blended Thai iced tea version and it's pretty on-point. The consistency of the pearls is excellent, although flavor-wise, they could be a *touch* sweeter and less pasty-tasting. It didn't detract from the extremely delicious Thai iced tea, however and I'm definitely a fan.

Although Honeydeux is more of a take-out kind of place, they also have a decent seating area, with a comfortable loungey area up front that's nice to work at, especially if, say, the closest coffeeshops are packed with people.

For my 1100th review, I review the iconic Muriel's Jackson Square, one of the loveliest restaurant/event spaces in New Orleans. I first attended a wedding here on Halloween 2010. My two fabulous friends pulled out all the stops and had an amazing horror movie-themed wedding where Jason and Leatherface got things started with a bang (er, a chainsaw). Sure seems like the folks behind Muriels worked well with my friends and the wedding was an occasion to remember. We were upstairs, where private events are held, and took breaks from the main room in the bordello-like seance room. One of my favorite things about this night included hanging out with cocktails on huge balcony overlooking Jackson Square. 

By the way, if you're dining here and there isn't an event going on, you're free to go upstairs and check all that out. You can even have a drink and bring it up to the Seance Room (and I strongly recommend that you do, if you like rooms dripping in red, chandeliers, velvet and brocade. It makes me want to decorate my entire apartment in a similar fashion). 

Recently I came to realize that besides the gorgeous environs, the restaurant serves up some really great food and drink. My friends and I had lunch here recently. We were seated in the room where they open the huge glass doors to the sidewalk so you can watch passersby and listen to music being played out in Jackson Square. 

At lunchtime, they offer $4 Bloody Marys, wines and martinis. I indulged in a Bloody Mary, as I am often wont to do, and found it to be quite satisfactory (garnished with olives, pickled green beans and citrus and served in a pint glass. No skimping here just cuz it's a mere 4 bucks). 

I ordered the modestly-named Vegetable Plate. I'll be honest and say I wasn't expecting much because I've had many a pedestrian veg plate where they barely even marinate the vegetables before skewering them and grilling. Booooring. 

I'm thrilled to report that Muriel's Vegetable Plate belongs in the Vegetable Plate Hall of Fame. First of all, it contains braised kale. Almost 'nuff said there, but I'll go on to say its flavor is just so so so very good. The other star of the plate is that compact square of polenta flavored with herbs and Parm cheese. Everything is so delicately placed, which I love, and nothing overwhelmed with oils or heavy sauces to "make up for" the fact that you're eating a plate of vegetables. There's a delightful little bit of everything from beets to parsnips to tender shittake mushrooms. A healthy, hearty plate. Thank you, Muriels! I seriously could not stop thinking about it all day.

They also have a gluten-free menu.

I think I'll be dining here on the regular when I have visitors in town. It's just the perfect place to take them when they want the quintessential French Quarter dining experience.

Yes, you're reading this correctly: I, Joi B, mostly raw vegan chick, not only went willingly to a steak house, but I'm giving this steak house 5 glorious stars, yo!

It's old school as you can get. The kind of place where even someone like Yours, Truly, is compelled to order a steak and a martini. While that didn't actually happen, what I did order made me extremely happy, not to mention the attentive and friendly service, and the environment within this boisterous old jernt. 

My friends and I got in on one of those fabulous curtained booths. I love private booths, what can I say? So, they had me there. I was dubious about what I'd be served here, I can't lie. And I was ragingly hungry after having worked up quite the appetite at the ostrich and zebra races earlier (yes, yes, I realize I was not a very good vegetarian on Saturday. I might as well have worn leather shoes while I was at it. Oh wait...)

A perusal of the menu had me ordering sides of spinach, mushrooms and German potatoes. I also indulged in some of my friends' garlic bread, though I've pretty much sworn off all kinds of white bread. It was impossible to resist because seriously, this garlic bread is perfection, pure comfort food and like I said, I was starvin' marvin.

And I had a glass of wine, a decent pinot noir (they have a very respectable list of wines by the bottle and glass). 

And then I gorged on the side orders I mention above. Whereas I expected reheated dishes of frozen monstrosities, I received: *fresh* baby spinach leaves, *fresh* whole mushrooms  and freshly sliced/flash fried potato rounds. Granted the spinach had been sauteed in butter, but not overly so, and the mushrooms were served in a butter broth (oh come on, like who the hell could resist that?), but it wasn't overpowering. I prefer olive oil to butter any day, but this restaurant is, like I said, old school, and hey, they treat vegetables right! I ate all of it. ALL. Of. It.

After dinner, I commenced upon cigars and brandy.

I'm going to start off this review with an exclamation: Hallelujah! I've found a hotel that *has it all*. I felt so privileged to be staying at this top-notch property and that's pretty remarkable, seeing as I typically have found some fault with just about any hotel I've stayed in.

When thinking of how to describe the style of hotel, the words "casual luxury" comes to mind. It doesn't have the glitz & glamah of the Four Seasons, nor is it tragically hip like the W Hotels (read: no glowing Buddhas in the room). 

Think: sophisticated, yet approachable. No bells & whistles. No parading ducks. No fountains, nor waterfalls. No Buddhas glowing in your hotel room. No dance music in the lobby and no suits on the make in the hotel bar. It actually makes me think of how hotels might have been in the 1960s (though it does not have a consciously retro vibe or look). Classy!!!

There's a complimentary wine hour. There's art that's not trying too hard. There's comfy couches and shiny wood floors (slight criticism that they need to avoid the orange oil as I almost took a spill a few times).

Not for a minute do they skimp on the amenities you'd expect (bathrobes, killer bath products, amazing rain showers, sumptuous beds), and then some (turn down service with ice, chocolates and bottles of water) 

Espresso machines in the hallway are a nice touch seeing as I don't like drip coffee (there are drip machines in the room, if you so desire). I hit these up periodically throughout the day. The gym is a step above any hotel gym that I've used before, with complimentary bottles of water, headphones, green apples and towels for your convenience. I used it three times during my five days, which made it AOK for me to indulge in those damn fancy peanut butter cups and chocolate turtles the housekeeper left on my pillow every night. 

The staff, from front desk to concierge to valet is superb (and I might add, quite easy on the eyes. Hells yes, you can help me with my suitcase, kind sir!) I swear, I did not purposely leave my purse in the cab so that I could rely on the help of the valet to retrieve it for me... *bats eyes*... but I can't say I regretted it either.

Hutton Hotel, I can't imagine how you could be better. I want to return to Nashville just so that I can stay here again.

Soooo, it's like this:

Now I have to decide what's the lesser of two driving evils: Uptown or Metairie for my WF needs (I have such needs on the regular). I swear, I've inherited my father's utter surlitude (TM) when it comes to driving just about anywhere there is potential traffic. 

The prepped foods and salad bars are more extensive at this location than the one Uptown, where I've been known to spend 20 minutes figuring out if I want to pay a small fortune for food that just doesn't appeal to me. Never had that happen to me in a WF before, just staying.

Here, there's sushi/noodle bar, pizza, bread, display cases of deli prepped stuff (plenty of veg options), a sandwich bar with plenty of tempting options, as well as build-your-own. Yeah, I can get behind all of this. 

There's also a g-damn COOKIE BAR. Is that really necessary, I wonder? Too funny. Thanks for putting that in my head, Whole Foods. Whatever. I can't quit you. 

Their bulk section is also far superior to Uptown's. They have chia seeds! If you buy them by the bag, they are a small fortune, so you do save a considerable amount buying in bulk (tip: use the peanut butter containers for these, as a tiny hole in your bag of seeds will ruin your day). 

Then there's the massive produce area that's so well spread out, thanks to the much larger space. While this location lacks the charm of old Arabella Station (of course), what I need in a supermarket is not necessarily charm (imagine that coming from me). Everything here is sparkling clean and I must also mention that the staff is oh-so-helpful and say hello as soon as you approach their counter area.

You know it's bad when the suburbs are beckoning to the likes of someone who prefers to stay within a safe drive away (that is, not driving at all, if you must know).

What a fun, friendly place! Y'know, I'm not normally prone to saying, rather, *appreciating* such things, but it holds true in St. Lawrence's case. I like. I like very much.

There's the little surprises. First, it's on N Peters, so it keeps company with places like Coyote Ugly. So, you'd expect lousy drinks, a gimmick and tourists lapping it all up. That's not at all the case here. There's local art on the walls, craft cocktails (even the daiquiri choices are craft. I mean, Pimms and Harvest Pumpkin?! Plus the best mint julep I've ever had, with ginger and St. Germaine, no less!) and good food coming out of the kitchen. I only tasted the chips with pimento cheese, but a perusal of the menu reveals that there's lots of good going on there. It's an inspired menu, with comfort favorites, as well as creative takes on such favorites. I did hear people going on about the special of the day (duck, so obviously I can't comment on that). There are at least two vegetarian options besides salads and apps, including a sloppy joe. 

Then there's the extremely nice and as of yet, non-jaded staff. Our bartendress was extremely nice and came and checked on us regularly. We arrived hella early, so we were the only ones in there. Nice that no one forgot about us (far more common than you'd expect and I can totally understand, having worked in the industry for so long) and went the extra distance to be friendly, while not overly attentive. It's a delicate balance, folks.

This is a pretty straightforward review (what? no stories?), but I'm sure I'll be back so I can embellish upon things...

A bearable bar smack dab in the middle of Bourbon Street? I've found it in Funky Pirate. Not only bearable, but a good place to catch some good blues acts that play on the regular (Big Al, and the trio that plays on Sunday late afternoons), cuz it's intimate and what's more, no cover, just a drink minimum (one. One?! Yes, one.) The Bloody Marys are as decent as you're going to get in just about any New Orleans bar and all drinks are just 2 bucks more for a double. Can't argue with that, right? Even during Mardi Gras, this place was a refuge from what was going on outside on Rue Bourbon. 

Do check out the sweet little courtyard in the back, which affords you to still hear the music and enjoy the (sort of) fresh air (if such a thing is possible in the FQ).

So far so good. I hesitate to write this review before the necessary procedures for my cats are completed, but so far I'm liking this place more than Magazine St. Animal Clinic when it comes to follow-up, which I've come to realize is pretty damn important overall. 

Especially appreciated: the friendly vet techs who spoke to my kitties not unlike I do (thus making me feel like less than a cat freak? Possibly).

The thing here, though, it's really expensive. Also, it's now located on the other side of town now that I've moved. So, I'll probably looking for something closer to home (and hopefully cheaper) once current procedures are completed.

Ode to the overused "hidden gem" on Yelp.

Sentiments might be my favorite place to ever stumble upon in New Orleans. It is perfect.

Perfect, I tell you.

First of all "wine and cheese dive"-- if I could have thought of that myself, I would have written the business plan.

Located above the gorgeous Feelings Cafe, you simply cannot get a more divine environs. Sit inside and feel like you've stumbled upon The Lost Generation's hideaway in Paris.

Drape yourself over the balcony alongside it and feel dangerous, as you sip a glass of something wonderful, decadent and red.

It was a slow night. I cannot complain... just wish they would have stayed open later (selfish, I realize). 

I will come back with my bestie, Oscar W and we'll scribble bon mots as our vision blurs and our tongues get thick.

The eternal (yelper) question: Does this- insert iconic establishment- even need another review, when they already have X hundred reviews? To this I say, uh, yeah they do. You can never have too many positive reviews. Plus I look at it as a note to myself upon returning (ie, see my note below).

Yo Mama's is one of those places that was always on my itinerary when I'd visit NOLA. Truthfully, though, once I moved here, I have not been back since yesterday. And I also had only drank here, back in the days before they even had veggie burgers. 

So, it had been a long day of drinking and no eating. A parade day... By 6, or was it 7 or 8pm, I was really feeling it. I hate being hungry in the French Quarter because I don't have tons of options here (that aren't dress-up places, that is). I remembered Yo Mama's famed burger list and immediately was craving some crazy veggie burger piled high with whatever other crazy concoction they could come up with and insisted we make an immediate beeline (er, crooked, inebriated beeline). My friends and I were relieved to find an empty booth and slid on in. I love the atmosphere here-- just a cozy FQ bar with all kinds of characters hanging around. I remembered the bartenders always being pretty damn nice and that still holds true. You might have to wait a bit for service, but that's how it goes and it's never too long. The bartender also waits the tables. Something to keep in mind. 

While the veggie burger here isn't anything special, the way it's dressed up makes a plain girl into a vixen. And that giant baked potato is her perfect not-to-be ignored accessory (you can get these all dressed up too, if you'd like!) I had the Mexican version with salsa, avocado and jalapeños. While I agreed to have it dressed, I think next time I'll have them leave off the mayo because it didn't go with the salsa at all (that's my note to self, in case you were wondering). The baked potato is perfect, by the way. 

Drinks are cheap and good. I'm glad that I have another go-to for a cheap, casual and quick meal when crawling the Quarter.

A cobbler saved a life recently. That of one of my favorite purses.

Out on a day of shopping/sightseeing far from our hotel, the zipper on my purse became stuck thanks to a bunch of stray frayed bits of material. I thought I was doomed to having my purse tucked under my arm all day so that my wallet and phone didn't fall out...then I walked by this place and almost screamed with joy (again with the hyperbole). I walked in and it was like walking into my grandpa's basement (he was a wizard with shoes). Every inch was CRAMMED with shoes, cobbler flotsam & jetsam and family photographs. I knew I had found the right place to save my purse's life.

Sure enough, the friendly cobbler was able to fix the zipper in minutes. In addition, he showed me a neat trick: the way to get rid of those positively evil stray frays is to light 'em on fire! For real! They shrivel up and disappear, not unlike the feet of the Wicked Witch of the East when Dorothy takes the red shoes from her after she kills her with her house.

Just to be clear, I look at mani/pedis as necessary evils. I dislike having to take the time out of my day to get them done and in New Orleans, that always means for me having to go to one of the places I like Uptown, which is too much of a trek (crossing Canal. Dealing with traffic and road blocks and schools letting out) and even more time out of the day. I'm limited on time, can you tell? Cue the stress. Is it really worth it? All I need do is look at my hands and feet. Sigh.

Don't tell me to just relax and enjoy it! I don't relax because I'm too busy being neurotic about someone touching my feet and kneading them to the point of serious foot cramps if I don't catch them in time. And after paying all that $ for manis/pedis, I inevitably wreck the polish because I can't take the damn time to just sit without touching my phone, moving, etc. I am the WORST customer.

But yesterday, I was kind of the best customer at Nail Spa 27! I've found my quick and easy, no hassles salon, friends. First good sign: easy parking right out front. Second, a mostly empty salon around noon on a weekday, so no wait! Third, a friendly greeting right when I walked in. Fourth, a wall of cool colors. And... best of all??? They did my hands and feet at the same time! And it was so fast, I had time to sit there and wait for that shit to dry! They have gel, but I've sworn off gel b/c it truly was destroying my nails (naturally I cannot resist peeling that stuff off).

The salon is not much to look at and I really don't care because efficiency and speed are all I care about when having to endure mani/pedis. Both nail techs were nice, didn't try to torture me with massage, and when I asked for a second coat on my hands, it was not big deal. Again, it was such a quick, thorough job, I couldn't stop thinking that I'm now going to be a 2X a month regular!

And the price is right. No, these aren't New York or Chicago cheap deals (none to be had in NOLA), but 34 plus a generous tip. I'm down with that!

Octavia Books is perfection in an indie bookstore! I think that I could happily live here. I don't take up much space, I promise!

You've got the charming environs with lots of natural light. You've got helpful personnel who are clearly passionate about books. You've got events/readings by local and touring authors. You've got support for the indie book publishers (my friend did a reading here a couple years back and she was published on the tiniest of presses). You've got good selection and good organization.  You've got actual *books* with that good new book smell. You've got actual pages and hard covers and stuff.

I know that it's so easy to just "buy it on Amazon," add it to your kindle or IPad, but let's indie bookstores from extinction, please.

Why, hello, there, Pelican Bay, newest restaurant on Elysian Fields, purveyor of the absolute best frozen daiquiris in the city, not to mention fresh & delicious food prepared & served with much love. Check me out - FTR (First To Review) and first to set a 5-star precedence, I'm sure.

Stupid me, I didn't bring an appetite, just a thirst for a piña colada because I knew here they have it in the machine so I wouldn't tempt the stink eye from a bartender (I was that bartender once, I admit). Here, you can order any kind of frozen concoction you want because they have a wall of frozen drink machines glorious churning up the colorful sweet stuff. You might feel like a kid at buffet where you can mix & match Pepsi and Mt. Dew and even Dr. Pepper (I was that child once). They have all these varieties and then will do something outrageous like a Piña Colada/Hypnotiq parfait. I stuck to the classic piña and wow, it even tasted like it wasn't filled with that obvious artificial flavor that some daiquiri places typically use (Gene's version is not drinkable, I'm sorry). It's true that I normally shun the sweet boozy stuff but there's something about a hot New Orleans day and the way these days practically beg for frozen cocktails. I'm a believer now. And this is where I'll be getting my fix. Sunday fundays, here's looking at you! 

Despite not bringing an appetite, I wanted to try their veg black beans (perfection-- just the right texture and seasoning) and oh, I can never say no to homemade tortilla chips. So, yes, I ate. It's kind of impossible not to at Pelican Bay. Know that if you're a vegetarian there are options for you (and how cool is it that they have a separate fryer for veggies?) and they note what isn't vegan on the menu, too. When asked by chef/owner Tanzanika what they could do to make the menu more veg-friendly, I suggested having some tofu options, maybe (I just love tofu. I know it's crazy). She laughed but seems like she's open to the idea. It's not even really necessary and if you're open to dairy, they have pizzas that look really great, too. Their emphasis is on FRESH food and yes, they shop daily. My guy had a burger that he said tastes just like "Mom's burger," which for him is a big compliment (for me, not so much. My mom's burgers possibly turned me off meat forever. Please don't tell her I mentioned it, K?)

Service is fantastic from the moment you open the door and are warmly welcomed. Our waiter couldn't be sweeter or more attentive and a special shout out to bartendress extraordinaire, Paris!

It's a slice of pure Southern comfort, friends. Get thee here immediately.

PS. There can't be a better place in the city to watch Saints games and other sporting events. TVs galore!

Vegan vogs alert!

What can I say? I love John Fluevog *long time*! I have dozens of pairs and still have my first pair from 20-odd years ago (they are a square toe boot with Chanel-inspired quilted tops). Thanks to my born-again vegan status three years ago, though, I crossed leather off my list forevermore and although he has been known to have a vegan shoe or two in his repertoire, that stopped a while back. Ages ago, I used to justify buying leather shoes and honestly, there weren't many affordable quality non leather options out there. Not to mention the fact that I have weird small feet that are also wide, have very high arches and an annoyingly high instep. Many shoes just do not work for my feet. Especially cheap ones (ie typical non leather shoes that you might find at Payless, Target etc).
#excuses

So yes. I was buying vogs like nobody's business because when they work for my feet, they really are pure bliss. They are gorgeous/quirky/cool and wearable. Then there are the outrageous super high ones that turn heads (the Malibu. I wore these to MOMS one year and I may have been sobbing in pain by the end of the night, but damn, I looked good). 

The other day an email arrived from John Fluevog. Angels sang. Cartoon birds landed on my shoulders. The bright purple stretchy velvet over the knee boots, aka "The Munchies" are in fact vegan! I called the local store and was informed that they have them in stock. Ten minutes later, I arrived, tried on my usual size 6, though because they are pointy toed, I expected I'd need to go up a size. The 6 fit perfectly and because they are stretchy, they can accommodate a variety of calves; skinny to muscled to those with some heft. These boots are perfect for Mardi Gras... and for Prince tributes. 

JF, thank you for making my dreams come true. Please continue making vegan vogs for those of us who live your motto, "Life is too short to wear boring shoes."

I love this little yoga mecca, and if it were closer to where I live, I'd be back and forth between here and Life Yoga.

I've been to two classes here so far, both in the first floor studio, which is spacious, cool, and has a good vibe all around. The upstairs studio, which I couldn't resist taking a peak at is incredible because it's all open, full of natural light and they even do acro yoga up there with aerial silks. 

It's like one big house of yoga up in here on Canal Street. Can't miss the brightly colored happy house. Oh and it's across the street from an abandoned building and the cutest tortie kitty who likes to hang out in the ditch. Only in New Orleans...

One thing I really appreciate is that both teachers I've had offered an opt out on being touched with oils during shavasana, so I'm assuming it's a studio policy. I can't tell you how much I appreciate that. For years, I've been in classes where I hear the teacher going around the room and it ruins my shavasana because I'm stressing out as I wait for them to reach me. I don't like to be touched by strangers, especially my face and head. So imagine trying to deep relax when your skin is crawling. It's nice to know that this studio takes it into consideration and now I know I must not be the only one out there!

Let it be known that I'm notoriously more stingy with my stars when it comes to hotels. I mean, I gave the W three stars and I'm sticking to it! It's just that I've stayed in all kinds of hotels pretty much my entire life, and I do mean those ranging from budget family joints like Days Inn to luxury hotels like the Hyatt, to smaller, cooler boutique hotels like Hotel on Rivington and now the Moonrise.

I'll be honest with you, the amenities aren't quite as great as those at the W, and so normally I'd give the Moonrise a solid 3 stars (A-OK doesn't mean average in hotel stars, believe me). The Moonrise gets an extra star for the vintage moon photos that are just about everywhere in the hotel. I think decor-wise, Moonrise is my favorite, beating out even the Hotel On Rivingon's sleek rock and roll blood red/black decor! I just love the theme to death!!  There are the cute touches like the voice in the elevator making it seem like you're taking off/landing, the way that it always feels like nighttime is falling in the public parts of the hotel, the stationary, pens, all of it. LOVE.

That said, they don't replenish your products (H20, which I may like even more than Bliss' shower gel, shampoo and conditioner...Bliss wins for that facial wash, however), the way the W does. Oh well, not really a huge deal, and I guess I don't blame them. My room was spotless, extremely cozy and the bed was really luxe with loads of pillows. Temperature in the room was also perfect. 

The gym was sufficient for a traveling morning workout. Three elliptical machines, three treadmills and three stationery bikes. The strengthening equipment left a bit more to be desired (no free weights and just one weight machine in the place that shares two sets of the same weights, so essentially only two people can work out on half the equipment at the same time). Again, not a big deal. I was thrilled by the lounge outside of it that allowed for working stations overlooking the main lobby. All so very well-appointed.

Courtesy of the staff was adequate. I had an annoying check-in experience that I'm too weary to even talk about. Nothing major. Front desk staff was courteous (especially the gal working there in the evening). 

Not sure what was up with the cleaning staff. I had this one very eager dude wanting a greeting early in the morning and did not *get* that all I was able to utter was "good morning." I hate being rude, but uh, it was early, I hadn't had much sleep and I just wanted to get to the effing gym. I stepped onto the elevator feeling guilty about not being more pleasant.  I really hope that guy wasn't cleaning my room. I do have issues with male housekeeping staff. The very idea of it just creeps me out, especially when traveling alone.

Noise, well, I'll be honest, there was a morning when people were talking way too much in the hall (step to the elevator, please!) and there was a night that I just couldn't sleep due to the crowd spilling out into the street (apparently the lobby has that disco after hours thing going on that the W has) and what was more annoying was the asshole in the room next to me who banged on the wall to indicate that I was talking too loudly on Skype. F-You. It wasn't even 11pm. I'm hoping that the revelers kept his ass awake at 2am like they did me. Misery loves company. Bwahahahahah

They drew me with that couture frock in the display window. It's a strapless number, with my favorite construction in fashion: the bustle. If I had a spare chunk of change, it would be in my closet right now.

There isn't much to this end at Posh, though. Think more along the lines of labels that have clothes made in China (I know, I know... it's a lost cause to complain). That said, if you can get past this, they have a well-arranged delightful array of clothing to suit just about any style, with a concentration on young and trendy... and a leaning towards slightly conservative (nothing that I'd call head turners, besides that piece in the window). Perfect stuff for work, too. Then there's the shoes and accessories. I could easily spend an hour in here.

Also, I have to mention that the sales staff is incredibly nice! One guy even complimented me on my style (nice to hear on a day when you feel like you look kind of meh). 

Another star for the sales. Head to the back and be prepared to have your mind blown a bit with the sheer volume of items. They have tons of dresses, tops and bottoms, all arranged by color and the walls are lined with shoes that have major mark downs.

I am completely obsessed with the soy candles Arbor House makes! Originally I had gone in for some of the Bougie Scents candles that I thought they carried. Walking into the lush n' lovely shop filled with greens and blooms, you're hit immediately with the luscious scent of burning candles After speaking to the extremely nice guy behind the operation, I learned that they now pour their own candles. In addition to that, they make soaps and lotions in the same scents. 

I purchased the following scents: gardenia (this has a really intense scent that makes you feel like you're in a tropical forest full of these intoxicating blooms), All That Jazz (their signature scene of jasmine and lemon grass-- it's absolutely heavenly!) and fig (a little more subtle, but still amazing). It's a good thing that they have a recycling program because I'm getting all three of these candles refilled as soon as they run out. I think gardenia is my favorite, with All That Jazz a very close second. I've never been all that happy with floral candles because they seem almost artificial. Not sure what magic they have going on up in here, but the candles smell like the most intense varieties of blooms and it makes me happy just walking into a room where I have one burning. Typically high quality candles of this size run you upwards of 40 dollars, but Arbor House charges you about half that for one of their masterpieces.

It's just not fair to leave them at three stars when I've been back a couple times over the years and had pretty great experiences, especially as they've expanded on their vegan options.

It was after 10 on a Saturday. Happy hour was a distant memory. I considered my meager options within a city where nightlife and eating are mutually exclusive and remembered Juan's. Lifesaver.

Their guac is legit outstanding and chips are paper thin and so crispy. We arrived hangry and devoured the basked in less than five minutes. Paired with a frozen marg with sangria floater and hanger turned to bliss in as much time. By the time the tofu tacos arrived, I decided my night couldn't get any better.

Our server was awesome. I've got to say, service at both locations is always excellent and pretty standout for a casual punk rock joint like this. 

Kudos for Juan's staying open an hour past the typical NOLA 10pm closing on Fridays and Saturdays (way to keep people drunk, New Orleans) and having decent vegan options.

Their Pimm's Cup... shockingly good! And I was mesmerized by skee ball here. That's a remarkable thing for me to admit.

They have cocktails. They have an array of bar games. They have comfy places to sit. I sure as hell wouldn't classify The Other Bar as a dive, but it appears most yelpers do, so we'll leave it at that.

Note: the bartender served my boyfriend an unchilled shot of vodka. If that would have happened before I ordered a drink, I probably wouldn't have ordered anything. I just can't imagine any bartender in their right mind serving a warm shot of vodka.

While not a destination bar (I live on the other side of town), The Other Bar provides a great option if I'm on Freret and not in a Cure kinda mood.

I encountered the motherload of all things awesome and Asian here the other day. WoWowoW. Groceries were made, oh yes.

The produce section is enough to make me weep. I mean, 1.19 ea. for young coconuts that run you three times at that Whole Paycheck? There's an entire freezer section of exotic fruits, like bread fruit and duriyan (one day), if you can't find what you're looking for. I picked up a couple packages of frozen lotus root just cuz I love it and have never seen anywhere in a grocery store. 

If, like me, you're a saucy girl or guy, you may lose yourself in the hot sauce aisle. Dozens of varieties beyond sambal, Sri Racha and the like. Soy sauce... are you kidding? I've never seen so many different varieties. Although I tend not to buy premade curries and the like, there is scores of these too. 

There was something I was hoping to find: I would sell my soul to find bean curd skin, aka, yuba, and sadly was not able to find it the other day, but I'm sure it has to be somewhere here. If you're a fan of gluten and soy meats, you'll find an aisle devoted to this stuff (it's dried and you add water). Personally, I was more taken by the varieties of tofu in the fridge area. Mucho miso paste varieties right over there, too. Again, insanely cheap compared to WF. 

I'll be back soon and report more on this grocery paradise.

I've been a fan of Zotz since it was in its original location across from R Bar, what was it, 7 years ago.

Punk rock coffee joint at its finest, tasty as hell, environment right up my alley, tasty baked goods, too (vegan choices, too!). The kind of place you can walk in at any hour and get what you need (in my case, a high voltage caffeine joit).

Oh yeah!

Why I'd opt to go to Rouses over Whole Foods:

1. It's Louisiana-owned
2. They have Cajun hot nuts
3. Related to the above, they have an array of other NOLA specialty items (tourists, buy your foodie souvenirs here rather than the FQ)
4.They play New Orleans music rather than hippy dippy crap
5. Their employees are nice without making you feel like you've committed a sin by asking for plastic (to be fair, the cashiers at WF aren't nearly as self-righteous as the floor staff who seem like they'd spit on you if you ask for something that is against WF puredom, like artificial sweetener. Not that I'd ever ask for it, but a friend once had the audacity to do so and was met with a lecture).
6. Kick ass olive bar
7. They just have a lot more grocery items, and more affordable options at that
8. Not everything has to be gourmet specialty foods and products. They have those, but sometimes you want a bag of Zapps chips or a harsh cleaning product for eff's sake!
9. Nowhere nearly as pretentious (for example, you probably don't notice, but WF has plenty of produce that's from Mexico, California and other places).  
10. Aeroponic rooftop garden! How cool is that?
11. Phenomenal booze/wine/beer selection

Issues with this particular Rouses that would have me head to WF instead:

1. The oils area is confusing not only to shoppers but to employees as well. I had three different employees attempt to find me a vessel in which to pour truffle oil from the jug thingamajig and no one could help me. Not their fault as apparently they had just changed all that around, but no one clued the staff in. 
2. There's just not enough organic produce. It would be ideal as well, if the organic stuff wasn't all mixed in with the other stuff.
3. Not enough produce in general (uh, dino kale shouldn't be that rare).
4. Lack of gourmet whole bean coffee


Numbers 2-4 have double weight, as I'm all about the organic produce selection. A fine whole bean coffee i(extremely dark roast that I grind myself) is what gets me through a morning. I realize not everyone is as particular as me, but there you have it. Supermarket shopping is painful enough, I'd rather not have to go to more than one store per week.

Other things to note:

-gourmet and deli sections in this Rouses is really outstanding and similar to WF. I didn't check out the prepared food section too much, so I can't report on that just yet. 
-the staff really did go out of their way to find me an oil vessel. 
-that wine selection blows WF's out of the water

Expect review updates!

I don't know what it was this weekend, but I could not tolerate most bars I went into because of the overwhelming cloud of dirty ashtray that hit me as soon as I crossed the threshold. Wait, I do know what it was this weekend: I had a shitty head cold. That said, 700 Club only added to my misery and although the crowd seemed friendly and fun enough, I just wanted to get outta there! Cucumber gimlets to go, please! 

I will say this really isn't my type of bar due to the huge TVs that dominate the space. Bonus points for the fellas... nice to be a gal in the midst of a boys' club with nary a lame pick-up line.

Verdict on the gimlet: nice cucumber scent/flavor, but a little too much Roses lime juice.

Give me liberty or give me death! Ok, so that's a bit dramatic and unnecessary. But I take black bean burgers very seriously and Liberty's Kitchen's black bean burgers are in the top 5 BBBs that I have ever had. 

I wasn't expecting this. I expected decent, but my mind was blown! Liberty's Kitchen's BBB is homemade, has an almost fluffy texture, and it's not trying to be "meat" -- this is just the patty which I would have gladly eaten on its own. They make it even better by piling on just the right amount of guacamole, and thinly sliced tomatoes & cheese. Get the cowboy caviar on the side- it's scrumptious. I could eat an entire bowl of the stuff. I'm just going to call it cowgirl caviar henceforth. And I might be inspired to ride a horse across the desert just to get more of it.

Thank god that's unnecessary. Though there is the parking situation (don't even think about parking in the lot. You'll be towed, according to those signs that point blank state, "NO LIBERTY KITCHEN CUSTOMERS." Jesus. Can't we all get along? I wish I could give you solutions but I lucked out with parking right out front.

My lunch for less than 10 bucks kept me full for the entire afternoon and into the evening. 

And the kids that work here are super cool, too. Love what this place is all about.

Sometimes, when all is right in a restaurant, you need to grant it "infinite stardom" and perhaps even yelp about your subsequent visits.

My second visit to Maurepas Foods had me trying a new cocktail, a Chameleon.  As I recite its contents, be prepared to drool: ginger limoncello, cucumber, grapefruit and the wide glass is rimmed with smoked salt. The result is just about indescribable (even for me), but if you're a fan of the Salty Dog, this is a creative and delicious take on the classic, making it perhaps one of the best drinks I have ever had.

Although I almost ordered the same thing as I had the last time, I had faith in the fact that trying something new would yield most positive results. So! The Brussels Sprouts can be made vegetarian (vegan, in fact) and I'm never one to pass up Brussels Sprouts. You get a huge portion of these caramelized cabbage babies. Delish! I also loved the orecchiette, small pasta pillows tossed with pesto sauce and haloumi, a slightly salty Middle Eastern cheese, topped with a sweet balsamic carrot garnish and shredded crunchy kale.  We're talking serious mouthgasm time.

We had a different server this visit and he was just as fantastic as Danielle, the gal we had last time. I'm not sure if it's how management trains the staff or just that they attract these fine folks to represent their restaurant but however it goes, I think you can just expect to be taken care of very well here.

I realize my last review had me professing my deep love to Maurepas on Valentines Day. I think it's appropriate at this time to propose a long time commitment.

Props for the cheap-a$$ prices on food and drinks. Props for the tasty margaritas, chips and salsa. Props for the cool staff who are pretty damn nice and are at the top of their game. Props for the guac.

Juan's is a really fun place and no doubt I'll give it another go. Just wish my veg burrito had more flavor and more recognizable vegetables rather than muddy mush wrapped in a giant tortilla. An instance where I ate 1/4 of it, took home the leftovers and threw them out a week later. I'm bad with leftovers. Really bad, but I typically don't have any when eating a burrito, because I can't control myself around them. I go into a Mexican restaurant resigned to the inevitable burrito baby belly thing, but it didn't happen here for me.

In honor of Valentine's Day, I'm going to offer up my deep, deep love for a new restaurant. 

Maurepas sits on a corner in the Bywater and looks unassuming from the outside. The inside is open, airy, has lots of windows, and if this were 1955, I'd expect a good blue plate special. Not to stay it's diner-like. For some reason, I want to say "lodge with an edge." 

The staff is completely on point from the moment you are greeted at the door. Danielle, our server, was one of the most knowledgeable servers I've had in a while. You can tell that she works there because she wants to, not because she has to. She asked us if this was our first time, which it was, and explained with enthusiasm that they make almost everything in house, using whatever they can from local purveyors. I ordered a Bloody Mary, figuring it had to be top notch there and oh yes, it was. There was a hint of an usual spice in there (I'm thinking allspice) that didn't overpower it, but made it extra tasty. I believe they pickle their own green beans too, which may be the reason I was tasting the all spice. If the Bloody Mary is the most complex cocktail, then the bartenders at Maurepas are surely at Mensa level. 

The menu is divided into 2 sections grains, vegetables, and starch and then meat and fish. Note that several of the dishes may be in the first category but are not vegetarian, however, Danielle offered up suggestions and said they'd alter things to make them so.  

The soba noodles in hot broth (made from andouille, but you can get it made with veg-based broth) was just what I needed on this frigid day. It's served up with tofu on the side that might have been flash fried, not sure, but I liked what they did with it. The root vegetable gratin was thoroughly delectable, too.

 It took every ounce of control to not order one of the insanely amazing sounding desserts. Something to look forward to next time. I didn't want to, you know, "rush things." Oh screw it... I am in utter love with Maurepas and want to marry it and have its babies.

With all these check-ins (and being declared the duchess, sorry, Scott S, muahahahahahha) you'd think I'd write a review already...

I'll be honest. It's taken me quite a while to warm up to Gym Matrix because I'm used to more of a "health club" atmosphere... with crap I never used, granted. Like a sauna, steam room, indoor/outdoor pools, massage etc. etc. But those things were there if I wanted them. And decent yoga classes. And spinning (I miss these and I can't deny that once I move, I'll just join the New Orleans Athletic Club). Hell, the last club I belonged to had several bars in it, too. And that is most definitely not part of the Gym Matrix business model.

But I can't fault them that. For what I'm paying for, a basic gym with cardio that is made up of 4 elliptical, 4 treadmills, 1 stairclimber and 2 reclined cycles, it's worth it, in my opinion. There are decent weight machines and plenty of free weights (I do wish they had one of those pull up machines that has counter weights so that I could continue to work on my goal of doing a damn pull-up). The staff here are all extremely nice and helpful. You don't get any training pressure, either, which is nice. It's also not ever crowded. They get points, rather stars, for all of that. I think of it as a bigger hotel or apartment gym. I just take yoga in other places.

It is what it is. And it's open 24-hours.

"Fly me to the moon(rise)
Let me swing among those stars.."

My second stay here and I think this is one of my favorite hotels in the country. That's saying a lot as I'm notoriously picky about hotels (see my hotels list).

The front desk staff is beyond helpful, welcoming and friendly. I love that they seem to love St. Louis so much and want to point you in the right direction for sightseeing and restaurants. I love that concierge is the "Master of your every desire." Come on!! Genius! 

That bed is seriously the most comfortable bed I have ever slept in in mah life! I found myself thinking that I could live in such a bed. 

That rain shower is the stuff dreams are made of. And H2O products rock (I'm so finding that salt shower gel online and buying it).

And those vintage moon photos everywhere... the cherry on top!!

For this price point, the Moonrise has achieved "as good as it gets" status in my opinion. I recommend it to all who travel to St. Louis. 

Note to self: return when the weather is most conducive to rooftop bar dwelling!!

Just a really quickish update to reflect the following: St. Lawrence has become my favorite place to stop in for a drink and late night snacks in the upper Quarter. It started to become a downright habit this past summer on those steamy hot Sunday Fundays that demanded a frozen daiquiri. Although I maintain that sugary drinks are among the worst things I can put in my body, sometimes you just have to... Especially on a day with 100% humidity. Being that they make theirs in-house rather than pour crap out of a plastic bottle with a list of ingredients that include an array of poisonous flavoring and HFCS, St. Lawrence is going to give you your very best frozen daiquiri option in the Quarter! 

I love the Pimm's Cup daiquiri and just recently became enamoured with the holiday special, pumpkin. A place in the upper FQ that cares enough about their customers that they craft frozen daiquiris speaks volumes (let's face it, a fair portion of their customer base stroll in with their giant plastic tumblers of the shit from Bourbon St so you'd think they wouldn't know any better anyway) and St. Lawrence has a devoted crowd of locals to show for it.

Oh and everyone walking in the door is treated extremely well. The waitstaff and bartenders are among the friendliest in town and hell, you might even start chatting up one of the cooks while you're at it.

I just really love this place.

It's been about 5 years since I last reviewed Swan River Yoga and although regretfully I can't add stars (I would, if Yelp had a 6, 7, or heck, even 10 star system), I just want to show them more love.

In the years since my last review, I've moved a couple times and was super close to Wild Lotus in the Marigny.
