Walking to yoga is of course ideal, and Wild Lotus is also a phenomenal experience, so I moved my practice over entirely to there. A couple years, a lapse in practice - I'm living a half hour from civilization- and I started up again at Swan River back in May. It's just been idyllic! I love this studio, with its enormous room upstairs with tons of natural light and air. I love that they burn incense, making for the good smells! I love the morning/afternoon vegan cafe downstairs that makes some of the best cold brew in the city, along with delicious plant-based options (and sinful baked goods that everyone needs once in a while). I love the teachers, especially Michelle and Keith. They both make yoga so approachable that I'd happily bring anyone new to yoga to one of their classes. Love love love. 

One thing that makes this studio unique is the "Assist" cards (at least I've never seen those at any other studio I've practiced at). If you're not feeling like having the teacher do hands-on assists any given day (or time during the class), you turn the card over. There's also the option for no touching during Savasana. 

Their schedule is especially appealing to me, as I live a half hour to 40 min in traffic from Downtown. Those mid and late afternoon classes work for me, but there's also morning and evening classes if that works better for people with more conventional schedules. 

Having two yoga studios that you love in town is priceless! I'm so glad to be practicing on the regular again at Swan River.

I've been a long time fan of dba in NY (and just recently went to their location in Williamsburg). In fact it was my bar of choice when I worked right across the street (at another bar, go figure). The Frenchman location has all that the NY location has but ups the ante quite a bit. There's live music and a cozier vibe (I'm particularly fond of the window booths in the second room... great for crazy sidewalk watchin').

You probably don't need me to remark on the most impressive selection of beers by the bottle and on tap. I'm going to anyway, of course and let's consider the spirits, while we're at it (I'm not a beer drinker, but appreciate that they have Ace Pear in the bottle). Awe-inspiring spirit selection, actually. They have an entire gin *department* if you will, rather than the usual Sapphire and Tanqueray (and Hendrick's if you're lucky). If you're a whiskey/bourbon drinker, you'll be in heaven. If you're a beer drinker, you'll be in heaven. If you love to drink, you'll be in heaven. You get the picture, surely.

The other night I stuck to plain old vodka sodas for some stupid reason, but sometimes I feel overwhelmed when presented with too many choices. Here's to you... and my return soon!

This parade is long, full o' throws, full o' cool floats (this year designed after streets/alleys/places of interest in NOLA) and full o' good will (the parade route is made so they pass by over a dozen organizations for people with disabilities/illnesses). Favorite throw was the blingy medallion beads. Love that the 610 Stompers are a part of it because they crack me up. Less thrilled with what seemed like more boom box pop music than brass bands.

I think this parade has convinced me, however, that I need to maybe not live on a parade route next year. So many people set up shop on "my" front lawn (if I owned this house, you can bet on it that I'd construct a fence) and left tons of trash including a tarp behind. Then there was the dude who brought a GAS GRILL and ran a picnic (he did not know anyone who lived here) for his family. His kids kept running up like roaches on my front porch to grab anything they could find. Actually, so did he. I know, I know, it's Mardi Gras, but... let's just say that if they had some manners, I wouldn't really care.  His kids and the kids with the family who set up their ladders on the front lawn started throwing beads, footballs etc back and forth with the revelers who live upstairs. After all the parades were over and everyone was drunk, for a grand finale, one of the fathers got into a fight with the a guy upstairs on the balcony and charged into the building to kick his ass. Quite a ruckus indeed.

But it's not Thoth's fault. Great parade.

The more I practice at Swan River, the more I am thinking that I'm actually going to start going out of my way to practice more here, despite other more conveniently located yoga studios.

The reasons:

1. Classes here are 90 minutes long which allows for good warm ups and even singing/chanting, which is a pretty nice aspect of yoga that I enjoy occasionally.

2. Both rooms are spacious. Extremely spacious. Upstairs has the added bonus of crazy high ceilings that make you feel like you're practicing in a temple. Really lovely.

3. The rooms are at a comfortable temperature. Read: not stifling hot. I've never liked hot yoga or Bikrim, but at least when studios advertise that the class is such, I know to avoid it. There are a few studios and teachers in town who don't advertise their class as hot yoga, yet shut off a/c and fans on mid summer days. I understand when they don't want a room to be cold, don't get me wrong. And I prefer windows open/fans on most days-- just not in July/August usually!

4. Lots of props.

5. A unique array of classes (check out all those descriptions!)

and most important (and related to #2):

You will not be on top of the person next to you. You know what this means? You will not smack into them nor get kicked in the head. And in general, I am not a fan of someone else sweating on my space either, thank you very much. I appreciate the generous amount of space at Swan River!

Students here range from beginner to advanced and classes are marked as such. I love Sunday eve's Jivamukti class with Keith. She is awesome. And I'm not just saying that because we did a ton of heart openers last night because those are my favorites :)

I have come to know and love a lot of yoga classes in New Orleans over the past 9 months or so and in most cases that is due to the teachers. In Swan River's case, it's due to both the space and the teachers.

Win!

I can appreciate a lot about Naked Pizza.

I'm not so sure about the name. I keep thinking of people eating pizza naked, I can't help it. I don't like thinking about such practices. 

Onto what I do appreciate...

I appreciate the health angle (though FYI, there's plenty of non healthy options, if that's what you prefer). I appreciate all the crust/sauce/cheese options (I'm picky when it comes to pizza... it's gotta be a thin crust and not too much cheese) and I appreciate the easy peasy ordering online (I hate calling in orders. I can't really explain why. Also, if there's a paper trail, I don't have to deal with they forgetting my mushrooms *and* olives *and* extra sauce). 

I appreciate the fact that they deliver. (This may shock you, but sometimes I can't bear to leave the house). 

But...

This pizza tastes so much like Papa John's that I just can't get past it. Perhaps that says it all.

In a pinch, I'd order from here again, but it wouldn't be a number one choice.

As soon as I walked past this place, I made a mental note to stop in, as its slightly dark and comfy interior looked irresistible. I didn't even need to look at the menu (but when I did, I was glad to see several veg options). 

Don't let the name fool you. The vibe is far more cozy/quirky coffeehouse than deli, which is of course something I totally la la love! Sit at a table or sit on a couch, admire the robotic/sci-fi sculptures/lights that are scattered throughout the place. The service is extra-friendly (our waitress was adorable and we had her two days in a row).

And the food. Expect monstrous portions! I had a veggie sandwich and managed about half of it. Crammed with the most fresh & crisp lettuce, carrots, sprouts (I think) and cucumbers (possibly more that I'm forgetting), topped off with provolone and avocado and a side of fries. It was just what I needed that evening (and the leftovers came to my rescue 6 drunken hours later). My guy had the shrimp po boy and it came with a massive mound of fried shrimp. He seemed intimidated at first, but managed to conquer it.

Royal Street Deli is the kind of place that you wish existed within walking distance of your home so you have access to scrumptious deli-esque food late into the night, whether dining in the super cute restaurant or grabbing something to go.

On my last night in New Orleans, my friends and I found La Maison thanks to the phenomenal music that we could hear from across the street.

Our mission that night was in fact to find a club with live jazz, not really so difficult to do in this town, obviously. 

What I really like about La Maison is that it's larger than the Spotted Cat down the street where you're really going to have to be OK with being on top of strangers that surround you (the music is so phenomenal there, though, you really don't care).  

We were able to grab a table, despite it being a pretty crowded night. Drinks were good and didn't seem overpriced considering that there was no cover to get in. 

But what we came for was the music and damn, did that band deliver. The stage set-up was good, afforded a decent view and the sound was pristine. 

Check out their calendar, however, for reoccurring events, as they seem to have a varied schedule. After the band was done, there was an open mic/jam thing that wasn't really what we were in the mood for (although if we didn't want to check out other places, I'm sure we would have stayed and enjoyed it). 

La Maison, you're on my list of NOLA favorites, for sure.

My new obsession. The Crêpe Place is a newish brick & mortar for The Crêpe Cart located in the French Market. A simple name, but I'm just going to refer to it henceforth as Vegan Crêpe Paradise.

Although crêpes lend themselves well to eating in transit, unless I'm in a rush, I prefer to sit down and eat. This airy cafe with plenty of seating is all kinds of perfection for me. I had a lunch meeting here the other day (though to be fair, I was so into my hummus crêpe, it was hard to concentrate on anything but!) 

The folks behind this operation are so dang nice, too! I believe the owner was training a new crêpe maker, and both were super helpful and enthusiastic about their product. I am not used to having an entire menu of vegan options, so I was pleasantly overwhelmed. I mean... sweet *and* savory crêpes for vegans (and GF, though this is not me)? SWOON. For my first food of the day, I always go with savory and the hummus crêpe was calling my name. 

But first, the perfect latte. Although I'm used to paying more along the lines of .50 for almond milk and here it's a $2 up charge, it's worth it (not sure what brand they use but it's very creamy and steams well). 

My crêpe was lovingly prepared and bursting with goodness: creamy hummus, greens (basil and spinach, I believe), tomatoes. Honestly, I cannot get it out of my head and I need to go back immediately. I was encouraged to try the pesto crêpe next time and I'm counting down the days. 

This is also a great dessert place. Besides the aforementioned sweet crêpes (I've never had a sweet crêpe in my life, but memories of walking past crêperies in Europe are vivid. Especially because I knew them damn crêpes would never be vegan!), there's also vegan donuts.

I adore this place so hard.

What a fun place. Friendly, casual, festive (brightly painted, multi colored lights and muchas piñatas), good for groups (read: louuuuud!), Taqueria Corona is kind of just what you'd expect it should be and when you're looking to swig back a couple of margaritas, hot, salty chips and queso, you'd do well to do so here. Make sure you ask for the trio of hot sauces, too. I loved the chili paste/oil. So tasty when mixed in with the queso.

Ditto for gut bombing burritos. The emphasis is on meaty things here from the usual (chicken, beef, fish) to the more adventurous (tongue, anyone?) It would be grand if they could add a spinach/mushroom option to the list, rather than the yawnsville "no meat" option (that is, just beans, rice, cheese, lettuce, tomato and guac, which inside the burrito becomes a bit of a bland, indistinguishable mush). As such, I will return for chips and drinks and forgo the "real food". That doesn't mean you should listen to me, as this probably only applies to vegetarians. My plea to Taqueria Corona: please think about giving us a bit more to choose from! I want to love you...

Seven years (and dozens of visits) since I've last reviewed DBA? How is that even possible? And because I'm on a bit of a nostalgia trip these days, it seems an update is due.

My favorite time to hit up DBA is within the first hour or so of opening. The place is all sparkling and empty and smelling of that new bar smell. My guy and I belly up and over to our choice of coveted window seats. This is the ONLY place to sit, trust me on that, daylight or nighttime, you're going to get an epic show of people parading down Frenchman Street in various states of sobriety and questionable attire. 

While we're on the subject, whatever happened to travelers looking sharp, y'know, wearing those special vacation clothes? NOT. ON FRENCHMAN. EVER. I mean, maybe there's an awful lot of people vacationing out of their cars these days, but there's some seriously interesting looks going by those windows.

I digress. I will leave it at this: One of my favorite things to do in New Orleans is to sip a glass of sparkling and gaze outside at the local flavor here at DBA. That said, this will always be a favorite music venue. It's a MUST for anyone visiting New Orleans and the cover is worth it. The selection of wine, beer and spirits is impressive (especially beer and brown liquors, but any bar (that's not a wine bar) that carries both Prosecco *and* Cava has my undying loyalty. 

DBA will always be on my regular rotation when I'm back in New Orleans.

Iced. Coffee. Obsession. 

Coast Roast at the St. Roch Market has the best iced coffee I have ever had and they have it available in a cup as big as my head, so basically I am set for the day with one of these babies.

I don't know how much more you need to know than this. If you're a coffee fiend, you're already on your way...

PS. They have almond milk

Em Trai! Thank you for being a tasty option that is walking distance from my house! Thank you for being vegan-friendly! Thank you for both quick fast casual service and easy takeout! Finally, thank you most of all for the superb customer service!

It's not just sandwiches, by the way. On a chilly fall day, pho was on my brain. The place was buzzing on a mid week afternoon. Clearly it's a favorite in the neighborhood and with good reason. Service is friendly and accommodating (more on this shortly) and the space is welcoming and quite open. Larger groups can be accommodated.

I ordered the vegan pho with tofu and an order of the fresh spring rolls. Both were good and what I needed (healthy, nourishing food) and what you probably need after a few days of excess (tourists, I'm looking at you). Honestly thought the pho could use some... heft, though. Noodles are plentiful, but veggies are not. Also, the tofu doesn't come tasty and fried as it does in places like Lily's, Mint and Magasin (though the really awesome counter guy who may be the owner said that I could definitely order it fried if I wanted, which is awesome). The fresh spring rolls come with a tasty peanut sauce... there was something missing in them, perhaps tofu? I've definitely had better and not sure if I'd order these again. Note to self: bring soy sauce in your bag next time, because there's none on the premises and this is a need for Yours, Truly whenever eating the tasty foods of Asia (and most other places. #addicted)

I really can't wait to return. This place has good vibes in droves. And tots... what?!

In a city that has no shortage of superb bloody marys, the one I had at Igor's yesterday is particularly memorable. It kind of tasted like spicy pizza in a glass! OK, I suppose that sounds disgusting. But trust me, it was perfect. Sometimes when a bloody is spicy, it's extra tangy because of the Tabasco. While I'm thoroughly addicted to Tabasco and all but carry it in my purse, I prefer this kind of bloody that's extra savory, salty and just... oh god, it was *that* good.

I'm writing this on a Sunday morning and thanks to Daylight Savings Time, I may be indulging in a bloody mary at an indecently early hour (before 8am and no, shockingly I'm not up from the night before).

Really nice bartender, too.

Praise to Bouligny Tavern for keeping their kitchen open late!

It's been a while. To be honest, I hadn't returned to this dark little lair in over 6 years. The reason we stopped in recently was because it was after 10pm on a parade night Uptown and we were hungry. Bad times for hunger in NOLA. But, there's Bouligny, so that's awesome and we (especially my non vegan friends) appreciate that.

The food options, as I expected, are close to non existent for vegans. I was regulated to a small plate of pickled vegetables and an order of fries, minus the aioli. Our waitress, while nice, was pretty clueless about the vegan diet and started suggesting items that are clearly not vegan. I think in this day and age, servers need to be informed about dietary limitations. But hey, even going back to the kitchen and talking to the chef would have been appreciated.

Love their wines. Love the dark, sultry atmosphere. I'd only return to drink wine and eat elsewhere.

I was recently asked by someone where they should stay in New Orleans. Options are so overwhelming! You could stay in an AirBnB in a cool neighborhood, but if you don't really know the neighborhoods of this city, it could mean you're in a less desirable/safe area (AirBnB is illegal in some parts of town, including the French Quarter). You could stay in a small local hotel in the Quarter. For the most part, I don't particularly love these as I haven't had the best experiences in them (weak service and amenities). Locally-owned bed & breakfasts are a great option but book quickly. Posh hotels are awesome but $$$ and trendy hotels like the Ace (my favorite) are great but also book quickly as they are smaller so if you're coming during Mardi Gras or JazzFest, you better book ahead. That leaves the solid chains like the Hilton, Hyatt, and of course Marriott. You can't go wrong really!

I was in town during Mardi Gras and couldn't stay in my own house, so we ended up staying here. At $350 a night, it wasn't cheap, but it was literally Mardi Gras weekend leading into Fat Tuesday itself and it could have been a lot worse.

The best part about this Marriott, other than its edge of the FQ location, is the lobby action. Seriously! It's an attraction within itself. During Mardi Gras you need a wristband to get in to see these sights, as it's right on Canal, the major parade route. Each evening, we'd wind down in the lobby bar. It's expensive for New Orleans and there are better hotel bars out there, but the characters that found their way in and out of here... you can't put a price on people watching. 

There's also a(n expensive) coffee bar serving Starbucks if you need your fix before leaving the hotel, and a very convenient little grocery & souvenir shop that serves liquor, too (no mini bar in the room, which is fine with me because that removes the temptation to dig into a $6 mini can of Pringles. Get me?)

Our room was small but clean and comfortable. There's a fridge for your leftovers. There's a coffee maker and huge TV. Beds are comfy and you get a robe, too. 

I usually work out when traveling but not this time. I checked out the gym anyway and it's small but does the trick (although it's a pretty dark/depressing gym like in most NOLA hotels. It's such an afterthought and I get it, "who works out when they are on vacation in New Orleans" but still... put in a Peloton bike. It would be such a game changer). 

The pool is really a decent size for a French Quarter hotel and affords a view over (not so pretty at most times of year) Canal Street.

The New Orleans Marriott is, as I mention above, a solid choice. It's not the most charming nor does it have that oh-so-gorgeous old timey New Orleans vibe, but you also likely won't have a giant palmetto bug making its way into your room. And if you're as phobic of these monsters as I am, that's peace of mind right there :)

I died last night due to a vicious killer... po-boy. And killer spicy nuts. And killer Thai watermelon salad. 

My friend, who has historically been vehemently averse to the "P" word ("Pop-up," not po-boy) must have had an epiphany recently because he has been insisting that we come here for some time now. Really, all I needed was Andrea B's seal of approval (and ROTD last week) and it was a done deal. I was going to love Killer Po-Boys.

And I do, boy, I do.

I will report back once I actually eat one of the sandwiches, but my friend, who also has the appetite of a bird, managed to eat his entire pulled pork po-boy. And god help me, despite my vow to never indulge in Wilbur again, I was tempted. The bread is just how I like it, crusty, yet soft. The fillings spill out. It's po-boy perfection.

And there are two intriguing vegetarian choices (not deep fried, yay!) on the po-boy menu. Plus a grilled cheese.

I did inhale the entire serving of spicy nuts and watermelon salad. The flavors are just that incredible. Impossible to stop. IMPOSSIBLE!!!! And I wasn't even hungry (hence me not ordering the curried vegetable po-boy that has my name written all over it).

Prices are insanely cheap ($3 spiced nuts, helllllo perfect cheap drunky snack; $2 salads, $7 po-boys) and the glorious lady behind the entire operation is a saint. She may make killer food, but she is a fucking saint. There, I said it.

Death by po-boy. It has happened.

Tip's is the sh!t!

Besides the fact that it's one of the only venues I can actually walk to from my house, it's also one of NOLA's venerable institutions, so how very lucky am I?

It deserves its accolades because the sound is fantastic. The drinks are reasonable, (considering they could really ream you here) and it seems like even if it's packed, there's no bad place to stand/dance/listen. I saw Firewater here a couple weeks ago and props to Tipitina's for putting them on their bill because Firewater is fucking amazing. Oh and  Zydepunks opened for them!! Perfect bill. Just perfect. Who knows, maybe I'm just slap-happy because I didn't have to trek down to One-Eyed Jacks to see them.

Something else that's pretty darn nifty and unique: the bartenders are personable here and that's pretty rare at a venue. I expected a vodka/soda slammed down in front of me with the demand of 10 dollars, no pleasantries... Quelle suprise!

I've heard their bills used to be better. OK, maybe that's true (I saw lots of stuff coming up that I have no interest in seeing. Death metal anyone? Why?) But for now, I'm giving Tipitina's 5 stars and I'm sticking to it.

Hold, on, let me be your wing-women for a moment, yelpers! 

Take it from a straight lady who has scores of dudes as close/best friends: Bouligny Tavern is packed with hot women on a Saturday night.

As a side note, I will note that many of them were unfortunately attired. I mean, "unfortunate" from the perspective of anyone who has a clue about fashion. Hey, who needs a beach, when you have the Bouligny Tavern? Bad style aside... I don't know if they were plants or what, but I haven't seen a scene like this yet in New Orleans. It was quite interesting to observe. My friend and I were seated by the bathroom so the line up afforded many a viewing opportunity.

Onto more germane details. I realize not everyone reading this review will be a slobbering male (or female).

As our cab drove past Bouligny Tavern last night on the way to elsewhere, the positive memories of my stellar experience here just a couple weeks ago had me asking the cab driver to make an immediate U-turn. The Pavlovian response was too much to bear. I needed more of those spectacular small plates.

Now let me tell you about the delicious (and modestly described) fried squash. The absolute best I've ever had. Slices so large had me wondering if they were giving us eggplant instead. They are lightly battered, but what makes these babies sing is the lemon zest sprinkled on top. Gorgeous!! An Amalfi Coast moment in time. I half expected to see the dark, dark sea a hundred feet beneath the terrace I was dining on. Alas, there was no such terrace. And the only indication that we could possibly be on a beach were the aforementioned outfits.

No matter, I still adore you, Bouligny Tavern.

Chinese food seems to have magical properties, doesn't it? It can satisfy a certain kind of desperate hunger. It can cure hangovers. It can make you feel nourished and possibly invincible. 

New Orleans is severely lacking in Chinese food when you compare it to other major metropolitan areas. There's cheap corner joints a-plenty, don't get me wrong. But I prefer not to walk away from meal swollen for hours due to liberal use of cheap oils, MSG and sodium (even though damn, that shit is good, even at its worst!!!) 

But now, NOLA has Red's Chinese. When I heard that the chef was affiliated with one of my favorite Chinese joints in SF & NYC (Mission Chinese), I knew we had a winner here. Admittedly, I have been meaning to hit this place for over a year, as I heard they had some killer vegan options, but for some reason when I have Asian food urges when I'm in town, I don't even consider Chinese (like, it's not even on the brain) and opt for Sukho Thai or one of my many favorite Vietnamese joints. 

I'm so glad I made it a goal to get to Red's because it definitely lived up to my expectations! I love its modest Chinese opium den basement chicness. It fits in so well on the slightly dodgy (but "up and coming" as they keep promising) St. Claude corridor, close to Sugar Park and across the way from Saturn Bar. If you're not familiar with the area, don't be turned off by the blighted property right next door or the dudes shooting dope across the street (not trying to be funny, it's just the way it is). Just go on in to Red's and you will not regret it. 

I need to note again how much I love the atmosphere. I feel like I'm in Chinatown in NYC back in the early 80s when I'd go in with my mom who had taken up Chinese cooking and would go to grocery stores for supplies. We'd then get dinner at one of the bustling family joints that crowd the blocks. There's just something decidedly cozy about these types of places.

Although they were out of the main course I originally came here for (Buddha's Delight), they had another vegan option, bok choy with Chanterelle mushrooms in a black bean sauce. Just the idea of Chanterelle mushrooms in Chinese cooking made me happy because it's not typical (usually it would be Shiitake, which I don't love at all). I also ordered the smashed cucumbers (salty, with tahini and sesame seeds giving it a divine smoky flavor). While their wines by the glass are limited, the chilled Portuguese red is quite good (and they also have frozen drinks and an intriguing cocktail list). 

My entree arrived and I went to town on that thing. Yeah, you just *do this* with good Chinese food. You know what I'm talking about. You're in this food-induced fugue and eat like an animal. Because of that, I don't know how much sense I can make at this point with the words to describe that pile of baby bok choy and chewy mushrooms swimming in a pungent salty black bean sauce. 

Portions are large. They suggest the family style thing at the beginning of the meal, which I personally dread because no one wants to share with vegan me, nor do I want to share my vegetables with anyone, so hands-off, OK? 

Although I can't say much about what my guy ordered, I know the egg rolls were spicy and good and the Kung Pao pastrami that everyone goes on about wasn't really doing it for him, but that's OK because there are a bunch more things I hope he'll go back and try (read: when I make him go back and try;)

What would make this five stars? A couple more vegetable options. My dish would have been next level if it had a little protein in it (dare I suggest tofu skin? Really, any type of tofu would be cool). Besides the on-menu Buddha Delight, there's an eggplant dish that I'd be down to check out in the future but wouldn't want to have as a main course.

Regardless, I'm a fan and can't wait to return!

What better way to enjoy a perfect weather late spring evening in New Orleans! What better way to appreciate the gorgeous Crescent City vista than from high up above (high for NOLA at 13-I think?- floors).

When we first arrived, we had to grab the 70s Addams family chairs and reenact Morgan's exact same photo, of course (bonus: there's now creepy baby photo that's on the wall between the chairs). A quick glance at the menu and I was overjoyed to see there wasn't just one choice for sparkling by the glass but at least 5, two of which were moderately-priced. As I always say, girl with the Krug taste on a Cava rose budget and all... My guy soon spotted precious space had opened up outside, so we grabbed it. Another round later, we gave our space to some other view-hungry citizens. And we were out. An hour is the perfect time to spend here.

A few things:

-it was quicker going to the bar for drinks than waiting for the waitress.

-the crowd... let's just say I expect and appreciate a little more diversity. This is New Orleans, after all. 

-inside is almost as enjoyable as outside and I might even prefer it in the future. More chill, more space to breathe and comfy seats!

Most important thing to note: I would never even consider coming to this place on a weekend. Nope. Not going to happen. The lines to get in are insane (I witnessed this once back in April from my car and just drove on by) and now that I've been here on a weeknight when it was moderately crowded (expect every spot to stand on the not very large terrace to be crammed with selfie seekers), I know that I would not at all enjoy the weekend madness.

**Stellar lunch specials**

But first let me remark on the chandeliers that appear to be dripping with swan feathers. Now, I'm sure they are not actual swan feathers, but how gorgeously Josephine Bakeresque! On a similar note, while Origami may not be as disco-sushi- fabulous as Sake Cafe (read: trendy), I like their ambiance a great deal more. It's half way between authentic Japanese minimalism, with a more sleek & modern appeal. The long sushi bar is more inviting and less intimidating than at most Japanese restaurants I've been to, with young, friendly sushi chefs behind them (one female! So awesome). 

On to our meal. There is a lunch menu with reasonable prices for Bento boxes and sushi/sashimi plates. I got three vegetarian rolls (choose from avocado, cucumber and asparagus) for 11.95 which included soup *and* salad. Everything was fresh, flavorful and the sushi chef arranged my wasabi in a leaf and carrots in the shape of blossoms. How lovely can you get? Our waitress was as sweet as pie, speedy (much appreciated at crunch, I mean lunch time) and our water glasses were never empty.

Note that there are a fair number of vegetarian options. I look forward to returning regularly. Tofu steak, here's looking at you!

Yet another small plate slingin,' slightly swank, trés chique establishment that wins my immediate favor. I think I'm rather predictable because if a place has:

-an array of plates with a bite or two on them
-a bangin' cheese plate
-low lights
-dark wood
-sit at the bar or banquet (outdoor side patio, too)
-stellar cocktails
-a good wine list
-people acting like grown-ups; no battle to get to the bar (read: it's not Delachaise on the weekends)
-waitress service (yes, this matters)

So, an enthusiastic yes! to all of the above. I'm a total fan girl. 

*waves self*

I mean... they had me at the truffle popcorn, housemade wasabi peas and potato chips (one handful of each-- just enough to share with a pal).

No, they really had me at the board of 3 cheeses. These change daily, but I have no doubt that unless you're picky, you'd do well to trust them and order whatever they have. Especially if you like strong/blue varieties. There was also a very interesting cheddar and I rarely, if ever, find cheddar to be interesting. 

My friend and I also shared the spinach gnudi, which is a lot different than the dense, pillowy gnudi that I'm used to (think: giant ball of gnocchi). Not that I don't love gnocchi when I'm in the mood for dense pillows of potato goodness, but Bouligny's is a much appreciated lighter fare. I'm not even sure if pasta was present because the spinach and tomato sauce the star of the dish. I could be wrong, but I also detected something akin to ricotta. I don't like to make suppositions in a review, so just take it as an impression. A favorable one at that.

I stuck to a couple glasses of Valpolicella, but tasted my friend's fantastic cocktail, La Madrugada, smooth, bitter and best to sip slowly. I love the lack of super sweet stuff on their cocktail list. It's definitely a refined list and reflects the overall restrain of the place.

Top fucking notch.

What. Fresh. Hell. Is. This?

I wish I could claim that I originated that expression, as it popped into my head as soon as crossing this dreaded threshold, but I did not. You can thank Dorothy Parker (I do, quite regularly).

If the idea of a "2 Dolla Holla" is appealing to you, come here on a Saturday. If the idea of a 2 Dolla Holla is appealing to you, I'm afraid we have nothing in common.

In closing, is where you might end up at Misery O'clock looking for a cheap beer or worse.

I'll be back on the 12th of Never.

I guess the days of kitchen and bath showrooms are over (at least in New Orleans), because BC Kitchen & Bath is typical of most stores of their kind: walls of samples, maybe 2 or 3 layouts in a chaotic, cramped tiny storefront. That said, I was asked if we wanted help as soon as we stepped inside, only without anything to look at, who the hell knew what to ask for? The lady who worked here was extremely nice and it seems if you do your research beforehand, the turnaround is pretty quick and they are well-stocked in some mysterious warehouse nearby.

Don't expect regular hours. I think that's a "thing" too with these places as they all seem to close whenever they want (closing hours are even rubbed off on the door). Again, this is probably due to the fact that there isn't much browsing going on.

I'll report back if I go with them, but I wasn't wowed by any of the marble/tile/cabinet samples that I did see. Think more typical and nothing that would belong in a book or magazine. I'm thinking it's probably where a lot of landlords shop?

With just one visit & one bowl devoured, I'm well on my way to obsessionville with Poke-chan!  

I'm a lover of all things bowl, from açai to bun to bi bim bop to burrito. Believe it or not, I had yet to try a poke bowl because I figured they were more oriented to raw fish lovers and being that I'm vegan, I couldn't imagine anything too exciting going on (a bowl of raw veggies... isn't that just a salad? WRONG!)

They had me at the get-go where you fill your form out. I have very specific needs and get hellannoyed when, say, the sauce or the nuts or the avocado is left off whatever bowl I've ordered. And it's inevitable because human error is more the norm than the exception in New Orleans. I think there were roughly a dozen different asks on my form and all were executed as desired.

They allow for your bowl to be served over rice or greens. I went with the latter and loaded that baby up with fried tofu, wakame, nori, daikon, marinated bean sprouts (one of the most delicious things I've ever put in my mouth), macadamia nuts (nice Hawaiian touch!) and a bunch of other things that give justice to the over-used phrase, "party in my mouth." This might have been more of a blow-out celebration!

All of the ingredients are super fresh (my guy confirmed the same of the raw fish) and generously arranged in the bowl. I'll be honest. I was regretting not ordering the large for $2 more (I'll be honest. I almost ordered a second bowl to go) because it was so damn delicious!

Environs is a cozy, transformed shotgun with plenty of seating and a really nice back patio that will be enjoyed in weather that is not over 90 with even higher humidity. 

I'll be back in less than a week. Not kidding.

Disclaimer: I am not at all the sort who would typically be cavorting at a go kart track. (Although the actual drag race track seems incredibly cool, this review merely reflects the go kart portion of the park.)

That said, I am open-minded enough to try new things all the time. I've been on go karts before at theme parks and was always kinda, wow, that was so not exciting. My brother, OTOH, was always all about the go karts. And so are most of my friends. It's just that I don't get it. 

But now I do. It's all about getting out there and burning rubber, baby!

THAT said, I didn't realize this was the point until after my leisurely joy ride around the track.

You get a 10-minute ride and it's a pretty decent sized track, but with all those turns, I found myself feeling really car sick and almost threw in the towel. But then I figured, hey, I can stick it out. I'm a trooper.  I was still wondering what all the fuss was about, and kept thinking, wow, this would be so much cooler if it were like that ride at Epcot Center where you're in a race car going 200 mph. Now *there*'s an adrenaline rush like whoa.

So I continued driving responsibly around the track, wondering why everyone around me was being so carefree, if not downright aggressive. I mean, I believe everyone passed me 2-5 times, even. I kept thinking, tortoise, you're gonna get to the finish line slow and steady and not once are you gonna spin out like them other fools. 

Except this tortoise finished last after all. Little did I know that when you registered, you registered to COMPETE with your group... as in with speed and getting to the finish. By any means necessary. Phooey to that, because then we were met with all these stern rules and threats that we could very well be put off the track if we were driving too recklessly.

So, there I was, penalized and humiliated because I actually followed the rules. 

For once in my life. 

As it turns out, they weren't really rules. None of my daredevil compadres were pulled off the track once, not even in their second race (oh yeah, it's a race alright, don't let your friends let you think otherwise), when I backed out gracefully just to watch them smash bumpers, spin out and all but drive each other off the track just to come in 1st place.

So, there you have it. If you're in it, to win it, by all means bring it. Or however those competitive sports logos go.

In all seriousness, it's a top notch facility. You get a safety run down, a helmet (with a hideous head wrap) and neck roll. It's safe. Don't do what I did and lose out on your time by taking it easy. Don't be a responsible tortoise. 

Go, rabbit, go!

Le parade for the skull and bones set. Lots of satire, lots of skeleton jesters and slightly horror-inspired (but more on the humorous side) imagery. 

Theme had to do with local and national political and celebrity "scandals." Lots of great plays on words and the art on the floats was hilarious. I don't know much about Kim Kardashian, but that float with her and the NBA Players was a riot. 

Favorite walkers: The Skeleton Crew! Genius!!!

It's a loooong parade with a fair amount of stopping. I think it lasted roughly a little over 2 hours.

Yes, they are generous with their throws, but holy hell is the Friday night crowd brutal (and I hear the beginning of the route is nothing compared to the St. Charles crowd). Lots of killer stuff for kids (blinky neon gel gargoyles and skeleton jesters, plush toys). I just got a couple cups and later found a gel necklace that I'll be sending off to a kid who will appreciate it.

Friday night parades are fun and the best thing to do is just sit back and enjoy it. 

My porch!! It's a bead explosion!!

I had what I felt to be an all around extraordinary experience here on my birthday, a night where a meh experience is even less acceptable than normal, so my five stars come in with extra weight. 

From the moment we stepped in the door, I felt really welcome here. The space demands it. I mean, imagine if they were cold and stuffy in a tiny joint like this one? It would be like attending an uncomfortable Thanksgiving dinner where the family hated each other and you, by extension.

We were treated extremely well by the bartender who I think is a manager/hostess. Odd, but I'm not complaining! I saw this women right a wrong at the table next to us that would have had this couple leaving very unhappy otherwise (sometimes you can sense that people are just unhappy and it's very, very hard to turn them around). The atmosphere is quaint, romantic... you could easily arrive dressed casual as you could fancying it up a bit. I remember when this place was a casual wrap joint and I like how they fixed it up so that it's now classy & intimate.

After we were seated (yes, we had reservations. *Recommended!), we were taken care of by our gracious waiter who recited the long, detailed list of specials as if he memorized them with love. After complimenting him on this, he told us that he sincerely loves working here and it's a pleasure to be so informed about the food. Who doesn't want to hear that at the start of a dining experience?

There's an array of tempting salads, but I was intrigued by the special salad, which is just like the Nicoletta salad (mixed greens, red onions, cherry mozzarella cheese and cherry tomato) but instead of being tossed with a basil and balsamic vinaigrette, the dressing was a pesto base. I love all things basil, so I couldn't pass it up. Incredible! I may have licked the plate (no, really, I didn't). 

For dinner, I had the truffle/porcini ravioli, because I love all things truffle similarly to the way I love all things basil. Although it came in what is described as a creamy white wine sauce and I avoid cream sauces, this one was really good and not too heavy as they often are. It is, however, decadent (truffle oil has a way of making anything decadent, doesn't it?). 

And so, despite the best intentions to order the vanilla vodka orange sorbet, I found myself too  full for dessert, as usual. What's a birthday girl to do in New Orleans but to go out for craft cocktails instead, right?

Happy birthday to me!

Red's is without a doubt my favorite place to get Chinese food in New Orleans. Our recent Lundi Gras dinner was one for the books and I'm sitting here now, fondly recalling it. At a time like this (COVID-19), amazing dinner memories are therapeutic and I want to share one of my "last suppers" here!

As you should know, family style reigns here. I'll be the first to admit that I don't like family style. As a vegan, it just doesn't work out for you if you're sharing your meal with meat eaters. Luckily I was with only 2 friends and they knew not to share too much of my food. Heh! I'll stab you with my fork if you take one smashed cucumber too many, OK? Seriously. Those smashed cucumbers are infuckingcredibly delicious. I blame the tahini pool. We also shared the kimchi. Its spicy perfection complimented the other dishes so well.

I broke the rules and devoured my main dish without asking my friends if they wanted to taste it: General Tso's Tofu. The ensuing food fugue makes it almost impossible to recall the details, but know that it's an enormous portion of perfectly fried tofu and broccoli in a sauce that is almost sensuous with its abundance of chilis, soy sauce, garlic, slightly sweet ginger and peanuts. Look, I'm selfish when it comes to a perfect dish of food. No regrets.

And because I was feeling it, at least two Permanent Vacations. All of their cocktails are intriguing. This one is sweet and delicious. I feel like I would die happy drowning in a bath of kaffir lime and lemongrass. Is that wrong? 

Excuse me while I lose myself in this memory. I'll be back later.

A straight-up comfy little spot, Harry's Corner is worthy of its iconic name. If a bar is named Harry, it has to be good or it needs to change its name. Simple as that. And *this* Harry's, I like just fine.

No bells and whistles here, just a Quarter corner bar with seasoned bartenders and cheap enough drinks. I've been in here when packed (Halloween) and empty. Empty is preferable if you're feeling *old and cranky* which BTW is a state of mind that I do my best to avoid, but sometimes it's inevitable.

On that note, I shall create a list of my favorite bars to hit up when in that OAC state of mind...

Welp, Yelp, this ain't so fun to review. But I know it will help a chica out.

I give Dr. Ross 5 stars for the easiest and most comfortable exam I've had, pretty much ever, including my favorite GYN, who was one of the best in New York. The question portion of the exam was also the least invasive I've ever had, which is nice, because I prefer to check that stuff off on a form than give verbal answers (ie, "how many drinks do you have per week?" Who is that going to help, really?) Got my pap done in two seconds and then there's that typically awful part of the exam where it looks like an alien is running around in your abdomen, but Dr. Ross made it comfortable enough and damn quick. Nice, right? She is also overall extremely easy to talk to, as mentioned in other reviews. 

It was also wonderful not to have to wait two months for an annual exam (actually, they had an opening for two weeks away from my call!) 

The only reason for 4 instead of 5 stars is the whole waiting 45 minutes to be seen by the doctor. I just cannot deal with any waste of my time. There has to be a way for this to improve. At least have magazine options that aren't all about parenting in the waiting and exam rooms.

If you don't like wine bars, I'm afraid you and I have nothing in common. 

Even though this one did not have too many food options for the likes of Yours, Truly (a couple salads, a cheese board and the ever present grilled vegetable plate), they did have plenty of wine and a perfectly affordable and good Montepulciano at $34. 

The inside is cozy, dim and charming, but we opted to sit at one of the sidewalk cafe tables (next time I'll have to take a look at that courtyard). This provided endless entertainment as the Quarter was kicking last night. 

I ordered the spinach/goat cheese salad which was quite tasty, although heavily over dressed. Don't get me wrong, it's not like the dressing wasn't good, but I would have preferred twice the amount of spinach. The cheese board is good, but I will say that Bacchanal, Delachaise and Il Posto blows Orleans Grapevine out of the, uh, vineyard with their cheese plates at similar price points. There are four cheeses, one of which I didn't like and it's rare that I meet a cheese I don't like (it had orange bits in it). The cheeses were also not explained by our server and the board was so small, the cheese kept falling off of it. 

That said, I will return here should the opportunity present itself. I am a huge fan of Patrick's Bar Vin located nearby, but they don't do food, so this is a decent alternative in the Quarter.

The. Best. Falafel. I. Have. Ever. Had.

I'm talking *just* the falafel balls themselves, as I didn't order a sandwich, just an app. 

So many places just get these things wrong. Or, maybe they are "right" according to some ancient Lebanese recipe that's been passed through the generations but far too many times I've had to all but choke down (or drown in tahini) falafel that is too dry, too dense and just pasty in flavor. 

Courtyard Grill's falafel is the opposite of the falafel fail: moist, full of delicious flavor (the owner tells us they are made with chick peas and celery) and straight-up delectable. They all but melt in your mouth.

Service is just so nice. You feel like there is a lot of love going on (definitely family-owned and operated). 

Lentil soup is fine and the hummus, a touch tangy (lemony) for my liking. The only real bummer was the truly disturbing condiment bottle placed in front of me (I noticed a strange grey matter in the Crystal *after* I poured it all over my food). A small thing, but these things need to be inspected regularly. I did my best to ignore, as the falafel was just *that* good.

Still can't get them balls outta my head!!

Tiki bars are among my favorite types of bars. From the lush over-the-top Tonga Room in SF to NYC's rock & roll East Village haunt, Otto's Shrunken Head, you really can't go wrong with some palm, tiki torches, orchids and nifty vintage Hawaiian shirts. Blame the love on an early fascination with Disney's Enchanted Tiki Room.

I do admit, however, to not loving those sickening sweet rum concoctions, often a color not known to exist in nature and often set on fire. Pretty to look at, not so pretty to look at the next day if you know what I mean.

Latitude 29 is more craft cocktail purveyor than pina colada slinger. The cocktail list is a compelling list of drinks made with all sorts of spirits, not just rum, with cool names like Mississippi Mermaid and Pontchartrain Pearl Diver (in addition to your classic Zombie and Mai Tai). Ambiance offers a dark, lush bar side (I'm so sitting there next time) and the bamboo-filled, more brightly lit dining room that lends itself better to eating. And really, you should eat here. 

Yes, you can eat here if you're veg, G/F etc. How refreshing. They had me with this statement: "Executive Chef Chris Shortall and his staff are dedicated to creating beautifully composed, modern, playful Tiki Cuisine that includes options for our gluten-free, vegetarian, and vegan guests." I guess I can't stress enough how it good it feels to not have to get apologies and confusion from a waitress and the dreaded/reluctant "I'll have to check with the chef." Other NOLA establishments would do well to start with such a welcoming policy. 

As part of my birthday weekend, I landed here for the first time and I'm an immediate L29-lover. Jen L had informed me that the genius behind the menu was none other than the chef from Twelve Mile Limit so I knew I was in for some good grub.

Oh my god, friends... that's an understatement. I ordered the Bahn Mi. It comes stuffed with lightly fried tofu and pickled veggies, as well as soy mayo and Sri Racha on the side. Get the fries (why wouldn't you?) I couldn't even finish, the portion is that huge. 

And the drinks. I first went for the Hawaii 504 and was pretty blown away by how light, fresh and spicy it is. I mean, the perfect warm weather drink... who am I kidding? The perfect cold weather drink too. What a brilliant twist to sprinkle a little Chinese Five Spice on there, which goes well with the ginger liqueur of course. I then couldn't pass up the idea of Frank Sinatra's favorite Tiki drink and ordered the Navy Grog, which comes with a straw inserted into a huge cone of ice. I knew what I was in for... an extremely strong concoction worthy of Old Blue Eyes, but a little too rumtastic for me, so I switched back to the 504. If you're a fan of strong rum drinks, however, do order the Navy Grog.

Love the atmosphere. Love the cocktails. Love the service (everyone is so nice). I don't love that they close so damn early (11pm on weekends... what?) Welp. I have a new favorite French Quarter bar.

Second visit's the charm! I had a really great pedicure here last week and my only regret is that I didn't get the girl's name. 

For starters, she used a razor to chop away all that dead skin that has been plaguing me. I realize the razor is frowned upon by many people, but with my high arches, the calluses are ghastly, so I need that damn thing. And if I'm paying 25 bucks for a pedicure, well, I expect to walk out without calluses. A vigorous scrub just isn't gonna do it. The nail cutting and polish job, also perfect one week later.

Bonus: my nail tech did not hate me. No mutterings across the room which I translate to mean nothing complimentary. No, "oh my god, your nails are so short, why?" And no foot cramp-inducing massages as punishment either.

Why, oh why did I not get her name?????

Pure crack is more like it.  

I felt drawn to Pure Cake because they had a funny sign outside saying something to the effect of "No, we don't have cupcakes... try a cake pop instead!" (or maybe it was "cupcakes are so passé." JK!) So I felt it was my responsibility to do just that. I tried two, in fact (I shared. I'm all about sharing the sweets). One chocolate peanut butter and one vanilla with salted caramel filling. I refer you to my first sentence. Yep. That good. Not that I've ever tried crack, mind you.

Whereas I've found most cupcakes to be rather pedestrian, dry affairs (with a few exceptions, of course, no disrespect to the bakers who make kickass cupcakes), these cake pops are like cake art. Moist, sweet, decadent-as-a-bon-bon... and fun to eat as well! Plus there's just something undignified about peeling a wrapper and shoving a cupcake into your mouth, leaving a mess of crumbs and frosting all over you, right? Cake pops are both delicious, graceful *and* elegant. I could picture Marie Antoinette eating one. Or, like even Fred Astaire.

Annnnd here we go again! *Full* redemption for Earthsavers, as I returned to an appointment with Nelly and it was a 5-star waxing. You can't get more thorough than this. I mean... waxing, plus tweezers for those stubborn hairs. In and out in 20 minutes. Friendly service. Nothing awkward or brutal (ie, like last time). While I can't call the session fun or relaxing (impossible, let's face it), I do plan to return for regular appointments. I just won't ever stray from Nelly again, though.

Rosalita's Cantina has a really festive atmosphere that reminds me a lot of cantina-style restaurants in San Francisco. They have easily the largest booths I've encountered in my life (no joke! If you're first in, 3 or 4 friends could easily follow, so be sure and figure out who has the smallestl bladder and put them on the end). Large booths makes group dining a much cozier experience.

Not surprisingly, the margarita menu is larger than the food menu here. I'm a plain, on the rocks, salted rim kind of gal, so that kind of thing is lost on me. I'm also not a tequila connoisseur, but if you are, I daresay you'll be satisfied here. 

We started up with an order of table side guac, which is only available on Thursday-Saturdays, so we were out of luck. To be honest, I don't see the allure of table side guac, unless you're really opposed to some of the usual ingredients. I can totally understand this of course, because too many onions can ruin a good guac. That said, a regular order of guac here is very impressive and delicious! The aforementioned onion overload is not a problem, I'm happy to report, and the avocados used within are top notch. The chips and salsa that come out on the table, gratis, are also excellent (let me lament the lack of good salsa in any of the dozens of Mexican restaurants in Kansas City. A major, Mexican't, KC!)

Next up, the tortilla soup which yay, is vegetarian! Unheard of, in my experience. So props to Rosalita's for serving up a tasty tortilla soup that omnivores and vegetarians can enjoy.

The vegetarian burrito, on the other hand, not so good. I had asked the waiter if one of the sauce choices was dairy based because it looked like the word "ranch" was implied (however, if it was more like ranchero sauce, then, awesome. In the Midwest, I must ask, due to the popularity of that detestable dressing). Our waiter said he didn't think so, but when our food came out, and I saw the sauce, I was immediately suspicious. I didn't take a bite, but dipped my fork into it. Sure enough, this burrito baby was smothered in ranch dressing. As I considered this to be an abomination (I'm sorry!), I had to send it back, which I rarely ever do, but under these circumstances...The manager immediately came over and offered to rectify the situation (I mention this because in a previous review someone spoke of the lack of managerial presence in the restaurant). I ordered a tomatillo sauce instead.

I wish I had taken a bite of the first burrito, though, because then I would have changed my order altogether. Instead of being stuffed with a variety of vegetables, it was stuffed with onions. Yes, those damn onions. Personally, I don't consider onions to be a vegetable, but a condiment, so they shouldn't be the main ingredient in a vegetable dish.There were also a few pieces of squash strangled by long strands of onions and a little bit of rice and beans. The tortilla must have been the size of a basketball because it seemed you go through blanket folds of it to get to the inside. Not a fan. Really, really not a fan. 

I would return here and order something else. Or I could just stick to chips, guac and a large tortilla soup and be pretty happy. The service was overall excellent and the staff in general seemed very accommodating and friendly. Rosalita's would be a fab place for a party or large after work gathering.

What the hell, I haven't reviewed St Joe's yet? No, no, let's leave hell out of it. St. Joe's is can be a religious experience... at times. 

Not on weekend nights, though. I worship on weeknights better when mass is less full.

I love the back where you can sit in the chapel, a rather idyllic courtyard or if you smoke, kneel at the pew, I mean, bar area back there, too.

As many times as I've been here, I've yet to form a bond with the ministers behind the bar.Bless me father, I want to sin... and you kind of ignore me.

All in all, a decent place to worship. But I'm not yet really devout.

Let's face it. Waxing is never under any circumstances *fun*- no matter how luxe the environment of a salon or spa may be. And believe you me, Earthsavers has a really soothing environment. The spa is located upstairs from the store that sells an impressive selection of products (yay, Kiehls!!) They put you in a small curtained waiting room if you arrive before your scheduled appointment time. Now's the time to breath deep, take in the smells, relax to the calming music. Look through their catalogue of services ranging from mani/pedis to facials to massage to waxing. I believe these are all unisex, boys!

After all that and when your aesthetician is ready, she greets you and escorts you to... the torture chamber.

*Totally* kidding! It's not that bad. I highly recommend Nelly who will get you through your procedure like a champ. She guides you through it, makes conversation so that you barely are aware of what's going on (barely. heh!) She takes her time, if you need it, say, to take a break, etc. I swear it's not bad. And yes, a 5-star service all around. This, I say at the risk of Nelly being all booked up henceforth. It's not easy finding someone who makes you feel comfortable during such a procedure. Simple as that.

Off topic. Does anyone else feel compelled to scream out KELLY CLARKSON during a wax? I've only seen 40 year old Virgin twice, but that waxing scene is the stuff of comic genius.

Although I acknowledge that I tempt screams of blasphemy, I'm gonna come out and admit it:

I never liked pancakes. 

Wait! Don't hate! Because guess what? I am totally on board with crêpes which, in my opinion, are the Audrey Hepburn of pancakes. 

Seriously, don't hate.

For here is a glowing endorsement of Crêpes Etc. where you will have a delightful breakfast experience. You will have crêpes that will make you forget that a pancake ever existed. I daresay there is no such thing as a Caprese *pancake* yet here, there are Caprese crêpes! And these are so delicious, they may make you cry.

Description: savory crêpe wrapped around slices of *fresh* mozzarella, tomatoes, basil and spinach leaves. Smothered in a delectable mornay sauce. 

Are you still hating me? 

Didn't think so.

And now for an update on the new additions to the cocktail menu!

To be perfectly honest, lately I've been avoiding hard liquor and although I come here regularly and that gorgeous tiki drink menu tempts me, I stick to sparkling wine (I know. Killjoy). But when we came here for dinner the other night, our waiter told us about the new drinks on the menu, the Deadbeat Daiquiri (described as a not overly sweet Piña Colada) and a punch (forgot the name and the online menu hasn't been updated) that sounded like it had tons of booze in it, so I went for the Daiquiri.

This is the best daiquiri I've ever had *and*  (I'm gonna call it like it is) the best damn Piña Colada I have ever had. I absolutely "get" why they don't call it that because true Piña lovers are going to be cranky about the lack of tooth ache sweetness and phony baloney sugary drink mix. But this Daiquiri is divine! It has a rich, fresh coconutty flavor. It's blended, but not a super icy texture like most daiquiris are in this city. It just fucking delicious. And perfectly strong.

My guy had the punch and naturally I had to try it. I'm so not shying away from it next time! It's strong, yes, but the tropical flavors are so fresh and I love that passionfruit seems to dominate. It's also not sickeningly sweet.

On that note, the drinks here are crafted so that you're getting such good quality spirits and juices, that your days of suffering the dragon bowl hangover the next day are over. You get me here. 

I didn't know I could love Latitude 29 even more, but there you have it.

Waxing woes... Let's start at the end. I walked home shaking and crying. You may think I'm a downright wuss, but I have inner arm, sternum and clavical tattoos that caused half the pain of the other day's 35 minute Brazilian wax job at Earthsavers.

I hesitate to write this review for a couple reasons, mainly because it's totally TMI. I'm not going to share on FB lest my mom read it and become disappointed in me for being extremely unladylike and perhaps even a bit graphic on Yelp. But I look at it as my duty to protect prospective customers from horrific experiences like the one I recently endured. 

Stupidly, when making the appointment, I didn't ask for Nelly this visit. Let that be known from the get go as I've had Nelly done my wax jobs before and found her to be top notch. 

I've waited several days since the appointment to make sure I didn't write the under the influence of pain or anger. 

I won't name the technician in this review. I'm in this conundrum. I don't want to mess with this torturer's, I mean *woman*'s livelihood, but I also can't help but think she should find another career. Say, prison guard. At Rikers. I'm sorry, but I don't think those folks deserve that either. 

I can't tell if she's a true sadist, because despite some awkward conversation held for seconds while my most tender region was being ripped and pulled repeatedly, she was silent. Instead of keeping my mind off of the procedure at hand, all I could do was silently scream in my head, as I quivered and begged for the bullet. I would have rocked, too but that's hard to do in goddess pose. 

Now I ask you, wouldn't any seasoned professional technician NOT pour hot wax onto the same spots over and over again? But this woman did just that and kept doing that with no more than a "You need to get numbing cream from your doctor next time." Like there would be a next time. No GYN exam has been 1/10 as traumatic. 

I had to wonder... am I being punked? But, no. There were no cameras. Just the bitter glare of the high wattage light bulbs overhead burning into my retinas. Say something? I *yelled* something. Twice. And it wasn't "Kelly Clarkson!" Safe words don't exist in the waxing world, my friends. I would have made her stop but I knew I'd be paying greatly for this "service" whether I continued or not (Earthsavers, in their infinite wisdom, charges you for "missed" appointments and warn you repeatedly when making the appointment). 

So, after 15 minutes I turned off and went into survival mode where I was staring into space barely existing anymore. Seriously. In that moment I became one with Sybil. I composed songs. Sonnets. Yelp reviews. This horror show lasted a full 35 minutes. It never took that long before.

So, Earthsavers, I bid you farewell. I loved Nelly but I will never step foot into your place again when I know that you keep on a woman who should not be allowed to bear a wax wand. No less in a posh spa where a Brazillian runs you 70 bucks before tip. That's the thing. If you're going to charge more than anywhere else in town, then you better damn well be sure your technicians are top notch. Or at least capable. And there's this thing where when you're done with getting a service at a so-called posh spa, where they ask you how was everything. That didn't happen and the girl who took my card barely noticed that I was clearly disturbed.

Oh well, at least my house is spotless. Cleaning sprees. The cheapest therapy. 

And now, I shall go to the some kind of medical supply store to see if they will sell me one of those rubber donuts they give women after childbirth.

My first mani pedi in New Orleans, I review Star Nails a bit hesitantly and with a disclaimer: realize I don't actually like getting these services done and only consider them a means to an end. 

I was on the bus recently and shamelessly eavesdropped these two ladies' conversations (well, they were talking pretty loudly). One was a tourist and one was someone who moved here a year ago and they were talking manicures. And how it's impossible to get your nails done for cheap in this city. I took that as a warning and waited until I absolutely had to get the job done (I hope no one saw my cuticles in the meantime). I come from the land of the cheap nail salon and once I left a couple years ago came to realize that people in the US pay a pretty penny to have decent nails.

See, I practically go in kicking and screaming. To pay a lot for this is adding insult to injury. It's just that it's an uncomfortable experience for me to have some stranger handling my paws. I hate that it takes well over an hour, no matter how fast they are and in that time, I obviously can't use my hands to get work done or check my phone. And I have sensitive feet and hate the way some of these pedicurists use their crazy strong hands to wring them out like they are trying to kill small animals. Then when it comes time for the manicure I am usually made fun of and told I have baby nails or "so short!" I hate long nails!! I use my hands a lot. I hate having nails past the nail bed. Yes, they are small. Whatever. At least they aren't covered in rot, bitches.

Suffice to say, I just hate the entire experience. What I hate even more is paying top dollar for it. At Star Nails, a regular manicure/pedicure is 39 dollars. 

And then there's the inevitable: After all this, after wasting a precious 90-120 minutes, I WILL smudge my nails. Unless I get gel or shellac, but if a regular manicure was this pricey, I didn't want to even think about getting shellac. 

The good:
The salon is large. You won't have to wait. There's a big fish tank you can gaze at to calm down while your hands and feet are being mauled, I mean, tended to. My nail tech was fine, not overly talkative and I guess I felt like she only hated me a little (let's be real here, don't you always feel like they hate you?), and that was when I immediately smudged the so-so polish job she did on my fingernails. My toenails, which usually stay pretty pristine for the most part, already have a chip in them four days later and forget my fingernails, they are toast. (the polish was definitely too thick. I sat for twenty annoying minutes under the dryer and they still smudged a half hour later. the next day I was using tape and that meant goodbye manicure).

So, I've learned a couple things:
1. Shellac/gel is the only manicure I should bother paying for
2. It may be the nail tech's fault for using thick coats, but I'm pretty sure that OPI had seen better days.
3. I need to rate salons from the perspective of a normal person. Hence, Joi B would have given Star Nails one star for all the agita it caused her. But responsible Joi B rates them 3 stars because that's probably fair. 

At least it's not a day spa where I'd probably pay an additional 20 dollars for the so-called "relaxing experience."

So Crowded. So Unreliable. So Slow. A veritable transportation trisuckta, right? But...

You've gotta ride it and you've gotta love it! 

If you're just visiting the city, and you keep in mind that you're not using this as a mode of transportation, but a sight seeing vehicle, you're fine. Wait! I take that back. You need to keep in mind that locals actually *do* use this as a mode of transportation. Be polite. Have your damn cash ready to give the driver and step aside to let people on and off. Also, don't jump in front of it because it'll hit you and that will cause major delays and inconveniences to people trying to get to work.

(I love when I can use a Yelp review as a vehicle for lecturing people, don't you?)

I love the smell of vintage clothing stores. Perhaps it's just a conditioned response to the delights that I know are in store for me, as I slip between the racks and start hunting. 

I have an ardent appreciation for clothing pre- 1967. From what I could see, Retro Active has mostly 50s/60s/70s... some 80s (in my world, that ain't vintage. Well, at least I don't want to admit it's vintage), but we'll forgive them for that little transgression (and I do realize the kids today love wearing this stuff so they can be all ironic and stuff). Sure, I'd love to see earlier decades represented here and other stores, but it's increasingly rare with each passing year. I try to keep care of my 20s-40s clothing and really can't even wear it anymore because all too often it falls apart *as I'm wearing it*.

Unlike some earlier reviews suggest, I don't find this store at all overwhelming, nor did I see anything "creepy" or "bizarre." It's just a vintage clothing store with a decent selection. Maybe there's another part of it that I didn't see? Wait, maybe *I'm* creepy and bizarre?

Loved the window displays for St. Paddy's day and the cute pup who greeted me at the door. The ladies who work here are helpful without being overbearing. Seriously, I don't know if there's been a change in ownership or what, but this store is just like the vintage clothing stores I've loved forever. Prices seem to be competitive with stores I've shopped in Chicago, San Fran and Kansas City. And yes, a bit lower than New York, where I rarely if ever can even find decent vintage anymore. 

I adore beaded vintage sweaters from the 1950s. Often these are very pricey little numbers, especially if in good condition, as they can be quite fragile. I've had a few that I had to toss just because everywhere I went, I would rain tiny beads. While that may sound all magical and stuff, it really sucks. Retro Active has a decent selection of these sweaters. I found a lovely cream colored one for about 70 dollars (and the beads were tightly sewn in). Only it's over 80 degrees out today and I just couldn't justify buying it, when I have a drawer full of these babies and barely anything that's remotely presentable for warm weather. It was hard, but I put it back.

If you like vintage jewelry, hats, gloves and other accessories, you will love love love this store, by the way. I even saw a gorgeous old umbrella. Even umbrellas were pretty back in the day. I'm sure these were less dispensable, unlike nowadays when you buy a cheap umbrella for a single use. They have plenty of coats, too and a nice selection of vintage lingerie. Another irresponsible purchase I almost made: a princess style nylon nightgown that's similar to one I have and wear as a dress. I guess one only needs one of these, though, right?

In closing, as much as I'm trying to make more responsible purchases these days, due to my an closet that holds close to 100 vintage items, stores like Retro Active are still a hell of a lot of fun and one day soon, it's inevitable that I'll be off the budget wagon, so I'm glad it's here in New Orleans!

I have my favorite coffee shops in town in which to sit, socialize and/or work, but I can easily say that Merchant makes the best Americano with steamed soy. It's strong and smooth with a tinge of bitterness. So, the five stars are for the perfect man... I mean perfect cup of coffee. 

Now, if you're looking for a cozy coffee shop kind of vibe, Merchant doesn't have that. No big deal to me, though, because I like that little loungey space that's to the side of the main room (in the hallway of the adjoining building). It's very attractive, bright and modern and, most important, has *tons* of outlets in the floor! I'd come here for a glass of wine early in the evening. It's quite tranquil.

Extremely nice service is a departure from the universally taciturn barista type... (especially in a place where the coffee is masterfully prepared and served). 

Can't wait to try the crêpes!

I'm a firm believer that too much fusion means for mediocrity across the board. Hoshun promises Japanese, Chinese, Vietnamese, and even Thai food. Despite four pages of menu options, only the sushi appealed to me (there is one single vegetarian option on the menu: a rather pedestrian sounding vegetables in brown sauce dish).

Then there's the *con*fusion. I mean, deep fried Chinese noodles served alongside miso soup... have you ever? I chalked it off to purely unintentional camp. That said, the miso soup is really damn good, not fishy tasting like other miso soups I've had, as traditionally there is some bonito (fish) stock involved in the making. 

I went with my gut and ignored the other regional cuisines and had my sushi usual- avocado cucumber roll, which was done right, although jeez, could they spare a couple more sesame seeds on the rice? My plate happened to be sans ginger/wasabi. Sure, sure, I could have shared my guy's, but I happen to typically eat all the ginger that comes with. Also, I know that's a huge no-no in any place that takes their sushi seriously. When I worked in an authentic Japanese restaurant, if I accidentally grabbed a sushi plate off the bar before the chef had garnished it, he would really freak out, so I learned quick. 

Luckily Hoshun's staff is really great and attentive, so I received a small dish of the missing gingerwasabi right quick, despite it being a busy night, and despite the fact that they had the bartender waiting tables in between shaking up tons of girly girl martinis for the table of 20 next to us. Oh and add me to the annoying martini orders. Two lychee martinis. I couldn't resist! Props to George. He rocked it last night.

With a fair number of non fushion Japanese options in town, I think I'd probably hit up Hoshun when I'm dying to eat something that's not a sandwich after 11pm. 

I will say I probably would have given 4 stars if I had eaten here between 11pm and 2am (gotta love the late hours they sport!) Otherwise, that menu needs some help, i.e. editing, I think. They really americanize everything-- even the sushi names are in English. Most of us know sushi by the Japanese word (toro, unagi, kappa, tekka etc.) My boyfriend was actually thrown off to the point where he didn't even know what to order. Funny, but true! Again, I'll bring up the issue with serving Chinese fried noodles with the soup. That's not authentically Chinese, but authentically Chinese for Americans (I'm kind of surprised they don't have Chicken Chow Mein on the menu). Believe me, I am not implying I'm up for eating authentic Chinese delicacies either, but some balance would be cool.  As such, the restaurant feels a bit dated. Sure in the first half of the century, Americans flocked to Chop Suey joints, thinking they were eating exotic foods of "The Orient," but I think we've evolved since then. Give us some credit, Hoshun!

Now that I've had Superfood Bar's Green Avocado smoothie, I fear I may never be the same again. I'll glance at my daily green juice with woe. I'll choke it down, visions of Superfood Bar's green goddess-like drink, which is creamier, richer, and if possible, even healthier than my daily dose of kale, spinach, ginger, celery and apple. Containing such glamorous-and mysterious- ingredients as frozen coconut kefir, pro-biotic water, VMG and homemade Greenola, I believe the name of the drink should be Ambrosia.

It's OK. Superfood Bar is just a mile from my house. A good walk on a nice day. It's $8 and I deserve it. You deserve it. We'll all become superheros if we keep drinking this way. I'm up for the challenge.

But Superfood Bar, you've ruined me for healthy juice and smoothies forever.

Sweeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeet jaysus! I confess, I strayed from my beloved tart the other day because I was wooed by an array of flashy, slutty flavors at FroYo. I sampled: red velvet cake, cookies & cream, cake batter, and cheese cake. Slatterns! What the hell was I thinking? At one point, I think they all pretty started tasting the same. 

There's also a lot of topping choices (but no *cherries*). The asking price seems typical and I know plenty of people prefer sweet stuff, so if you're one of those people, you will love the slutty offerings from FroYo!

Witches are some of my favorite people and I cannot deny feeling a little bit spell-bound after leaving Kitchen Witch. Cookbook and vintage kitchen gadget bliss! As soon as I walked into this darling shop, I was smitten because besides piles upon piles of books, there were artfully arranged kitchen "scenes" conjuring up memories for just about anyone who grew up in a home where mom liked to cook. I just wanted to curl up next to the gorgeous 1950s gas stove and read Betty Crocker cookbooks (the ones with really unhealthy recipes, of course). 

But it's not just a nostalgia trip. Some of the books are indeed vintage but they have new books for every kind of diet and interest (vegan, New Oreans/LA cooking, gluten-free, etc). And the owner is nice as pie, too. We came in for the sole purpose of buying a rolling pin and were delighted to see an entire section of vintage rolling pins! We took two up to the counter when we were apologetically told by the kind owner that these are among the few items in the store that are not for sale. Sadness! But we couldn't be too sad because she has a way of turning a frowns upside down in a jiffy (she's a good witch, remember!). She referred us to a kitchen gadget store a little up Broad (who knew?) and we were on our way.

I didn't mention two other important things: there is a tortie cat on the premises.

And. A vegan pop up most Fridays!

After coughing up 20 bucks to see Tab Benoit and Big Chief Boudreaux the other night, I settled into Publiq House and decided it's a great to place to see a show...

It was hard for me at first to grant a fourth star because... $20?! In the end, no matter how many cool repurposed wooden shutters and old window frames that decorate every inch of the space, you're there for music first and foremost, and why is that cover so high? Ok, Ok, Grammy-nominated artist. I get it. Grumble Grumble. And to be fair, I just looked up other shows and find them mainly in the $15 high end, $5 low *and* there's an all night HH on Mondays. Ladies night on Wednesdays. I can get behind all of this. Four stars it is.
