Props to the wall of frozen drink machines that will be nice come warmer temps. Also, that side patio. And no smoking policy.

I do prefer DBA for live local music (and living walking distance away is a big plus, I can't lie nor deny), but Publiq House is definitely on my list for being worth the drive Uptown.

Just noticed that this review is for the one on Decatur when I meant it for the one on Royal! Although the quality of the product holds true, and my experience at the Decatur location was just as good as the one on Royal, I can't say that this place gets the same line out the door on Sunday! 

Therefore, the review stays, I'll add one for the Royal location and hey, maybe check this place out if you're nearby and in more of a hurry! It's definitely in a part of town that's on the way to other things (ie, the CBD, Canal St., the St. Charles Trolley, etc), from the Quarter, so it's convenient to stop in for a cup on the way to a day full of touristic exploration (and I prefer it to PJs on Canal). If I were staying on Canal, this would be my go-to place for sure.

It's over 100 with the heat index.

It's early afternoon.

Or first thing in the morning (early afternoon).

Or really late at night.

Hot. Bleary eyed. Lethargic.

*Cue the sound of the zombies*

mmmmmmmm Frozen Irish Coffee mmmmmmmmmmmmm


Must. Have. Now.

For those of us who find a certain kind of charm in waitresses who might shout, "kiss my grits" without an ounce of irony, this is the place for you. 

Yes, we sat at our table for a good 15 minutes before we got our menus. Yes, they were out of half the items on the menu ("it's coming...but so is Christmas"). Yes, the food arrived lukewarm after a 45 minute wait. If you're like most folks these days, none of that is acceptable. 

That said. I LOVED our waitress so much that I would surely return (preferably  on a less busy day). You must keep in mind that this was a Sunday afternoon, on Halloween and during a big football game that had the place packed to the rafters (luckily we were seated at a big table no where near the damn TV), so a top-notch experiences wasn't to be expected (every restaurant in the vicinity had lines out the door). 

Our girl handled the crowd like a pro (even if she forgot a few things), was friendly in that way that meant you'd forgive a lot of her, and she was funny as hell. She was also prone to saying "Our fried chicken ROCKS!" which is an unusual way to think of fried chicken. The best part: while I was hemming and hawing over what the hell to order because every single thing I wanted was coming along with Santa Claus (including the grits I was so in the mood for), she deftly applied lipstick (after saying "excuse me" first, of course). You just don't get that kind of sass in a waitress these days.

We had an awesome spot that wasn't in the packed dining room, but in the vestibule area before you enter. This was a great people watching spot that made our brunch even better. 

I can't say much for the food, except for the fried pickles which were thin chips, just like I like them. I'd advise against ordering the "bread in basket" which sounded amazing, but is basically toasted bread with crumbled parm on top (ew) and a big bowl of not very amazing tomato sauce on the side. 

And the fried chicken? It did indeed "rock" as promised, according to my dining companions.

I like. I like a whole lot.

So, you know the score by now. I had sworn off all nail salons in the city except for Magazine Nails, which gave me the best pedicure, like, ever. Althought it is an all around good experience, there's a lot left to be desired for gel manicures (my most recent one there lasted less than a week). I had decided that I could live with the meh gel manicures because those pedicures are *that* fabulous.

At Lilly's, it's the other way around. Similar to Magazine Nails, the technicians are super nice (unlike Star Nails where I've yet to have a technician that isn't surly and/or makes fun of me in another language. Yeah, yeah, they *are* - and they seem to have supersonic hearing and projecting skills, with the muttering and mumbling under their breath and then, I SWEAR TO FUCKING GOD, someone across the room answers them. Call me paranoid. I'm done).

I'll admit I was a bit hesitant after receiving a pedicure that was nowhere in the same league as Magazine Nails. BUT::: the gel manicure is absolutely a 5-star experience. My hands and nails look perfectly acceptable, nay, *gorgeous*!!! No tiny bits left on the cuticles that cause the rest of the nail to peel off within days, either.

So, it's looking like I'm going to be going to two different nail salons for mani/pedis from here on out, but I can live with that. The price is right, too. A tiny bit cheaper than Magazine Nails.

A review is long past due and I'm making it up for it by giving 1808 Grille the five stars they rightfully deserve. 

I stay in hotels pretty often and come hell or high water, I do whatever it takes to not eat in their affiliated restaurants. I'm also one of those rare souls that actually doesn't like room service. 1808 changes all that, though, and I would even go so far as to say I'd enthusiastically eat (and drink-- lovely bar area!) here even if I wasn't staying at my beloved Hutton Hotel. 

Similar to the superb customer service at the Hutton, 1808 goes above and beyond what you'd expect to accommodate their customers with a tempting menu that they are able to adjust for various diets. There are always vegetarian options. There are always vegan options. They change seasonally along with rest of the menu (ever notice how some restaurants have the perpetual butternut squash ravioli, even when that stuff isn't in season? Are you bored with butternut squash ravioli as much as I am?)

Come breakfast time, I'm happily accommodated with a non dairy milk option for my latte. Come lunch time, there's vegetable entrees-aplenty. I love their quinoa dish of the season, but I recently opted for one of the main dishes that came along with three glorious sides. As this dish changes seasonally, all I will tell you is to trust them. They do magical things with vegetables, my friends.

Finally, did you know they have their own signature batch of bourbon? Oh it's true and yes, I sampled it, despite not being a brown liquor kinda girl. It's smooth & smoky and best sipped neat.

Before ending this review, I must tip my hat to the servers. They are the best! They will go out of their way to make your visit sublime.

It's December 23 and if you're anything like me, you probably have a bunch of gifts left that need to be bought STAT! Maybe you even have a mulled wine hangover and can't bear the idea of shopping all day around town. Maybe even the idea of taking a stroll down Magazine St. is too intimidating for you. I'm here to say... get off  your tuchus and DO IT! I'll even make it easier for you... head straight to Miss Smarty Pants. 

This will be your one-stop shop for any gal in your life (and even a guy or two). Think arty/bohemian-but still extremely classy- accessories and home accents. Think lovely framed pictures, chic ornaments and magnets, flashy jewelry and delish smelly candles. I'm kind of in love with this store and want to marry it. I mean, get married in it. Or at least visit it regularly and frolic about.

There ya go. Bonus points if you can hit up Plum across the street for even more quirky gifts and ornaments and Scriptura down the block for the wrappings... the people in your life will love your for it.

This one goes out to the mechanics I love...

Yeah, yeah, this station is fine for gas (they have diesel, which my car requires and if you have a car that only takes diesel, you know how it can be a pain in the ass to find a gas station. Pro tip: Diesel fumes will get you going the extra mile). Prices, I can't really talk much about because I don't pay attention to that (cue the sound of my dad cursing gas stations and driving the extra mile to the one that offers gas for a couple cents a gallon cheaper. But I didn't inherit his frugal sensibilities. I'm a lover of conveniences). 

This review, however, is for the brake tag renewals. I had long been warned that this is an annoying process in this city and that many people put it off for months past expiration. Maybe that's true. In general, I put off anything car-related. I mean, I'd sooner go to the dentist, truth be told. It's wrong. I love my Beetle, but UGH all I can think about is waiting and waiting for shit to be done. Wasting my time. Though of course it's not a waste of time. 

I figured I'd get it all done in one fell swoop. My oil hadn't been changed in over 14 months (yes, you're reading that right. I don't drive all that much) I was still driving on a donut from Isaac, around 9 months prior. I shit you not. Yeah, that's me. I probably don't even deserve my dream car (a Bitchin' Camero, if you must know). Aaaand I was ONLY a week past my brake tag expiration (go me!)

I wait on line for about 5minutes before the most kind lady in the universe took my cash (CASH ONLY for brake tags) and noted the burnt out left headlight. "Want to get this fixed now?" she asked casually. "Sure, plus I'd like to get my oil changed, plus a new tire."

I pulled my car around and met up with an angel mechanic prone to saying "oil" just like grandma used to. "Ya wanna get your ERL changed too?" 

I went over everything and disappeared in CCs down the block for an hour. When I returned, the angel mechanic informed me that they can't replace headlights on a VW, and the tire I needed wasn't actually in stock. He also sagely advised me the following, "That erl was really black. You should change it more often..." But he didn't speak to me like I was a moron girl. He was practically avuncular. 

"Now, we're just gonna go ahead and give you them brake tags anyway..."

*SCREEEEECH* WHA??????

Swallowing back my marriage proposal, I took the bill inside whereupon I paid a very nice cashier who complimented me on my style and reminded me again about getting that "erl" changed more often. I can't for the life of me remember HOW often, and the mileage they wrote on the window decal was less than the mileage on my speedometer, so I can't really go by that, but it's all good.

With that I was on my way.

Shell Station Uptown, I love you.

I'm sure this is blasphemous in some parts but I'm not the biggest fan of Leidenheimer bread. I hope we can still be friends. The good news (for me) is that Parkway's po-boys are made on French bread made on the premises! And it's dang delicious.

We all have friends visiting us in search of that illusive "best po-boy." I pretty much go by what my trusted cronies on Yelp say because I don't eat roast beef, nor do I eat oysters either. I like Mahoney's, though they always have that line plus it takes 20 min or more to serve you. So unless I'm willing to kill an afternoon (which is never), it's not happening. I'm also a fan of Freret Street Po-Boys. But, I also wanted to try something new, so I brought my friend who was visiting and in dire need of a roast beef po-boy, to Parkway.

There's several options for seating: inside the bar, which is dim, charming and tavern-like as the name implies, in the brightly lit side room or on the patio. We picked the bar, as it was a particularly muggy and buggy night.

The bartender here was extremely nice and really went out of his way to make sure we had all that we needed (I had figured it'd be a serve yourself kind of operation). I was pretty thrilled to see a dedicated vegetarian section of the menu and although it's not exactly thrillsville in options, you never can go wrong with a Caprese sandwich, right? Vegans can get a plain ol lettuce and tomato sandwich which makes me really glad I'm not vegan anymore, just sayin'. I think there is a French fry one, too and that's about it. I was just happy to see that I didn't have only one (fried) option!

The sandwich can be ordered in small (6 inches) or large (12 inches). I ordered a large, figuring I'd eat the other half for lunch the next day. I advise that you don't do this because the balsamic vinegar soaks through the bottom half of the bread and makes it a kinda gross mush, so it does not hold up very well. So suck it in and eat up both halfs. You know you want to.

The sandwich comes absolutely loaded with ingredients! The mozz is fresh, possibly Buffalo, not sure, but definitely not the low moisture stuff. It will come out cold, just like a Caprese salad. Oh and I recommend the potato salad, too. The perfect compliment to your po-boy.

So, yay, I have another notch on my belt of po-boy adventures.

If you are looking to buy someone a gift that's a souvenir of New Orleans, and wish to get something a bit more special than a mask, beads or alligator head (hey, I'm not knocking those items either), check out Sterling Silvia. I visited this recently opened shop (their FQ location has been open 30 years, as I was told by the owner) the other day and was blown away by the lovely designs engraved into the rings, bracelets and pendants. I'll let you in on a secret, if you don't already know, these are designed by none other than Cristy A!

I had a really enjoyable shopping experience here. I felt like I could talk with Cristy's mom, who was working that day, for hours about the inspiration for the designs and the stories behind some of the other nifty gift items in the store (ornaments, housewares and accessories) I wasn't there just for talking, though. I also purchased a gift for my mom. It's a key pendant with a fleur de lis and St. Louis Cathedral on it on a fine silver chain. The collection ranges from larger statement pieces- medallions and bracelet cuffs to more delicate, like what I got my mom.

I daresay anyone would appreciate gifts with New Orleans flavor and flair and Sterling Silvia is yet another locally owned store that makes holiday shopping so easy for us!

I see a movie in the theater an average of twice a year. I used to go once a week. I blame the internet. I also blame the audience. I've turned into one of *those* people. The ones with movie rules: no whispering, no annoying paper crinkles, and I will never ever see a horror movie again in the theater because people screaming (that is, those in the audience) make want to stab them repeatedly. Funny, that. The worst offenders are in any NYC movie theater, by the way. I think I was so shaken up there, that I stopped going altogether in 2008 or so. Once I left NY, I found that any theater that has booze readily available is a theater that will get me out of the bar and into a comfy seat to gaze at the big screen.

And not to keep complaining, but last year's experience in a similar theater to this one (but it's AMC in Kansas City), where they jack up the prices so that you have the privilege of waitstaff walking in front of you to serve others... and then there's the people who make loud masticating sounds thanks to eating a full meal in the theater... UGH fucking kill me, OK? Like I can concentrate on a movie at that point. 

Theatres at Canal Place is making a believer of me yet. I haven't gone to a movie theater in a mall since I was in high school, for crying out loud. I didn't know what to expect. 

Maybe it was the movie (Beasts of the Southern Wild), because it blew me away, but maybe it was the bottle of wine, reasonably priced at 36.00... or maybe it was the truffle popcorn-or the black pepper/parm (I was hungry) that we ate quietly... or maybe it was the comfy seats. Or maybe people in Louisiana aren't annoying movie audiences the way they are elsewhere. Who knows?

Reserved seating means for me not having to get there 45 minutes early. And really, there's not a bad seat in the house, including the front row. 

I like it. Maybe I love it.  And I will be back.

CC's and I go way back. For a chain, they make a damn good cup of coffee (hey, at least it's a local chain!) Their coffee houses sell their premium blends, while you can get their standard roasts and chicory blends at any area grocery store (and from what I've heard, it's preferred by locals, over Cafe du Monde). I liken the stuff to Cafe Bustelo, the only acceptable grocery store coffee, in my world! 

Besides their coffee, I'm a huge fan of their branding! Years ago, I'd buy their coffee online and I couldn't resist their fab retro coffee mugs (one fashioned after a 1930s cup with their old logo and another after a 1960s style). Not sure if they still sell them, because I fear if I go to their website, I'll buy yet more mugs and I have no place to put them! Yes, I have a mug problem. As we speak, I'm drinking my morning brew out of a giant Loveless Cafe mug.

Baristas here are nice, if a bit slow (on weekends, lines are to the door) and will do their best to get you your coffee just how you want it (hence the potential slowwwwwwness). Hey, it's New Orleans! Accept that people move a bit more slowly (makes sense if you've ever been there in the months of June, July or August) and all will be OK.

This review is for Alexis Kyman's pop-up yoga classes that started today at Crescent Lotus. For those of you who don't know, Alexis was a popular teacher at Life Yoga on Magazine Street before moving out on her own.

The originator of "funky flow" (as far as I know), Alexis' classes offer a vigorous Vinyasa class (*at your level* as they are open to all levels) to hip hop/R&B and dancey pop music. Yes, this goes outside the "yoga box," so if you're used to traditional citar/chanting and a soft spoken teacher it may be jarring at first. Alexis teaches the class in a spirited way with a unique voice and presentation. It really gears you up to get going  and flow, flow, flow your heart out and I love it. 

Besides all of this, classes are the lowest priced you'll find in the city, at only $5 a class. The room is large and mirrored, the floor is wood (it's meant for dancers, after all) and at a comfortable temperature.

I mention all of this because I've realized that this is rather important to me. Don't get me wrong. I like to sweat, but I like to sweat because I'm generating my own sweat, not due to a room being 90 degrees (or if you practice Bikram, well over 100 degrees). 

Yesterday, I took a class at Life, who has some of my favorite teachers in the city, that had me a little less than blissful by the end of it. The reason for this? The room was stifling to the point that I couldn't hold postures because I was slipping off my mat. Windows and front door open and fans running should be a requirement if the a/c is off. In addition to this, they pack in students to the tiny railroad studio to the point where if you're next to the wall, you're kind of blocked *and* due to this, one of the students knocked a statue off and onto the floor, creating a mess of debris all over my mat. Sure, I can try and be as yogini-like as the next person, but it was a bit much to handle. I'm really at the point where if I have the time to not just run across the street to practice, I'm going to practice elsewhere. I love Life, I love the teachers, but I think they've outgrown their space. Bravo for them... and it's great to see so many people into yoga here in New Orleans (where I love practicing more than anywhere else b/c it's so much less competitive in feel than, say, New York City).

I feel bad that I'm littering Crescent Lotus' page with all of this when I'm just trying to leave them a good review. But maybe it will help you if you're trying to make a decision for a Sunday midday class.

 I hope Alexis' classes continue and grow here (in addition to Sundays, I mean).

Supergirl back to report on the expansion of Superfood Bar! They took over the next door storefront to allow for a dining room and a larger kitchen area in the original tiny storefront. I also noticed some new additions to the menu, including a raw falafel salad that is out of this world. The falafel is made of raw seeds and spices and tastes far better than an actual falafel (which at their worst, I find to taste rather pasty and sometimes like the oil needs to be changed. Gross!) I might also add that the tahini dressing is magical.

I spied a fantastic deal where you get 7 salads or wraps, plus 7 juices or smoothies for the low price of 100 dollars (must use it in the span of 10 days). I figure that would be 2 meals a day and would solve my problem of getting sick to death of the same damn massaged kale salad I eat day in and day out, not to mention my out of control Whole Paychecks. The *only* issue would be the trip Uptown daily to get fresh juices, as I figure the salads/wraps can be bought a couple days in advance. I'll have to think on a way to make this work. Or maybe by some miracle, they'll do a delivery service? Hint hint :) This supergirl still hasn't mastered her flying powers and detests driving.

Anyway, I'm really happy that there's a place with such raw talent in the kitchen that gives us all super powers. Blizzow!!!!!

Open only a week and so far, so so good! Stopped in for the first time this evening. You'd think that I probably need to go back about 5 more times before I write a review, but trust me friends, in a week that 5 times will have happened. So might as well go for it now. Not to mention, there's that handy dandy "update my review" feature on Yelp.

Faubourg Wines is so nubile it glows. Perhaps it has to do with some kind on Dionysian ritual, but whatever. It works for me. Part wine shop, part wine bar ($5 glasses? Yes, please), this is where you may find me in upcoming days throwing back a glass or two, stealing the free WIFI, meeting up with a friend or drinking alone and staring into space. 

So be it. A fine place to do any of that. This evening I walked away with two reasonably priced bottles and a vow to return.

Love love love Rue! Where else can you sit in a refurbished old timey bank and enjoy a well-prepared latte? 
 
Although the atmosphere in December was a bit hushed due to all the students frantically preparing for finals (hard to get a seat midday), there's still something really inspiring about working/writing in this environment. I really like it! Also conveniently located to shops and restaurants on Oak, if you need to get out and take a quick break. Although those sandwiches coming out looked mighty tasty and tempting enough to make us think twice about heading out to lunch.

Cash only!

Hoooray for Mojo's new location on Freret! Being that I'm a Downtown dweller these days, you may be wondering what I'm cheering about because realistically, at about a 15-30 min commute depending on traffic, it sure ain't gonna be my neighborhood coffee joint! I give Mojo's the honor of being a *destination coffee joint* 

Why?

-delicious iced coffee
-almond milk options
-accepts cards unlike the Magazine location
-has extremely nice staff (a note on the staff on Magazine: I've stopped going due to a certain male barista who made my drink wrong the last two times and when I corrected him, he didn't look at me, didn't say anything, merely dumped my coffee down the drain and sullenly made me a new one. Call me neurotic but once I think a barista hates me, I never return to a coffee shop. I'm seriously a nice person who always tips, I swear!)
-TONS of outlets
-plenty of seating
-spacious
-lots of natural light
-clean, amazing bathrooms
-delectable-lookin' baked goods that I understand are as good as they look

Really, it's everything I need in a coffee shop. WTG MOJO!!!

Let me start off by saying I love Saint Louis. Lovely city. Really great food, bars, architecture, etc. And, you know, it has several things that Kansas City does not. An internationally recognized and iconic landmark/symbol. A baseball team that locals are proud of and adore. A subway. An authentic Little Italy neighborhood. Benson. Nelly...

But its historical landmark "train station"... has no trains! WTF? 

I've traveled a fair portion of the world and cities' train stations all have trains in them, so silly me for making such an outlandish assumption when attempting to take Amtrak home yesterday. It boggles my mind that St. Louis' train station is instead something that is trying to be a mall.

This would be fine, really. If only they would warn idiot visitors like me. Like, with signs pointing out that you will not find Amtrak here, but several blocks away, tucked back by the highway underpass that is a long walk (and nearly impossible to find). What's more? Not one employee in Union "Station" (more like a sad mall) could help point me in the direction of where one might find an actual train. Today, I found information booth so that I could get a cab to take me the hell out of there, so that was nice.

See, I missed my train yesterday, after frantically running all over this lame excuse for a mall that has maps and signs for the shops and food courts (all of them really quite sad and deserted... not one decent coffee shop to be found, not even Starbucks), but not ONE SIGN FOR WHERE ONE MIGHT FIND TRAINS IN THE TRAIN STATION!!!

That's right. And like I said, everyone looked at me like I had a second head when I asked where the trains were. One "transit" worker (that's what his jacket indicated) outside by the commuter rail barely grunted at me and pointed in the vague vicinity of where the small Amtrak/Greyhound station actually exists.

Before I could make it there, I had to drop my fifty pound bag and decompress by the highway underpass. At that point, I was approached by a fatherly type asking me basically WTF I was doing standing on a corner practically crying because by then I had missed the last train back to KC. Then there was the red mini van that kept slowly following me. How Christiane F can you get? 

I really don't know what the point of Union Station in Saint Louis is, besides a pathetic excuse for a tourist attraction for Marriott guests in the attached hotel. And next time I hear anyone complain about Kansas City's far superior Union Station, which is not only a gorgeous structure that makes you feel like you're stepping back in time, but is an operating train station, I'm going to virtually slap them.

And someone really needs to reevaluate the "transportation" description above in the Yelp listing.

Don't even think you'll avoid day drinking here. We landed at Le Bon Temps the afternoon after Christmas Day with the best intentions (bloodies!) and immediately received a free shot and a Merry Christmas from the awesome bartendress. 

And then there was Mary. I watched as the bartendress dressed her up like a spicy lil tomato on dollar day. Never before had I witnessed such primping and flair! My Bloody Mary arrived decorated with no less than five different kinds of garnish: olives, celery, okra, green beans, lemon/lime and I'm sure I'm forgetting something. Talk about exceeding ones daily recommended servings of vegetables! Ah, nutrition New Orleans-style. 

I suppose one might thoughtlessly call Les Bon Temps a "dive bar" but that would be kinda lazy. It's so much more! Besides, I daresay that in New Orleans there are no mere "dive bars" as you know 'em. I'm going to think on this one because it deserves a new classification.

Just call me Super Girl...

Last review mentioned the avocado smoothie. Well, hold the presses because if that ruined me for smoothies forever, I don't even know what the hell to say about the cacao shake I had yesterday. Sublime. And I was feeling the effects when I had a workout 2 hours later. Hello, boundless, blissful energy.

And then there's the house made maca and green bars that I can't stop snacking on.

Really, I don't know how anyone will be prepared to deal with a gal who's going to have as many super powers that I have. 

Look out world.

Besides Lafitte's and The Funky Pirate, Saints and Sinners is pretty much the only other place I can tolerate on Bourbon Street. I do more than tolerate it, though, I quite like it, with its sensuous red walls, chandeliers, marble and overall old timey bordello vibe. Love the spiraling staircase (you're surrounded by shady ladies peeking out of keyholes!) and the upstairs room that is vaguely VIPish... maybe more than vaguely as it's celebrity-owned. I dig the dark Victorian parlour vibe up here immensely. 

On note on the celebrity-owned aspect of this place: I don't go out of my way to go to celebrity-owned places, nor do I go out of my way to shun them. 

I've only had drinks here (and never at one of their packed events nor on a weekend), but besides the lush environs, I want to note that the staff's enthusiasm is rather infectious. In other words, it's refreshing to not see surly sorts who deign to give you your drink that you've politely ordered. Every bartender I've encountered at Saints & Sinners is extremely nice, allowing one to feel more like they are at a local hang rather than a typical Bourbon St. watering hole that packs 'em in and spits 'em out. Do check out Ellie's flair. She's adorable.  I bartended for years but never even attempted the flair (to be honest, I would have probably knocked out the entire top shelf). This girl can juggle the shakers and strain a martini on her head, I tell ya! Even the bouncers here have been pretty darn nice. 

Maybe it's just that I've been here on mellow nights, but the crowd doesn't annoy me. Saints and Sinners is a good place to people watch (and of course there's no shortage of that). You can even do so from the balcony upstairs, but the front porch makes you feel kind of like you're in a posh viewing space at the zoo, so that alone is worth the price of a drink here (which, by the way are reasonably priced for Bourbon Street). 

With this four-star review, I'm their patron saint!

It was a ruff day (sorry!), I mean rough day. I woke up after a long night out and just 4 or 5 hours of sleep to an apartment that was freezing cold. Ok, listen up, it was 31 friggin' degrees outside yesterday at 9am! When I went to bed at 4:30ish it was 29. So, the idea of being outside made me shudder to think about it. But I was determined to go see this parade of pups and not only because we were going to have a Yelp table here with Bloody Marys, either (not to mention the idea of drinking more vodka made me sick to my stomach, but I'll spare you the details). 

We arrived to set up around 11am and Louis Armstrong park was bustling with dressed-to-the-(ca)nines and their proud companions milling about. We grabbed a good spot behind the police barricades on the neutral ground across from the park and settled in. The parade started on time and everyone was just so awesome in our area, between the humans and the cutest dogs ever. I had my fill of puppy eye candy and was in a good mood for entire duration of my time here. I don't think I've ever cooed and cawed and eeeeeeee'd so much in a single day, just sayin'. I may be a proud cat lady, but if you don't like dogs dressed up in costumes, then I can't imagine wanting to know you. Think that sounds extreme? Look at the damn pictures that are posted.

Favorite floats were the CIA (Canine Intelligence Unit), as well as the so-cute-you wanna-kill-them crawfish pups in a big pot. Seriously. So cute they have to be illegal. Also, little Miss Smushface, our Yelp mascot, was all dressed up like a vegas showgirl with a feather headpiece and all. Loved all the rescue groups marching in this parade with the dogs wearing their "adopt me" coats. Yes, I want to adopt them all. Yet again, I'm reminded of my aspirations to own a farm one day so that I can have as many dogs, cats and ducks (I talked to someone yesterday who told me about her pet ducks and now I want some) and maybe even peacocks and a serval or two. 

While only my second parade to date, I think this is going to be my favorite. A good part of it had to do with the entire experience and the crowd I was surrounded by. How can anyone be rude or mean in the face of all these cute doggies, right? Also, there was the most polite child in the world standing near me who was handing out the beads he kept receiving to other people around him. This made me think that there's hope for the future.

I really dig this airport. In fact, this may be a first for me: five stars for an airport?! Yes, it's true. I actually look forward to landing and taking off from here.

First and foremost, they've got the right way to welcome you to Music City. As in the presences of actual, live music! I've witnessed a variety of singer/songwriters and small bands and it may not always be my cup of tea, but it just feels right and gets you excited to be here. 

The fun stuff: There's a good variety of eateries and shops for a small airport. Louis Armstrong International could stand to learn a thing or two from Nashville, as this airport has it going on. It's been modernized, at the very least to the point where you don't squint your eyes and wonder if you've traveled back to the 1980s. There's rocking chairs by baggage. Plenty of coffee options (crucial. If chains have to be at airports, and I know they do, at least give us more than shitty drip coffee. If this means Starbucks, I'm OK with that). I love those Benefit vending machines (kinda pure genius if you ask me. I've seen them in several airports now). There's plenty of comfy seating with outlets (at the Southwest gates at least).  Heck, there's even an area for parents to bring their restless children so they don't make the rest of us suffer (on that note, I wonder why airports don't consider putting in a gym with treadmills and weights for us restless adults?! And, like, punching bags even. Just an idea.)

The nitty gritty: I've never seen crazy lines at check-in or security. Getting baggage is a breeze and it's a pretty short walk to find a cab from there (go down the escalator, but if you have a ton of luggage, never fear, there's *actual signage* pointing out the elevators). Everyone's pretty friendly and helpful.

Really, I don't know what more you could ask for in an airport that's not a major hub! I appreciate the efficiency as well as all the little extras that make going to the airport a less miserable experience. I daresay I could even stand to be stranded here...

I like the concept of doing just a few things and doing them well. That's an understatement for Crescent Pie & Sausage.

So, you know the name, you know the deal. There are a variety of pies: savory, sweet and pizza, my favorite kind of pie (right above key lime, which they make when it's the season). There is a variety of sausage, which I'm not really going to tell you much about since I'm a vegetarian, but if they are as good at tubed meats as they are at pies... There are cocktails. Those, of course, I can tell you about. Oh, delicious, unique cocktails. They infuse their own vodka! My favorite is the pear lemonade, just right for the warm day. I think I sucked that down in less than five minutes. The blueberry gin fizz is also quite refreshing, but stronger and sweeter, if that's what you need. 

The space is open and modern and comfy. There is a side porch you can sit on in nice weather and I plan on it. This is the kind of affordable casual eatery I like. A lot.

And the food... the pizza is SO SO SO fucking good. Sorry for the f-bomb, but I am prone to dropping them when I'm impressed. Or furious. This time I'm impressed. Instead of sauce, they slice up heirloom tomatoes, not too much fresh mozzerella and a liberal sprinkle of fresh basil leaves. I'm just dying over all the freshness. It's also huge, so you can share or have leftovers.

Now's the time for me to drop the f-bomb cuz I'm furious: I left half my fucking pizza behind in a to-go box! ARGH!!!!!! I was probably too distracted by thoughts of how good it was going to be for lunch. Fuck fuck fuck me for always having my head in the clouds.

I would be remiss to not update this review to reflect the excellent customer service I received following my negative review. Not more than a week later, I received a phone call from the woman in charge of such matters to go over what had happened more in detail. They definitely do not want to leave a dissatisfied customer with a bad impression! At the end of the call, I was offered a complimentary session with the aesthetician I had been with two time before and who I highly recommend, Nelly.

I will go back. 

Another FYI, if the pain is too excruciating for one reason or another, you may ask the esthetician to stop and you will *not* forfeit your money for the session. You will be permitted to return at another time to finish. Great to know!

See Rome and die, they say. Eat at Commander's Palace and die, *I* say (and I love me some Rome, don't get me wrong). This is an experience *nonpareille* mes amis! To quote Yelp NOLA Elite, the great Harry T: "She is absolutely the Grande Dame of the restaurants of New Orleans." Mayhap the world? Who knows? I've eaten in great places, really, I have, but Commander's is in a league of its - nay, her own. Think of her as the mother ship. It's wonderful to see a place live up to each and every expectation. True, I write this in a #CPC (Commander's Palace Coma), but I think you can trust me by now.
 
In cities like New York, where I'm from, there are dozens of truly great restaurants. The old guard. The new guard. You'd think never the twain shall meet but they do in New Orleans at Commander's Palace. I came here for the first time for my friend's birthday last night. We were a group of 5. I could just as easily see me bringing my "One if by land, Two if by Sea"-adoring parents here for our special NOLA restaurant occasion. They will love it. This is the thing: everyone is made to feel welcome here. I waltzed in with dozens of tattoos visible. I was greeted by at least half a dozen people. It didn't feel false. Whomever is in charge of FOH here should make the standard for others to live by! Thank you for making me feel at home, CP.

So, the food. Wow. Delicious. What with the chef having just won a James Beard award, so you don't need me telling you that. Vegetarians, there is an incredible risotto here. I love any risotto, but what makes it different here is that they add a lot of green vegetables to it (peas, asparagus...) and as delicious and decadent as it seems, it didn't feel as heavy, ie artery-cloggin', as most risotto often can. As in, I was able to order dessert, that bread pudding, in fact. *That* bread pudding. And although bread pudding can also be a very ponderous (yet sweet and delicious) affair, Commander's makes theirs into a sensational soufflé, so that the initial bites are light and airy and heavenly, but you dig down a bit more and get to the "meat" of it, a not-terribly-sweet bread pudding. It's DIEvine. 

And then there was the complimentary Sidecar shots served to our table. Delectable enough to sip. I wasn't going to shoot that back, oh hell no.

Yeah, yeah Commander's has almost a thousand 5 star reviews, but I wanna say my piece!!! I love writing 5-star reviews. It's not too often I get to do so.

Finally, how can one not love a restaurant that issues a most compelling plea: men must wear closed-toe shoes.

Note: avoid this store if you're feeling particularly anti social on any given day.

I'm not the first one to say it and I won't be the last. These ladies are just doing their jobs but I wish they weren't so darn "good" at it. Note to  Lush corporate: can you let these chicks breathe a bit? Who can be this bubbly all the time (avoiding the obvious product pun here)? It doesn't feel authentic. And sometimes I feel guilty for not being up to par on the enthusiasm levels. Sometimes I fear I'm downright surly.

This is all to say... I stress out before coming in most Lush stores and this one is no exception. I kind of like to be left alone when I'm shopping and sniffing and reading and that is just NEVER going to happen here. Accept it and move on, I guess. 

I love Lush products long time. Almost twenty years, in fact. I remember that first Lush shop I came upon on Kings Road in London (rather, I smelled it first. Heavenly!) I was hooked ever since (and I used to mail order their products from Canada before they finally opened in the US). 

Most recently, I tried a couple new (to me) hair products and adore them (Big shampoo and Happy Happy Joy Joy *shut up*) And now, my hair smells like fresh orange blossoms. Their shower gels are my absolute favorite. When I'm in need of a little something something extra, I get one of the Shower Smoothies (the creamed almond and coconut definitely smells good enough to eat. OK so I tasted it once. Don't judge. I know I'm not the only one). 

There are some product misses, don't get me wrong. The Angels on Bare Skin face mask, for example. It feels like barely moistened sandpaper. Thankfully I tried the sample before buying. Don't get me started on their henna (such a disgusting mess that I threw it out but when is henna NOT a disgusting mess?)

One of the first Yelp reviews I ever wrote received my most "funny" votes (or at one point, it did. I might have been funnier since), so I suggest you search my reviews and find it if you want to see me at my best. Or don't. The reality is, I love Lush. Their products are top notch, innovative, usually have catchy names, smell great and the list goes on. They are environmentally conscious. They are vegan conscious (for 20 years, so not due to any recent trend). I even may have developed a crush on the people who are pictured on the package because they are responsible for making up my fix. 

I just wish I didn't have to get therapy in order to feel comfortable about walking in a Lush store.

*This review is for the marina bar only*

On July 4 we decided to scout out some places along Lakeshore Dr to see if they were worth driving our boat & then dock there (cheaper and faster to drive first, obviously). We started with Brisbi's outdoor bar. The service and drinks were questionable (you know it's bad when you're drinking quickly so that the ice doesn't melt into your vodka soda). We moved on to The Blue Crab once the cover band left the stage. No disrespect to the musicians. I don't want to listen to rock cover bands ever, for the most part. Especially those who play two of my most hated songs, "Brown Eyed Girl," and... well, anything by Elton John. 

It was hot. So so very hot. We had frozen drinks on the brain and lo and behold, they have them here! Three kinds: Piña colada, Bushwacker, both of which I avoided assuming dairy would be in them, and some kind of strawberry thing. I went with the latter, but not before rubbing elbows with a creepy guy who wasn't wearing a shirt. He ordered a vodka Red Bull (of course he did) and when he was told they don't do energy drinks, asked the bartender what he should get instead. The sass she gave him back was well-deserved and I couldn't help but be entertained. We got our drinks, chatted with a nice biker chick sitting next to us and went to sit & sip. 

My drink was so sweet I could barely drink it. It was so strong, I didn't drink again for hours and hours, if at all. Danny liked his piña. 

It was decent, though I'm not sure it's a destination bar. It *is* cool to sit by the water and watch the boats. There's plenty of spots of dock, too. I don't have a problem returning if we hit up this area on the boat.

Arrow Cafe is a charming throwback to chill coffeehouse culture of the 90s. There's not a single Edison bulb nor pour over, nor digital sign announcing what the single origin is. Hell, even the WIFI is unapologetically spotty. This is refreshing. 

The barista couldn't have been nicer and the cold brew couldn't have been colder and more delicious. The only thing that gave me the sads was the fact that the Girls Gone Vegan goodies I had heard were available here (or it might have been another local brand) were nowhere to be seen. Besides bagels and energy bars, I didn't see much in the way of food. Might have just been the day that I was there?

Would I come here to do actual work again? Probably not (I depend on WIFI). Would I come here to indulge in a coffee and a book (not a book on a tablet!) Would I come here to meet up for some coffee & conversation with a friend? Hell, yes.

BJ's Lounge... it's simply The Awesome.

Oh did you want to know the recipe for The Awesome?
Just throw in equal parts:
- dark/divey basement-like atmosphere (while not being icky/dirty)
-fantastic music (hello, punk night with DJ Christion playing stuff I haven't heard in ages)
-comfy bar stools 
-nice/fast barkeep

Season with all the cheap a$$ drinks you want!

Distinctly Bywater 'phere... like another favorite, J & J's (uh, is there a relation, Mr. or Ms. J?)

If I could travel with my three cats, I would bring them everywhere. Somehow I know they wouldn't really appreciate that. Normally I have friends stay in my house while I'm away, but this year it seemed that wasn't going to work out, so I turned to Yelp and found Uptown Girls was very highly-rated. I easily was able to schedule a preliminary meet and greet, as well as 13 days of visits. Cat sitting is 1/2 hour a day and priced quite reasonably! 

Recently I returned home after being away for 2 weeks to 3 very happy kitties who asked me to write this review, as they tend to be tempted to sleep on the keyboard rather than use it for its actual purpose.

Mary took such amazing care of my cats and kept in daily contact with me via their online messaging system (she also posted photos daily). Of course I'm like a nervous wreck leaving my beloved pets alone for such a long time. They are used to me working from home and loads of attention. I also have one cat, Chick, who is extremely timid and only comes out for me. The photos eased all my concerns, as several showed rare appearances by Chick out from under the bed! Klaus is my little party animal and loves all people, so true to his nature, he was the one hogging the cuddles and playtime, although his sister, Sparrow, appreciated head pets and kisses from her favorite perch on the cat tree. Mary was very responsive to just the kind of interaction each of them needed!

She also noted their new habits and preferences (ie, eating upstairs rather than downstairs). She spoiled them with lots of attention and playtime. In fact Klaus reminded me last night that I don't give him enough playtime with his favorite toy on a stick that he likes to chase. 

Finally, I also wanted to mention that my house might have been cleaner than I left it! It smelled great and the floors were all swept and it was really nice coming home to that.

I very much recommend Uptown Girls and can't thank Mary enough for being so kind and loving to my cats!

Updating with an ode to the new magical vegan green curry dish that now graces the menu!

I used to be addicted to the tofu bánh mì (the very best I've ever had in a city full of excellent tofu bánh mì) but now Lat 29 put a green curry cauliflower bowl on the menu and it's a delight. The cauliflower is roasted, slightly blackened so that it's very crisp and chewy. It's the perfect compliment to the rich curry sauce and the chick peas, mushrooms and rice that accompany it. I typical devour the entire thing, as hard as I try to eat it slowly and worship each bite. Truth be told, I could drown in that green curry and die a happy death. 

I'm the duchess of this joint, so you know you can trust me on this...

There's something so sublime about sitting way up above from it all, sipping on a cocktail on a warm summer night. I feel like New Orleans was a little late to the game with these types of places, but now we have a decent array (typically at hotels like this one). And like most of the other rooftop bars at hotels, you don't have to be a hotel guest to take advantage! 

This past Saturday evening was surprisingly quiet up there, possibly due to White Linen happening on the other side of the CBD. I wasn't complaining, believe me! It was perfect out there for me and just when I thought things couldn't possibly get better, I saw the cocktail menu. Frosé, baby! Passionfruit frosé, yes please. Also, prices are not as high as you'd expect. My guy got a $3 Modelo. Frosé was $8. 

Pretty views of the surrounding buildings, fairy lights against the dark summer sky and a slight breeze... living my best life with a glass of frozé in mah hand. Thanks, Catahoula!

Some say that finding a good tailor is priceless. After all, we're different shapes and sometimes sizing in the realm of 2, 4, 6, 8,10, 12 + just ain't gonna cut it. 

Reading the reviews of the skilled seamstresses at Thimbelina had me convinced that I would hit them up when I needed to. I only needed a hem on a cotton pencil skirt, ie, nothing major. I went in, put on the skirt and they swiftly pinned it to where it needed to go.

That's where the swiftness ended, I'm afraid. I got my ticket and could not believe that a simple hem would take two weeks. I mean... two weeks? Is that the norm in town? I'm used to such things taking two business days.

I picked up my skirt yesterday and admired the excellent hemline. I won't be walking around looking like a ragamuffin anytime soon. But... 17 dollars? Really?

All this said, I would entrust them to expert tailoring for something major and I am willing to pay for it.

But for a simple hem, I most likely will go elsewhere (Mom?). Or finally break down and buy that damned Singer.

I only come to St. Roch for O! Vegasm, but because you have to order drinks from the bar separately and because I do on occasion indulge (that is, every occasion I've been there which is about half a dozen times), a review for St. Roch is due.

First, let's talk about that bathroom sign. I find not the misspell of "neighbors" funny, but the fact that so many people have taken it upon themselves to put in corrections or comments on the sign. I just imagine some new crusty come to town whipping out her sharpie and going to town on that thing before she realizes that she has bigger dogs to adopt.

Second, there's the great Ketel One Mystery. As in, for some reason, Ketel One tastes like gin here. First time I ordered it, I sent it back. I never do that. The bartender actually poured the drink in front of me to show that it was, in fact, Ketel One. But I know my gin better than I know my mother and because I order vodka with soda, any extraneous flavor is immediately noticeable. My friend, also a bartender, concurred that it tasted like gin. I figured that they just didn't clean the pour spout properly. A week or two later, I returned and thoughtlessly ordered my usual. Again, the flavor of juniper berries made me wish I had just ordered tonic instead of soda. This time I didn't send it back. I also barely drank it. Yes, you read that right (ever drink a gin and soda??? Ugh). I'd normally be hard pressed to stick to Stoli henceforth, but it's been happening. 

Regardless, I've gotta give St. Roch props for live music, cheap drinks, friendly (non crusty punk) regulars and the fact that they have O! Vegasm operating out of the kitchen means that there are good people behind the entire operation. It is what it is.

Finally, I think that from now on, I'm just going to call it St. Roach. Hey, it's out of fondness. Think of it as a cute mascot. I prefer them to crusties, if the truth must be told.

When Bearcat opened, the vegan angels sang because finally, there's a second (Surrey's would be the first) full service breakfast/lunch place in New Orleans with a good portion of the menu dedicated to plant-based entrees! That would be the Good Cat part of the menu, of course. Might I also add how I love that there's Good Cat/Bad Cat action on that menu! So cute and cool.

Clearly the concept is popular because it was packed on a Tuesday afternoon. I really wish other places in town, especially ones where you can get brunch cocktails, would follow suit. (Ruby Slipper, Katie's I'm looking at you). Bearcat is proof that there is success in vegan options.

This whole looking at the menu and not being able to decide thing is a foreign concept for vegans in New Orleans. But there I was. So I just picked the vegan quesadilla and let it go, despite the other breakfast items (available all day) and lunch items that all sounded incredible.

But first, I need to talk about the rose water latte because it is simply exquisite. The flavors of rose and coffee really do well together. There's really no better way to feel all fancy during the day than by sipping on this latte. It is dusted with tiny petals for gods' sake!

One might think that it's tres gauche to pair this up with something like Buffalo cauliflower but I'm not like most civilized people.  And Bearcat's Buffalo cauliflower is delicious. It's of the breaded and fried variety and it comes with a creamy vegan dipping sauce. 

The tofu quesadilla, sadly did disappoint. You will never hear these words from me ever again: it was too salty. The tofu scramble is packed with bell peppers which I really really hate (no mention of them being in there on the menu), as well as rubbery mushrooms. I guess I was hoping for some vegan cheese (I mean, it is called a quesadilla). The menu description mentions cashew queso, but this is more of a garnish than a feature of the dish. 

My friend let me try her roasted potatoes and they are SO incredible that I vow to return just to eat these. And any of the other enticing vegan options on the Good Cat menus.

I love Bearcat and will be a forever customer!

Seven years and 22+ check-ins later and I realize I had wrongly only granted this sweet local biz four stars. This is one of my favorite places in town and I'm gonna right that wrong.

On my most recent visit, we were looking for a chill place to de-Carnival. You know what I mean. We wanted to avoid the Lundi Gras revelry and just relax in one of those sweet window seats. This place is a true locals hang. Yes, it's a wine shop, with a great selection of bottles (and quality affordable ones at that), but I like to order by the glass and enjoy the scene because there's always interesting conversation and meet-ups happening. It was a more quiet night, but there was a dog that we made friends with. I mean, he ran away from his people who were gathered at the long bar to sit on our laps! Never had that happen to me before, but there's the magic of Faubourg Wines. 

There's always something delicious by the glass and it's only 5 bucks. Where are you going to get a deal like that in town? My first glass was a sparkling red, similar to a dry Lambrusco. Apparently it was a rare bottle and sorry to say, that they are probably not getting more of it. I like that it makes things seem extra special. And anyway, you can follow that glass up with another excellent $5 red, white or sparkling. 

I cannot believe it's been 7 lucky years since they've opened shop on a sleepy block of St. Claude, but it's such a vital place in the neighborhood. I'm a forever fan.

When I was driving past their new location on St. Claude I could hardly believe it! "Fair Grinds moved from the Fairgrounds to St. Claude?!" No, even better, it's their new, second location.

And I love it. Another coffee option that's within walking distance. The new location has plenty of outdoor seating in the alleyway leading up to the shop, which is smallish, but there's a fair amount of seating and outlets inside, too.

As you may or may not know, Fair Grinds has a mission behind their coffee (fair trade, locally sourced baked goods - didn't see any vegan treats, but hopefully they'll add some). The iced coffee is cold drip and that's just what I needed on a recent steamy Saturday. Oh and a really nice barista serving up the brews. 

I suspect I'll be a regular quite soon. Although I'm more of a grab & go kinda gal, I also have been known to set up shop and work for a couple hours in local coffee shops in town. I can easily see myself doing so in this sweet spot. 

Thanks for opening up in our neck of the woods, Fair Grinds!

Overall I had a great experience here:

Pros
- Costumer service is top notch
- 24 hour room service, which is surprisingly good.  Plus they deliver wines by the glass or bottle.  And they tell you your order will take 30-40 minutes, which is totally tolerable, but every time I ordered I had my food in less than 20 minutes.  I'm talking breakfast, dinner, and dessert.  No idea how they do it, but damn Loews, you're winning me over
- Safe
- Convenient location (especially if you are going to Thomas Jefferson).  There are tons of restaurants featuring different cuisine within 4 blocks and many of them give you the option of take out
- Awesome gym.  Not only is it huge, but it has large windows that enabled me to stalk people in the Marriott across the street. Makes my feeble attempt at a workout so much better
- Cucumber-lemon water in the lobby and gym (naturally detoxifying!)  
- Amazing bath products.  The conditioner is off the chain and thick enough to use as a shave cream if needed (you're welcome)
- Super duper comfy bed
- Free wi-fi
- They'll hold your bags at Customer Service for as long as you want
- Nice lounge, with outlets everywhere

Cons
- Housekeeping could be a little better, but overall the room was clean, spacious, and very comfortable
- I stayed in room 923 in a Deluxe King room.  Per the website it says that 
Deluxe King rooms face "either downtown Philadelphia or Delaware River."  Yes my room did face downtown Philadelphia as in office buildings and other hotels.  However, it was not a big deal as I was only in my room to eat and sleep
- Parking is crazy expensive, but it is a city.  What did you expect?  

Next time I'm traveling I will definitely consider staying at a Loews again.

I can't get over the concept of a BYO (Bring Your Own alcohol).  It truly is genius.  You can bring as many bottles of booze of any sort without paying a corkage fee.  If you are feeling PWT you bring your Coors Light or whatever you people drink.  Now don't get all sensy.  If you are feeling reds you bring a nice bottle of Shiraz.  Or if you are like me, I find the only bottle of Chenin Blanc in Conshy and I bring that and polish it off.  Now that makes little Justine a happy camper.  

Fellini's itself is very cute with the romantic soft lightening.  The tables spaced closed together, yet you still feel comfortable.  It could serve for romantic purposes, but it seems that more groups come here, like me and my hunny pie on our double date.  

They immediately bring you bruschetta, which is quite nice.  The calamari was good, typically calamari.  I'm not going to rant and rave.  I will say that I have never seen an appetizer so big in my life.  That could have been a meal in itself.  Good thing there were 4 of us.  

However, the RIGATONI ALLA VODKA with sun dried tomatoes and capers was outstanding.  It was probably one of the most delicious pasta dishes this fat girl has ever consumed.  To make it even more delectable I asked the waitress if it was possible to put meatballs in my dish and sure enough it was.  So there you have this ginormo dish of beautiful drunken pasta floating in a sea of vodka sauce with two meatball boats and little fishie tomatoes.  I tried to consume the whole dish.  FAIL.  Too much food.  I'm talking Cheesecake Factory portions.  And for the more than reasonable price of $12.95. Score!

But a girl is never too full for dessert.  The special of the night was Creme Brule Cheesecake.  We didn't even need to look at the rest of the menu. He was excited!  It was amazing.  I had a few bites, but I had to let him be the fat girl on a rampage.  I highly recommend ordering this option if available and I don't particularly care for creme brule. 

Came out to $40 per couple with shared appetizer, 4 entrees, and shared dessert.

First time trying this place and was really looking forward to the pizza since I had heard great things.  Called in for a pizza for take out on a Sunday night.  Apparently everyone wanted take out last night.  Medium half cheese, half Hawaiian with a side of ranch.  Not too hard.  

It took over 45 minutes for our pizza to be ready.  After 45 minutes you expect your pizza to taste like liquid gold.  Now, I've never had liquid gold, but I was expecting some delicious pizza.  The Hawaiian side was mediocre at best.  I never go for cheese pizza, but at least it had taste to it.  I wasn't impressed, but I was starving.  They also forgot my ranch, but I forgot about it after the long wait and being so hungry in there with all the smells.  Total came to $13.33.
Wish I had come here not so trashed for better assessment.  Asked for a dirty martini with extra olives.  Got a solid martini with 3 olives.  Hmm?  Chill spot.  Liked the dark lighting.

This place is DERICIOUS!  That means it is way better than delicious.  Restaurant, deli and butcher.  WOW!  

Anyway, back to breakfast.  The owner greeted us.  The BF grew up in the area and he got the special hello.  That always makes you feel special.  I was sad that I didn't see waffles on the menu since that was the only thing I wanted, but sure enough it was the special and I got my waffles cooked to a perfect golden brown and bacon on the side.  Everything comes dry and you can choose your own butter or whipped butter.  I loved this.  Why don't all places do this?  I wish I could have eaten every bite since everything was so good, but I was simply stuffed.  The home fries were also unbelievable although I would call them more of a hash.  I would highly suggest getting them on the side.

The owner was also really sweet and asked if I wanted to take the rest of my neatly eaten food home to go.  I like good customer service.  Lots of breakfast options and sandwiches.  The place is very comfortable.  

Loved it!

Nothing special.  Came in because me and the BF were starving.  What I really wanted was a sandwich.  What I settled for was chicken tacos.  Normally I can polish off 3 chicken tacos no sweat.  

These tacos are just really bland: 
-soft flour tortilla (I prefer corn, but that option then becomes crispy...yuck), -bland chicken that must be drenched in Chulula
-lettuce
-salsa of your choosing
-cheese
-"lite" sour cream (who cares you're eating cheese.  It's not supposed to be healthy.)

Once again here is where taco bell takes the cake.  I will give them recognition for having my favorite hot sauce Chulula, which makes most any type of "Mexican" food taste a whole lot better.  But good Mexican good doesn't need to be drenched in my favorite hot sauce.  

The BF's taco salad on the other hand, was tastier.  It had a lot of lettuce for substance.  Nice rabbit food.  All in all, he likes the place. 

I was still hungry after my two tacos and all I wanted was a cookie.  That's how you know I really was satisfied.
Delicious and fresh!  I'm talking super fresh.  And fast too.  I ordered for pickup from yelp and  15 minutes later I was back in my room eating.  Say what?!?!
Been here twice and I am impressed that even with a long ass line the whole order a drink and pick it up process is fast and smooth.  Works for me.  Plus almond milk Cappuccino?  Holler!

I walked in and immediately I knew where I was.  Yes, the signs, the layout, the ceiling.  This had to be related to Safeway and sure enough Genuardi's is part of Safeway, Inc.  Safeway is only the GREATEST store ever!  Back home, I go there at least 3 times a week.  Sushi, good deli sandwiches, produce, Safeway's own products, club-card holder deals...Enough said!  Love, love, love!

Slogan: "We do a little bit better at WaWa."

They do a whole lot better at WaWa!  I'm back in the land of San Francisco and boy oh boy do I miss WaWa!  The light vanilla latte in the latte machine is off the hook.  Better than the skinny vanilla latte at Starbucks.  I'm addicted.  There coffee is avg, but they have so many choices (like 10) and various creams (hazelnut, vanilla, light cream, half-n-half, milk, skim milk, etc.), sugars, honeys, teas.  This is just a great go to for everything you need and this location is open 24/7.

I love milk and honey! Big sign right in front. Walking inside to see some great designing. The store build out is very clean and great attention to detail. The menu ranges from brunch items to cold pressed juices. We got the fried chicken biscuit and the mean & green juice. It was really good the biscuit nice and fluffy. Chicken juicy and crispy. The juice was lightly sweet. I would definitely recommend this spot for brunch. 

Recommendation: fried chicken biscuit / mean & green cold press juice

Been wanting to go here since forever. This place really put the hot chicken game on the map. A staple to Nashville and what it's done in the food scene. Visited their newest location and there was a line down the parking lot. As we entered inside they had a clean looking restaurant. We ordered quite a few items. The hot chicken sandwich with Mac and cheese and collard greens. Then we got the 3 wings medium spicy with the bacon grits and fries. A side of comeback sauce. And a chicken tender with the spiciest sauce called "shit the cluck up" and they was crazy. The heat level just kept getting worse and lingered on my tongue. Had to was it down with sweet tea and Mac n cheese. The chicken was juicy on the inside but wasn't hot in temperature. I wanna come back and try the banana pudding. Checked off my food bucket list 

Recommendation: medium spicy chicken wings, Mac and cheese, bacon grits , and sweet tea

It's like being back in Elementary School all over again! The lunch lady serving up food with personality. Just that this food quality is much much better. Arnold's also won the James Beard award. Not the best looking place but that's when you know the food is delicious. Cafeteria style dining. Each day they have different menu items. I came on a Monday and went with the daily Roast Beef. Fried Chicken was available on the Monday that I went. Got Mac and Cheese and creamed corn as the sides. It also comes with a cornbread and butter. The roast beef is amazing. A strong taste with lots of flavor. The fried chicken seasoned as well and crispy. Comfort food done right. 

Recommendation: Roast Beef

Flatbread here is amazingggggg!! Fresh and home made on the spot. The menu consists of pizza, burgers, stuffed flatbreads, wings , fries and more. I got to try all of it. Including some desserts. The flatbreads here are simply amazing. A nice garlic taste with fillings and toppings. You can't go wrong. The service is also on point. I really appreciate the quality and love that goes into the food here. Mission Viejo doesn't have a lot of exciting things going on but this is one of them. A must visit spot! My favorite item was the chicken chipotle and bbq chicken stuff flatbreads. I also recommend trying all 3 sauces that they have at the tables. I will definitely come back! 

Recommendation: Stuffed flatbreads

Damn this is the best cheesesteak I had in Philly! Long line when I opened the door. There's still others I need to try but during this trip.. Sonny's had the best one. The ribeye meat chopped up perfectly. I got the cheesesteak wit wizz. The cheese wizz here is made in-house and was so damn good. The onions cooked perfectly. The roll lightly toasted. Oh man this was too damn good. I wouldn't mind having another one right now. 

Recommendation: Cheesesteak wit wiz

The Good.

-There's a very decent hoagie shop.
-I'm a sucker for high ceilings. 
-There's always places to sit. 
-It's better than Penn Station* in almost every way.
-The bathrooms are surprisingly not that filthy. 
-Free wi/fi.

The Bad.

-There are no late night food options except for McDonald's.
-I broke my three year streak of not eating McDonald's.
-It costs more to get a bacon, egg and cheese than it does to get a platter of eggs, bacon, homefries and toast. That's not right.
-The place that serves fried chicken, meatloaf etc. puts all that food out on the hot plates at like 9:30 am. Which scares me. 

The Ugly.

-Eagles fans.
-Phillies fans. 
-Me.
__________

*NY Penn. You couldn't pay me to get off in Newark to see what that station looks like.

The dulce de leche gelato is absolutely fantastic, except when paired with Brooklyn Brown Ale.

The cones are nice, but not as amazing as you would think, considering that they are handmade in France and smuggled into the US by pre-pubescent teens that are summarily executed if even one cone is cracked.*

There is nothing emasculating about having another man buy you ice cream. Especially if you call him Daddy for the rest of the day. I swear. 
__________

*I may have made part of this up.

Upset that the line for Acme is around the block? Your charbroiled oyster fix can be had right here in the middle of the French market. 

If you don't mind ruining your shirt and/or you are more coordinated than I am, the crawfish are big and beautiful and $10 a pound. Grab a tray, post up at one of the tables and get in there. Don't forget to suck the heads.

Bourbon Street, when you look beneath the surface, can be pretty depressing. It stinks of desperation. And vomit. 

But if you drink a couple hand grenades, you're quickly rendered incapable of seeing anything beyond the surface. Sometimes you're incapable of seeing anything at all. 

And you're ready to have a good time. For pretty cheap.

I wish I could tell you about the sandwiches, or the selection of snacks, but I don't know anything about that. 

What I know is that I promised to provide ice for a party nearby (a necessity for any party, and something that will get you in just about anywhere), and I was late and frantic.

Olde City may not pick up the phone...ever, but they sell ice for $2.50/bag, they have plenty of it, they are conveniently located, and the guy at the counter seemed nice enough as I ran in, grabbed ice, and threw money at him. 

Thanks to them, I have not been disowned by my family.

My train arrived at 30th Street Station on a Sunday afternoon; I needed a late lunch, and Bridgewater's fit the bill. 

Normally, I would order their burger and never look back. Unfortunately, my girlfriend recently accused me of eating four burgers a week, which is completely absurd. OK, so MAYBE I had already eaten three that week, but I would NEVER eat four. What sort of glutton eats four burgers a week? 

In any case, since I would rather be unhappy than allow her to be right, I went with the crabcake sandwich on the bartender's recommendation. When it finally arrived, the accompanying sweet potato fries were barely cooked, but the sandwich itself tasted pretty good. The crabcake fell apart (as crabcakes are wont to do), but I bet they make a good burger, which I'll have to come back and try when I haven't reached my weekly quota.

Now, Bridgewater's doesn't look like much. The food is a little better than decent, and their flatscreens could use some updating to HD (you want to be able to see the pain on Favre's face). But this is the best train station bar in existence, and I'll tell you why: their beer selection is shockingly awesome. You'd never expect to find so many great beers available in a train station. It's even updated seasonally. Right now, they have all sorts of Christmas ales.

If they would only stay open a bit later, I can guarantee I'd have a pint here before every train back to NYC.

I can't say for sure why we chose to spend our afternoon at Winners and not Losers when we all know where my friends and I stand. However, with some folks (not me) it's probably difficult to diagnose the full extent of their problems with a cursory glance, so they let us inside anyway.

In any case, Winners might look like your average sports bar, but they did have complimentary bail bonds koozies, picklebacks, buckets of six Bud LIghts for $12, and the sweetest bartenders around. 

And although the food is just your standard fried fare, the cook will gladly give you handful of flour as long assure him that you just want to slap your friend in the face with it.

Forget cowboying up. Personally, I prefer to burger up before I do anything at all, and that certainly includes before consuming prodigious amounts of bourbon. 

I'm not sure there's a better choice for a gigantic group of dudes to have dinner. We were seated in the outdoor patio under a few heat lamps, and the staff here handled us like pros: offering advice when it was needed (which included when to urinate outdoors), kept the alcohol flowing,* and brought us plate after plate of excellent eats. 

We started with the habanero wings (not as hot as you'd think, but fantastic), fried pickles, fried mushrooms and more. They've got some great sauces, which I always appreciate: the blue cheese dressing was legit, the honey mustard fantastic, and the homemade Jack Daniels ketchup good on everything, especially the motherfucking TRUFFLE FRIES. With sliced parmesan on top, those things rocked, and the sweet potato and the house fries were nothing to sneeze at either. 

And of course, we ate burgers. Grassfed, juicy burgers. Cooked correctly, well-proportioned to the bun, and flavorful. Not the best I've ever had by any means, but damn good nonetheless. Our waiter made no bones about the fact that the Woodstock was the move, but I must say the pimento cheese option was no slouch. Having tasted both, I'd be hard-pressed to pick between the two. 

Basically, Burger Up held up their end of the bargain: If you put a dish in the name of your restaurant, it has to be good. And it was. 
_________

*Be warned. If you ask for a double bourbon on the rocks, you are basically going to get a pint glass of bourbon. Two in, I was a mess.

Cocktails and Dreams, Flanagan's isn't...and for that we can all be grateful. Of course, I can't promise you that Tom Cruise won't recite inane poems from atop the bar when you come in, but it hasn't happened for me yet.

This is one of the best bars in the Quarter precisely because you'd never know you're a few blocks from Bourbon, and as such they aren't trying to completely rip you off with their prices. The bartenders are good people with heavy hands, and the low-key crowd is always a winner; whether local or out-of-towner, everyone's trying to have a good time, and that's how it should be.

Oftentimes, the first thing I do on a NOLA morning is find a good bloody mary to wander around with, and Flanagan's makes my new favorite bloody in a city full of fantastic bloodys. It's like drinking meat in a glass. In the best way (as if that could be a bad thing). 

"Days get shorter and shorter, nights longer and longer, before you know it, your life is just one long night with a few comatose daylight hours."

He might've been talking about New Orleans.

A charming bar with undeniable character, Pravda specializes in absinthe and vodka. After a stint in Amsterdam, we decided to stick to the latter which is more than enough to sustain your buzz before you stumble home in the AM. 

The real prize here is the bathroom, where there is unfailingly a roach waiting for you, and at least once, a phone number scrawled on the wall requesting a picture of your genitals.

There are a lot of bars on Bourbon St. that can give you the same things you can get here: live music, cheap drinks, aggressive shot girls, grimy everything.

While I do love at least 50% of those things, I'm not a fan of this bar in particular. 

I'm pretty sure they can't be blamed for the fact that my wife's wallet was stolen out of her purse that was hanging on her shoulder (but that did happen inside their doors). However, they can be blamed that they wouldn't give a visibly overserved girl water, instead demanding she buy a bottle of it. 

I'll find my aggressive shot girls and grimy everything elsewhere.

Nothing but good things to say here.

We got a great rate via Priceline, the bed was comfortable, and the towels were huge and fluffy. No problems.

Also, I forgot toothpaste, so I called the front desk. They answered "Hello Mr. Peter!" I love that. They sent it up right away, along with a little bottle of Scope and a mini-toothbrush.

And I think we must have stumbled on some sort of convention, because they were giving out sandwiches downstairs. I skipped those because I had to go get myself a cheesesteak, but I did grab some hot chocolate, complete with white chocolate shavings, mini-marshmallows, cinnamon and whipped cream. Fantastic.

I knew it was going to be a great place to stay when we pulled up and there was a man in a wife beater using a nail clipper to trim his calluses on the front sidewalk.

Unfortunately, that usually rock-solid indicator of quality was a bit off. 

I was surprised that a man like that would stay in a place where the beds are so uncomfortable, the shower is so unimpressive, and the hairdryer is so useless (so says my wife). I do appreciate the risqué touch of the full wall mirrors behind the bed, but the horrible lighting and the general appearance of her husband turned my wife off to the point that it was a futile design choice.

What especially galls me, though, is the blatant favoritism. The room my in-laws booked contained a fridge; where am I supposed to put the leftover wings I definitely should not have ordered on the drive down? Where is my fridge, Microtel? And while my wife's towel was shabby at best, it was downright luxurious compared to the scratchy, threadbare napkin that I was forced to dry my body with. 

This inequity cannot stand. 

At least Tina, at the front desk, was nice. And the room rates are affordable, because you get what you pay for.

There are really only two things you have to do in Philly:

1. Shake your head in disgust at all the Phillies/Eagles fans. 
2. Eat a cheesesteak.

I had #1 well in hand, so that left only the cheesesteak. Fate (or Miriam) brought us to Tony Luke Jr's. The place is spartan; a counter, tables and chairs. No decorations. This is a place to eat meat and cheese, and nothing else.

I recalled seeing an episode of Bobby Flay's Throwdown (see below for rant) with Tony Luke, and I remembered that their specialty is the broccoli rabe they toss on top of their signature steak. So I went for the steak w/ greens, and asked them to throw some whiz on it too. 

The bread was fresh and tasty, the steak plentiful and juicy, and the greens definitely added a nice garlicky flavor. This wasn't the best cheesesteak I've ever had, but it was pretty damn good. And big; at the end of the meal, my companions were debating whether or not to bring the rest of their sandwiches with us. They asked me what I was going to do with mine. 

Bitch, please. I ate that shit. 

***

Throwdown Rant: Sure, the premise is cool; challenge people to see if you can beat them at their specialty. Competition breeds excellence. But why is deception necessary? Why does the Food Network have to lie say they are doing this whole showcase on them because they make the best cheesesteaks (for instance) around? 

Because then, when fuckin' Bobby shows up and ruins the whole thing, half these people look like they want to cry. They were so jazzed up at being chosen, at being recognized for their excellence in a particular area of cooking...and then they see Bobby's smug face and they realize they've been sandbagged.

These people are proud of what they do, and instead of being celebrated (as they originally believed), suddenly they have to go up against some d-bag who has been preparing for this for who knows how long, and has the benefit of picking out a ton of gourmet ingredients that could never be used on an everyday basis because it would cut into their profit margins. It shatters them. Fuck Bobby Flay. I want to see him lose every time.
