At least once in their life, everyone should partake in the pleasure that is a jazz brunch.

While Muriel's might not serve the best food in the French Quarter, their brunch is an experience anyone with a soul will enjoy. After all, this might be the only time in your life that it's acceptable to eat veal, or a pork chop, or pecan-crusted drum first thing in the morning. 

My alligator hash and her andouille omelette were solid, if a bit overpriced. (Don't be frightened by the gator; it's in tasty sausage form, and you wouldn't know what it was if they didn't tell you.) The flavors were good, but the eggs (poached and scrambled) were overcooked. 

But although I might not revisit either of our entrees, I would GLADLY start any day with Muriel's Bloody Mary and the ridiculously rich crawfish and goat cheese crepes. That's the move here. 

The band starts the party and keeps it going, and in between songs you'll see that they are not only talented performers, but genuinely good guys as well. Not realizing my absolute ineptitude with all instruments, the leader asked if I wanted to sit in on bass. I declined, but offered him some of my Bloody Mary. Now we are best friends forever and ever. 

And ever.

I'll say it: I'd switch teams for John Besh. 

Restaurant August was already among my favorite restaurants in the nation, and Luke is a casual alternative that offers up an entirely different but equally tasty view into New Orleans food. 

For one thing -- and let's be serious: probably the most important thing -- they make an EXCELLENT burger. It is massive (and shareable according to some), covered in caramelized onions, Allan Benton's bacon, caramelized and Emmenthaler Swiss cheese. And although the brioche bun stands up well, it's unavoidably messy when cooked to a juicy medium rare. Our bartender friend informed us that this particular burger was chosen as 8th in the nation; I'm not sure by whom, but I'm not mad I got it, just mad I'm not on the committee. 

The shrimp and grits are also apparently a specialty of the house. We were told that they do them a bit differently than most places; as far as I can tell, they just cook the shrimp perfectly, and make the sauce good enough to drink. 

I was a bit disappointed that the fries were cooked past crispy into crunchy territory, but the lady on my left loved them all the same. For me though, the only downsides were said fries and the fact that their bloody mary is merely a mix (although I do like the Gator Blood), and they don't provide a spicy bean. Sacrilegious, I know, but give them a chance to make it up to you with the food.

Welcome to The Hutton, the Unofficial Bachelor/ette Party Hotel of Nashville.

At least that how it seemed. On our own mission of mayhem, we ran into large group after large group of folks also there to celebrate a friend's impending doom...nuptials. I meant nuptials. 

But I can't blame any of them for choosing the Hutton, because as far as I can tell, this is the best hotel in all of Nashville. All right, this might be the only hotel I've hit up in town,* but I have absolutely no complaints and I'm not sure how it could've been better.** Basically though, they've got everything I want:

-Free, fast wireless. Without even the hassle of a username/password.
-Clean, well-appointed rooms with outlets everywhere.
-The most comfortable of beds.
-A modern, gorgeous bathroom with every amenity.
-A friendly, courteous staff that was on top of our every need, and didn't even stop the 3:30 am Natty Ice chugging contest that took place on the front steps.***

Well, almost everything. They didn't let me extend my checkout time past noon. But I can't really blame them; I would've wanted us out as fast as possible too.
____________

*The filthy fleabags I slept in during college visits do not count as hotels. 
**Unless they could somehow find the hundreds of dollars that seem to have gone missing from my bank account at some point over the weekend.
***Although, several people who shall remain nameless would've sincerely appreciated it the following morning if the contest HAD been stopped.

This. This is why St. Louis is known for barbecue.

For starters, Bogart's makes some of the best ribs I've ever had. They are properly cooked, porky as hell (in the best way), and if I had been smart enough to order a full slab, I would've eaten until I was very, very ill. 

As it is, a half slab of ribs is a solid meal, and Bogart's offers the generous and astonishingly sweet deal of adding a 1/4 lb. of any meat on for just a few bucks. Forgive my saying so, but if you don't add on at least some burnt ends, you're a goddamned fool. 

The burnt ends are the most delicious meat candy you've ever been lucky enough to put in your mouth, and walking out of here without any is the worst mistake you've made since the 90s.*

I'm of the opinion that neither the burnt ends nor the ribs need anything else, but Bogart's offers up several sauces for your use. Of the four, the Sweet Maegan Ann is my favorite, with its sweet molassesy goodness mixing in very well with pulled pork (which does need something else). My wife is a very saucy lass, and she threw the Voodoo and the Vinegar in there as well. 

As always, sides are an afterthought to meat, and Bogart's could honestly serve slaps to my face along with those ribs and I'd still come back for more. Thankfully for my already misshapen face, they've got a delicious deviled egg potato salad, some nice pickles, beans, and slaw instead. 

To sum up: 

Come here. Get ribs, burnt ends and some sides (more than you think you need of everything). Eat all of this food on the picnic tables outside. Listen to the blues covers coming out of the speakers. Enjoy the beautiful day and our place atop the food chain, because at one point in human history we were just gnawing on berries and sticks. And barbecue is better than that. 
_____________

*Don't think we don't remember that summer.

12 Facts About Snake & Jake's. It's Christmas [Club Lounge], after all.

1. It is the best dive bar in existence.*
2. It has the best dive bar name in existence. 
3. You drink for free if you are naked.
4. I've only seen guys take advantage of this.
5. It isn't pretty.**
6. I don't know if I've ever been there before 3 am.
7. It embodies that saying, "Nothing good happens after 2 am."
8. Don't leave with anyone you meet here. 
9. Your decision-making skills are impaired. 
10. They probably have a gun.
11. Nobody will ever see you again.
12. This is New Orleans, and I love it.
____________

*Undisputed, now that Mars Bar is no more.
**I suppose this depends on your taste.

Warm beer. Lousy food. Poor service. If you want to see just how ironic that sign is, step inside.

If you don't want to wait, go early. If you don't mind being part of an impromptu party in the street, go whenever.

If you don't want to miss out, get the alligator cheesecake. 

If you have an enormous appetite, or just want to get something that'll last you three days, get the stuffed pork chop.*

If you're lucky, Jack will be in the restaurant, jumping on tables, dancing on the bar, telling stories, pouring free shots and enjoying life.

If you want to dance off the heavy food, head to the Maple Leaf next door. Rebirth is on Tuesdays, Papa Grows Funk on Mondays.

If you're looking for a quintessential New Orleans experience, a meal that embodies this city's focus on good food, good drinks, and good times, go to Jacques-Imo's.
_________

*New Orleans is the only city I know of where bums will straight up ask you for your leftovers as you walk home from dinner. In NYC, if you try and give your leftovers away, a bum is likely to list his dietary restrictions before refusing. I'm not sure if that says more about the food or the cities.

The frontman insisted that we make a little noise if we came to party in this mo'fucka... and since we made some noise, I must admit that we were in fact there to party in this mo'fucka. 

Maison is one of many stellar spots to catch some live music along Frenchmen. If you like the sound of the band, just head on in because there's no cover. The bartenders are quick and smart, the drinks could be more expensive (I suppose), and they've got food if you need the fuel.

Remember though, there's no cover, so you probably want to tip the band or you'll find them ALL in bed with your girl in the morning. They know voodoo.

The Good.

1. This place is huge. If you need to seat 14 people together for brunch at the last minute, this is probably your best bet in the neighborhood. The back patio is perfect when the weather's nice, too. 

2. All of our servers were exceedingly nice. 

3. The fried chicken sandwich is pretty solid. The ham french toast is good if you like a big ham steak. My wife didn't, but I did so I ate her big ham steak. The breakfast potatoes are excellent, especially when combined with ketchup and hot sauce. All the dishes are fairly striking; presentation matters to these folks. 

The Bad.

1. They were understaffed. Our server also appeared to be bartending, and she was understandably a little frazzled, and missed a few things. 

2. Judging by our other meals in Fishtown, KQ is a bit overpriced, and the portions (except for the ham french toast) are a little on the smaller side for said prices (my fried chicken was barely visible inside the bun that swallowed it up). 

The Weird.

1. When asked about her preference between a few different dishes, she recommended the ham french toast if we were looking for a smaller portion. When our food arrived, the ham french toast was without a doubt the largest plate at the table.

2. My brother. He ordered both a cold brew and a hot coffee, which confused our server to the point that they either thought he was kidding and forgot the cold brew, or just didn't bring the cold brew out of spite for his weirdness.

The French Quarter is a touristy place. And when I say touristy, I mean that people will rip you off every chance they get. If you are looking for any sort of groceries, at somewhat decent prices, this is your spot. 

For example: I wanted some Tony Chachere's Creole Seasoning because I can't seem find it in NYC, and Rouse's sells it for $2, as opposed to the $6 they want at the tourist shops.

And if you don't have anywhere to cook, and you're just in town to drink yourself into a blind stupor, the liquor prices here are as good as you'll find in the area.

Sitting outside in the early spring air, across from a beautiful woman with the streetcar rumbling by...Herbsaint might just be the ideal setting for a date. It is an airy, casual space with a lively bar crowd, and with Donald Link at the helm, we came in with high expectations.

Sadly, the food and drink were not as consistent as one might hope. I had my first Salty Dog (a cocktail, sans pooch as far as I know), and it wasn't too bad; I also had my second pair of frog's legs, and they were good. The burratta salad was solid (although I'm not sure it's possible to make burratta taste bad), but unfortunately our shrimp dish was under-seasoned, overcooked, and actually just...not good. I left shrimp on the plate which, believe me, I have never done. 

A nice meal to be sure, but at this price point, you can do better not too far away. Of Donald Link's spots, I prefer Cochon.

Amada is apparently very popular. At 8:30 on a Tuesday evening, there was a 40 minute wait for seats in the bar area. Luckily, there's a bar in the bar area; bars are good for drinking, and drinking is good for waiting.

It is also quite charming; I took my girlfriend to here for the most romantic of dates. When we arrived, I leaned in, and whispered in her ear, "Bitch, you wait here, I've gotta take a squirt." 

She also needed to use the facilities, and followed me towards the back. As we worked our way past the packed bar, we found ourselves in a long hallway lit only by intermittent candles. A Labyrinth of Passion, if you will, which also happens to be one of the [laughably named] signature cocktails.*

"This is a very romantic hallway," she smiled seductively, "It makes me want to..."
"What? Eat? Are you hungry? Why are you looking at me like that? Are you gassy again?"

I never did find out why she was looking at me like that, but our meal ended up strangely silent, and was punctuated by angry glares from her. Luckily, the food kept us occupied. 

We both enjoyed the crab-stuffed peppers that came highly recommended, as well as the shortrib flatbread and the cheese plate. I was less enamored with the unimpressive mushroom rice recommended by a friend we made in the bar. He was a vegetarian though; I should've known he couldn't be trusted.

All in all, a slightly pricey spot with good tapas and better atmosphere.
__________

*Talk to Her? Broken Hugs? All I know is that I couldn't order a Law of Desire and respect myself in the morning, so I got myself a Matador. Because nothing says "macho" like drinking in a strong, Spanish man. (On the real, I enjoyed the bourbon, elderflower and ginger concoction.)

Drago's is basically a hotel bar. But they are a hotel bar with huge, decadent, heart-clogging* charbroiled oysters and Abita Amber, which automatically makes them better than most hotel bars. 

And if you're nice to your bartender, he might bring you some chips that taste exactly like pappadam.
__________

*I love clogging my heart, but it tastes like Drago's might use margarine in their preparation, which is more heart-clogging than I would normally like.

Let's face it, people. I am the best. You know it, and I know it. The world has never seen such a combination of average height, sub-par intelligence, weird facial structure and irrational self-confidence.

And even though most places should pay me just to walk through the door, d.b.a. sets itself apart as one of the only places that I willingly pay a cover, because I have never had anything less than an absolutely awesome time. 

Every time I show up here, there is good live music; some shows you'll show up for specifically, some you'll stumble upon. All fun. There are excellent options for all sorts of booze and beer. The crowd is laid-back and amped up at the same time, even though I know that makes no sense. 

Perhaps I have bestowed upon it out-sized expectations that no establishment can live up to, but d.b.a. epitomizes the thing I love most about New Orleans; unlike any other place in my experience, it seems as though every single person around you...guy, girl, native, tourist, freak, ghoul...is just out to have a good time. 

This is my favorite bar in my favorite neighborhood in one of my favorite cities in the entire world. Forgive the cliche, but pay your cover, walk inside, and laissez les bon temps rouler.

Things I Like About The Logan.

1. Somehow* they had the most affordable** rooms in the area (with double beds). 
2. The bars downstairs (Urban Farmer and the other one) are gorgeous. 
3. All the lights (except the blinding ones in the bathroom) are on dimmer switches. 
4. Good beds. 
5. Good showers.
6. The alarm clock is some crazy Bluetooth hybrid that charges your phone and doubles as a speaker you can play anything you want through.

Things I Don't Like About The Logan.

1. They aren't great at communication. I specifically left word at the front desk for them to give my brother a key when he arrived (late, as always). Somehow, there was no record of that, which cost me a little sleep. 

2. The valet fee is $55/day. I don't drive a lot, but am I wrong in thinking that's absurd? I feel as though parking should be included when you stay at a hotel of this caliber. And even if it isn't, I feel like the service needs to be faster if I'm paying $55/day + tips for valet parking. And if it does happen to cost the ridiculous amount of $55/day, they should pay the valet guys (who obviously work hard) enough and tell us customers that they make good wages, and not to worry about tipping. Maybe they do pay them well enough, but there was no notice I could find, so we were still tipping them on top. You know, because we aren't animals. 

Solid hotel, though.
____________

*Hotwire.com.
**Still not affordable, really. But better than some.

If you're in need of some real food in Fishtown around midnight, the late night menu at Interstate is as good as many regular menus.

We drove in late and got down with a legitimately fantastic burger that was more rare than medium rare (juicy as fuck), chicken fingers, guacamole, and various draft beers (anything from sours to stouts to bocks to IPAs to hefeweisens). They call this a drafthouse for a reason. 

You can turn any of those beers you order into a beer and a shot too. I don't think they actually have beer/shot combos, but you just order a shot and there you go. Stay for too many rounds with your friends and you may hear a story you didn't want to about using Nair inappropriately. 

The only thing I don't like about Interstate is that they have Hunt's ketchup. What is that nonsense? Heinz, people. It's the only real ketchup. Don't mess with a good thing.

This is such a weird coincidence. Yo Mama's is exactly like MY mama's house! 

Lit only by sleazy red lights, it's filled with S&M gear, mannequins wearing g-strings, creepy photos of people in compromising positions, paintings of lions getting busy, AND they've even got the SAME stripper pole upstairs! Just like home. 

Oh yeah, and if you're hungry, this place serves some of the juiciest, messiest, most delicious burgers EVER.* The peanut butter burger is definitely good, and a unique combination worth trying, but overall, I prefer the seasoned flavor of the Texas BBQ burger, or the classic combo on the bacon & bleu cheese burger.** I haven't tried the one topped with caviar yet, but you better believe I will.

Lastly, I wanted to mention that yo' mama is so ugly she makes onions cry. 

Yeah, it's a lame one. And yeah, the dozens hasn't been cool since those Snaps! books from back in 5th grade. But how can you hate on a joint that puts a different "yo' mama" joke on every receipt?
________

*I'm sure my opinion is not influenced by shots taken of the 50 different kinds of tequila you can drink here.
**Really, you can't go wrong adding smokey chunks of bacon to either the burger, or the baked potato you're getting on the side.

Chefs, friends, yelpers, food writer acquaintances, cousins, clowns...all of them have been telling me for years that I need to eat a meal at Zahav, as it is ostensibly the best restaurant in all of Philadelphia. Granted, that is a fairly low bar (seeing as how this is just a sad little town* filled with Phillies fans and worse, Eagles fans), but Zahav easily met and obliterated the outsized expectations. 

There were eight of us, and we decided to spring for the Taste of Zahav. With 16 mezze and 8 al ha'esh (skewers) to choose from, we quite literally ate everything the menu had to offer, and a few things that it didn't.** And I loved every single bite.

From the colorful and gorgeous Salatim plates (think the Israeli version of banchan) through the surprisingly fantastic and varied desserts, Zahav maintains a level of quality that is astonishing. I'm not going to lead you through each item, but just call out a few of my favorite things:

1. The warm, Turkish hummus paired with their impossibly fluffy laffa was the best of the hummus. Not just their hummus. I mean it is the best of all the hummuses (hummusi?) in the world. 

2. The fried cauliflower is as good as any vegetable has any right to be.

3. Anything where beets is involved. 

4. Of course, the grilled haloumi. As with all haloumi, eat it quickly. And rejoice.

5. The wine pairing. Not just perfect pairings, but an incredible value as well. I would certainly choose this over cocktails on a return trip. 

6. The sirloin shishlik. It will make a believer out of vegetarians, and it will make the meal for anyone hesitant about eating things they've never heard of (it's a steak skewer, people).

7. The lamb tartare in lettuce wraps is ridiculous. Order this. 

Speaking of lamb tartare, Zahav has an uncanny ability to take dishes that may sound unappetizing to your average diner, and turn your preconceived notions on your head. Duck hearts, lamb tongue...even if you're a little hesitant, give them a shot and you'll realize that this kitchen could make anything taste delicious.

And therein lies my only issue with the meal I had at Zahav: I wanted to taste everything, and everything tasted fantastic.

I realize that this doesn't sound like a problem, but prior to our meal, we spent the balance of the day drinking and eating (as usual). However, the Taste of Zahav is surprisingly affordable, so we assumed that it wouldn't be too large a meal and that we could handle it. This was a serious miscalculation. By the time dessert rolled around, I was simultaneously doing my best to take at least one bite of everything, and also trying not to die. My stomach just quit on me.

About twelve hours after we ate dessert, I finally felt like I could take another bite of food. And please believe that the first thing I did that morning was pull our leftovers out of the hotel fridge and desperately inhale them them with a pair of coffee stirrer chopsticks. 

What I'm trying to say is that this was one of the best meals I've had in recent memory. 
____________

*Just kidding, everyone in Philly except Eagles fans.
**The incredibly hospitable staff knew we were celebrating, and brought us a few dishes on the house.

This place felt a bit too much like a fraternity house basement. And I'm not saying I'm too good to hang out in a fraternity house basement, just too old. 

There were also far too many angry dudes who looked like they were drinking straight out of their own personal pitchers of beer in order to get up the courage to punch someone (probably me) in the face. 

But at least they had Buck Hunter.

Crispy, fatty chunks of salty bacon (strewn about so liberally that many morsels littered the surrounding plate), buttery eggs and melted cheese laid upon a flaky, freshly baked croissant...this is breakfast sandwich perfection. 

I wouldn't change a thing.

Get there early though, because I can certainly see how the wait might become excessive as they get busier. However, if this one menu item is any indication, Merchant is worth waiting for. After an evening of excess, that pancetta croissant will be the best $5 you've ever spent. 

And even though she may have declined food, bring your lady friend a macchiato. She deserves it considering she basically carried your fat ass home last night.

They say everything's bigger in Texas, but I've found that hotel rooms are bigger in St. Louis. A standard king room was big enough to be a suite at this joint. The bathroom is bigger than my apartment, and it sports a serious shower and a SEPARATE bath so nice that my wife ran out and bought some weird bath salts (but not the fun kind). 

I did find that despite many, many, many lights in the room, the lighting is actually terrible. On the other hand however, the blackout curtains do the trick and I could've slept in the fantastic bed for the rest of my life if I didn't have to fly home.

The only thing sad about our stay was that some ignoramus has defiled the artwork* that was in our bathroom, but other than that, it was a beautiful stay. 
_____________

*There was a lot of random writing on the painting, and above where it reads "dry like an oil well" someone has scrawled in, "My lady parts are..."

If the people you're with have never been to Bourbon Street, or are just insistent on spending some time there for gods know what reason, the Cat's Meow is about as good as it gets. I could probably do without this entire street...forever, but much like cats,* this bar is growing on me.

They've perfected the art of MC-led karaoke,** with talented singers/dancers that get the party started and then keep the party moving. If you must head to Bourbon, sing your karaoke, take your shitty shots, and woo your woos here. 
_____________

*If only because of this stupid idiot: https://vimeo.com/148491871
**Although, the song selection is very, very limited. Journey, piano bar favorites, and Top40 only.

You have to love a hotel bar that's perfectly cool with 18 dudes noticeably binging at 11 am. Perhaps it's because the entire Hutton seemed to be filled with bachelor and bachelorette parties. Perhaps it's because we somehow blinked and ran up an enormous bar tab (it isn't the cheapest spot around) without even partaking in the excellent-looking food that was being paraded past.

Regardless, they treated us quite well.

In fact, the manager was not only keenly interested in finding us things to do, he also offered fine tips on where to meet the lovely ladies of Nashville, as well as midget strippers. Although, we didn't even ask about the latter, that information was just volunteered. 

Seriously, we didn't.

Things I Recommend at Kraftwork:

1. Calling ahead if you have 11 people. Probably a good idea anywhere. We had to split into two tables because you can't just walk in at prime brunchtime and expect an open table for 11. 

2. The fries. I was told they were the best fries in the world. I disagree. They are very good fries, but I think Donkey Kong is the best game ever.

3. Beer. They have a lot of it, and you should drink it. I had an excellent Founders gose, but you do you. Also, the bloody mary is very solid.

4. The roasted beet salad. Everyone likes goat cheese fritters, and if you eat beets you can all talk about the fun colors in your poop the next day. (Yes, we're delightful conversationalists.)

5. The fried chicken and waffles. With two eggs, it's a gigantic, delicious meal.

6. Telling the server that your parents are sitting at the other table, and they will be paying for your table as well.

Things I Don't Recommend at Kraftwork:

1. The beer can chicken sandwich. It wasn't bad, really it was just a little bland and the pulled chicken wasn't really what I was expecting (and I almost broke my tooth on a bone lost in there). Then again, I don't know what I was expecting. Either way, if you're in a chicken mood go for the chicken and waffles.

2. Telling the server that your parents are sitting at the other table, and that they will be paying for your table as well...unless that's actually true. This can get you in trouble.

3. Chatting the server up about the origins of electronica in the krautrock scene. They don't know what you're talking about, and you sound like a dick. Yeah, I'm talking to you.

Sure, it's not always the most reliable mode of transportation, but it gets you quickly from the Quarter to Uptown via St. Charles, the most beautiful street in the city, it only costs $1.25, and it's historic. You can't hate on history.

Also, the drivers are hilarious.

A woman and her child were walking too close to the track, and our guy powered past as she yanked the kid out of the way, rang the bell and screamed, "You must not want that kid!"

I wouldn't want that kid, either.

I came to St. Louis for a wedding. When I wasn't doing wedding things, I wanted to (1) eat some barbecue and (2) see this arch. I must admit that I enjoyed the former far more. 

In my limited arch experience I guess it's one of the better ones, landing somewhere behind the best and in front of the worst arches in Arches National Park. Unfortunately, if we're counting the Arc de Triomphe as an arch, The Gateway Arch is going to get bumped down another notch. 

I hate to say it, but I found this Arch to be far less impressive after we took the ride to the top. My reasons are twofold:

1. In the little video they play before you get in the tiny little cars to ascend, they talk a lot about the Eads Bridge, an impressive structure that was the symbolic Gateway to the West. A lot of history surrounds the bridge, and they talk a lot about how Eads built a dream for America. And then the video ends, because there's apparently nothing interesting to say about the Arch. Or maybe there is, but I'm assuming there isn't because it wasn't mentioned. 

2. The system is poor. It takes about 45 very crowded, uncomfortable minutes to go up, see a pretty solid view of the city for about 25 seconds, and come back down. Nearly all of that is spent waiting in line in the company of screaming children. 

If I were you, I'd just appreciate the Arch from down below. You'll probably end up liking it more.

You probably didn't know me in high school. But I did. So take my word for it: I was the WORST. I ruined furniture. Raided liquor cabinets. Destroyed priceless Oriental rugs. Ate EVERYTHING. I assure you, my parents couldn't wait to get me out of the house. 

But after I moved to New Orleans, something odd happened: my parents were suddenly eager to spend time with me. And let's be serious, it wasn't for the pleasure of my company. 

My theory? They were just using me as an excuse to get to Commander's Palace. When my father started planning a visit to New Orleans, who do you think he called first? His beloved younger son? Laughable. He called the maître d' at Commander's. 

And I don't even blame him. 

Commander's Palace is the best. Every meal here feels like a special occasion. The service is warm and friendly; professional, but not stuffy. They truly make you feel not only welcome, but like an honored guest. 

There are no bad seats in the house. There is the gorgeous garden, as well as several different rooms, and they are all beautiful. If I had my druthers, I would sit in the back room with the tree growing in the middle, encased in glass. I love that they walk you through the kitchen on the way to your table; it conveys cleanliness and trust. As they lead you past, stop and take a whiff. Smell that? That's happiness.

And of course, the food is spectacular. I have loved every single bite of everything they've served me. 

:: lowers voice :: 

Now, I'm going to share something with you. But only you, because I like you. And because I know you'll repay me with drinks the next time I see you.

Although dinner at Commander's is a wonderful experience unlike any other, believe me when I tell you that their lunch is the best deal in the city. 

They have several price fixed options, and it's always changing, but you can pay as little as $16 for an appetizer AND an entree. And not just some worthless garden salad and grilled salmon combo. I'm talking a MEAL. Perhaps their legendary turtle soup, and char-grilled pork over smashed sweet potatoes with barbecued onions, brown sugar roasted apples and a winter mushroom fricassee.

Combine that with 50 cent martinis (that's right I said 50 CENT MARTINIS!) and you can have a world-class, eight-martini lunch for $20. 

Although, eight martinis is a lot. Slow down there, tiger.

This was the best cheesesteak I've eaten in Philly. And admittedly, my experience with Philly cheesesteaks is somewhat limited, but I assure you that my meat and cheese sandwich résumé is quite impressive. And this was a damn good sandwich. Onions, mushrooms, provolone...perfect. 

We only got a few weird looks when my buddy jokingly mentioned he would beat his girlfriend for one of these. I think he was joking. I wouldn't beat his girlfriend for one of these. Well, maybe I would if I could take her, but she's a big woman.

If you ever want an entire ice cream store to stop what it's doing and glare daggers in your direction, you should loudly state, "Chocolate ice cream is an abomination."

It's like going into the Vatican and denouncing the Pope.* People aren't into it.

But I stand by my statement. My wife has been craving ice cream a lot lately, and she likes chocolate ice cream, which is stupid when there is the far more delicious Cookies 'N Cream available. Vanilla based ice creams are just better.

Weckerly's Cookies 'N Cream is top notch, if you were wondering. They also have a very popular flavor called Speckle & Scrap which is chocolate ice cream, vanilla ice cream, and chocolate chip cookies...which would be fantastic if you took out the chocolate ice cream.

Where Weckerly's really won me over though? The strawberry basil sorbet. It is unique, refreshing, and insanely delicious. Get some this summer. 
_______________

*Obviously I would never denounce the new, awesome Pope. But as someone who routinely puts his foot in his mouth, it's possible that I would've denounced the last Pope. The one with Nazi ties, who resigned. But probably not even then. My strong opinions really only extend to things I can eat.

When I was young(er) and dumb(er), I made an older, wiser friend. He watched me consume a wretched bodega "po' boy" with disgust, and insisted we go get a real sandwich. He took me to Domilise's.

It's been a couple of years, so I was worried that nostalgia and high expectations were going to lead to disappointment, but Domilise's still makes the best shrimp po' boy in New Orleans. This makes it the best worldwide. If you are keeping track, that puts it up with the best sandwiches in existence.

Dressed, with plenty of Cristal, it's untouchable. The French bread is impeccable, the shrimp crisp yet tender, the pickles, hot sauce and everything else culminating in bite after bite of sublime tastiness that will make you hate yourself for ever eating anything else.

The prices have creeped up over the years, but good seafood is worth paying for. If you don't think so, then you've never exploded from both ends from eating the wrong mussels. And I hope you never will.

After wandering around the store for a bit, I ran into an employee.

Me:  Do you have those plastic tubs that you put kegs in?
Him: Honestly man, I have no idea.
Me:  Um...all right. Thanks anyway.
Him: Oh, wait. I've definitely seen those. You just gotta go...
Me: *waits expectantly*
Him: ...find a Home Depot, or a Lowe's or something.

I can understand not having any Wal-Mart pride, or loyalty to your brand, but really, Wal-Mart employee? REALLY?

The only saving grace of this Wal-Mart was the toothless* cashier, who was a very sweet girl. But I have to say...and I'm not one to judge...she had a Twilight tattoo on her forearm. 

I can understand you loved the books, but really, a Twilight TATTOO? REALLY?!
________

*This is an exaggeration. She had one tooth on the top, and a few on the bottom. But she was under 25.

Although Delta in Nashville is nearly as incompetent and worthless as Delta everywhere else, we didn't have to spend too much time in this airport, thankfully. 

No one here is in much of a rush, but everything was run quite efficiently. Despite flying out on a crowded Sunday afternoon, we moved through security quickly and without incident. Smiles abounded, and the fine folk running things didn't steal my peach preserves, even though I'm pretty sure it was over three ounces of deliciousness. As it was the only present I was bringing home for my lady friend from my Tennessee jaunt, I'm grateful, because presents are the only way to make her love me.

12.24.11

When in Rome, do as Romans do.

When in Reno, eat here.

Fresh, house-made bread and pastries daily.

Simple breakfast and lunch menu.  No item over $10.

I went with the California - egg white, monterey jack cheese, avocado, and tomato 
on house made focaccia.  Healthy, simple, delicious.

Don't forget a cup of drip coffee to complete your meal!

Random Monday night, two people.  Indetermined amount of wait time.

Finally sat at the bar.  Water was quick to come, but not the food.

Once again, I didn't get half of what I ordered.  And hello, I was sitting right at the bar, ordering with the chef directly!

Back to regular Sushi Pier next time around.  And hopefully make a reservation or something.

We drove two hours round trip to dine at this place, so I figured it must be to-die-for.  We got there and was told the wait would be an hour.  That's fine, we can gamble in the meantime.  An hour later we returned and they split our group up into 3 different groups.  Um, I thought the point of the long wait was so we can all eat together.  Anyways, we were starving by this point, so I proceeded to order almost 2 of everything.  The (really young) waiter comes by, looks at the four of us, and said...I think that's too much food.  So fine, we cut it to one of everything.

When our food came out, we were so hungry we didn't care what it was on our plate.  I then realized, half of the stuff wasn't even what we ordered!

I think I'm just (still) super bitter about not being to get my hand roll.

03.06.10

And I'm back.  With six others.  We called in to put our name on the list.  I don't think it helped much.

After an hour, and some waiting time at the bar, we squished into a booth.  Round one went smoothly.  Nigiris and hand rolls all around.

Round two had two long rolls that we didn't order.  Plus things that I guess we did order?  But we ate most of it regardless.

$30/person out the door, including beer and sake.

Patience.

Perfect! 

After horseback riding in Goleta, we decided to walk on historic State street...which I have to admit is amazingly charming. Small town feel with historic buildings..... yet tons of shops and very cute. 

Anyway, we happened on this farmers market in the middle of the town on a Tuesday! :) 

They had tons of organic fruits and veggies, cheese, a pie lady and tons of flowers. 

I ended up getting some of my favorite flowers, daffodils! Lovely! Since our local Calabasas farmer's market never has daffodils...and since it was my birthday, it made it all the better.

And for 3.00?! You've gotta be kidding me... plus, it's a potted plant... so if I take care of it correctly.. it should last much longer than a bunch of flowers. :)

Yay! :)

After spending the day in Carpinteria looking at the Seal Breeding area (and baby seals!!!), this place has my SEAL of approval! (Okay, I stole that one from someone - but it was just too good to pass up! Hahahaha!) 

Anyway, we were trying to figure out some place to eat and since we were so close to Santa Barbara, I was thinking how could we not go up and eat there! 

I originally wanted to try this pastrami place but they were closed on Sunday and being near the ocean, made me crave some seafood - and when my boyfriend suggested this place but wasn't sure I would like it (I'm typically not much of a seafood eater - although I'll do shellfish!), it sounded good! The last time I was in Santa Barbara, I was on the pier and I noticed this place. It was constantly crowded but at that time - I was too enamored with the tons of Pelicans on the pier! Anyway, I wanted to try this place out when he mentioned it and away we went! 

Anyway, this place is right on Sterns Wharf! 

It's this smallish, seafood shack type place! The inside is just basically made up of barstools but there are some tables outside by the side of the pier! It's modest inside but you have a great view of the ocean from the inside of the restaurant (and I guess outside too).

Also, as far as service goes, we didn't have any sort of problem at all! We put our names on the list outside and were seated relatively quickly! Also, the server came and took our order quickly and refilled our drinks. We definitely didn't have any problems with that! 

I chose to have one of their specials - half a lobster with Caesar salad! It was absolutely delicious! It came with a little container of butter and the lobster was so delicious! Juicy! Fresh! Tasty! The Caesar salad was also good - it was a vinaigrette Caesar - and added a nice balance to the meal! 

Pump had the Alaskan crab! Honestly, it was even more sweet than my lobster! I thought it was so delicious! Especially with that butter sauce! But it looked hard to get out! 

All in all, I loved this place! The view was amazing and the food was so fresh and just plain delicious! It's not anything super fancy but it's great fresh shellfish! I would definitely come back!

It's a beautiful place to visit. Obviously, it's a farm of roses... so you see rows and rows of rose flowers. My parents owned a flower farm for years... so this is probably much more impressive for someone who hasn't grown up with things like this...

I went on a "tour" of the rose farm and it was lovely. The tour guide was very nice... but I felt as though, not very knowledgeable. I don't know.... I wasn't that impressed.

Other than that, they give you a little brunch/lunch deal. We were with all much older people (well, everything I like to do typically works out that way...) but it was lovely. Rose tea... definitely the best! Rose lemonade I believe too... :) Some finger sandwiches... they were okay... but I don't eat mayonnaise so I ate half the sandwich (minus the other half with the "bad stuff". hahaha!)

It was lovely... but not something that I feel the need to do again...

Did I mention that I like Santa Barbara? Crazy... because it was a place I never thought I would.... but then again, I am totally like that. I always think something in my head and then change my mind about it...when I actually experience it... so yeah. Typical me.

Anyway, State street is adorable. It has old fashioned charm with tons of stores and restaurants. I definitely need to go back and recheck it out another day... 

Other than that, even at night, it feels like a very safe area. There are always police around, which isn't a bad thing.

The mission itself is really a 5 star place... minus 1 star for the shortness of the tour...and because I remember this mission being so much larger. 

The "tour" is basically following a roped off area... which kind of detracts from enjoying some of the splendor of the place...as I wish we were more able to roam the grounds freely. Meh.

Other than that, it was interesting. Lovely architecture and what not.

There was a big basin... in the church which I guess was for baptisms (or whatever the religious do) and I was trying to figure out if there was anything in it... so I stuck my finger in it...and I can report that there is... hahaha. Oops!

Oh well.

I've had this place bookmarked for quite some time! So when the Pump planned a birthday trip to Santa Barbara for me, I figured instead of seeing the seals we saw last time in Carpinteria, it would be great to see the butterflies this time! (And it was!)

If you come here, thinking that you'll be surrounded by butterflies flying all around you - you'll be disappointed because it doesn't quite look like that!

You'll see some butterflies flying about high above you but the majority of what there is to see is this - high up in the trees! Clusters of butterflies! 

This area is covered with butterfly clusters that are harder to see (and quite honestly look like leaves - but you can barely make out the pattern) but the trees and foliage are just storybook and breathtaking! I love it! And it's just so relaxing! 

And don't miss checking out the sea cliffs when walking out a little from the wooded butterfly grove! It's seriously breath taking! 

What a beautiful place to take in!

Where are you going to go to get a solid sandwich while rocking out to Pentagram? Yellow Sub of course! It's seems to draw the alternative crowd and it's full of crazy things seemingly stacked throughout the years? Creepy baby dolls? A pic of young Selma Blair? The logo of Buena Vista the bar with the great Irish Coffee in SF? It's all here. Capocollo and provolone for the win. Oh and rock out too.

Maybe one of the more interesting businesses in one of the strangest strip malls Ive ever seen. Walking in it looks like a fast food place. Milk tea on one side and food on the other. THere are lcd screens above that highlight both generic and Taiwanese specific fare. If not for a friend's rec, we wouldnt have known what to go for or that this place existed. Got the stinky tofu, Taiwanese sausage, beef tendon in chili oil, pork belly bun and green onion pancakes. The pancakes were under cooked but the tofu, tendon and sausage were good. Pork bun was ok. Service is what you'd expect and they were efficient but not too talkative. I guess for Reno this is pretty good.

I used to go to the Truckee one a while back but that's gotten really popular and crowded. Cool to find they opened up one in Reno too. Got a pretty solid iced tea after they couldnt make an iced con panna (even though it says any espresso drink iced). All the workers seem to be young and female. Actually most of the clientele too. The link to the pizza place next door and the cool industrial patio area to the south makes it good for hanging outside. It does get a bit toasty inside as one of the baristas declared as she was pouring.

Similar to my beloved Dutch Bros, a drive through caffeine vendor. The girls working are similarly attractive though not as uber friendly. Their specialty hazelnut coffee is quite good. They also give out a chocolate covered coffee bean with the order. The whole poor coffee convenience thing is being turned on it's head as now you can get better coffee from a kiosk than some cafe's now

Id been to the coffee shop next door a year ago and recently the desire for wings and pizza hit. Ao we dropped in for a few bites. Angey pig which had a load of pork and the baked wings were the fare. Pepperoni, salami, bacon, sausage goodness. The one problem was the outer crust was good but the center was a tad soft in the center. I think the cooking style has to adjust for this i think. Aside from that it's a solid pie and wings. Next time i try the hidden pig which has a garlic sauce instead

Wow people really be hatin on the Steak and Shake. I have a friend from Indiana that doesnt shut up about this place having grown up with it. So when driving through town we had to check it. Didnt realize it was a sit doen style place, though they do have a drive through. Double bacon steakburger, fries and an orange cream shake. Burger was actually pretty darn good as was the shake. Fries were decent but not killer. Servers seem to all be young women while the cooks were all guys. Interesting. Anyways for a fast food joint it's pretty decent.

Holy Moly,. Did Cabela's and Sports Authority have a baby with an amusement park? That is what Scheels is. Lots of sporting goods stuff throughout and then the crazy hunting stuff upstairs. The giant hill of taxidermy is crazy next to a hanging airplane. But then there's more. A ferris wheel! this place is just nutz!

I had no idea Grimaldi's was so open across the country. I always envisioned it as a small place under the Brooklyn bridge. Guess they're all over the place. I did not envision them being in Sparks NV! It's large and very un NYC I have to say. But the pizza was actually pretty solid. Pepperoni, sausage, and black olive. Crust is nice and thin and has a good crunch/chew factor. Not quite the same as my old upper west side go to (replete with two old Italian American dudes) but still solid. I like that they've simulated the old brick oven with the flapping door and such. It's just crazy big with lots of seating which is the opposite of the counter only standing room that Im used to in NY

The Hub has become my coffee of choice in Reno. I've been to the midtown locale and really loved that one too. Though this one is way more spacious, has a great design and it's next to the river and thsoe huge-mungous houses on the hill. Got their Toddy cold brew iced coffee. So damn good. The quote of the day came from my friend who when seeing the new Strada they had yelling" NO WAY!!!" and then running over to practically pet it. Not only great coffee a humorous outcome too.

Haha, I totally forgotten that I had eaten here. Sometimes when you're bored in Truckee the next biggest place for things to do is unfortunately Reno. Sometimes you get caught up with people with not so ordinary lives and they restart their future in less glamorous ways. I never was able to track that person again, but this was one of the stops I made to find them. Had decent solid meal but still It's Olive Garden. Nothing to write home about!

I guess this used to be called Pie Face Pizza? Had read an article about their Backyard Chicken pizza and we were intrigued. Though it's dark and the name was different. We did some more searching and they still had the pizza, just a different name. Walking in, it's hot, dank and smells of cigarettes for some reason. The folks remind me a lot of my time in art school. Lots of tattoos, piercings...alternative lifestyles if you will. There's a girl in a Milan Lucic Boston Bruins jersey putting up posters and flyers for the many bands playing in the area. Wait what? Black Flag is still around? We grabbed our  pizza and took it out to the river and enjoyed the slices in the cool breeze and sunlight.

Why is the meat pie such an alien thing in the US? Pot pie's seem to be few and far between, relegated to the 70s and 80s. When I was in Australia, the savory pie was all over the place. The Cravery seems to be the only business here that is trying to carry this to lukewarm success (ie the one near me closed). Found Z Pie while looking for eats in the area. Got both the beef and lamb pies and they were extremely satisfying. Good savory filling, flaky crust. A meal in a pastry is a good thing! Hope Z Pie spreads the goodness savory pie concept like Australia

I like this old timey aesthetic they tried to put onto the gas station to blend in with the rest of the area. Problem is it's so much newer it still sticks out. The way into here with Cabela's nearby is maybe one of the worst feats of traffic engineering flow I've ever seen. Even with very few people it's a pain in the ass to navigate. The station itself has a huge firezone with tons of cones to tell you to not park there. With so much land here why not just build a separate area instead of including it in the structure then not letting anyone go near it? At least the gas kiosks are standard, maybe one of the few intuitive things here.

This is the burrata that started it all for me. The introduction happened at Per Se in NYC with the rich pairing of Armando Manni's Olive Oil. Holy F. Fresh Mozzarella, encasing a scoop of fresh cream. Hand stretched, it's not stringy but smooth and ultimately very tasty.

What a sweet place. Tiny little shack specializing in the classic tube shaped meat arts.  I had already eaten but lightly so we got another snack. Sauerkraut dog and the orange ice cream shake. So good. Next time it's chili cheese dog time. Dig all the classic hot dog art and knick knacks.

I have to admit that I found this place surprising. I have friends that swear by Taiwan 101 and believe there's no other good Chinese food out in Reno. Well I think this is a new contender. Being mostly Cantonese dishes with some other influences. Got the namesake crawfish with the salted egg sauce, sizzling pepper lamb, deep fried pork intestines, peking duck, ong choy and iced tea .The crawfish and lamb were stellar. Everything else good. Considering where they are, in a strip mall where it's hard to tell there's even a restaurant. It's a gem in the rough. Service is awesome and they take good care of everyone. Definitely worth checking out if you're in the area. 4.3 stars

oh man I almost totally forgot about this place. Years ago I worked with this guy who was totally aggro. We were on a company ski trip and strippers, booze and gambling were on his mind. At some point in the night we end up here. We survey the talent and he ends up with a fairly attractive girl. She starts talking to him and the next song comes on. She's still talking and I hear from him:

"Hey let's go! You're wasting my song here!!"

Oh man. Needless to say we didn't stay too much longer.

'evs.

The scorpion bowl tasted more like a candy bowl filled with cough-syrup flavoring; the two actual gummy worms didn't help. Though you get to keep the giant glass, allowing you to wave it around downtown Reno like you're decreeing something important, it's not worth the effort or the sugar-induced hangover the next day. The appetizer platter was bland at best, and all these goodies will cost you approximately 1.5 arms and half a leg.

There were good things about Fireside, though none of them had anything to do with the products we paid for. It was intimate, good for chatting, good for couples and/or small groups. It has a fire pit in a pool of water, and fairly comfortable couches to lounge on. It's also in the fabulous Peppermill hotel, where you could enjoy a lengthy seizure from all the mirrors and interior neon.

Nice place for a quiet chat and a drink, but bring your credit card and keep the drinks simple.

We had another restaurant in mind on Frenchmen St. After a so-so vibe at the place we were considering -- I honestly don't remember its name -- we bailed and went with a recommendation from the bartender (bah-tenduh) at Hermes Bar at Antoine's.

The place was pretty low-maintenance with a lot of cool-looking servers in hats. It seemed like a mix of tourists and locals.

Since we never got the hang of ordering properly -- us Californians are used to smaller portions -- we asked for an ungodly amount of food. An enormous basket of fried okra, fried chicken, mustard greens, collared greens, mashed potatoes, and cornbread. Though the fried okra was pretty good (also seems hard to mess this up), and the sides were fantastic, the fried chicken stood out for me. That batter is insane. We didn't talk the whole way through the meal: a sign of a good one! Pralines to go made my day later on.

I'd love to spend more time on Frenchmen St. -- for food, music, and bars -- next time we're in town. Nicely out of the way from Bourbon Street madness.

My boyfriend did a very good job picking this place for our first breakfast place during my trip to see him in August.
I loooved the vibe....

It's very movie-ish. I felt like my boyfriend and i were the only "tourists" in the restaurant...

I did enjoy my food... and my boyfriend did too...

They do have a variety of selection to choose from...

Loved the quesadilla.....
Loved the pancake....

Great coffee taste...

Quality is So there... But why only 2 stars? READ on...

I had the almond milk latte and it was good.

The butterscotch cookie was intensely satisfying as well...

But..what's up with the cashier??? Minus 1 star for a rude male (or in between) cashier.
He calls me and my husband over and asks us for our order.. and in the middle of my order; he gets in a conversation with another customer..and lets me repeat my order? oh hell no.
My husband asked if he could get a latte. Male(or in between) cashier asked if chocolate or vanilla.. My husband said chocolate... and he said.. so you want a mocha... He said it in a condescending tone... He might have just left it as how he said it at first. chocolate latte. easy. less confusing. 

My husband got our table while i went to use the restroom...
I came back and saw my husband sitting with a plastic cup of his iced drink and a paper cup of my hot drink.
We were sitting in and why is it that we didn't get a REAL cup like everyone else?
Why did that cashier assume we were to get our orders to go?

I'd think because Santa Barbara is like a tourist spot... they shouldn't be rude to tourists who live in cities with the best coffee EVER. (i miss you Philz Coffee).

Ambiance is Great... it's just full of students and their macbook pros sippin on teas. (FYI. i just read how one coffee shop shut down their wifi and their sales went up! because people who actually pay have a place for them to sit... not with students being there for hours and hours just having one of the cheapest drinks they offer.)

-1 star for not having a trash bin in each stall in the bathroom.
hello. not everything is flushable like the plastic part of a tampon.

GREAT COFFEE.
UNFRIENDLY and RUDE CASHIER.

Total Vibe Killer.

I observed every single person working at that bar. all of them seem to take their job way too seriously.. no personalities shine here.

Do Not Recommend unless you want to feel agitated to punch someone in the face.

Def a must see if you like old churches. The lawn across the street from the church is pretty. We did find girls in bikinis sunbathing too. uhmmm.. weird... 

Moving on....

I liked the rose garden area with the stations of the cross.

I didn't do the tour.. but yes; they have a tour.

The church is pink and HUGE from the outside.

This market is small but has all of the essentials covered, in addition to some very tasty baked goods.  Some highlights from this year (opened in May, I think):

Daily Loaf :  organic flaxseeds and whole-grain flour

Marliscious: the pistachio torte cake is 3 fantastics layers of pistachio cake sandwiched between and enrobed in a pistachio-filled cream.  I have not found a pistachio cake anywhere else and this is just delicious.  The Prinzregententorte is amazing to even look at, with 8+ layers of super-thin sponge cake layered with chocolate cream and covered in a thin chocolate coating; it's very good and has just the right amount of sweetness.  She doesn't always have every cake every time, but you can always order a particular flavor.  
 
Farm Fromage: creamy, organic goat cheese - it's delicious paired with a spring mix salad and glazed walnuts.
 
Frecon Farms: hard cider.  need I say more?
 
Jimmies Cupcake Co.: James Taylor/Boston cream cupcake with a custard filling, vanilla cake, and chocolate frosting.  Personally, I just like the names.  Cupcakes taste pretty good, too, but aren't as fantastic as House of Cupcake's in Pton.
 
Livengood Family Farm - grass fed ground sirloin - makes REALLY good, tender burgers
 
MacDougall's Irish Victory Cake: You HAVE to try the sweet butter cake!  It's rich, buttery, and full of simple, delicious goodness.  They have other varieties but this is the traditional tried-and-true, and, in my opinion, the best.

Definitely stop by if you live in the area and don't feel like driving down to Reading or Ardmore for your farmer's market goods.  I only wish that they had more prepared foods and snacks, like sandwiches and roasted meats.

I really really missed this cozy, eclectic cafe.  It's the prime place for studying or just catching up with friends on a weekend (or before a mixer/dance, if you're in HS...ahh, those good ole days).  My extra frothy cafe latte hit the spot and the baristas are still just as friendly as I remembered.  Make sure you grab a fresh-baked chocolate chip cookie with your espresso, even if it's to go.  Your mouth will thank you.

The chicken here is amazing!  The last time I ad authentic Peruvian rotisserie chicken was at malecon in NY. The skin is crispy and flavorful and the meat juicy. I ordered a whole chicken meaning to save half but...  Oh well, it'll be time to hit the gym. After my sat gorge fest at a NY style deli of course but I digress. Anyhow great food and friendly people. I'll definitely be back because I love my meat.

I really do like this Shop Rite.  The prices and hours are great, and the service is generally decent.  The deli has usually has a special, which is a nice surprise everytime (like turkey for $3.99/lb!), and I always get samples of meats and cheeses to snack on while I wait for my order.  The bakery is usually well-stocked although the donut selection is not as fantastic as Giant's; they do have the essentials, though.  The store itself isn't the most well-organized but it has everything at relatively low prices.  Plus, if you shop on a Sunday morning, they have complimentary coffee, danishes, bagels, and cookies, which is a really nice gesture, I think.  I've also noticed that service has gotten a lot better over the years.  They also have an entire aisle dedicated to Mexican groceries, too, which most other surrounding groceries stores don't have.

Thursdays during Lent are my burgers days so I decided to stop in to grab a cheeseburger and coffee milkshake.  The burger was just okay: 2 thin, kinda dry patties and 2 cheese slices.  I was kinda surprised at the size since they claim to be better than Five Guys.  Well, um...not quite.  The housemade chips were the saving grace; they were fresh, thick-cut, and crispy.  Much better than your Lay's or Herr's.  My milkshake was just okay; it was decent but didn't really stand out.  I actually would have much rather gone to Baskin a few blocks down.  So, in summation: come here for the chips, and get your burger and shakes elsewhere.

The food here is just okay.  The crawfish etouffee was on the small side and not very flavorful.  The puff pastry wasn't as flaky and light as I have had at Border's in MA.  Lobster ravioli was decent but the filling wasn't seasoned that well; the blush sauce was pretty good, though.  The grilled eggplant with goat cheese and pesto was very different but delicious.  Give it a try if you are looking for something different!  Service was good, but a little on the slow side.  Prices are on the steep side.  I did like the fact that they have espresso drinks (latte anyone?) and offer wifi (can't live without the ipad).

I love the Strawberry and Irish Mint.  The froyo here is creamy and smooth but it can definitely add up at $.49/oz. Nevertheless, I love the flavors and the fact that they have tapioca bubbles as toppings.  It is also extremely clean, which is another plus.  It's not Pinkberry, but it definitely cures a froyo craving.

This is the cutest thai place in the area.  The restaurant itself is decorated like an Asian nursery rhyme with elephant marionettes and bird cages hanging near the windows.  It's small but cozy, and the service was fantastic.  The waitress was so sweet and constantly refilled our water glasses.

In terms of food, this is Chiangmai's sister restaurant so it was excellent.  I had the lady's slipper, which was nicely presented.  It's not that complicated to make (steamed chicken breast stuffed with shrimp spinach, and shittake mushrooms, then covered with a glaze of orange sauce) but did look pretty and taste good.  I wish that I had gotten a curry since I did sample the panang curry and it was amazing.              I will be back to try more since it's soooo close to where I'll be living that it's likely i'll have to refrain from ordering here every other day.  I'll give it 4 stars for now (4.5 actually) and if the seafood medley is as good, it'll be 5.

Oh goodness the red curry here is addictive.  As is the lamb rack.  It is cooked to tender perfection and the seasoning really brings out the meat's flavor without overpowering it.  One of my favorite Thai places.  And it's only 5 min away!

I wasn't that hungry today but we wanted to grab a bite on our way to the dealer, so we decided to meet here for a healthy and light late lunch.  I decided on a cup of the mushroom bisque  accompanied by a croissant, which was surprisingly filling and very savory.  The bisque was delicious: creamy and savory with a hint of fennel and perhaps truffle (I think?).  Anyhow, whatever the exact flavors were, they meshed well and made for a very good soup.  The croissant was buttery and flaky, although it wasn't amazing; The Little Chef in Princeton still holds the crown for best croissants.  They do bake them on the premises here every day and you can definitely taste the difference, though (not a fan of mass-produced supermarket croissants).  It also comes with a side of pecan butter, which was quite possibly the most delectable spread ever.  It was a nice change from the typical cinnamon butter and just so creamy with a perfect balance of pecan and the butter's inherent flavor.  It almost made me want to get another croissant just so I could finish it.  But then I would have been brought more butter and gluttony would have taken over.  So I desisted...with much restraint on my part.  Dad's BLT with pepper turkey bacon and aadditional semi-spicy fried egg was great and makes me want to add a fried egg to every BLT from now on; it's absolute ingenuity.  My friend's shrimp salad on croissant was creamy and fresh, but it's not my favorite because I'm not a huge fan of raw celery; your mileage may vary, though.  And of course, we split the truffle fries because you can't come here and not get an order.  It would be the equivalent of going to Five Guys and getting a plain "veggie" burger (if you're not vegetarian, that is).  Service was superb, as always, and our food was served quickly.

Stopped in to grab 2 salads tonight.  It came to $9.75 for 2 small cobb salas with addiitional cheese.  Not bad.  The bbq chicken was nicely seasoned, the avocado was fresh, and the scallions added a nice touch.  The portions are very small (pint-sized) but the ingredients are high-quality and the ranch dressing was great.  Plus, they have groupon now! deals everyday, so it came to only $5 for both.  Not bad at all.  And you get rolls with the salads too.  Great for lunch if you work in the area and want to grab a quick lunch with a friend or coworker.

We had the pistachio pesto and apple crisp.  The pizza was delicious.  It sounds rather strange but the flavors meshed very well.  The apple crisp was also very good. Cooking instructions were straightforward and I loved that it was hot and fresh from our oven.  It would have taken longer for delivery.

I would give this sorry excuse for a Manhattan Bagel zero stars if I could.  Stopped in to grab coffee and a bagel with cream cheese and ended up waiting over 25 minutes for my food.  No excuse/apology/"miss, your order is coming up."  There were only 5 customers (with normal-sized orders, not catering) in front of me!  The place itself is tiny and not very clean.  There is minimal seating and the tables were dirty and covered with crumbs and used napkins.  They do not take any national offers (not a big deal) and don't make any of the special bagels like the CA powerbagel, chocolate chip, asiago, onion (not even a special variety!), or bialys or bagel sticks, ALTHOUGH they DO list them on the menu, along with prices (much bigger deal).  The coffee was cold (it had obviously been sitting in the carafe for a long time) and barely passed as colored water; usually, the House Blend is medium-bodied and decently flavored.  The coffee here was incredibly weak and tasted off.  I would almost venture that they used a generic/less expensive coffee blend and just passed it off as the official blend.  The everything bagel was so salty that I had to guzzle 2 whole bottles of Nestle Pure Life in my car.  And I hate drinking plain water!  It was also way too dough and did not have the nice characteristic shell (the entire reason for going to a Manhattan Bagel in the first place versus Brueggers or Einstein's or Panera's). It came to $4.54 for a small coffe wannabe and a barely edible bagel with cream cheese that I threw away half of.  Avoid at all costs and go to Panera's across the street.

The food is pretty expensive and the bagels are average.  My everything lacked that aromatic, crispy shell but it was soft and flavorful with plenty of cream cheese.  And I do love the fact that they are open early and serve La Colombe coffee.  A decent bagel place but not an outstanding one.

Solid tandoori chicken but it is a bit on the dry side.  An order is comprised of 2 drumsticks and 2 thighs. The roti is very chewy and a bit tough, so stick with the naan.  They also use quite a bit of butter, as well.

The Three Cup Chicken is amazing here as is the stir-fried cabbage with chili.  I actually think that it's better here than at Jane G's.  The salt and pepper jumbo shrimp and mei fun are also solid.  The mei fun comes with plenty of protein and egg.  The prices are definitely much more reasonable and the $8.50 lunch specials are fantastic.  A portion will easily last 2 meals, and the food is served very quickly.  It's also close enough to campus that a 1 hour student-faculty lunch is completely feasible.

Food is the same as that from any other panera.  Service is just not that friendly though. Pardonnez moi for asking for freezer bags for my bagels. Does it really cause you to have to exert that much more effort?

I love this cute little BYOB with Thai and Laotian dishes that pack a nice, flavorful punch.  We were here for UC Dining Days and the dishes were great.  I had the chicken satay app with the red curry chicken, and found both to be very good.  The satay was juicy and flavorful with a great peanut dipping sauce, and the curry was very solid although it wasn't very spicy.  I also had a few bites of the triple flavor tilapia in the sweet and sour sauce, and really like the crispy, pan-seared fillet combined with the garlicky sauce.  Will definitely have to get this next time.  Most restaurants like to fry the fillet when they make a sweet and sour dish but pan searing actually brings out the flavor more and gives that delicious crispy exterior without killing your arteries.  We finished off with the mango sticky rice and coconut rice pudding.  While the mango sticky rice was very good, I liked the coconut rice pudding more because I love all things coconut and this was a delicious coconut-based concoction.  If you are in the area this week, and need to grab a bite, definitely stop in for the $15 dining days special.  It's a great deal and the food is very good.  They also have homemade beef jerky at $6/order, which I couldn't resist getting to-go; while it wasn't as fantastic as my aunt's homemade jerky, the meat was very well-marinated and flavorful and great paired with the accompanying chili paste.  The ambiance is very cozy and the unique curry soup bowls add a nice touch.  Service was friendly but we did have to ask for water refills a few times.

We came to try the Prix Fixe and it was surpringly good.  I had the prime rib, which was juicy, fatty, and flavorful - just as a good prime rib should be; I can't stand overdone beef..  Was it the best ever?  Not quite but it was still tasty and definitely satisfying.  To be completely honest, the crab cakes are probably the better pick, with plenty of lump crabmeat, but sometimes you just really want artery-clogging steak.  The clams casino appetizer was flavorful with plenty of actual clam meat, and the creamed spinach side was on par with that found at any other steakhouse.  The creme brûlée dessert was okay but nothing special: it was creamy but a little too sweet for my liking.  Service was very attentive and the ambiance was great with leather couches and a baby grand.  Business casual dress though so I wouldn't come in jeans and a T-shirt.  Overall, a good steakhouse with a decently priced and tasty Prix Fixe.  I would definitely come for that again but I'm not sure if the steaks and dishes  are actually amazing enough to warrant the full price.  For that, I would probably head to Del Frisco's or Fleming's.

3 pastries for $1.25 after 7:00 pm!  I love coming here on a Sunday and stocking up for the week with a box full of rolls and custards.  The baked goods here are always very fresh and consistent.  I'm a big fan of the egg custards, which have a layered, flaky shell, and the coconut milk buns.  The cakes are better at Greenleaf's but the breakfast pastries here are excellent.

The chicken tikka masala was very good.  The sauce was a bit creamier than what I'm used to but I enjoyed it all the same.  The paratha was nice and crispy and not overly greasy.  I'll be coming back to try more of the dishes but I'm happy with the food quality and service thus far.  It's small but very clean, and the servers are friendly and helpful.

Probably the most authentic Thai restaurant in Rittenhouse with friendly service and very good food.  

Some highlights:
1. Pad See Yew: Made with Chinese broccoli and plenty of egg in a savory sauce.  Very very good.
2. Red Penang Curry: Spicy and creamy with fresh veggies, plenty of beef, and the best curry broth.
3. Ginger stir-fried chicken: Amazingly savory and cooked with tender pieces of chicken breast.  Great if you are looking for a non-spicy dish.
4. Crispy duck fried rice: The duck definitely rivals Morimoto's with tender meat and a crispy skin.  The rice is delicious with plenty of veggies and egg.  
5.  Siam Salmon: Great tangy sauce with a delicious fillet accompanied by crispy, fried crab.  Love!
6. Salt and Pepper Shrimp Rolls: Filled with actual whole jumbo shrimp and served with a delicious dip.  This is unique to Jasmine Rice so highly recommend trying.
7. Papaya Salad: Good but not differentiated from the other versions.
8. Chicken Lettuce Wraps: A great spicy version of a classic.  It's a Gar pao accompanied with large Romaine leaves.  I would recommend getting a bowl of sticky rice and having the chicken with the rice.

Service is very attentive but the seating is pretty cramped so definitely book reservations for a party of more than 2.  It was a Tuesday night and packed!  Will be back to try more of the curries but so far so good!

3-4 stars for Dawa our chef who was amazing!  I noticed that he performed many more table-side theatrics than the other chefs and was very meticulous about even the slicing of the meats.  I would recommend asking for him.  

The food itself was pretty standard and be forewarned that A LOT of butter is used so it's not a meal for the light of diet, although you can definitely ask for a lighter version.  I was happy with my Seafood Diablo udon, which came with plenty of shrimp, scallops and squid.  The squid was surprisingly very tender, which is very hard to achieve; most places overcook it.  The yakisoba was decent as well and the chicken teriyaki was very juicy and tender.  The portions are also pretty generous and definitely get the fried rice instead of the steamed.  

We came in a party of 2 and had our own table, which was really nice, as a lot of places will make you share with other diners.  Our hostess was pretty stand-offish with an entitled air of ennui, which was rather annoying, although our actual waitress was great.

The Cochinita Pibil is marinated and slow-cooked until it is wonderfully tender and full of flavor.  I get this every single time and will probably continue to do so.  The accompanying rice is nicely seasoned and fluffy, although I'm not a fan of the fried plantains.  The crab and shrimp empanadas are a nice diversion from the usual beef, pork, and chicken, and the guacamole is very fresh.  The service is very friendly and the sangria is great.  If you're a margarita person, they have pitchers of those, too.  The menu isn't very extensive but they do a good job on the dishes that are offered.  A nice place to grab some Mexican food and ritas.

They have a great selection of grocery items, all at low prices (tahini and rose water anyone?).  The falafel is pretty good but just a tad on the bland side, which the hummus hides pretty well (at least in the sandwiches, which will only cost you about $3.50).  The owner is very pleasant so plus 1 star for service.  The place itself is small but you can rest assured that everything is freshly prepared.  The baba is pretty good too.  I will return to try the kabobs and gyros.

Love this place.  We got our supply of gourmet panchetta, sopressata, mozzarella, and truffle pate, along with generous samples of the torrone and pecorino romano.  Service was fantastic, as always.  A must-try for any Italian meat purveyor.

Selection here is not as good as that at Bryn Mawr and Manayunk but the store itself is better organized.  They do have a nice stock of designer handbags although their jewelry and designer shoes selections are a bit limited.  The clearance section (all the way in the back) is also larger than Bryn Mawr's and Manayunk's; a lot of boots are under $10 right now.  Service is very friendly and helpful; I love that they greet you with smiles and a "let me know if I can help you with anything?"  I love and miss those good ol' days of manners and courtesy.  The location is great; it's literally across the bridge from Main St, New Hope and across the street from Bucks Co. Coffee.  Friend them on facebook to get a 10% discount.

They finally have pho!  But I was in a charbroiled pork chop mood.  The pork was very tender and moist although the seasoning is a bt different from nam phuong's. The broken rice was perfect and the meatball skewers app was great. Prices reflect the area so although they might be high for Philadelphia, they are actually relatively low for the main line. About $8 for platters, $6 for banh mi, ad $10+ for entrees.

Not a vegetarian but I love love love the wild mushroom risotto (marsala broth with shitake and oyster mushrooms with marscarpone - yum!).  Get it topped with the optional goat cheese and the fingerling potato salad(roasted potatoes, onions, pecans and gorgonzola in a honey mustard dressing) along with the blue corn asparagus (asparagus with pesto and monterey jack cheese in a BLUE tortilla) tacos.    All of the dishes here are pretty original, delicious, and kinda addictive.  The dining room is very small but cozy, which just adds to the charm.  Plus they offer sparkling cider too.  Definitely stop by, even to grab a few tacos to go.

The good earth salad with the citrus vinaigrette is fantastic with plenty of beets, apples, candied pecans, goat cheese, and chicken.  They don't offer craisins as a topping but I highly recommend grabbing a a bag from the CVS and tossing in a handful.  They still have the Groupon Now deal, which means that you can get 2 lunches for ~$5.  The small salads seem tiny but are filling and definitely enough for a meal, especially if you stop by the Bagel Factory and grab a multigrain bagel as a side.  Plus, I love the brown cardboard boxes  because they remind me of the ones they use at Witherspoons in the Frist student center.

The reclining seats are amazing!  They are huge and you can lift the arms up.  The assigned seating can be a hassle but once you are seated, all is well.  Prices are $11.95 for an evening ticket, which is on par.  Weeknights are also pretty empty so you might actually have the theater to yourself - in which case the assigned seating will not matter.  There is also a small bar that offers beer and wine at a premium - but you can bring drinks into the theater, which is a nice option.  You also get free refills on fountain sodas via a Coke soda machine (tons of flavors!).

Decent food with private karaoke rooms upstairs.  The dishes were solid save for the fried chicken, which was definitely sinewy and subpar.  The fried rice with minced dried shrimp was very good, as was the shrimp toast.  Actually, the shrimp toast was amazing with the lightest, crispiest shell!  Portions are pretty generous, as well, except for perhaps the fried jumbo shrimp in a honey walnut cream sauce.  Service is pretty good and the owner is very friendly.  A decent option for dinner and karaoke with a group.

Cream-filled doughnuts. Get them. But only a few per trip because you won't be able to stop until the bag is empty.  The buttercream is very addictive. Add a pastry shell to the creamy filling and you have doughnut magic.
Yes I am updating my review just so I can recommend the sesame sticks at 2.29/ bag. They are amazing and you can't et them elsewhere.  It's happiness in plastic packaging.

We came for a late dinner and were very happy with the food and service. They gave us a complimentary soup to start with, which was a nice plus. My scallops with broccoli was very good with a savory garlic white sauce and HUGE scallops. There were plenty of them too. The frog with ginger and scallion hot pot came sizzling and was very flavorful with meaty pieces of frog. Service was great as well. A good option for Chinese in South Philly, for sure.
