We were shopping at KOP and were hungry so we stopped by the food court intending to grab something light, akin to a salad or smoothie.  However, on my way to the smoothie station, I was offered a sample of my food court addiction: the Bourbon chicken.  Against my better judgement, I decided to go for the sweet and deliciously juicy chicken despite the fact that I had probably already consumed a week's worth of meat a few hours earlier.  Nevertheless, my combination of the Bourbon chicken, chicken with mushrooms, and sauteed vegetables was satisfying and delish.  Plus, the seating in the food court is great and there are even "fireplaces" dispersed throughout.

The sticky buns with the cream cheese icing are just amazing.  The icing is rich and creamy yet simultaeously light and fluffy.  The sticky buns themselves are buttery, flaky and literally-melt-in-your-mouth delicious.  I had one for a late lunch and it was the best thing ever.  They also have cakes, cannolis, and brownies here but the stickybuns are the items to get.  Grab a dozen for ~$12 and an extra container of icing for $3.  Your friends and/or family will be very grateful.

It's a good place to grab a quick lunch if you're at the mall and don't want to eat at the food court.  They let you substitute turkey, chicken, or veggie burger on any of the burgers, and fruit salad for fries (extra cost but it's not much).  Service can vary by a lot, but I'm not exactly expecting much in this area.  Kids love it here and they have a decent menu for them.  I usually end up getting the Ruby Melt with turkey, which is a decently sized burger that tastes freshly made, not processed.  Not the best burgers but pretty good for the mall and the price.

We came for some late night drinks and were able to grab a sofa section in the beautiful lounge.  The following is a breakdown of the drinks:
-The Last Word: very strong with a hint of lime 
-Absinthe Minded: bitter, strong, and slightly sweet
-Long Live And: sweet and tart, almost like a pomegranate juice
-Green Vesper: refreshing with a hint of lime and cucumber
-Old Cuban: very good with a taste resembling that of a good apple cider

Service was great, and the ambiance beautiful.  You can see the entire skyline from the lounge, which more than makes up for the $14+ drinks.

The service is very efficient and the sandwiches are good.  I usually get the Turkey Tom (turkey breast, sprouts, mayo, lettuce, tomato) or Big John (same except w/roast beef minus the sprouts).  If you're an Atkins fan, you can get a sandwich wrapped in lettuce although I do believe that the French roll here is one of the nice qualities.  I love Subway but stop in here every once in a while.

I was in the mood for a lot of lamb so we decided to stop in and grab a few take-out dishes.  We got the keema naan (soft, fresh, and stuffed with plenty of minced lamb, garlic, and onions - very good!), lamb kabab (okay but not as well-seasoned as Persian's; the slightly grilled onions and peppers gave it a nice, crunchy boost of flavor, although we definitely got a lot more onions than peppers), and the ubiquitous tandoori chicken (juicy, tender, and very thoroughly marinated - every bite was flavorful).  Of course, when I saw the coconut barfi listed in the dessert section, I had to get an order of that too.  And am I glad that I did!  The coconut flavored cheese was creamy and indulgent; this was the first time that I have had this dessert and I really liked it a lot.  It was a delicious combination of 2 of my favorite foods: nuts and coconut.  Will definitely return for this since I haven't seen it at other Indian places in the area.  Overall, I was pretty satisfied with the dishes and portions.  They also gave us a 10% discount, which was really nice since we weren't even aware that there was such a promotion.  It was about $40 for everything, which was packed carefully with plenty of accompanying fresh, aromatic basmati and chutney.

New low-key BYOB with great apps and creative gourmet pizzas.  The sweet potatoes are a must-try as are fried cauliflower and roasted brussels sprouts with bacon and onion.  Anything with bacon and onion is bound to be delish and the brussels sprouts are certainly no exception.  The cauliflower is crispy yet tender and tossed in a spicy fra diavolo sauce with a thin coating of parsley.  Very very good.  And those honey coated sweet potatoes - absolutely ingenious.   

I'm not a vegetarian but somehow managed to pick all non-meat options - and very glad I did.  The Verde pizza is great: handmade crust with a slight char and good amount of chew topped with plenty of roasted brussels sprouts, artichokes, asparagus, spinach, roasted garlic, and mozzarella. There's a very slight hint of citrus which was refreshing.  Very solid.  

I'm dying to try the arancini and chicken Milanese and will update shortly.  Overall, very good option for a casual dinner with friends.

It's decent enough but nothing to rave about.  Lunch specials are pretty cheap and not overly greasy.  The moo goo gai pan was well-seasoned and on-par with your typical take-out dish.  The curry here is well, not exactly curry.  No coconut whatsoever.  I haven't tried the sushi yet but I think that I'll stick with Bluefin for sushi.

It was very empty in the afternoon when we stopped in to grab a quick bite.  The Southwest burger was very solid, with a nice chipotle sauce, bacon slices, and avocado, all on a buttered, toasted roll.  The fries were fresh, hot, and crispy, which I loved; the shell had the perfect crunch!  The roast beef with provolone on a onion roll was also good, with tender slices of beef, horseradish, and  a side of au jus, although I kinda wished that they had added sauteed onions and mushrooms, which would have made it great.  The chicken cobb salad was the standard version, but the chicken was tender and grilled perfectly and there was plenty of gorgonzola; plus, I loved that I was able to add a crab cake to it (you can add ahi tuna, salmon, shrimp, chicken and/or a crab cake to any salad) and a bowl of the short rib chili as a side.  The chili was very meaty and flavorful, and was a great dip for the fries, too.  Our server was very sweet, and kept our drinks refilled.  Service/food was a bit on the slow side given the fact that it wasn't busy at all but that gave us time to catch a game while we were waiting on one of the many LED screens throughout the dining room and bar.  Overall, very solid.

Really wanted a good, comforting (aka fried) roll with eel tonight.  Was recommended the spicy scallop tempura roll and it did not disappoint.  I didn't have time to sit down and eat so I got that, along with an eel avocado roll to go.  Prices weren't bad ($16 for both) and the rolls were well-prepared and tasty.  It wasn't very spicy but I didn't mind.  The service was very friendly and fast.  Will be back.

The banh mi here is very good, especially the house special, which is filled with veggies and sliced, cured meats.  The daikon/carrot mix is more finely shredded than that at the other cafes, which I'm not sure if I like; the flavor is good, though, but it is sweeter than Ba Le's or Cafe Huong Lan's.  They use a seasoned butter spread on the Sarcone's rolls rather than plain mayo, so that gives the hoagie an extra flavor boost.  The sardines in tomato sauce banh mi is also pretty good, if you are: a)vegetarian or b)want a hoagie but not the usual banh mi.  The vegegie banh mi is probably the best option here; it is stuffed with plenty of jicama, tofu, potato, daikon, cilantro, peppers, and cucumber on a crusty, buttered roll.  Yes, it's slightly more expensive at $5 but it is a fantastic sandwich and a great veggie option that has all of the delicious flavors that a proper banh mi is known for.  The special and sardine are $3.50, and the other varieties are $4.00; it's also buy 10, get 1 free.  I would call in your order since it gets very busy and there is barely any standing room; the cafe is tiny with no air conditioning (there is a tiny table with 2 stools max).  Overall, a good pick for banh mi but I still like my banh mi ga from Cafe Huong Lan slightly more (and the seating a WHOLE lot more!).  Would def recommend the special and vegetarian here, though.

This is a good option for Thai on the Mainline.  It's small, quaint, and offers a nice selection of tasty dishes.  I love the sauteed ginger flounder, which is a rich and delicious stew-like concoction.  The mussels appetizer is tender, well-spiced and very flavorful.  The curries can be made extremely spicy and the green curry, in particular, is excellent.  The pad thai is also very good.  Whenever I'm on the Mainline and in the mood for Thai, I come here.  It's small but offers much better cuisine than the chains in the area for a good price.  Our waitress was very pleasant and sweet.  Definitely recommend.  We also get take-out here quite often, and that has always been great.

Excellent peshwari naan!  Soft and fluffy on the side with a crispy, flaky exterior layer.  It wasn't greasy at all like some versions can be and was a great compliment and vehicle for the curry.  I also loved the chicken kalburi, which is a variation of the traditional korma with a creamy cashew sauce and tender pieces of boneless chicken cutlets.  The sauce was amazing and I will definitely return to try the chicken korma.  The chicken coconut was also solid but it's not a cream-based sauce but rather one made with chili-oil and shredded coconut.  It's a great dip for the naan and fantastic mixed with the basmati rice.  I can't tolerate too much spice and they were great about making everything very mild.

Service is very friendly but the food can take a long time to come out, although they do bring everything out at once.  It came to about $45 for a naan and 2 entrees, which is slightly on the pricier end but the food is solid.

Finally stopped in for lunch and ordered the hibachi chicken lunch.  I was in a rush so I opted to sit in the lounge, where the hostess doubled as the waitress.  No complaints there as she was efficient and friendly.  it was pretty quiet during lunch so the food came out very quickly.  The salad was okay, and the chicken was flavorful but slightly tough.  The hibachi rice was cooked with butter, which gave it an odd taste when paired with the soy-based sauce.  It didn't taste bad, just different.  Portions were decent for the $10 price.  Overall, a good, relatively inexpensive place to grab lunch.  Dinner did look a bit pricey, though.  They also have sushi but I'd be a bit hesitant to get it here when blue fin is a hop away.

Yes, the food is cheap but I found it to be somewhat lacking in flavor or actually, richness.  When I want Indian, I expect my dishes to be prepared with a small amount of ghee to give it that rich taste, which was lacking in the entrees here.  I suppose my heart should thank me?  Anyhow, the chicken tandoori was a bit disappointing, as was the chicken tikka masala; both were a bit on the bland side.  While I have yet to find the perfect chicken tikka masala in the tri-state vicinity, the tandoori chicken at Mehek in Princeton remains to be surpassed.  The naan here was not that fantastic but still edible; it wasn't as crispy as i would have liked.  Overall, the place is a very clean, organized restaurant to grab an inexpensive meal that is pretty healthy.  Maybe a bit too healthy for my personal taste but it is cheap and fast.  Kind of like cafeteria-style Indian food.

Great place for groups with comfortable seating and a nice variety of dishes.  I love the create your own salad option, which starts at $9.5 with 3 free toppings, cheese, and condiments like seeds and crouton.  The pan seared tilapia with mushrooms was very solid as well.  The portions are reasonable and most entrees are under $15, which is a nice plus in Rittenhouse.  They also serve breakfast all day, which means that you can get alcohol, pancakes, and omelets at one place!

We stopped in for a very late dinner after catching Godzilla and the service and food were great.  Our server, in particular, was attentive, helpful, and very friendly, even at 10 pm!  The moo goo gai pan was good and the buddha's feast had a great source and tender five spice tofu.  Plus, having a brown rice option is always a plus.  3 stars for the food but an extra star for the service.

I love this place and getting the nadia duck definitely reminded me of what I missed .  The drunken noodles are fantastic and great with almost every main entree.  The best Thai in the area, for sure.

I'm not going to lie.  I've been a regular patron (whenever I'm around) of this Starbucks since I started high school.  Yes, it's a chain but I still love my frappacino (venti java chip) and soy latte.  They have plenty of seating and outlets, along with wifi, and the baristas are very friendly.  A lot of regulars come here, along with students from nearby Villanova, Bryn Mawr, Rosemont, Cabrini, an Eastern, so if you're looking for motivation to work, then nothing beats seeing students in hoodies with their buried in books and computers screens, a cup filled with some caffeinated drink clutched in hand.  In terms of food (because you need some fat and sugar to make the caffeine work properly, or at least I do), I also love the mini iced donuts but it's so easy to eat all three in one sitting, so I alternate between getting those and a pack of Annie's.  They also keep their bakery display well-stocked, which is a plus in my book, because I hate it when I walk into a Starbucks with a craving for a cinnamon chip scone and have t settle for a blueberry muffin.  Those are the dire times that call for extra whipped cream on my frappacino.  

Oh, and if you have a Gold Card, you get free wifi!  Minus 1 star for the parking, though.  If you're not adept at backing out (aka me), park in the less treacherous back lot.  You'll thank me later.

We came with a group of 14 today, and they were extremely accommodating with both the setup and service.  It was a friend's birthday and they were great about serving the cake and didn't charge us a corkage fee.  The food was very good, as well, albeit a tad on the salty side.  The mee goreng was very flavorful, and the sizzling beef was very tender.  The chicken satay was a huge hit as well, and I really loved how the pieces were numerous but small and well-marinated.  The seafood curry casserole was solid, with a spicy green curry broth and green beans, tomatoes, carrots, and eggplant.  Service was fantastic and our food came out very quickly.  The ambiance is great, as well.  Definitely a great restaurant for a group!

Not great at all.  The coffee is pretty bad and my chicken noodle soup was extremely salty.  Stick to Au Bon Pain for better and fresher options.  The best part was the multigrain flat-bread, which was only semi-decent.  It is one of the few options still open at midnight at 30th Street Station, though.

Solid fusion ramen although it's not actually authetic ramen.  My yakisoba with soft-cooked soy egg, kimchi, and lamb sausage was good, albeit greasy.  There were only a few pieces of the lamb, and I wish that there had been more as it was very tender and flavorful.  The noodles themselves were pretty standard and a bit on the greasy side.  We also tried the katsu rice bowl which was just okay, although the actual katsu was solid.  The fried coating could have been crispier but it was still tasty.  The brisket ramen was nice fusion take on a classic with a flavorful broth and chewy noodles.  It wasn't served steaming hot but was solid, regardless.  The beef croquette special was okay but nothing special.  I would stick to the ramen and noodle dishes here.  The venue is TINY but the tables turnover very quickly, at least.

The pastries are decent but the coconut bread and raisin breads are very dough-y and had the tendency to stick to the roof of your mouth.  The coconut bread only had a very scant amount of shredded coconut and was, itself, a bit on the bland side.  Definitely not even close to what you would get in Flushing.  We had to toast the bread just so we could actually swallow i The sesame butter cookies were fantastic: light, crisp, covered in sesame seeds, and containing the perfect amount of sweetness.  These are much akin to the butter cookies from Roma's and Isgro's, except with an Asian twist, compliments of the sesame seeds.  The almond puffs are also quite delish and very flaky and light with plenty of sliced, toasted almonds and a drizzle of honey on top.  The egg tarts are great with a flakey, layered, and buttery crust.  Come here for the cookies, egg tarts, and pastries, not for the breads.

Get the nutella-tehina-pomegranate and coconut pineapple. Between those two, most of my favorite flavors were included. The nutella was definitely an interesting combo with the pomegranate but it almost tasted like a trail mix flavored donut: nutty yet sweet and refreshing. And the coconut?  Well you all know my obsession with all things piña colada.  If you like coconut cake, you will like this donut. It was very crowded but the donuts were worth the wait and trek. Will return to try the fried chicken.

The Thai basil is still as good as ever, but the Grand Palace Vegetable with chicken, veggies, and glass noodles was a bit on the bland side.  I had to mix the basil sauce in, which was actually really good.  The portions are still very generous, and our food was served very quickly.  A solid option for Thai but I would stick to the standard entrees.

Judy, in the designer bags section, is just about the sweetest customer service rep ever.  She was attentive and helpful, with a perpetual warm smile.  The actual selection is just okay but the service sets this location apart, for sure.

I love this food court staple.  The portions are great, the bourbon chicken is very nicely seasoned, and the prices are amazing (less than $6 for 2 entrees and 2 sides).  The cajun fries are very good and quite flavorful.  Honestly, a combination can feed you for lunch and dinner.  A cheap yet delicious meal for when you are shopping at KoP.

This is my favorite place to get prosciutto, ricotta, and fresh mozzarella.  The staff is very friendly and the quality of the meats and cheeses is unmatched.  I tend to go to DiBruno's for the hard cheeses but I always head here for the fresh cheeses.  The prices are also better here, too.   And they sell huge jars of Nutella, as an added bonus.  The olive oil-packed seafood is also very good and not something that is easily found elsewhere.  If you're making any cheese-based pasta dish, it is worth it to come here.  They sell imported pasta and every ingredient you could ever need, including San Marzano tomatoes.

We had a friend's birthday event here, and it was a great night with performances at the dueling piano, solid drink specials, and efficient, helpful servers.  There is a central bar but servers also circulate the room taking drink orders, which is a nice plus.  If you are looking for a range of song covers from the Backstreet Boys to Usher to Journey to Billy Joel, then this is the place for you.  A dance floor typically forms between the two stages, and the audience sings along, making for a memorable night.  It was crowded but the space is very open and didn't feel overwhelming.  I had a great time, and I will say that the bartenders here are amazingly fast and attentive.

This is a hybrid of Minado and your ubiquitous Chinese buffet, with bibimbap, hwae du bap, udon, soba, some rolls, teriyaki, and salads.  Thank goodness there was no Genral Tso's/Sesame/Fried chicken in sight!  The tempura was decent, and I loved the made-to-order soon duboo and sukiyaki, which they delivered to your table.   The only sushi at lunch was kani and salmon skill, but they did have a salmon and tilapia sashimi salad, which was decent, and your standard sushi rolls.  A salmon sushi or sashimi option (and eel, for that matter), would have been nice.  I can't complain, though, as I was able to taste my fair share of chicken yakitori (okay), and steamed mussels, along with the seafood options.  The vegetable japchae was very greasy, though.  The dessert bar has a decent selection of tiny cake slices, soft serve, and fruit.  To be honest, this is an extremely healthy option for lunch, considering the focus on Korean-style seafood dishes rather than fried and sugared take-out style options.  Plus, the lunch, for now, is only $9.95!  Our server was very sweet and attentive and checked in on us regularly for refills and to clear our plates.  Will be back to try the dinner ($19.95 but that includes sashimi and hibachi, I believe).

The service here is amazing but the takoyaki?  Let's just say that I have had better.  My octopus and spicy shrimp could have been cooked for a few minutes longer to attain that desired level of crispiness.  The batter itself was also a bit lacking in flavor.  This is a cute and inepensive place to stop by if you have never had takoyaki before and want to try it (it's the only restaurant of its kind in Philly, that I know of).  Just don't wait until the balls are cool to eat them because they really don't taste good then; takoyaki is meant to be eaten as soon as the dish is served.  Me?  I'll wait until I'm in NY or CA.

It was dad's turn to pick up dinner tonight and we were all in the mood for pizza so I asked him to head to Felicia's (thanks Steve T for the rec and directions!).  He came back home (after getting lost, calling me, and finding his way thanks again to Steve T's directions on Yelp) with a small thin crust margherita (mozzarella slices, tomatoes, and a savory blend of herbs) with prosciutto and a small special (spinach, spinach, tomatoes, cheese blend with mozzarella and provolone - I think,  and white sauce) on the thin crust.  Both were delicious but I was a big fan of the special; the garlicky sauce was absolutely delicious and the crust was perfectly crispy and chewy.  The crust reminds me a little of Emma's crust in Cambridge, and  brough back fond memories of my beloved college pizza go-to and its paddles and wooden benches. I also loved the cheese blend (provolone is sharp but a small amount gives the pie a nice kick), which really boosted the flavor to another level.  The margherita was also very good and almost rivals Taconelli's - for a much shorter wait time and easier ordering process (no dough reservations needed!).  You can definitely tell that these pies are baked in a wood-burning brick oven since they have a slight smokey flavor that you can't really get from the more modern gas-powered ovens.  Love it!   Will definitely be getting more pizzas here in the future.

I love coming here.  It's such an adorable, quaint, and friendly cafe that serves great sandwiches and amazing truffle fries (crisped to perfection with a light topping of shredded Parmesan).  I love the Cape May panini (turkey with strawberry mustard, cheddar, and slaw; the mustard gives it a nice twist.  The corned beef reuben is tender and not sinewy or tough, and the blt with turkey is the perfect balance of mayo, crispy bacon, turkey, and lettuce/tomato on lightly toasted, smooth white bread.  Anything on their breakfast menu is good, but I'm a huge fan of the breakfast sandiwch.  One bite of this and you will NEVER be able to go back to McDonald's or Burger King's (or even Wawa's) sad excuses for the most important meal of the day.  I'll be back for more next week.
The coffee here is amazing.  Fresh, rich, and aromatic.  Baked goods are pretty good too.  Stop by for an espresso if you're shopping in Rittenhouse Square.

It's a Wawa so by virtue of its very existence, it already has my favor.  This one is located right across the street from Vance, which gives yours truly reassurance that coffee and sandwiches will be in plentiful supply for the next 2 years - even without a company-provided Alterra brewer and Birdbath Bakery.  Overall, it's your standard Wawa with decent service and all of the usual offerings.  I do love the chicken salad and am very glad to see that I can now order it in platter form, with my selection of veggie toppings and condiments.  Plus, Hoagiefest is now in full force!  I can imagine that it is packed during the academic year but hopefully the undergrads will be back in the dining halls?  Maybe...

The ambiance here is great and it's a great setting for a business dinner or lunch...which is probably why it's across the street from the Sofitel.  The food was decent, at least with regards to the canapes.  The garlic parmesan fries were flavorful and crispy, and the truffle popcorn is a nice twist on an otherwise standard item.  The pulled pork sliders were also solid with a flavorful and sweet bourbon bbq sauce.  We had a group gathering here and the setting was perfect for mingling and catching up with friends..

Every once in a while I do like to indulge in greasy, takeout food when I'm home, and this place definitely gives you that in massive portions of decent artery-clogging goodness.  I am not ashamed to admit that I've been coming here since I was in middle school for their $5.50 lunch specials (gotta love the moo goo gai pan and pepper steak - the meat is very tender and not sinewy), which include an entree, fried rice, and appetizer, and walked away with a huge plate of food.  They actually fill a styrofoam container rather than just one of those measly little plastic tupperware wannabes.  It will usually suffice for both lunch and dinner (the campus life has made me more financially conscious).  The owners work there everyday and are a sweet couple.  I'm always greeted with a smile and a "how's school/life?"  Parking can be um, interesting, or I should say that backing out can prove to be quite a challenge but that's why I have a backup camera that beeps annoyingly as a warning to those unfortunate souls in the cars behind me.

This is a cute, friendly neighborhood cafe with great, health-conscious espresso drinks and a sweet, balanced, and fruity house coffee.  I personally love the classic latte made with almond milk (so excited to find a coffee bar that even offers it!).  Plus, they feature local artists on a rotational!  Check out Kathleen Byrnes' landscape this month.  They do have a solid selection of pastries and bagels (gluten-free options), but no breakfast sandwiches yet.  The pound cake and croissant are pretty good substitutes, though.  Welcome to the neighborhood 'feine and we can't wait to visit you more in 2013!

I wanted a salad and my friend wanted Five Guys.  We compromised and decided to grab "healthy" burgers here.  They actually give you a choice between a veggie-cheese patty or a vegan, vegetable-tasting patty.  I went with the veggie #1, which was the veggie-cheese patty, topped with caramelized onions and the elevation sauce (ketchup-like).  It was kinda messy and tasted a bit like gardenburger; while it was certainly edible, there was anything to set it apart from what you would buy from the store and make at home.  It definitely made me jealous of my friend's cheeseburger, which I proceeded to steal of bite of.  It was juicy but I still couldn't taste the organic part.  At least it makes you feel better mentally.  To me, it could have been just another decent burger.  Still, it was better than my veggie.  We didn't really like the fries, which were slightly soggy and had a rather strange taste, probably from the EVOO.  Plus, isn't "heart-healthy fries" an oxymoron?  The service was very fast and pleasant.  this may be for you if you are very much into organic fare, but tastewise, especially after trying the veggie burger, this just doesn't cut it for me as the best burger place.  It's definitely decent but not the top of the (main) line.

I love tea, especially if it is of excellent quality.  The tea here is overpriced for the quality.  The dragon well longjin is quite mediocre, in particular.  The other teas are pretty creative and worth a try but only that.  I mean, it's over $20 for a half pound!

This P.F. Chang's is in a prime location in the mall, but it is a chain so while the food is decent, there is nothing special about it.  The Singapore noodles were okay, but the lo mein was drowning in sauce.  The spicy scallops were pretty good,and I did enjoy the chicken lettuce wraps.  Our server Marcus was great and kept our drinks refilled.  A decent choice if you're at the mall and want some Asian food besides the greasy fare found at the food court.

Pretty decent bar with 3 levels, good happy hour specials, and solid food.  The garlic fries are very good, with a nice crispy and flavorful exterior and a chipotle mayo dipping sauce.  The pulled pork nachos are also a great pick if you are looking for something slightly more savory and, well, massive.  The pork is very tender and juicy, and complemented nicely by the pico de gallo.  They also have lamb chops but you need to order a minimum of 3.  They weren't bad but definitely not the best that I have had, by far.  The bar has your usual selections as well as a banana bread beer, which was interesting.  The ambiance is fun and relaxed, so it's great for grabbing a few drinks and/or a casual dinner.

Very respectable burger with thousand island dressing.  The meat was a perfect medium and fantastically juicy.  Finish it off with a side of duck fat fries and you have a delicious comfort meal...in addition to a heart-attack but, hey, you gotta live a little right?

I will eat anything and everything that they make here but I do love the cream filled donut.  It's so light, fluffy, and creamy that I feel like I'm in one of those Phila. cream cheese ads every time I eat one (the ones where the woman is floating up to heaven on these little white wings).  The chocolate iced cake is delicious as well, and nothing beats the apple fritter with a glass of cider in the fall.  Dunkin, Honeydew, and Krispy Kreme just don't compare.  We get a dozen every week, and if I recall correctly, my mom still has to hide them in her car to prevent my dad (and me when I'm around =) )from eating them all at once.  Guess the addiction runs in the family.

I really really really miss this place and envy those who live close enough to come on a regular basis.  We came for a late dinner tonight and the Thai eggplant with chicken was superb with a perfect balance of sweet, spicy, and savory flavors, the chicken pad thai was perfection as always, and the vegetarian lovers was refreshing and savory.  Service was great, and the quaint, whimsical ambiance has not changed.  I think that the golden utensils are definitely one of the highlights and identifying trademarks, for sure.  Plus, the portions are very generous.  The Rittenhouse Square Thai places have nothing on Thai Orchid.  They are all overpriced and overly salty.

This is my favorite sushi place on the Main Line.  They had blue fin otoro, lobster tail, scallops, and amazingly sweet, creamy, fresh uni.  I felt quite gluttonous (I'm talking 3rd circle of Inferno) after eating my heart's desire of otoro, uni, soft shell crab tempura (crisp and delicious), a Samurai roll (basically combine my 2 fav. spicy rolls and what do you get? spicy tuna, salmon, avocado covered with roe on the outside), and a Lobster roll (so good!  spicy lobster tempura with roe), topped off with a squid and seaweed salad (so much better than plain wakame).  The service is very attentive and the waiter was great about making recommendations for a friend who doesn't eat raw fish.  It's also about 2 min. away from Hope's Cookies, where I drag myself to after every meal here.  The best combination: fresh sushi and sashimi capped off by a cookie (or two) from Hope's.
The bacon, egg, and cheese on baguette is amazing.  Truly.  If I lived in the area, I would be here quite often.  It's literally pure happiness in a sandwich.

The Boureki and Flatbread are fantastic. The flavors just blend together deliciously. The hummus contains enough garlic to keep you safe in Transylvania but it was great with the pita triangles. My lamb however was very dry and tough despite the tasty seasoning. I requested that it be medium rare to medium and it was definitely mre than well-done. Service was friendly but alas the delicious appetizers and friendly server are not enough to trump the overcooked lamb. I will give 3 stars because our server was sweet and offered to give me another entree and because I just loved the Flatbread.

Now I'm not a diehard Phillies fan but I am still in love with this stadium.  There is not a bad seat in the house and there is a plethora of dining and shopping options, including gluten-free offerings and healthy fare.  The gatekeepers are very friendly and kept me company while I finished my larger iced coffee (you can't bring in any opened beverages) by telling me stories of past games and incidents at the field.  We had seats in the Diamond Club, which was beyond awesome.  The lounge had bistro stations, which served every cuisine from stir-fries to sundaes to huge burgers.  There were also TVs everywhere so you don't miss out on the game.  The food is a bit pricey though but that's to be expected.  The in-seat delivery/dining sounds great but it took them about 2 innings to deliver our drinks so it might be faster to just grab food at the concessions stand.  The view from behind home was fantastic and the seats were very capacious and comfortable.  Overall a fantastic experience and it certainly didn't hurt that the home team won by a single run in the 11th inning.  Parking is a pain but if you get there early, it's not too long of a trek from the lots ($15 fee).
The smoked mozzarella is the best ever.  It's soft, moist, and very flavorful.  I can literally eat an entire package by itself in 1 sitting.

I love coming here and am not ashamed t admit it.  Yes, it's a chain and yes, it's always crowded but that's part of the attraction.  The food is cheap and pretty good for being North of the Mason Dixon line.  I am a fan of farmer's breakfast and the chicken 'n dumplins; the spicy catfish is another reliable dish.  If you like cornbread and biscuits, you can eat them to your heart's content.  They are served fresh from the oven and refills on the basket are free.  I wouldn't get the steaks here but most of the other entrees here are nicely seasoned and tasty.  The service here has always been friendly and efficient.  And did I mention the store?  That's one of my favorite parts because it makes me feel like a kid again.

The burgers here are like the ones at Five Guys but probably healthier (or I want to believe that they are).  I usually get the double cheeseburger and the meat is always juicy and fresh.  The fries are cooked with olive oil and can be an acquired taste but come here for the burgers.  The organic, free range component will make you feel less guilty about the day's worth of meat that you just downed, believe me.

The sashimi sampler is a must. The fish is very fresh and beautifully presented and perfectly paired with seasonings. Try the special rolls too; I had a spicy tuna with spicy scallop topping and it was fantastic. Dont leave without getting dessert. The chocolate cake covered in coconut gelato is to die for. Quite literally too since it is a heart attack in a pretty package.  Well, just wait for me with an ambulance at the door, then.

I have definitely had better Indian food.  The rice was cooked al dente and the naan was a bit too chewy.  The tandoori chicken was just okay - a bit on the bland side and not tender enough, and the chicken korma could have been a little more creamy.  The portions are very small for what you pay (~$14/dish) and the service is pretty slow.  I would come here if I were dying from Indian food deprivation and this was the only place open...maybe.

The food here is amazing!  The nadia duck is perfectly cripsy and tender in a delicious plum sauce, and the siam rack of lamb is marinated in a wonderful basil sauce with a hint of cognac and grilled until it has this slightly crispy outer.  The Pad See You and Drunken noodles are excellent, as well.  The appetizers are very good, especially the crab dumpling, but the tiger cry salad is better at Thai Orchid.  The servers are very friendly and always smiling.  It's seriously a toss-up between Thai Orchid and here, in regards to the best Thai restaurants in the area.  I guess I'll just have to go back for more to help me decide.  :-)

The margherita pizza is decent here.  The crust is thin and crispy and the sauce flavorful.  It's not the best in the area but it is pretty good.  Plus, they sell individual slices, which is handy if you want a quick bite while shopping in Wayne.

It's your standard buffet but I do like the hibachi grill options, such as prawns, tuna, and steak, all seared to your liking.  Everything else is the typical fare.  The staff are pretty friendly.  I haven't eaten here but do grab a takeout box every so often ($3.99/lb for lunch).

I didn't think that it was possible to gorge oneself on vegan food...until I came here.  Due to the earlier massive consumption of cake truffles and cookies, we decided to go with a lighter dinner.  What we didn't realize was that the tasty albeit light and healthy food would cause us to consume more than we had originally planned to. 

Some highlights:
1. tofu curry wrap: savory with a creamy bean puree and plenty of alfafa sprouts and a hint of cucumber raita, which gave it a nice, refreshing touch
2. crispy hipcity ranch:  so delish!  it actually tastes like fried chicken burger with a great creamy ranch sauce.  my fav item here.
3. jerk chicken salad:  pretty tasty but it's not exactly authentic jerk chicken.  the thousand island dressing was good, though, and the plantains were nice and crispy.  
4.  sweet potato fries: crispy, fresh, and hot.  no further comments needed.  just go and get yourself some.
5. banana whip: dare i say it?  it tastes almost like ice cream but is a lot healthier!  we got ours plain but you can add toppings, too.
6. groothie:  besides having an awesome name, it's a very tasty smoothie made of apples, greens, bananas, kiwi, and pineapple.

The consensus?  The vegan food here is GOOD, healthy, and very filling.  Def. stop by and give them a try.  Staff are very helpful and friendly, to, which certainly doesn't hurt.

We came for dinner and had the lobster mac and cheese and the fig flatbread.  The mac and cheese was decent but only contained tiny pieces of lobster; the flavor was good, though, and it wasn't overly cheesy.  The full portion is pretty big, though, so I would recommend getting the half portion unless you are extremely hungry or want leftovers.  The flatbread was served on a paper-thin tortilla-like bread and topped with plenty of dried fig pieces, prosciutto, goat cheese, and mozzarella.  The bread and butter was your typical dinner rolls and butter set.  Service was solid, and the ambiance nice for a casual dinner.  We will likely be back to try the brunch and I will update accordingly.

My friend treated me to an eyelash extension full set lat year, and Kim did an absolutely amazing job.  They looked so natural and the room was so comfortable that I fell asleep during the process.  The salon is a bit pricey (minus 1 star) but they do use Aveda products and sell the full line (so grateful because I use the tourmaline cream almost exclusively and can get it here).  If you want to treat yourself for a day, come here, and then get some shopping done, too.  :-)

Food is just okay. Slightly better than takeout and the sushi rolls are decent. The seafood s pretty fresh and the rice isn't hard. Try the Sakura and sweetie rolls.  But the duck?  Um, I'd rather drive to Chinatown in my SUV and pay the outrageous gas price.

It's your standard Irish pub with great drink specials and friendly bartenders.  Other than that, it has several screens for games, and is pretty spacious, partly due to the fact that it is never really packed.  I wouldn't mind coming here again but will not go out of my way, as there are countless bars like it in the city.  The music is decent if you like hip hop/top 40.

No complaints about the actual dishes but if you get take-out, check your dishes because we got a cashew chicken instead of the cashew shrimp.  It was good but a bit unexpected when we got home (45 min later).

It is ironic that the roasted chicken here is better than the ribs.  We ordered a half chicken and a rack of ribs.  The tender chicken was devoured and the dry, rather tough and bland ribs left behind.  The mashed potatoes were okay but not anything to rave about.  I ended up eating a lot of rolls with cinnamon butter (which were very good.  I almost want to come back just for those.).  So 3 stars for the chicken and rolls.  Go to Lucy's or Percy St. for ribs.

The brisket sandwich is amazing!  The meat is tender, juicy, and flavorful with the best au jus (I always get extra!).  I always get it to go because I end up looking like a pig because the juice practically drips down your chin.  Emily Post would have an aneurysm.  The reuben knish is also a tasty option if you are looking for something a little different.  The turkey club is a more ladylike yet still delicious option with flavorful bacon.  Prices are great.  Most sandwiches are under $7.

It can be hard to find a venue large enough to seat 16 at one table, and that is one of the advantages to coming here.  The food itself was just okay, although we did like the make-your-own guacamole option.  If you do decide to add truffle, be aware that it will overpower the rest of the flavors!  They were also out of the marinated fish tacos tonight, and while the spicy brisket tacos were decently spicy, they were also quite small and a bit bland.  The braised boneless short rib was tender and flavorful, and came topped with a savory blend of mushrooms, corn, and onion, all served over rice.  I would recommend this, as well as the baby back ribs, although I am sure that you can get comparable quality, or better, at Percy's.  The perk here is that they were spicy.  The shrimp chile nogada was solid with a good balance of shrimp, rice, queso, and surprising addition of pomegranate seeds, but not very spicy.  The version at El Rey is definitely spicier.   The short rib tamales were probably the least favorite, as they were small, dry, and bland, despite the generous side of chili gravy.  Service was decent, but overall, the food was pricey (~$25-30/entree and $16 for tacos) for the small portions and not as flavorful as Veracruzana.  The location is great, though, and it is a fun spot for a larger group.

One of my favorite bakeries in Center City.  Definitely get the hazelnut cake.  The chocolate shavings and fluffy, creamy, buttery, and light whipped icing is absolutely amazing.  It literally tastes like the best tiramisu in cake form.

Solid Szechuan food with a solid tea smoked tea duck and traditional authentic dishes like dry woks and water boiled spicy fish. The chef is the same as the original Pin Wei so the food is still as solid as before.  A good option if you are local.

My first time back in probably a decade. The son has now taken over the family restaurant and the food is still solid with fair prices. We ordered in person vs calling in and out food was ready in less than 10 minutes. Portions are plentiful and they were more than happy to substitute a white sauce for the standard brown for our shrimp with broccoli. Lunch specials are around $6-7 with a free soda so it's still a great value.  My go-to items are still the chicken with broccoli and any of the shrimp dishes. The prawns are huge and there is plenty!  I also love that it's still family run.

We came for a late dinner yesterday (kitchen closes at 9!) and were told that the menu was recently changed to an all-day brunch on Sundays.  I had the grilled (rare) Skuna salmon Caesar, which was great with olive croutons, finely shredded kale, and  grated parmesan-romano.  The salmon was perfectly seared and tender.  The super food salad was also great with nicely grilled, jumbo shrimp, fresh avocado, spinach, blueberries, quinoa, and almonds in a light citrus vinaigrette.  The duck hash was a nice, more decadent option, as well.  We split the hummus appetizer and it was a nice variation with braised beef and a great, lighted pan-fried and buttered puff bread.  The bread was very different but absolutely delicious.  The carrot cake with vanilla gelato was huge and very solid, as well.  It came with a strawberry compote on the side.  Service was great and you can't beat the ambiance!  Great for a date or a dinner with friends!

Love this store!  Everything Is fresh and very moderately priced. They also have a fantastic selection of dried fruits and trail mixes, along with chocolate covered espresso beans. My personal fav item here is the soy wheat pita. $1.69 for 4 delicious, moist pitas with 16 g of soy protein each. They are so much better than the generic kinds in your typical grocery store. Cashiers and service are great. Just be warned that weekends are very busy here.

The food is great but service forgot about us and we had to get their attention for menus, water, etc. Otherwise, it was very good.  We shared a seafood crispy noodle (delicious sauce and the noodles were perfectly crispy without being greasy), mango chicken (tangy, slightly spicy sauce with lots of nano and ome peppers), roti (a must try here), and the hainanese rice.  Okay I love the rice. Incredibly flavorful and aromatic. I can literally just eat a pot of it and be happy. But I digress.  Anyhow, great food, meh service, and fun atmosphere.  Be warned that the tea can be a bit strong.

The king salmon here is just simply delectable: the meat is moist, flaky, and flavorful.  We get a delivery once a month of the king salmon and rockfish, which is fantastic in a cioppino dish made with garlic, onions, EVOO, dry red wine, clam juice, broth, shrimp, and clams.  The rockfish has a firm texture but a nice, buttery taste, which is perfect for a rich seafood stew.  They do have a minimum order requirement of 7+ pounds for overnight delivery but that's definitely easy to meet considering the quality of the fish here.  I highly recommend ordering a few pounds so that you always have a good, healthy meal option on hand.  The king salmon just needs to be grilled and seasoned with a tiny sprinkling of sea salt since it is inherently flavorful (had it for dinner and it was simple but very tasty - the skin was crispy and delicious but not everyone like that part).

I was really craving a dosa and chicken korma tonight so I decided to grab a takeout order here.  The onion masala dosa was great and still hot by the time I got home, although it would have been crispier had I had it at the restaurant.  Nevertheless, it was very flavorful, thin, and decently crispy yet chewy.  One of the best dosas in the area, for sure.  Will definitely come back to try the other varieties, namely the spinach masala.  The chicken korma was just okay; the chicken itself was pretty lean so it wasn't as tender and juicy as I would have preferred and the sauce was creamy and buttery but had too strong of an onion flavor.  While I do like onions a lot, I'm not too sure if I like it to be overpowering in a korma dish, which is supposed to be creamier and coconut-based.  The chapathi was very good for dipping into the extra sauce though and did tone down some of the onion so maybe that's the key.  Prices are very good.  It was a little over $20 for everything, which was served in generous portions.  I definitely had enough food left over for another meal.  The location is a bit obscure but parking is easy and the food prepared quickly.  I have yet to dine in but the ambiance doesn't seem that exciting; it's more suited as a takeout place.

It's a decent option in Chinatown if you are looking for a "generalist" type fare as they serve Szechuan, Shanghai, Taiwan, and some Cantonese dishes.  I would say that the quality is just okay.  The variety is the draw here and they also offer a 10% Yelp check-in offer.  The staff are fiendly but they seem very rushed as it was quite busy and there were only 2-3 waiters in the entire restaurant serving all the tables and taking takeout orders as well. 

Cash and Venmo only!

A recap of the dishes:
1. Sweet osmanthus and sesame mochi dumpling soup: This was perfectly light, sweet, and refreshing with thin shreds of osmanthus and egg whites.  The dumplings were fluffy and filled with sesame.  They are smaller than normal but each was  perfectly balanced bite of filling to shell.
2. Crabmeat and pork soup dumplings: These were kind of meh with a thick shell and barely any soup and filling.  Maybe it was an off-day but I would suggest the other pan-fried options instead.
3. Pan Fried buns: These were better than the soup dumplings but the filling was pretty sparse and definitely could have been more generous in portion.  4. Pan fried dumplings: These were solid with a plump, juicy filling and nicely crispy pan fried shell.
5. Chive buns: Nice nd crispy with a flavorful egg and chive filling.  The only thing that would have made them better would have been some vemicelli inside but pretty solid overall.
6. Stir-fried clams: Pretty flavorful clams albeit small ones.  It's a bit on the salty side but still pretty solid.
7. Plum spare ribs: Fried sweet spareribs with sweet plums.  Overall, a nice appetizer-sized option (the ribs are small).  The meat is flavorful and pretty tender but the dish itself is not very filling so this is more of a starter vs an actual main entree.
8. Seafood tofu casserole: Mostly light silkn tofu with 3 prawns, some fishballs, and 3 pieces of surimi.  This is very light but the seafood portion was tiny.  The nice part is that it isn't oily at all but it's definitely not your traditional seafood hot pot.
9. Seafood udon: Stir fried udon with seafood in a traditional brown oyster-soy.  This was pretty standard but it was branded as a Shanghai stir fried thick noodle and it resembled more of a Japanese stir-fried udon.  It was just okay but a bit salty.
10. Marinated sliced roast beef: This was just okay.  The beef was tender but slightly dry and didn't have that sweet and savaory marinade that is the hallmark of the 5-spice Shanghainese beef.
11. Seasonal stir-fried vegetables: This was light and refeshing and surprisngly one of the best dishes with sliced lotus, cauliflower, broccoli, snow peas, mushrooms, woodear, carrots, and asparagus.  There was just a very slight coagulation of the corn starch thickener on some pieces but they were very busy tonight and likely understaffed in the kitchen so they were likely making this in a rush.

I love this restaurant that is just a hop and a skip away from mis padres.  We stopped in for a late lunch and ordered the drunken noodles and evil jungle princess lunch specials.  The drunken noodles dish was solid, but the chicken slices were just slightly on the dry side.  The flavor was very good, though.  My evil jungle princess with chicken was very good, with just a hint of coconut milk.  For the appetizers, we had the crispy Thai dumplings filled with pork, mushrooms, and bamboo, and the house salad.  Both were good, although the vinaigrette is slightly tangy, for my taste, but that's just a personal preference.  Service was phenomenal, as always, and our food was served in less than 10 minutes!

We hadn't been here for quite some time and decided to stop in for a quick lunch.  It wasn't too crowded at 1:30 pm, and our wait was maybe 5 minutes.  The hostess was lovely but our actual server was an absolute atrocity!  She was very patronizing when I inquired about how big the turkey and chicken entree salads were.  "It's a salad.  It's lettuce."  Well, geez that was super helpful.  Thanks a million for letting me that a salad contains lettuce.  Anyhow, I decided on the grilled chicken tenderloins country dinner plate, which contained 4 TINY pieces of chicken.  They were tender but  wouldn't have satisfied a toddler!  The turnip greens were very good, though, as were the carrots.  My dad's hamburger wasn't that great and tasted like something from a fast food restaurant, although the turkey noodle was decent.  Now, since the actual entree was so tiny, I expected to be brought more than a single corn muffin and a single biscuit, but that was all.  Our server actually ignored us throughout the meal and we had to ask for refills, which she did bring albeit with exaggerated eye rolls.  I wish that she had actually told us her name so that I can call the management.  Usually, the servers here are great but today was horrid!  1 star for the server, but I will add another because the other staff here were great and I do love the turnip greens and the single biscuit that I did get.  BTW, we were seated near the 2nd door to the kitchen if that provides any elucidation into the identity of the waitress.  Yes, I realize that I could have checked the receipt but dad threw it away on the way out...

This is probably my favorite Mexican place in the area.  It's a somewhat upscale yet fun restaurant with outdoor seating.  The guacamole is really good and goes quite well with the crispy nachos.  I always get the chile abuelita because I like chili a lot and this one is particularly well spiced with very tender pork, raisins, and a hint of cinnamon.  Quite different from say, Wendy's.  The price is a bit steep but the ambiance (Cinco de Mayo/fiesta style anyone?) and decent Mexican food are worth it.  Also, they have pomegranate margarita pitchers, which is an added plus.  It can get quite busy during weekends and lunch hours so be forewarned.

Very meh Thai food that is overly salty although the service was good. The green curry and basil tofu were not very flavorful or spicy but they were extremely salty. It will do in a pinch but Erawan is right around the corner.

PF always runs a 20% off takeout discount on debate nights, and considering that this was the final presidential debate, we decided to order some dishes for our late dinner.  The food was pretty standard for the chain, and I did like that I was able to place my order online, pay for it in advance, and park right outside the takeout register and have my food practically delivered to me in minutes, complete with utensils, napkins, and fortune cookies.  Yes, I do realize that my laziness is almost sloth-like but c'est la vie.  I noticed that they have a few new menu items, like the crabmeat fried rice, pad thai, and a duck duo, so I ventured to try the duck, which had a slow cooked leg and a cripsy pan-fried breast served with a watercress salad.  The duck was just okay and the portion was a bit on the small side, but that may be a good thing considering that duck isn't exactly the most cholesterol-friendly poultry meat.  I liked the slow cooked leg more than the breast since the flavor was icily imbued throughout, whereas the breast was a bit bland in the innermost section.  It wasn't bad for a chain but I would definitely get my duck fix at Margaret Kuo, Sangkee, or New East.  The Shanghai shrimp dish was very solid, with tender shrimp, plenty of veggies, and a light yet flavorful garlic sauce.  Definitely better than what you would get from your typical greasy takeout place.  The crab fried rice was pretty good, and it had pieces of bacon, which definitely gave it a bit of a twist.  The actual amount of crabmeat was skimpy but that was to be expected.  The flavor was good, and I was glad to see egg and shitake slices in it; overall, I did like it a lot better than what Dad would usually get from China (insert noun here).  It came to about $37 for all 3, which wasn't bad at all.  Next time, I will probably go back to my usual Singapore street noodles, moo goo gai pan, and cumin lamb, but it was a nice change tonight and a good break from cooking.  The 20% off didn't hurt and we were able to thoroughly enjoy the debate while chowing.

What can I say?  I'm definitely a snacker who likes to try a bit of everything so this is the perfect place for me...well, in John locke's world.  The concept of small rolls is appealing but the execution was a bit lacking. The rice was pretty dry...not exactly ideal. However, I did like the fact that I got to try 5 rolls rather than just 2. The eagle, new wave, and southern comfort were creative and pretty good.  The salmon avocado was meh but the lobster roll actually contained fresh lobster meat and avocado in a soybean wrap. That was probably one of my favorites and it is relatively hard to find lobster rolls. Service is very slow so that was one of the detractors. A decent place for those of us who want to sample a variety of rolls.

Very fresh and delicious hwe du bap with a good banchan selection.  It doesn't look like much from the outside but the food and service are great.  The bibim bop is also a good choice if you are looking for the classic.  Definitely worth stopping by.  The sushi isn't bad but I would go for the Korean dishes.
Get the duck pad Thai if it's an available special!  It's the tried-and-true pad Thai topped off with a generous portion of fried duck with a crispy, light batter.  Amazing.

Appearances can be quite deceiving, as we know all too well from Macbeth. From the outside, this doesn't look like much but it is a treasure trove of authentic Taiwanese dishes that are simply too die for (or at least worth the Chinatown parking charge and rush hour traffic on the good ole I-76).  The Taiwanese beef noodle soup is the most popular dish, and is well deserving of its reputation.  Perfect on a cold day.  Also be sure to try the pork chops with the Shanghainese rice  cakes.  The basil/three cup chicken is pretty good.  Just stay away from takeout dishes because those tend to be well, takeout-like, for lack of a more precise description.  If you're in Chinatown, you need to stop by.  My family has been coming here for the past 17 years, and it is still one of our favorite restaurants.  I've brought friends from school here and even the Californians find this place to be authentic.  That, too me at least, says a lot.

The hoagies here are edible but nothing really special.  They don't compare to Primo's, that's for sure, but are okay if you live across the street and just want a quick, simple bite.  They have a "bistro/cafe" menu but I would stick with the hoagies and the cheesesteaks here.  The fries (both sweet potato and waffle)  are pretty good when hot and fresh from the deep fryer.  Today (and every 3rd Wednesday of the month) was half price Italian hoagie day so I ordered a few for dinner along with a half chicken caesar hoagie and waffle fries.  Overall, the food was good and the price was great.  I would definitely spend the extra $.30 and upgrade to the sesame seeded roll.  The chicken caesar hoagie was full of marinated, grilled chicken and cheese, although they did go a little heavy-handed on the dressing.  If you live in the area, it's a good takeout option.  Plus, they deliver, which is a nice plus.

The testing Zone with breaded chicken, pesto, and mozzarella was solid but a little bland. The end zone with steak, mozzarella, peppers, and onions fared better. The shell is decent without being too doughy which is key in a calzone. they are open pretty late so it's a good option if you're hungry and sick of takeout and typical slices.

I had heard about this place from a friend and was in the area so I decided to stop in and grab something for lunch.  Now, I am the girl who can never get enough of Thanksgiving, mostly because I love the food so much.  If you are like me, you will LOVE the Bobbi sandwich.  It's literally all of your Thanksgiving favorites on a roll.  I used to rely on Wawa but no longer!  The turkey is homemade and definitely tastes like such; the meat is tender and flavorful without the added salt and preservatives found in the D&W/deli varieties.  There was plenty of stuffing, which was moist (dry stuffing is the worst!), and just the right amount of sweet (but not overly so) cranberry sauce, complemented by the creamy mayo.  I also added Provolone, which gave it an extra flavor boost.  The roll was soft and fresh, and a footlong will easily feed 2 or be enough for lunch and dinner.  It was around $10 for a footlong, which isn't bad considering everything that is in the sandwich.  Service was very friendly and fast, too.  If you are out by Exton/West Chester, definitely give this place a try.  I only wish that there was one by home or work.

The quinoa loaf is a delicious gluten-free option that will satify any bread lover.  Seriously.  It's moist, soft, and flavorful.  Try it with chicken salad made with walnuts and craisins.  It's absolutely yummy and pairs well with the creaminess of the salad.

I came.  I ate. I conquered. The gringo Gordo that is. Yep a 5 lb burrito in 40 minutes. And it was delicious. The meat is fresh and tender, the saffron rice nicely seasoned, and the beans flavorful. If you aren't feeling gluttonous the $5.95 standards are a great deal. They offer more options than Chipotle or qdoba and you get to pick your tortilla flavor too. Owner is very friendly and knows the regulars (there are a lot of them and for good reason). This isn't a typical chain with pre made burritos. Everything is created to order and fresh.  And if you like hot sauce there is an ample supply and good variety.  They also have punch cards and daily specials.  Definitely stop by.

The best lamb chops and gyro in bucks county!  The lamb meat is perfectly seasoned and cooked to a succulent perfection. Many places tend to overcook the gyro meat so that it is too dry. Not here. The Greek salad came with an ample serving of feta. Prices are a bit high but still cheaper than what you would pay for the gas to drive into the city for comparable and slightly better food.

Decent selection of karaoke songs and pretty spacious private rooms.  We came here after dinner at Penang and definitely liked the setup more than that at Yakitori Boy.  It easily fit all 20 of us and the interactive song selection screen was much easier to use.  The drinks themselves were pretty meh.  The sangria was very sweet and I couldn't taste any of the alcohol, which says a lot since I have a very low tolerance and very high sensitivity.  It was pretty neat, though, that they brought out sparklers with every new bottle of Ketel One.  Our hostess was friendly and helpful, and we did enjoy the ambiance and msuic selection.  The actual club itself is nothing to rave about and the majority of the clientele are 30-35+.  Overall, it's nicer and cleaner than Yakitori Boy, likely because of its younger age.

We decided on a late, casual dinner at the bar tonight, and were pretty happy with the food and service.  My chicken salad sandwich was creamy and full of chicken, craisins and candied pecans, served on toasty, grilled sourdough.  I really liked that it was grilled rather than served cold, like it is at most other places.  The fries were hot and crispy, too.  Dad really liked his lobster roll, which was made with dijon rather than just plain mayo; it did have a nice zest and there was plenty of lobster, too.  It's not served with fries, though (you get chips instead).  We also split the warm pretzel bites with truffle butter, which were good but not as amazing as Frankford's or Brauhaus's, and the crispy and delicious beet and sweet potato chips (better than Terra's!).  Service was great and we had plenty of time to enjoy our Sly Fox pilsners and food.

The rococo pizza is very good. The feta added the perfect touch and the crust was flavorful and crispy. If it is your first time here, get the chicken Mykonos, hummus, and a pizza. I can assure you that it will be delicious. The wait can be very long on weekends though.

Barbacoa is very good and perfectly seasoned.  The tacos aren't as fantastic as Don Memo's but are great for the area.  Guacamole is decent but lacking in flavor.  But I always have mine on a taco with salsa so you can't really tell at that point.  As far as the enchiladas go, nothing beats Vercruzana in South Philly but the chicken mole is pretty good; the meat is tender.  Stop in if you're in West Chester.

We came for a late brunch today and, although this is still one of the best brunch venues in Philadelphia, it does somewhat pale in comparison to Balthazar.  My egg white with ratatouille omelet was very good, with a savory filling and fluffy, buttery egg.  I asked for mixed greens instead of the roasted potatoes, and they came dressed in nice, light lemon and oil vinaigrette.  The steak and eggs plates looked good, but I did notice that they had a tendency to overcook the steak.  Two of my friends asked for medium rare and their steaks looked like they were cooked to a medium well.  Service was solid, although our waitress looked somewhat frantic throughout the meal.  The bread basket is still a tried and true staple, and I would definitely recommend the cranberry walnut bread.  Try it with butter and a smear of the jam!

Yes, you have to call to reserve your dough but the margherita pizza is just amazing and worth the wait and hassle.  The crust is remarkably thin and simultaneously crispy, chewy, and flavorful.  The sauce is flavorful and topped off by the perfect amount of mozzarella and basil.  Love it!  BYOB and bring stuff to do while you wait (that iphone and ipad will definitely come in handy).
Closed
I love my meat and I love my potatoes. So I drag my lazy butt to the gym. And it is definitely worth it for a meal here.

It had been a long day so we decided on an impromptu father-daughter dinner night and headed next door to the Farmer's Daughter.  We decided to get the 3-course prix fixe ($35) since that had always been a good sampling option in the past.  I had the grilled romaine (love the hint of parmesan and who knew that grilled lettuce could taste so good?) and crispy skin salmon (loved the crispy, well-seasoned exterior that comes from baking, not pan-frying!) with farro succotash (a nice twist to your typical stuffing/succotash side) and creamed spinach (creamy without being overly heavy like some creamed vegetables dishes can be).  Dad had the same and didn't complain once that he was having fish and veggies and not red meat.  Dessert was the butterscotch pot de creme, which was good but not my favorite - the cinnamon marscarpone was a very different and I'm not sure if I like the combination of butterscotch, cinnamon, and salty nuts.  The bourbon cookie was great though (I actually ate Dad's too; he liked the pot de creme so we traded )!  Service was very friendly and efficient, and they have a great French press coffee (medium and floral-ly).  They have a bar too, and it was pretty busy tonight.  Plus, they have lobster rolls on the bar menu!  We actually got one to go since it has been ages since the two of us have gone to D'Angelo's.  Spilt it between the two of 2 about 5 minutes ago.  Now, that's what I call a good, solid, and very comforting snack.  Yes, it's slightly pricey at $17 but sometimes you just want a lobster roll.

Lamb chops were well seasoned and juicy. I very much enjoyed them. The accompanying potatoes were good but not amazing.  Now on to the pastitsio...  The béchamel sauce was delicious!  It did not overpower the met but complemented it perfectly. The pasta itself was cooked to perfection: neither soggy nor al dente.  The taramasalata caviar was delish and went very well with the pita, which is amazingly fluffy and buttery. Service is fantastic and the owners are very sweet. Be sure to bring along a bottle of red wine if you're getting the lamb. A Shiraz would be perfect.  Prices are slightly high but the food is very redeeming.

It's definitely not Machismo or Chipotle but the staff here are sweet so I do stop in every once in a while.  The chicken bowl here is decent and the free chips and salsa much appreciated.  The meat can just be a bit dry.  Portions are pretty generous though.

Nothing beats a cherry water ice and pretzel on a sunny Sunday, which is just what we got.  The mini pretzel was fresh and soft in the middle and delicious with a side of honey mustard.  The cherry ice was good but didn't really stand out either way.  About $2.50 for a small ice and mini.  Staff was friendly and they have a nice selection of different mustards.

Sushi here is decent but a little on the pricey side considering that it's not bluefin. The marble roll was the only standout of the bunch but the size was small forgets $16 price tag. The fish was pretty fresh, though. The Korean food is not spectacular but edible enough. The hot stone bibimbap was average, but the bulgogi?  Go to any of the Korean places in nearby blue ell or north wales. You also can't cook at your table,  which to me defeats the purpose of bbq. However, the lunch boxes are usually around $10, which is a pretty good deal considering that you get to pick between sushi, sashimi, maki, teriyaki, BBQ, udon, and bibimbap. If you craving sushi for lunch, stop in and grab the spicy crunchy tuna and 5 piece sushi for $10. Your wallet and stomach will thank me. Dinner?  Head to bluefin or Gaya.

The roast pork here is excellent; it is cooked in spices for hours until the flavors are imbued in the tender meat that almost melts in your mouth.  Get it with provolone and greens.  The other offerings are decent but I only come here for the pork because the area is a bit difficult to travel in, which is the reason why I am subtracting one star.

Sushi isn't bad at all.  I really liked the American Dream with avocado, shrimp tempura and eel and the spicy king crab roll (love the crunch!).  I wouldn't put them on the same par as Bluefin or Ajihei but it's a good option for sushi if you are close by.  They also have Chinese but I have never tried that.  Service was very fast.

It's definitely a small, rather inconspicuous restaurant in the same shopping center (if you can call it that) as the neighborhood oriental supermarket, but the dishes are great.  The seafood pajeon was served hot and filled with plenty of veggies and seafood, and the soondoobu chigae was flavorful and very spicy .  The banchan dishes were pretty good (although they didn't have the marinated shredded dried squid that I loved so much when I was in DC!) and I really liked the braised lotus root and white daikon kimchi.  The place itself is kinda small but the service is very friendly and prices are fair.  I haven't tried the barbeque here but I would venture that their specialties are actual dishes and not cook-your-own meats.

I love the cashew butter (unsalted por favor!) here, and although I confess to being a diehard Skippy Extra Chunky fan, I do have a weakness for the fresh, chunky, unsalted PB here.  It's literally just full of crunchy peanuts, which I just love. The hazelnut pb is a must-try if you like Nutella; it has a crunchier, more nutty taste and is not as sweet.  Get a loaf of whole grain bread and just slather it on a slice or two for a satisfying snack.  They also have a good selection of dried fruits, although I find that they are on par with the kinds at Trader Joe's and more expensive.  The dried pear is the only fruit that I tend to get here because it's not too tough (Trader Joe's is really almost leathery).  

Since today was national PB & J day, I had to stop in to grab a jar of the chunky unsalted to go with the Smucker's squeezable grape jelly at home.  It was still warm and tasted fantastic when paired with a thin layer of grape jelly and a toasted slice of Arnold's Multi-Grain.  Now that's what I call a yummy dinner in celebration of a true American classic.

It's still a humble-looking location but the service is fantatic.  They actually cook up the wings when you order them so they are hot, fresh, and sooooo flavorful.  AND they are still good the next day too (heat in oven).  Me?  I had a crabcake tonight (no meat on Fri) that was nicely seasoned and full of fresh, delicious crabmeat.  Just heat it in the oven and you're good to go.  Plus, I have those wings to look forward to tomorrow.

We haven't dined in yet but stopped in to pick up a few of our benchmarking Sichuan dishes last week.  The tea-smoked duck was okay, but the flavor didn't penetrate all of the meat (especially the thick thigh and breast portions).  The outer surfaces were very flavorful, though.  Definitely better than the duck that you can get at any other Chinese restaurant in the KoP area (it's a sparse picking since you're left with China King/House/Star), but it's not as amazing as New East's (in the NE), which has that authentic pink-ish flesh in literally every piece.  The crispy fried fish with pine nuts was good with plenty of seeds and a nice batter; the bass meat was tender yet firm and took on the sweetish sauce nicely.  Not as amazing as Margaret Kuo's but still tasty, all the same.  The dan dan noodles were flavorful with plenty of minced pork although the sauce wasn'treally spicy at all.  E Mei's version is definitely spicier and more authentic with a more generous addition of chili oil.  Overall, it's a good option for Chinese in an area that is severely lacking in even semi-authentic restaurants.  Will return to try the dry-woked dishes before deciding on a final rating but so far, there is potential.

I love the fresh steaks here. Nothing beats a huge  cut of the delmonico. The thick-cut smoked bacon is also incredibly flavorful. I'm almost glad that this is far from home. Otherwise I'd be buying stock in plavix and lipitor.

Solid seafood cafe in the French Quarter near Cafe du Monde with fresh crab, fish, and oysters and a very casual atmosphere.  The servers are friendly and helpful, and I was happy with my grilled oysters and etouffee.  It's not a fancy dinner restaurant but great for a quick bite.

This isn't the best Dunkin by a long shot BUT it is the only one in the area that will have a full inventory of bagels even after 6 pm.  And ya know, sometimes you just want a damn bagel with cc for dinner (multigrain por favor) and it is heartbreaking when your Dunkin doesn't have the multigrain.  Service is just ok and they have yet to get my usual order wrong (large iced coffee, half decaf, coconut, skim, half sugar...yes, I am very high maintenance).  The drive-thru is a different story but it's decent if you order inside.

I love the sandwiches here, mostly because they are just stuffed with plenty of freshly shaved meat and served on fantastic rolls.  Half of a catering platter sandwich has more meat than perhaps 3 Subway footlongs.  I'm not exaggerating.  My favorite is definitely the turkey and swiss on an egg roll.  The tuna salad wrap isn't bad either.  The roast beef on kaiser really depends on the cut you get in the sandwich; sometimes, it can be a bit on the tough side but other times, it is very tender. The pasta salad is decent (your basic ziti with Italian dressing, feta, tomatoes, and olives) but the garden salad is really nothing more than icebery, tomatoes, and peppers.  I would definitely skip that.  So, come here for the sandwiches and/or catering platters.  It's around $7.50/person so the price is pretty fair for the amount of food you get.

The coffee is definitely weak but the breakfast sandwiches are pretty good.  I definitely appreciate that they use shaved deli ham rather than a single slice of a ham-like meat.  The bagels are on the small side but fresh with a nice shell and soft interior.  I was disappointed that they didn't have any asiago bagels though.

Serious staff attitude problem here.  I almost considered conducting a study on the number of eye rolls it takes to complete a transaction.  The weekend staff are horrible and I had to wait for 17 minutes at the register to pay for a belt because there wasn't anyone at the counter.  Even after the cashier arrived, she exuded such an air of affected ennui and practically snapped the amount I owed while throwing the item almost angrily into a bag.  I' sorry if you abhor your job but that is no excuse for treating customers poorly.  I also noticed that other customers were getting impatient waiting for their shoes and just for someone to be at the register/counter to help them pay for their items.  The weekday staff is a lot more efficient and friendly, especially the day manager who is simply a sweetheart.  It's just the Sunday staff here that are certainly yelp-worthy, to say the very least.  They do have some cute accessories so I will continue to stop in every once in a while but never again on a Sunday.  The experience here definitely takes the term "customer service" (or lack thereof) to a new level.  1 star for the experience today.

Yum!  That's the only word that comes to mind when you have a bite of the vegan chocolate chip cookie.  Usually, vegan cookies tend to be bland and dry but not here.  It was soft, chocolatey, and delicious.  Minus 1 star for the hefty $3 price tag, though.

The brisket is a bit on the tough side but the broth is very flavorful and the meatballs nicely seasoned.  Plus they give you a generous serving of meat.  The summer rolls are good but very much on par with those at every other Vietnamese restaurant.  The service is what sets them apart.  They are just so nice and attentive here!  I was accustomed to the south Philly service level and it's a complete 180 degrees from that.  Even when we order takeout, our bags are handed over with a smile and double check to make sure that we have whatever extra sauces, utensils, etc we need.  Love it!  Plus it's only 10 min away.

This is my favorite Panera location in the area.  It's a bit smaller than the Norristown and Conshohocken branches but the cafe is cleaner and the service is A LOT friendlier and more efficient.  Plus, they always have most of the menu in stock (every kind of bagel), unlike the Norristown location.  The hazelnut coffee here is also slightly darker.

I love the salads here.  They are absolutely amazing and very easy to become addicted to.  I love the curry chicken an the apple and grape chicken, which is slightly reminiscent of a waldorf but creamier and crunchier.  The seafood salad is very fresh and not overwhelming with mayo (it's always a delicate balance).  The breakfast and paninies here are superb, as well.  I like the chicen caprice with basil and mozzarella; it's freshly tasted with a hint of butter spread without tasting greasy in the slightest.  They also allow you to make healthy substitutions like egg whites.  And instead of artery-clogging chips and fries, they give you pasta and potato salad; my cholesterol and doctor are very grateful.  Do your tastebuds and health a favor and get dinner to go or lunch here.

The brunch here is fantastic.  The highlights:

1.  apple-smoked turkey bacon (flavorful and lean - definitely not as greasy as your everyday bacon yet it is still crispy and tasty)
2. quiche lorraine (fluffly and light with a flaky, buttery crust and just the right amount of gruyere)
3. omelette station (need I say more?  they have every imaginable topping for a great made-to-order creation.  try one with a combination of spinach, fontina, and mushrooms)
4. carved lamb with rosemary and mint (tender and flavorful but it was well-done and I tend to like my meat a little on the raw side.  It was still delicious, all the same, and I went back for a second serving...because being pig-like is excusable at a holiday brunch)
5. chicken in bechamel (very juicy, tender breast in a buttery sauce that doesn't taste heavy - pretty good although it wasn't my favorite)
